Imports and Import Payments Specified items may be free ly imported under an open general license. Practically all other imports require ind iv idual licenses. Imports of specified raw materials, spare parts, and components required by key and priority industries, inc lud ing small-scale indus- tries, and by un i ts in other industries that had an export performance of 10 per cent or more of their production du r ing the previous year, are licensed lib- erally. Licenses for raw materials and components are issued on a con t inu ing basis genera l ly by way of importers c la im ing rep len ishment of goods actually consumed du r ing a period of not less than three and not more than six months. As for spare parts, licenses are issued annua l ly on the basis of prescribed percent- ages of the c.i.f. va lue of the imported mach inery and of indigenous mach inery having imported components. Licenses to actual users for imports of raw materials, components, and spare parts are not granted wholly against f ree fore ign exchange, but partly against tied-aid credits from particular coun tr ies. However, a greater preference with respect to the permitted origin of imports is accorded to actual users with specified m in imum export performance. Ind iv idual licenses may be issued ( 1) ad hoc, (2) on the basis of quotas allo- cated to established importers in accordance with their imports in a base period, ( 3) to actual users on the basis of their requirements, and (4) to registered exporters in accordance with the import con tent of their exports. Generally, licenses may be used to import from any country except Por tuga l, Rhodesia, South Africa, Nam ib ia (South West A f r i c a ), and Tibet; impor ts from these countries are prohibited.6 Such licenses are referred to as General Currency Area 6 The importation f rom Nepal of commod i t ies o r ig ina t ing in coun- tries other than Nepal or Ind ia also is proh ib i ted. INDIA Licenses, as distinct from Specific Licenses, which are issued for capital goods and other supplies against tied aid and are valid only for imports from the country or countries providing the assistance. Single Country Licenses are issued for certain imports from countries with which bilateral trade or payments agreements are in force. Licensing policy generally accords priority to food- stuffs, fertilizers, capital goods, raw materials, and other industrial requirements, while the import of other items is severely limited or prohibited. The import program for the period ending March 31, 1973 con- tains a prohibited l i s t7 of 795 commodities and a list of 339 items that are licensed on a "restricted basis," i.e., in minor amounts and only if comparable domestic products either are not available or are inadequate.8 Licensing is in most cases on an annual basis. There are special procedures applicable to imports of capital goods, of heavy electrical plant, and of goods imported to fu l f i ll government contracts and for irrigation proj- ects. Favored trea tment in allocating foreign exchange for imports of capital goods and equ ipment is given to "key" industries and "priority" industries. An import rep len ishment scheme enables registered exporters to obtain specified raw materials and other items needed for the ir export produc t ion; these commodities include certain items whose import otherwise is banned. In licensing imports of a capital na tu re, their essentiality, their potential for earn ing or saving foreign exchange, and the ava i lab i l i ty of med ium- term or long-term cred- its for financing such imports are taken into account. Import licenses for machine tools and other capital goods valued at more than Rs 750,000 are not granted un t il Ind ian producers have been given an opportunity by pub l ic advertisement to supply them; licenses are only issued if offers by domestic producers are dispro- por t iona te ly expensive or unacceptable for other rea- sons, or when no offers are received w i th in 45 days. For certain types of steel castings and forgings, this policy applies to all orders of more than Rs 50,000. A special fee is levied on a vo lun t a ry basis on imports of long-staple cotton. Where a valid import license is held, the required exchange is released by an authorized bank on presen- ta t ion of the exchange control copy of the license. License holders may make paymen ts by opening letters of credit or by r em i t t ing against sight d ra f ts. Advance rem i t tances before shipping documen ts can be sub- mitted are not no rma l ly a l lowed; but in special cases, e.g., impor ts of mach inery and capital goods, where deposits have to be made w i th overseas manu fac tu re r s, the Reserve Bank g ran ts special authorization for advance payment for a part of the va lue of the import. 7 Impo r ts of ce r ta in p r o h i b i t ed i tems are p e rm i t t ed e i ther ad hoc or u n d er the impo rt rep len i shment scheme. 8 The import program announced in April 1973 added 20 items to the list of imports to be channe led t h r o u gh pub l ic sector agencies, imposed a ban on the import of 220 a d d i t i o n al i t em s, and restricted the import of 55 others. 229 ©International Monetary Fund. Gold In Ind ia, detailed control is exercised over the manu- fac tu re, acquisition, possession, and disposal of gold in various fo rms through a Gold Control Administrator. There is a total ban on private possession of primary gold. A l though there is no ban on possession of finished articles of gold ( in c lud ing coins) previously declared, there is restriction on their m anu f a c tu re and fresh acquisition. There is no restriction on the manu fac tu re, acquisition, disposal, or possession of gold ornaments, except that holdings of such o rnamen ts (which may be of any p u r i t y) above specified l im i ts are subject to the requ irement of declaration. The consump t ion of gold by indus t r ial users is regulated th rough permits and authorizations. Control is exercised over the dealers and goldsmiths through a system of licensing. Gold r e f in ing is u n d er state managemen t. The Government M int is licensed und er the Gold Control Law to accept tenders of gold for purposes of re f in ing and conversion into s tandard gold bars, for which strict specifications as to fineness, weight, dimensions, and markings are prescribed. Forward trad ing in gold or silver is prohibited. With the exception of jewelry cons t i tu t ing the per- sonal effec ts of a traveler, imports of gold in any fo rm by residents other than the monetary authorities requ ire special au thor iza t ion from the Reserve Bank and are not no rma l ly perm i t ted; established jewelers, however, are f rom t ime to t ime gran ted licenses to import gold for the m a n u f a c t u re in their workshops of jewe l ry for export. Exports of gold in any f o rm other than jewelry pro- duced in Ind ia for export and jewe l ry cons t i tu t ing the personal effec ts of a traveler are prohibited unless the export is made by or on behalf of the mone tary author- ities. INDIA May 25. India's exchange control regulations gen- erally became applicable to transactions with Bangla- desh. Transactions not settled under the "limited pay- ments rupee trade arrangements" could be settled in any Sterling Area currency other than Pakistan rupees and were generally subject to the same regulations as applicable to other countries. Travel to Bangladesh, however, was not counted as visits abroad for purposes of the Foreign Travel Scheme, 1970. Special scales of allowances were fixed for visits to Bangladesh for vari- ous purposes; foreign exchange for travel to Bangla- desh was not granted for tourist travel, and when granted for other types of travel was made available only in Ind ian rupee travelers checks encashable only in Bangladesh. June 8. Indian citizens resident abroad and wishing to re tu rn to Ind ia to take up employment or to set up small indus tr ial un i ts were upon application exempted, for a period of three years, f rom the requirement that any fo re ign currency balances in their possession be su r rende red w i th in 30 days of arrival. As an alternative to holding such balances in the fo rm of foreign cur- rency, the holder could use the f u n ds for the import, subject to import license, of equipment and capital goods. Imports and Import Payments There is a registry of au thor ized impor ters and an in i t ial deposit is requ ired for registration. Since October 3 1, 1968, on ly Indones ian na t iona ls may obtain an impo r te r 's license, but cer ta in established foreign firms have been enabled to re ta in the ir licenses and new fo re ign inves tors can obtain an importer's license restricted to the import of ma ter ia ls required for their own projects. Imports from Angola, mainland China, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, as are imports from all sources of specified commodities, including com- pletely assembled commercial vehicles and motorcycles; radio and television sets in built-up or semiknocked- down condition; sarongs; galvanized iron sheets; iron roofing sheets; mosquito sticks; second-hand goods; matches; monosodium glutamate; mattresses; and speci- fied types of textiles, car tires, batteries, printed matter, office supplies, animal traps, bottles, and lamps and bulbs. The importing of cloves, wheat and wheat flour, fertilizer, and refined sugar is restricted to specified approved importers. No licenses are required for im- ports. Most goods may be imported either with general exchange (Devisa Umum) or aid exchange (Devisa Kredit). For imports financed with aid exchange a compensation payment is granted after customs clear- ance; this payment ranges from Rp 20 to Rp 60 per U. S. dollar of landed value, depending on country of origin and /or donor country. Importers may w i thout bank guarantee contract short- - Indonesia ma in ta ins inoperative bilateral payments agreements with mainland China, Czechoslovakia, and Poland. 235 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDONESIA term credit under "merchant letters of credit," but otherwise sight letters of credit are requ ired for all pri- vate sector impor ts with the exception of parcel imports, goods brought in by travelers of a value not exceeding US$100, and imports specifically authorized by the M in is try of Trade (such as goods constituting part of a fore ign i n v e s tm e n t ). A rup iah deposit of 100 per cent of the amount of the letter of credit must be lodged w i th Bank Indonesia when a letter of credit is opened in respect of government imports; for nongovernment imports, importers are required to make an advance deposit of 100 per cent of the letter of credit value when they subm it applications for letters of credit to authorized banks. Importers' requests for registration of merchant letters of credit with foreign exchange banks must be accompanied by an advance payment in rupiahs of 25 per cent of the value. The deposits are released to the impor ter only for payment or when he presents correspondence f rom suppliers indicating that the merchant le t ter of credit has been canceled. The amount of the deposit against letters of credit for non- government imports f inanced w i th aid exchange is left to the discretion of the authorized bank if the latter purchases aid exchange forward f rom Bank Indonesia. Import duties, which are almost without exception ad va lorem, are imposed on the c. & f. value of the commodities converted at the customs valuation rate (Rp 415 per US$1 on December 31, 1972). The import duty structure is complex; it includes a basic du ty, sur- charges, exemptions, and extra levies. Surcharges or exemptions are applied to most of the basic duties. For some tar iff items which are free of basic du ty there is an extra levy of between Rp 10 and Rp 250 per U. S. dollar on the c. & f. value of the goods. Sales taxes of 5, 10, and 20 per cent are levied on most imports on their c. & f. value plus import duty. Items which are exempted from import duties are also exempted f rom sales taxes. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted or subject to control. Pro- ceeds from inv is ib les need not be surrendered. Travelers may take out and bring in any amount in foreign bank- notes but only Rp 2,500 in Indonesian notes and coins other than gold coins; Indonesian commemorative gold coins may be taken out freely up to Rp 65,000 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Angola, ma in land Ch ina, Israel, Rho- desia, and South A f r i ca are p roh ib i ted, as are exports to all countries of gold ore and pure gold; certain cate- gories of unprocessed or low-quality rubber; certain logs and timber; and scrap bronze, copper, and iron (other than scrap bronze and copper f rom Irian J a y a ). The prior authorization of the Minister of Trade is required for the export of flatbark crepe, cinchona bark, iron scrap (from Java and Madu ra ), silver, and antiques of 236 cultural value. Otherwise, all commodities may be freely exported by registered private firms and state trading firms. Full surrender requirements are in effect for the proceeds from all nonpetroleum exports (except in "border-crossing" trade; see below). All exporters except the petroleum companies, cer- tain mining companies, and licensed "border-crossing" traders must require their buyers to open a bank letter of credit covering the value of the goods to be exported. For the principal export commodities other than petro- leum, the sales price must not be lower than "indica- tion" prices ("check" prices) determined periodically by the Minister of Trade. The f u ll proceeds from exports other than pe tro leum, products of certain min- ing companies, and goods exported by licensed "border- crossing" traders are subject to surrender and, except for finished goods, batik textiles and other handicrafts, and a few other items, are subject to a 10 per cent exchange tax; a 5 per cent exchange tax is levied on the proceeds from coconut oil exports.3 Exports of petroleum and of products of ce r ta in m in ing companies are also exempt f rom exchange tax. The exporter settles the tax on receipt of the export proceeds. A specific cess is levied on exports of certain agricultural products and on in ter is land t rad ing in the same products. Agri- cultural commodities produced in border regions may be exported to Ma lays ia and Singapore in exchange for certain eligible goods. In this "border-crossing" trade, the va lue of import or export shipments must not exceed M$600 a mon th, if transported overland, and M$600 a sh ipmen t, if transported by sea. Capital The Foreign Capital Inves tment Law of Janua ry 10, 1967, as amended in August 1970, provides various incentives for the inves tment of fore ign capital in Indo- nesia. Investments in specified fields of activity (includ- ing harbors, electric power, sh ipp ing, railroads, and commerce) may be unde r taken only through a joint ven tu re with an Indones ian par tner. The Investment Law specifies a system of inves tment priorities; it assigns the highest p r io r i ty to certain specified fields, followed by inves tmen ts which are located outside Java, inves tmen ts which genera te or save fore ign exchange, and inves tmen ts in i n f r a s t r u c t u r e. Enterprises that are wholly or la rge ly operated in Indonesia as separate business un i ts must be incorporated under Indonesian law and must have the ir domicile in Indonesia. The operation pe rm it for fo re ign inves tment is usually valid for a max imum of 30 years. Among the inducements o f fe red are exemp t ion f rom, or reduction in, corporate and d iv idend taxes for a certain number of years. Joint ven tu res by Indones ians and fore igners may benefit 3 Exemp t ion f r om the 10 per cent exchange tax was granted on J a n u a ry 10, 1973 for alcohol d i s t i l led f r om rice or manioc, and on J a n u a ry 16, 1973 for exports of v a r ious textile products, including ready-made clothes. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution from similar tax incentives. Other inducements include exemption f rom customs duties, accelerated deprecia- tion allowances, and permission to offset initial losses against subsequent profits; foreign investments with a minimum capital of US$15 million may receive addi- tional benefits. The transfer of profits (a f ter settlement of taxes and financial obligations in Indonesia) is guar- anteed. Guarantees of t rans fer are also given in respect of t rans fe rs relating to expenses connected with the employment of foreign persons in Indonesia, and in respect of depreciation allowances af ter the expiration of the tax holiday f rom corporation tax. The law pro- vides that no transfer permit shall be issued for capital repatriation as long as the investments benefit f rom tax relief; at present, however, foreign payments do not require a t ran s fer permit. The law implicitly provides guarantees against nationalization of foreign invest- ments. Equitable and mu tua l ly satisfactory arrange- ments are stipulated for resolving the issue of just com- pensation in the event of nationalization of any specific foreign investment. A special regime applies to enterprises previously nationalized but now restored to the original owners. Such enterprises are allowed tax holidays for a period of three years on new capital in foreign currency brought in w i th in the context of rehabilitation and expansion programs that have been approved by the Government. The transfer of proceeds from the sale of the assets of those restored enterprises which ceased operations could take place w i th effect from January 1, 1972 at the rate of one fifth of the proceeds each year, with a fu ll guarantee as to their value in foreign cur- rency. The t ran s fer of proceeds f rom the sale of assets of enterprises whose period of operation has expired or whose operations have been term ina ted by the Gov- ernment is allowed at the rate of one fifth a year effec t ive f rom the time of the sale of assets. This transfer is guaran teed as to its value in foreign currency. A Debt Investment Conversion Scheme (DIGS) exists for the benef it of fore ign creditors holding nonguaran- teed claims against Indonesia. Rup iahs covered by the Scheme are adm in is tered in two k inds of DICS-Rupiah Accounts, A and B, the former relating only to claims of which the creditor is the first holder. Private creditors willing to accept the terms of the Scheme and prepared to make inves tmen ts in Indonesia are paid in rup iahs in settlement of their claims. These claims are transferable to other potential investors in Indonesia, but only the original creditor's DIGS rup iahs may be used, in the creditor's own projects that have been approved under the Foreign Investment Law of 1967, for the purchase of foreign exchange for the impo rt of equipment and raw materials necessary for the es tab l ishment and operation of those projects. There are no l im i ta t ions on the remittance to Indo- nesia of capital in the fo rm of fore ign exchange or in commodities. Foreign exchange banks may free ly bor- INDONESIA row abroad within limits established by Bank Indonesia. Certain other borrowing abroad is subject to control. The prior approval of the Minister of Finance is required before any public enterprise or public sector body may accept a loan from abroad.4 Indonesian citizens and residents of fore ign national- ity may freely transfer, negotiate, import, and export securities denominated in rupiahs or in foreign cur- rency (w i th the exception of securities covered by a special arrangement w i th the Ne ther lands). Gold Indonesia has issued five commemorative gold coins, which are legal tender. Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold and gold coins in Indonesia. Exports of gold ore and pure gold, unless made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, are prohibited by virtue of Decision No. 68 /KP / IV /70 of April 17, 1970 of the Minister of Trade. Travelers may freely take out Indo- nesian commemorative gold coins up to Rp 65,000 a person; amounts in excess require the prior approval of Bank Indonesia. Nonresident Accounts Foreign nationals are permitted to ma in ta in accounts freely, in rials as well as in foreign currencies, with authorized banks; rial accounts may be freely used only for paymen ts in Iran, their conversion in to foreign currencies being subject to central bank approval. Foreign nationals may also ma in ta in time deposits in foreign currencies in Iran. Foreign currency accounts of foreign nationals may be used freely for t rans fe rs abroad or for sales to authorized banks, provided that such funds originate abroad. Iranian nationals may freely ma in ta in time deposits in foreign currencies in Iran; they also may freely retain, on current accounts with domestic banks, all foreign exchange they receive other than export proceeds. Imports and Import Payments All imports into Iran are subject to control by the Government. The import policy is re-examined annually, and a new Import List, effective for the next Iranian year, is published by the Ministry of Economy. The Import List distinguishes between "authorized," "unauthorized," and "prohibited" goods. "Authorized" imports, consisting of nonluxury goods which either are not produced in Iran or are produced in Iran but not in quantities sufficient to meet domestic require- ments, are divided into two main categories: (1) imports for which orders may be placed without prior approval by government agencies,3 and (2) imports that are subject to prior approval by government agencies (generally the Ministry of Economy) before the import order is placed. "Unauthorized" imports are goods that may be permitted occasionally by the Ministry of Econ- omy when the supply of the protected local product is considered insufficient. For "prohibited" goods, no authorizations are given; these comprise only a few items such as opium and firearms. Imports without payment of "authorized" goods require prior approval by the Ministry of Economy and the central bank; permission is given for the following: imports destined for official charitable institutions or government organizations; machinery, spare parts, and raw or intermediate materials for productive institutions, 3 Exports and imports of goods that are not included in the bilateral export/import list for countries with which Iran has bilateral payments agreements require special approval by the Ministry of Economy. 239 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAN up to US$500 a shipment; and all other imports of "authorized" goods up to US$150 a shipment. The import of g if ts, whe ther "authorized" or "unauthorized" commodities, is restricted to Rls 10,000 for each person a year. Specified commodities, such as sugar, tobacco, and cigarette paper, are imported under state monopoly. Unless otherwise specifically authorized, payment for all commercial imports must be made through the official exchange market, with foreign exchange obtained from the bank ing system. Payments may be made either against bills for collection or documentary letters of credit. Payments against bills for collection may be made without authorization for goods (mainly capital goods and raw materials) listed in the Schedule attached to Circular No. 116 of August 3, 1965 (Iranian date 12.5.1344). Payments for imports of other goods required by domestic industries may also be made against bills for collection with special permission from the central bank. All other import payments must be made against documentary letters of credit. All orders for imports must be registered with the Bank Markazi Iran through an authorized bank; registration is effected against a pro forma invoice. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited and special regulations apply to certain commodities when originat- ing in Hong Kong. No import registrations are accepted for commodities originating in Eastern Germany. At the time of registration of imports, an import registration fee of 5.5 per cent of the amount of an import order, calculated on the basis of the official selling rate of Rls 76.50 per US$1, is collected by authorized banks .4 The fee is charged on all imports except those brought in under the Law for the Attraction and Protection of Foreign Investment in Iran. Importers must at the same time deposit w i th the Bank Markazi Iran, through an authorized bank, Rls 10, Rls 15, Rls 30, or Rls 75 (depending on the essentiality of the goods) per US$1 for goods for wh ich payment must be made against a documen tary letter of credit.5 This deposit is r e fund ab le upon presen ta t ion of the customs clearance certificate a f ter the respective goods have been cleared th rough customs, or if and when the order is canceled. The advance import deposit is not required for commodities wh ich may be impor ted on a collection basis, whe ther they are in fact impor ted against a bill for collection or no t. The cen tral b ank may pe rm it the sh i f t ing of imports f rom the category in which an advance import deposit is required and f inanc ing must be on a letter of credit basis to the category in which bills for collection (with or w i thout advance deposit) are permitted. Authorized banks make payments for permitted imports against the presentation of shipping documents. Approval of the shipping documents by the authorized banks represents approval of the foreign exchange transfer. Almost all imports are subject to commercial profit taxes, which are either specific or ad valorem and are in addition to any applicable customs duty. The ad valorem commercial profit tax ranges from 1 per cent to 200 per cent. Monopoly taxes are included in the commercial profit taxes. The authorities specify in the Import List the commercial profit taxes for each year. These taxes are paid to the customs before customs clearance. The clearance through customs is authorized upon the pres- entation of shipping documents endorsed by the authorized banks, specifying that payment has been made or will be made, and, when required, that the special import authorization has been received from government agencies prior to lading of goods in the country of origin. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to imports are made on the same basis as payments for those imports. Exchange is granted to merchants for insurance of imports against bills for collection; for imports covered by documentary letters of credit, insurance must be taken out in Iran. Exchange is not granted to merchants for insu rance of Iranian exports sold f.o.b. Foreign nationals working in Iran as technical assistants and whose employment has been recognized as necessary by the Government may take out in foreign exchange about 50 per cent of their net salaries. The annual travel allowance for Iran ian nationals —which is limited to US$500 G or its equ iva lent in other currencies for travel to Europe, the United States, or the Far East, and to US$100 for other countries except Rhodesia —may be sold by au thor ized banks upon presentation of the traveler's passport. For children under 12 the allow- ances in principle are 30 per cent of the above amounts, but in practice the f u ll allowances are granted. Banks may sell up to US$2,000 7 a person for I ran ian nation- als trave l ing abroad or residing abroad, for medical trea tmen t. In add i t ion, authorized banks may at any time sell fore ign exchange up to the equ iv a l ent of <£ stg. 508 against a w r i t ten request, to I ran ian na t iona ls for assist- ance to persons abroad or for other personal use without the submission of supporting documen ts, provided that the remittance is made in the fo rm of a mail or tele- graphic t r an s f e r; au tho r ized banks charge a commission of Rls 130 on each such t rans fe r. I ran ian nationals may also free ly make remittances abroad f rom domestic current accounts in which they retain foreign exchange received f rom sources other than exports; balances in 4 The fee is 15 per cent for bananas and 100 per cent for impo r ts pe rm i t ted under the Export-Import Regu la t ions for the I ran ian y e ar 1351 but not allowed the year before. •"• For a few commod i t ies sub ject to deposit, the c e n t r al bank f rom time to t ime allows an ad hoc reduc t ion of Rls 10 per US$1. 0 Increased on June 12, 1973 to the equ iva lent of Rls 50,000. 7 Increased on J u ne 12, 1973 to the equ iva lent of Rls 200,000; addi- t ional f o r e i gn exchange could be obtained against medical bills certi- f ied by an I r a n i an consul abroad. s Increased on J u ne 12, 1973 to the equ iva lent of Rls 10,000. 240 ©International Monetary Fund. Purchases of foreign currency from the banks for payments in respect of noncommercial invisibles not mentioned above require licenses from the central bank. Iranian nationals leaving the country are required to pay a travel tax of Rls 10,000 for each single-voyage exit permit, except for pilgrimage travel, for which the tax is Rls 3,000. Lower rates apply to family members traveling on the same passport (w ife and children from 7 to 18 years of age), viz., Rls 750 a person for pilgrim- ages and Rls 2,500 a person for other travel. Iranians resident abroad and students studying abroad but visiting home temporarily are exempt from payment of the tax. Travelers leaving Iran may take with them Rls 3,000 in Iranian banknotes. Travelers of foreign nationality may not export foreign currency in excess of the amount they imported less the amounts they have sold to authorized banks, as recorded in their passports; they may, however, convert rials up to the equivalent of US$100 into other currencies upon presentation of their visaed passport. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of some commodities require licenses. A commercial profit tax is imposed on a few exports, ma in ly consumer goods or raw materials. The commercial profit tax and customs duty charged at the time of import of raw materials contained in manu fac tu red goods for export may be returned to the exporter after the export has taken place. Certain minor exports are granted incentive pay- ments by the Center for the Promotion of Exports. The central bank offers preferential discount facilities for export bills. The exporter must offer for surrender the foreign exchange value of his exports, as appraised by the customs, w i th in eight months a f ter the goods have been exported. Authorized banks accept export proceeds only in specified currencies (see footnote 1) or, for exports to India, in Indian rupees. Exporters who do not have foreign exchange proceeds from exports at their disposal may meet their surrender obligation by delivery of either foreign exchange f rom their own holdings or foreign exchange sold to an authorized bank by a third par ty; the central bank's permission is required to meet the surrender requ irement through these alternative means. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts f rom invisibles may be retained in a foreign currency account w i th an authorized bank, where they remain at the free disposal of the account holder (except for payments in respect of commercial impor ts). The import of I ran ian currency by travelers to Iran is permitted in unlimited amounts. The repatriation of Iranian banknotes through the mail is not permitted. IRAN Travelers, during their stay in Iran, may sell their exchange only to an authorized bank at the bank's buying rate. Capital Iranian nationals may retain in domestic foreign cur- rency accounts any capital receipts accruing in foreign exchange; transfers abroad from such accounts may be made freely (except for payments in respect of com- mercial impor ts), as may domestic transfers to other Iranian nationals. Transfers of capital abroad which would involve the purchase of foreign exchange from the bank ing system require the approval of the central bank; except as noted below, such approval is given only in exceptional circumstances. In accordance with the Law for the Attraction and Protection of Foreign Investment in Iran (1955) and regulations implementing the law, foreign capital invested in approved development or productive activi- ties in industry, mining, agriculture, or transport may be repatriated, together with net profits (in accordance w i th Article 1 of the Law for the Attraction and Protec- tion of Foreign Investment and the provisions contained in the implementing regulations), in the form of foreign exchange and /or goods. Transfers of exchange must be made at the selling rate prevailing at the date of trans- fer. However, the central bank has the option of buying the exchange or accepting it as a deposit to be con- verted into rials at a rate mu tua l ly agreed upon in a separate agreement, and this rate is applicable to the funds when they are repatriated. Capital imported in the fo rm of foreign exchange must be in currencies acceptable to the central bank; the exchange is converted into rials at the buy ing rate prevailing at the date of application for conversion. The law does not set up any limit of participation with respect to the ratio of foreign to domestic investment, but the Supervisory Board encourages participation by Iranians in the proposed investment. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Iran; imports and exports of gold in any form, except jewelry consti- tu t ing the personal effects of a trave ler ,9 require the prior approval of the central bank, unless the import or export is made by or on behalf of the monetary authori- ties; in practice, all imports of nonmonetary gold are made by the Bank Melli Iran (an authorized commer- cial b ank) and exports are prohibited. Imports of gold are free from customs duty and commercial benefit tax but are subject to the 5.5 per cent import registration fee. The week ly quo ta t ions of Bank Me l li Iran for domestic sales inc lude the import registration fee and a 4 per cent commission. Administration of Control The Board of Adm in i s t ra t ion of the Cen t ral Bank of Iraq is en t ru s ted w i th all powers and responsibilities in connection w i th exchange con t ro l; it has delegated this au tho r i ty to the Foreign Exchange Committee (headed by the Governor of the Central Bank, his Deputy, or a member specified in advance by the Board of A dm i n i s t r a t i o n ), to the Department of For- eign Exchange of the Cen tral Bank, and to the licensed dealers. Foreign exchange t ransac t ions must take place through a licensed dealer unless otherwise authorized by the Board of Adm in is t ra t ion. Import and export policy are de term ined by the Counc il for the Regula- tion of Trade. The Directorate-General of Economics (Gove rnment and Pr iva te Import Section) in the Minis- try of Economy, the General Organization for Trade, the General Depar tment for Indus t r ial Promotion in the Ministry of Indus t ry, and the Indus t r ial Organization in the M in is t ry of Indu s t ry are the pr inc ipal licensing authorities for impor ts and exports, but import licenses are also issued by certain other public organizations and government depar tmen ts. A foreign exchange budget, including an import program, is established annua l ly, and foreign exchange allocations under the import program are supervised by the Import Program Com- mittee. Prescription of Currency Settlements must be made in any of the listed cur- rencies l or, under the bilateral payments agreements w i th ma in land Ch ina, Egypt, and Yugoslavia, in dinars or pounds sterling through the appropriate clearing account. Balances in such accoun ts may be used for a variety of purposes, in c lud ing imports for the holder's personal use, impor ts of certain capital goods, or meet- ing expend i tu re abroad for t rave l, medical trea tmen t, and study purposes; paymen ts f rom these accounts up to the equ iva lent of ID 500 a year do not require Central Bank approval. Imports and Import Payments All imports f rom Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and all imports from Hong Kong other than certain essential goods are prohibited. Imports of some 118 commodities are prohibited f rom all sources. There is also a list of about 93 commodities whose import is sus- pended. Impo r ts of some 320 items, including ju te, sugar, tea, edible olive oil, certain medical supplies, machine tools, and automobiles, are a government monopoly. All private imports except those of the private sector oil companies require licenses, virtually all of which are issued in accordance with an annual import program. Imports of consumer goods generally are more heavily restricted than those of raw materials and equipment for industrial use. Some commodities may be imported only by government agencies or state trad ing companies; other commodities may also be imported by registered private importers or by con- tractors who have entered into contracts with the Iraq Government. A tax is levied on the amount of the import license at the following rates: % per mill for producer goods, 1 per mill for consumer goods, and, in addition, up to 15 per cent on any supplementary import licenses above a private importer's annual quota. To finance the Export Subsidy Fund, a tax of % per cent is levied on imports of capital goods and a tax of 1 per cent on imports of consumer goods. All imports subject to import duty are also subject to a surcharge of 15 per cent of the appli- cable customs duty. Licensed dealers make exchange available upon pres- entation of the exchange control copy of the import license, except in some instances where reference has to be made to the Central Bank. 243 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAQ Payments for Invisibles With the exception of certain payments from for- eign currency accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above), all payments for invisibles require permission. Exchange is usually granted for edu- cational and medical expenses abroad, freight on exports carried on a c. & f. basis, insurance premiums, royalties, etc. Exchange is not granted to merchants for the insur- ance abroad of their imports or exports. Licensed dealers are permitted to transfer up to ID 50 a month for fam i ly maintenance on behalf of foreign nationals resi- dent in Iraq, provided that remittances do not exceed half of the resident's monthly income; it is necessary to refer to the exchange control authorities for amounts exceeding this limit. Although tourist travel at present is prohibited, there is a basic travel allowance of ID 100 a calendar year for each person 18 years of age or over, of ID 50 for persons between 5 and 18 years of age, and ID 25 for children 5 years of age or younger. Tourist travel exchange additional to the basic allowances is subject to ad hoc approval of the Central Bank. Travelers may take out ID 5 in Iraqi currency notes, in addition to 50 per cent of the domestic currency equivalent of the foreign exchange allocated, which is considered part of the basic travel allowance, and the balance of that allowance in travelers checks. Residents on a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia are permitted to take out the equivalent of ID 150 in listed currencies or in Saudi Arabian riyals (ID 75 for persons over 5 and under 18 and ID 25 for children 5 years of age or younge r ). Travelers leaving Iraq must deposit with an author- ized bank 10 per cent of the Iraqi dinar equivalent of the foreign exchange granted. The deposit is refunded upon the traveler's re turn to Iraq, subject to the fu l f i l lment of certain formalities. Exempt from the deposit requirement are officials of government, semi- government, and public utility departments; students traveling for s tudy purposes; pensioners; foreigners, except non-Iraqi wives of Iraq nationals; and persons leaving on a pilgrimage. On leaving the coun t ry, Iraq nationals must pay an exit tax of ID 20, except when traveling to Gulf countries or on an official mission the entire expense of which is borne by the Government. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Hong Kong, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica and exports of certain goods to all other countries are prohibited. The Ministry of Economy has au thor i ty to prohibit the export of any commodity when supply falls short of domestic demand. The Coun- cil for the Regu la t ion of Trade may also prohibit the export of certain commodities. All other exports are licensed free ly. Exporters must generally under take to repatriate their foreign exchange proceeds through a licensed dealer and 244 to surrender them. Proceeds from exports of dates taken by sailing boats to countries of the Gulf area (excluding Iran) and India are exempt from these requirements when the amount does not exceed ID 600. Some com- modities may be exported on a compensation (bar ter) basis. This system links the export of certain "new" exports to the import of prohibited items. Exports of certain goods are subsidized through an Export Subsidy Fund. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be sur- rendered to a licensed dealer. Travelers may bring in foreign exchange, including currency notes (other than Israel cu r r en cy ), in un l im i ted amoun ts, provided that the funds are declared on an exchange control form; amounts not intended to be taken out of the country are exempt from declaration. Travelers may bring in ID 25 in Iraqi notes. Capital Nonresidents may import capital freely, except from Israel or South Africa, but they must deposit it with a licensed dealer; such deposits may be converted into local currency at the off ic ial rate, and repatriation to the coun try of origin is permitted. With minor exceptions, foreign companies starting operations in Iraq must use Iraqi capital to the extent of at least 51 per cent of their total capital. The transfer of profits net of income tax f rom fore ign inves tmen ts is limited to 10 per cent per annum of the paid-up capital for trading companies, and to 20 per cent of the paid-up capital for industrial companies. These percentages are applicable for each year separately. They also app ly to prof i ts on capital resulting f rom the manda to ry re inves tment of profits in excess of the t ran s fe rab le percentages. Arab capital invested in Iraq is exempt from these percentage limi- tations and entitled to preferential treatment in several other respects; interest paymen ts are not subject to any ceilings. All t rans fe rs of capital abroad by residents, whe ther Iraqis or fore igners, require exchange control approva l; such t ran s fe rs are severely restricted. Special facilities allow Arab investors to br ing in convertible currency f ree ly th rough a licensed dealer for specified investment purposes; such capital and any net profits may be t ran s fe r red abroad in convertible currency. Similar fac i l i t ies permit Iraq na t iona ls to bring in con- vertible currency through a licensed dealer and deposit the f u n ds in foreign cu r rency accounts, balances in which are free ly t rans fe rab le abroad. Under the Industrial Promotion Law (No. 164 of 1964), specified enterprises in Iraq are granted partial or total exemption dur ing the first five years of profitable operation from income tax on the ir prof i ts up to 10 per cent of paid-up capital, provided that (1) the principal work of the enterprise is done by machine; (2) all ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution workers and employees other than essential technicians or experts are Iraq citizens or Arabs; (3) the value of machinery and tools required, excluding power- generating plants, exceeds ID 3,000; and (4) foreign non-Arab participation in the enterprise does not exceed 40 per cent. Similar exemptions for profits up to 5 per cent of paid-up capital are granted during the second five-year period of operation. The specified enterprises are those whose main purpose is to process raw mate- rials into semimanufactured or finished products or to process sem imanufac tured products into finished prod- ucts, including assembly. Under the Iraqization Law of June 1961, all branches of foreign firms and all foreign- owned firms except banks 2 must have a majority of equity capital held by Iraq nationals; this law does not cover export agencies and operations requiring special skills. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in Iraq in any form other than gold bars. Imports and exports of gold in any form require the approval of the Central Bank. Since mid-1961, the Rafidain Bank has held a monopoly over the import and domestic distribution of gold needed for industrial purposes; it sells gold to registered goldsmiths only, under a quota system based on their past turnover of gold. Accoun ts of per- sons res ident in coun t r i es ou ts ide the Scheduled Terri- tories are treated as nonresident accoun ts and, w i th the exception of Rhodes ian Accoun ts, are designated Exter- nal Accounts. These may be credited w i th paymen ts au thor ized for t r a n s f er to coun t r ies outside the Sched- u led Territories other than Rhodes ia, w i th t ran s fe rs f r om other Ex te rnal Accoun ts in Ir ish pounds or in sterling, and w i th the proceeds in Irish pounds of any foreign cu r r en cy o ther th an Rhodes ian cu r rency sold by a resident of a c o u n t ry ou ts ide the Scheduled Terri- tories to an au thor ized bank in I re land. Balances on these accounts may be t rans fe r red f ree ly to other Exter- nal Accoun ts in I r ish pounds or in s ter l ing, used for paymen ts to res iden ts of the Scheduled Territories, or converted th rough an au thor ized b ank in I r e l and in to any fore ign cu r rency o ther than Rhodesian currency. Accounts held by or on behalf of residents of Rho- desia are des igna ted Rhodes ian Accoun ts. The opening of such accounts, and all debits and credits thereto, requ ire the prior approval of the Cen tral Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports of commodities originating in Rhodesia require a special license. With this exception, the import of goods into Ireland is subject to two types of admin- istrative control. Under one type, which covers only a limited range of commodities for protective and other nonbalance of paymen ts purposes, imports of certain commodities are subject to quan t i ta t ive restrictions, which, in most cases, are on a world-wide basis.3 Indi- vidual import licenses are required for these goods and are used to limit the quan t i ty of goods imported. In addition, special quota restrictions apply to certain textiles and yarns originating in any of 16 specified countries or territories.4 All other impo r ts are free of quantitative restriction. Under the other type of control, 3 Most of the remaining quotas are being gradua l ly increased in accordance w i th EEC comm i tmen ts and w i th an obligation in the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Area Ag reemen t; the en la rgemen ts to date have been made on a global basis, a l though the obligations under the latter agreement relate only to goods or ig ina t ing in the United K ingdom. 4 Bulgaria, mainland China, Republic of Ch ina, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Ge rmany, Hong Kong, Hung a ry, Ind ia, J ap an, Macao, Ma- laysia, Pakistan, Poland, Romania, U. For pe rm i t ted imports, app rop r ia te exchange or per- mission to credit Irish pounds or s te r l ing to an Ex ternal Account is g ran ted au toma t ica l ly. Exchange control fo rms a re required for impo rt paymen ts exceeding £2,000 to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. Payments for Invisibles Payments to the Scheduled Territories are not sub- ject to exchange control unless they are for transactions outside the Scheduled Territories. Paymen ts to residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require app rova l. App roval to make payments for most invisi- bles is delegated to the authorized banks; for other invisibles, it is given by the Central Bank. For tour ist travel outside the Scheduled Territories (other than to Rhodes ia) there is a basic allowance for residents of the State of £250 a person for each trip. For business t rave l, up to £1,500, at a ra te of < £ Ir 20 a day, is allowed for each journey. Limits are also established for allowances for education and other pur- poses. Applications for larger amounts are approved, provided that no unau thor ized export of capital is involved. Not more than £250 of an allowance of foreign currency may be issued in the fo rm of currency notes. Persons traveling to destinations outside the United Kingdom (other than to Rhodesia) may also take with them up to £25 in Scheduled Territory cur- rency notes. Travelers who are resident outside the Scheduled Territories (other than Rhodesia) may take with them any foreign currency notes that they brought into Ireland. There is no restriction on the amount of Irish or other banknotes that may be taken to the United Kingdom. Exports and Export Proceeds A system of export licensing is applied to a limited range of goods. There is a special restriction on the export of a number of items to Rhodesia. Exporters of goods to countries outside the Scheduled Territories must obtain payment for the goods within six months of shipment, if the value of the goods exceeds £100. When payment is received in foreign currencies, the exchange must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. Exchange control forms are required for exports exceed- ing £2,000 to countries outside the Scheduled Terri- tories. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no specific requirements governing exchange receipts from invisibles, but if foreign currencies are received they must be offered for sale to an authorized bank or permission for their retention must be obtained. Any foreign currency held by a person after his return IRELAND f rom a t r ip abroad may be retained for three months f rom the da te he received the exchange, for use on a subsequent t r ip abroad. There are no l im i ta t ions on the impo rt of Ir ish or fo re ign bankno tes. Capital Inwa rd and ou twa rd movements of capital between I re land and other Scheduled Territories are not subject to exchange control. Exchange control approval is required for all t ran s fe rs of capital to countries outside the Scheduled Territories. Applications for transfer of capital at the official ma rket rate of exchange by resi- dents of the State em ig ra t ing to countries of the Over- seas Sterling Area that on June 23, 1972 ceased to be Scheduled Territories are approved up to a limit of £20,000 a f am i l y. Where the total value of an emi- grant's assets exceeds £20,000, the t rans fer of the excess amount is restricted for a period of four years f rom the em igran t's redesignation as a nonresident, i.e., f rom the date of depa r tu re f rom Ireland. The corre- sponding allocation for persons em igra t ing to other Ex ternal Account Area countries (except Rhodesia) is £5,000 a fam i ly unit. A f ter the four-year period, the assets are to be treated in the same way as those of non-Scheduled Territory residents who have never been resident in Ireland. However, permission is given at any time a f ter redesignation for the restricted funds to be transferred outside the Scheduled Territories through the investment currency market (see below) or invested in sterling securities.5 For Irish residents taking up employment and residence in an EEC country other than the United Kingdom, applications are considered to t rans fer Irish or U. K. assets to their new country of residence in excess of £Ir 5,000; the additional facilities are authorized at the official rate of exchange if they are shown to be appropriate to ensure the applicant's freedom to take up employment in the country con- cerned. Applications for the transfer of resident-owned capital for purposes other than emigration are con- sidered on their merits, but there are special facilities for residents taking up employment in EEC countries other than the United Kingdom and for direct invest- ment in such countries. There are no restrictions on the inflow of capital, but net inflows into the banks may be subject to guidelines set annua l ly by the Central Bank, purchases of unquoted Irish securities by nonresidents of the Scheduled Terri- tories require exchange control approval, and the pur- chase of nonurban land by foreign nationals in most cases requires approval by the Land Commission. Incoming capital received in foreign currencies must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. However, invest- ment currency, i.e., the foreign currency proceeds from the sale ma in ly of foreign currency securities 6 sold out- 5 Securities solely payable in Irish pounds or pounds sterling. 6 Foreign currency securities are all securities expressed in the currency of a country outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesian currency. 247 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND side the Scheduled Territories may be fu l ly reinvested in foreign currency securities, provided that the securi- ties sold were held prior to April 7, 1965, or acquired by "switches" f rom securities so held, and that the investment is carried out within six months from the date of sale through a bank, a stockbroker, or a solici- tor. Where the securities sold were purchased with investment currency on or a f ter April 7, 1965, 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be surrendered at the official rate, except in the case of foreign currency securities payable in the currency of an Overseas Sterling Area coun try that on June 23, 1972 ceased to be a Scheduled Territory. Investment currency may be invested temporarily in foreign currency certificates of deposit and similar paper with up to six months to run to final ma tur i ty, without incurring the need to comply with the 25 per cent requirement on ma tur i ty or resale, provided that the limit of six months for the holding of investment currency is not exceeded. In certain cases, the proceeds f rom the sale or liquidation of direct investments outside the Scheduled Territories (but not situated in a member coun try of the EEC) are regarded as investment currency and are eligible for investment in foreign currency securities, provided that 25 per cent of such proceeds is surrendered at the official rate. The entire foreign currency proceeds from the sale outside the Scheduled Territories of property for personal use owned by residents are normally regarded as investment currency where the whole of the property is sold; in other cases the 25 per cent requirement is applied. Residents may obtain, subject to individual permission, reasonable amounts of investment currency to purchase from non-Scheduled Territory residents property out- side the Scheduled Territories for personal use; pay- ments for attendant expenses and improvements must also be made with investment currency. Approval is normally limited to one property a family. Purchases f rom residents of the Scheduled Territories must be settled in sterling. Transactions in securities are con- trolled to ensure that capital is not transferred outside the Scheduled Territories. Direct investment outside the Scheduled Territories requires prior approval and, depending on the merits of the project, may be financed with investment currency, with official exchange, or by borrowing foreign currency. Use of official exchange is allowed, however, for all approved new direct investments in EEC countries other than the United Kingdom, subject to a limit of <£ Ir 250,000 a project a year, and applications to trans- fer larger amoun ts at the official exchange rate are considered on their merits. Dealings in Irish registered securities are permitted freely between residents of the Scheduled Territories. Specific approval is required for all dealings by Irish residents in securities payable in Rhodesian currency. Remittances of cash gifts to Over- seas Sterling Area countries that on June 23, 1972 ceased to be Scheduled Territories are normally per- mitted up to <£ Ir 1,000 a donor a calendar year; the 248 corresponding limit for other External Account Area countries is <£Ir 250 a donor a year. Authorized banks may freely accept deposits in for- eign currency from nonresidents of the Scheduled Ter- ritories and lend such deposits on to other nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories. Application must be made to the Central Bank for nonbank private sector borrow- ing from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories; such applications are considered on their merits and on the benefit likely to accrue to the economy. Public sector borrowing outside the Scheduled Territories is under- taken following consultation with the Central Bank. Lending of Irish currency to nonresidents of the Sched- uled Territories is not normally permitted, except to the extent that overdraft facilities may be provided by the banks to members of non-Scheduled Territories diplo- matic and consular missions in Ireland, and except that banks may freely make available loan and overdraft facilities in Irish pounds or sterling to residents of Over- seas Sterling Area countries that on June 23, 1972 ceased to be Scheduled Territories, provided the under- lying transaction is a trade transaction or one associated with the movement of goods. Gold Residents may freely hold, buy, borrow, sell, or lend gold coins in Ireland. Dealings in gold bullion are restricted, and no dealings take place in Ireland. Although there are no import restrictions, residents require exchange control permission to purchase gold coins or bullion abroad; permission is normally given to numismatists for the purchase of gold coins. Exchange control permission also is required for the export of gold coins and bullion; this is not normally granted except to industrial users. Residents of Ireland are not permitted to hold gold abroad. Changes during 1972 January 1. A system of generalized tariff preferences came into force for specified goods originating in most developing countries. January 22. Negotiations for accession to the EEC were concluded. It was agreed that Ireland could defer, in accordance with the following arrangements, the liberalization of capital movements provided for in EEC Directives. 1. Ireland could, for a period of two years after accession to the EEC, defer the liberalization of direct investments in member states of the EEC by persons resident in Ireland and the liberalization of the liquida- tion of direct investments in member states by persons resident in Ireland. It was agreed, however, that Ireland would endeavor to take appropriate measures to pro- ceed from the date of accession to a substantial relaxa- tion in the rules concerning outward direct investment. 2. Not later than two and a half years after acces- sion, Ireland would liberalize the following capital ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution movements of a personal na ture: the transfer of capital belonging to persons resident in Ireland who are emi- grating (other than transfers connected with the free- dom of movement of workers, which would be liberal- ized from the date of accession); gifts, endowments, and dowries; succession duties; and real estate invest- ments other than those connected with the freedom of movement for workers, which would be liberalized from the date of accession. 3. Ireland could, for a period of five years af ter accession, defer the liberalization of the portfolio invest- ment operations set out in List B annexed to the EEC Council Directives of May 11, 1960 and December 18, 1962, when carried out by persons resident in Ireland. May 1. The exchange rate margins for the currencies of EEC countries were narrowed. Similar action was taken by the United Kingdom. The Irish pound remained at par with sterling without any margin. Ire- land's participation in the EEC arrangements was suspended on June 23, when sterling and the Irish pound were floated. June 2. Monetary policy guidelines to the banking system for the current fiscal year were issued, retro- active to April 18, 1972. In contrast to previous years, quantitative guidelines for individuals, banks, or groups of banks were not proposed. The guidelines for 1971/72 had suggested that no net inflow of capital into the banks from outside Ireland should occur. (On Feb- ruary 6, 1973 the Central Bank proposed that at least 50 per cent of capital inflows after Janua ry 16, 1973 be deposited with it on accounts which would not be included in the calculation of primary liquidity ratios. Banks were asked to bring about no net capital inf low over and above the Janua ry 16 position.) June 23. The Minister of Finance announced that the Irish pound would float in line with sterling and that the parity relationship between the Irish pound and the pound sterling would be maintained. The Irish foreign exchange market was closed. It reopened on June 27. June 23. The Exchange Control Regulations, 1972 came into operation. In line with similar measures adopted by the United Kingdom, exchange control was introduced between Ireland and the other countries of the Sterling Area, except the United Kingdom (includ- ing the Channel Islands and the Isle of M a n ). All Ster- ling Area countries, except Ireland, the United King- dom, the Channel Islands, and the Isle of Man, ceased to be Scheduled Territories under Ireland's Exchange Control Acts, 1954 to 1970. For exchange control pur- poses, countries were now classified as the Scheduled Territories, the External Account Area, and Rhodesia. The Irish pound accounts held by residents of the coun- tries that ceased to be Scheduled Territories were redes- ignated External Accounts. The currency of each of these countries became a foreign currency for exchange control purposes, and securities payable in such cur- rencies became foreign currency securities. All current IRELAND instructions regarding transactions involving nonresidents would now also apply to residents of the excluded countries. The extension of exchange control to the Overseas Sterling Area did not involve the introduction of restrictions on current payments to the countries concerned, but restrictions were introduced on certain capital transfers and capital transactions. June 29. Banks were informed in detail of the exchange control arrangements which would henceforth apply to the countries excluded on June 23 from the list of Scheduled Territories, i.e., the Overseas Sterling Area. The new regulations differed in various respects f rom those applying at the time to other countries in the External Account Area. The securities of the former Scheduled Territories now were considered foreign currency securities, and their purchase required the use of investment currency, but the "25 per cent require- ment" was not applicable when they were sold. Sterling securities were redefined as securities payable solely in the currencies of Ireland or the United Kingdom. Per- mission was required to make direct investments in the countries concerned, but permission would normally be given for funds to be transferred, without limit, at the official market rate of exchange, provided that the investment was not of a portfolio nature and that the finance required was to be employed wholly within fo rmer Scheduled Territories. Approval also became necessary for inward direct investments by residents of such countries; the normal rules relating to such invest- ments by nonresidents would apply. Irish pound or sterling loans and overdrafts to bodies corporate and branches resident in Ireland or the United Kingdom that are controlled by residents of the former Scheduled Territories became subject to the provisions of Sec- tion 24 of the Exchange Control Act, 1954 relating to lending. Banks could, however, continue to make avail- able to such companies, without reference to Exchange Control, facilities already appearing on their books as at June 23, 1972. As regards new or increased facilities, banks would normally be allowed to lend to Irish com- panies controlled by residents of former Scheduled Territories all the finance they required for their opera- tions in Ireland; similar lending facilities could normally be granted to U. K. companies of the same status. Borrowing by Irish residents f rom residents of the former Scheduled Territories became subject to Sec- tion 4 ( i) of the Exchange Control Act and henceforth required a general or specific permission. Banks could now make available new loan and ove rd ra ft facilities in Irish pounds or sterling to residents of former Sched- uled Territories only where the underlying transaction was a trad ing one or associated with the movement of goods. Export proceeds accruing in the currencies of former Scheduled Territories became subject to sur- render, and payments for imports f rom such countries had to be made in accordance with exchange control requirements. Residents holding accounts in the cur- rencies of fo rmer Scheduled Territories were obliged to 249 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRELAND close such accounts and to o f fer balances thereon for sale at the official market rate to an authorized dealer, unless otherwise permitted by the Central Bank. Pur- chases and sales of land and proper ty for private use located in fo rmer Scheduled Territories now had to be settled with investment currency. Residents em igra t ing to fo rm er Scheduled Territories would no rma l ly be allowed to t r an s f er on depa r tu re to their new coun try of residence up to £ Ir 20,000 a f am i ly un it from their Irish and other Sterling Area assets, together with any foreign currency securities they he ld; the existing capital allowance of <£ Ir 5,000 continued to apply to emigrants to other countries in the External Account Area. The basic travel allowances for travel outside the Sterling Area became applicable also to travel to fo rm er Sched- uled Territories. Insurers in Ireland could no longer issue to Irish residents or to other residents of the Sterling Area annuities and l ife and endowment policies expressed in currencies of former Scheduled Territories; such annuities and policies expressed in Irish pounds or sterling and owned by residents of Ireland could no longer, except with prior permission, be switched into a currency of, or assigned to a person resident in, a former Scheduled Territory. Cash gifts to residents of such countries would norma l ly be permitted up to £Ir 1,000 a donor a calendar year; for other External Account Area countries, the existing l im it of £Jr250 a donor a calendar year remained. Banks could author- ize payments to persons resident in former Scheduled Territories who are beneficiaries under estates and intestacies of deceased Irish residents, subject to the same conditions applying to distributions to beneficiaries resident in other External Account Area countries; applications, however, relating to estates in Ireland of persons who died resident in a former Scheduled Ter- ritory, had to be referred to Exchange Control. Resi- dents henceforth required exchange control permission to set up, or add to, a trust, or to make a settlement, in favor of residents of former Scheduled Territories. July 1. The seventh annual reduction in protective duties on imports f rom the United Kingdom under the Anglo-Irish Free Trade Agreement came in to effect. November 1. A value-added tax was in troduced. January 1. Ireland became a member of the EEC. The Anglo-Irish Free Trade Agreement remained in force. January L Certain measures to relax exchange con- trols between Ire land and member countries of the EEC other than the United Kingdom fo rma l ly came into effec t. These re laxa t ions had been in operation admin- istratively for some mon ths and were b road ly in line w i th s im i lar measures adopted by the United Kingdom. 1. Exchange control permission was still required for direct investments in the countries concerned. The use of official exchange wou ld be allowed, however, for all new inves tmen ts, subject to a l im it of c£Ir 250,000 a project a year, and applications to transfer larger amoun ts at the official rate of exchange would be considered on their merits. Since the relaxation would not apply retrospectively, the early repayment of for- eign currency borrow ing already under taken and applied to existing projects wou ld not be permitted. The for- eign currency realized on a sale or liquidation of direct investments in the countries concerned, whenever made, would no longer no rma l ly be eligible for sale in the investment currency market. Direct investments were defined as those where the Irish investing company par- ticipates in the management or operation of a project either d irec t ly or th rough the in termed iary of a com- pany or branch spec ia l ly established in an EEC country for the purpose. 2. Applications would be considered from residents of Ireland who intended to take up employment in an EEC coun try, other than the United Kingdom, and who wished to be regarded as resident in their new country of employment, to t ran s fer Irish or U. K. assets to their new country of residence in excess of the previous limit of <£ Ir 5,000. The additional facilities requested would be authorized at the official rate of exchange if they were shown to be appropriate to ensure the applicant's freedom to take up employment in the country con- cerned. 3. Irish residents taking up temporary employment in EEC countries would, during the period of employment, still be regarded as Irish residents for exchange control purposes. The transfer of funds would be approved to meet such items as settling-in expenses, unforeseen cur- rent expenditure, and the cost of accommodation; authorities given would be limited to amounts which were shown to be appropriate to ensure the applicant's freedom to continue or take up employment in the country concerned. 250 ©International Monetary Fund. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents' funds are held either on foreign cur- rency accounts or on local currency accounts. The principal type of nonresident foreign currency account is the PATACH account. The holder may freely effect transfers f rom his fore ign currency account. He may also convert funds held in the account into local cur- rency at the official rate of exchange. Local currency accounts of nonresidents are of two types: ( 1) Registered Accounts —for payments to and holdings of fo re ign aviation, shipping, insurance, and film companies and for nontransferable holdings of former residents —may be established only with special approval. Funds acquired from the sale of real estate and awaiting repatriation must also be held in Regis- tered Accounts. Aviation, shipping, and insurance com- panies may free ly convert at the official rate of exchange any amounts held on these accounts which are surplus to local requirements; film companies may do so under individual arrangements made with each company. Registered Account funds held by former residents may be used for investment in listed Israeli securities, for purchase of real estate, for tourist expenses in Israel up to an amount of I£150 a d a y2 for the account holder and for each member of his * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. Funds representing the sales proceeds of certain real estate become t r an s f e r ab le a f t er five years, in equal ins ta l lmen ts over a five-year period. Ownership of Registered Accounts may not be transferred. (2) Other nonres ident accounts in local cu r rency may be used to hold funds derived f rom fo rmer investments that are eligible for t r an s f er at the official exchange rate. Balances may be t ran s fe r red between nonresidents. The accounts may be l iqu ida ted at any time by the purchase of fore ign exchange at the official rate; such foreign exchange may free ly be t rans fe r red abroad or credited to a PATACH accoun t. Otherwise, funds in these accounts may be used w i th in Israel, and no limit is placed on the amount that may be withdrawn. Israeli citizens who are temporar i ly l iv ing and earn- ing abroad may ma in ta in foreign currency in temporary PAMAZ accounts in Israel. Balances in such accounts may be freely used abroad when the holder is abroad; when he is in Israel he may only convert these funds into local currency at the official exchange rate. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency Residents may ma in ta in foreign currency deposits with authorized banks in Israel on either PAZAK accounts, which may be held by all recipients of for- eign exchange other than those to whom exchange has been allocated from domestic sources, or TAMAM accounts, which may be held by recipients of restitution payments and disability pensions. PAZAK accounts are demand or time deposit ac- counts denominated in convertible currencies. All for- eign exchange receipts, except those derived from exchange allocations by the Ministry of Finance but including export proceeds, may be placed in PAZAK accounts. Account holders may retain funds in this manner or may exchange them into local currency. As an inducement to export, account holders may use for- eign exchange balances in PAZAK accounts to make any authorized foreign payments. Balances in PAZAK accounts are not negotiable between residents, but PAZAK accounts may be registered in the names of members of the immediate fam i ly of the account holder. TAMAM accounts are demand or time deposit accounts in convertible currencies. One third of con- vertible exchange receipts derived f rom personal resti- tution payments and f rom pensions, etc., of disabled soldiers who served during World War II may be cred- ited to TAMAM accounts. The permitted uses of TAMAM accounts include the following: ( 1) the pur- 3 Increased to I£ 15,000 a year with effect from February 8, 1973. 251 ©International Monetary Fund. NATAD accounts are transfer accounts in foreign exchange that are used ma in ly for transactions in for- eign securities. Holders of TAMAM accounts may purchase abroad foreign securities denominated in con- vertible foreign currency and registered on a stock exchange in specified foreign countries. Foreign securities thus acquired may be traded free ly between residents, th rough the in t e rm ed i a ry of the authorized bank that is the depository, against payment either with NATAD or TAMAM funds or in Israel pounds. If the original buyer resells securities bought w i th TAMAM account f u n ds for fo re ign cu r rency he may deposit the proceeds in TAMAM accounts. Residents who are not holders of TAMAM accounts may deposit the foreign exchange proceeds f rom the sale of foreign securities in NATAD accounts. Balances in NATAD accounts may be used to purchase f u r t h er fore ign securities but are not negotiable between residents. If foreign securi- ties are sold between residents against Israel pounds, the conversion fac tor used to establish their domestic currency value is the so-called NATAD rate. On December 31, 1972, it stood at I £4 .22 per U. S. dollar. Imports and Import Payments A few imports are prohibited f rom all sources and all imports f rom Rhodesia are prohibited. The cu r rency and method of payment are prescribed in each license; if a conver t ib le cu r rency is prescribed, payment may be made in any conve r t ib le cu r rency. Licenses are not issued for imports of goods on con- signment unless the recipient of the license imports goods valued at US$250,000 within three months and under takes to deposit 10 per cent of the value of the goods in local cu r rency w i th the Bank of Israel through an authorized bank. Importers are required to deposit with the customs, at the t ime of pay ing the import duty and for a period of six months, 30 per cent of the c.i.f. value of imports.5 Exempt are commodities subject to customs duty at a rate of less than 50 per cent, imports by or for the Governmen t, imm igran ts' personal effects, gifts, and imports on which the deposit wou ld amount to less than I £500. The funds are kept on deposit in the Bank of Israel for six mon ths and interest of 6 per cent a year is received by the impor ter. V i r tu a l ly all imports are sub ject to an import surcharge of 20 per cent of the c.i.f. va lue. The main exemptions are for fue ls, cer- ta in basic foods tu f fs, and uncut diamonds. A purchase tax is levied on almost all imported and domestically produced goods, other than capital goods. Payments for Invisibles Most paymen ts abroad for invisibles require individ- ual licenses. Each resident is allowed exchange equiva- lent to US$10-250, which is obtainable on demand, for certain purposes such as the purchase of books, mem- bership dues, and registration in a university. For tour- ist travel abroad, there is an exchange allowance equiv- a lent to US$450 a t r av e l er for each jou rney (US$225 for ch i ld ren und er 1 2 ); em igran ts a re not eligible for this a l lowance. Not more than I £100 in Israel bank- notes may be taken out by travelers. Foreign tourists leaving Israel are pe rm i t ted to repurchase through authorized dealers fore ign currency up to US$30. Resi- dents t rave l ing abroad must pay a travel tax; for travel by sea, the tax is I £550 p lus 10 per cent of the price of the ticket, and for travel by air, I £595 plus 10 per cent of the price of the ticket. Travelers to specified countries are exempted f rom the travel tax; these in c lude Cyp rus, Ethiopia, and Roman ia. Exporters doing more than US$ 100,000 of export business a year are exempt f rom travel tax on business trips. Immi- •"'The rate of deposit was reduced to 20 per cent on Janua ry 1, 1973.
