Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports do not require licenses if paid for in free ly convertible currencies. For some commodities, however, export licensing is retained for the purpose of quality control. The Ministry of Commerce and Industry maintains a check on export transactions with a low value-added content which are made with bilateral partners; this is done to discourage switch transactions. Export proceeds in foreign currencies must be surrendered or held in a PAZAK account. Exports of most commodities are eligible for incen t ive payments based on value added and designed to rebate estimated in te rnal indirect taxes and the import surcharge. At the end of 1972, the pay- ment for diamonds was about 50 agorot per US$1 equivalent, and for other commodities the payment ranged f rom 95 to 99 agorot per US$1 equivalent, with the higher rates applicable to commodities with a higher proportion of domestic va lue added. For inputs d irec t ly imported by an exporter there is a system of rebate of customs duties, wha rf charges, etc. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds f rom invisibles must, in general, be surrendered. A l te rna t ive ly, they may be kept in for- eign exchange on PAZAK accounts, balances on which may be exchanged in to Israel currency at any time or used to make au thor ized paymen ts. Any resident is f ree to accept specified convertible currencies from tourists in payment for services and commodities other than commerc ial exports, securities, and real estate; such receipts must be surrendered w i th in a few days. One th ird of the fo re ign exchange received by resi- dents of Israel as res t i tu t ion paymen ts, and as pensions by disabled soldiers who served in World War II, may be retained in TAMAM accounts. For ten years a f t er en te r ing Israel, new imm igran ts are exempt f rom su r rende r ing the ir fore ign exchange to the Treasury, and they may keep these currencies w i th authorized banks in Israel or w i th banks abroad. Tourists v is i t ing Israel are expected to bring with them the amoun ts of fo re ign currency that they will need d u r i ng the ir stay. Not more than I<£100 in Israel bankno tes may be brought in by travelers. Tourists and others v is i t ing Israel who are holders of Registered Accounts (see section on Non res ident Accounts, above) may draw upon such accounts to the extent of I £150 a day for themselves and the same amount for each member of the ir fam i l ies ," if they are holders of other nonres ident local currency accounts, they may draw on them without limit. 6 See also footnote 2. ISRAEL Capital Foreign exchange representing incoming capital and belonging to a resident has to be surrendered at the official rate or held in a PAZAK account. Capital brought into Israel for the purpose of investment may, subject to approval, be granted preferential treatment in accordance with the Law for the Encouragement of Capital Investments of August 16, 1959, which, inter alia, permits a nonresident who has made an "approved" investment in foreign currency to transfer all his profits abroad in the same currency at the official rate. Repay- ment and amortization of capital may also be trans- ferred on the following terms: if the investment has been kept for less than five years, the capital may be withdrawn in five equal installments; if the investment has been kept for more than five years, it may be with- drawn immediately. Current policy is to grant "approved" status only to enterprises in selected fields of production that fu l f i ll one of the following conditions: ( 1) that they are established in "priority areas"; (2) that they are export-oriented, i.e., either at least 50 per cent of output is exported or existing productive capacity is increased by at least 50 per cent while at least 50 per cent of the additional output is exported; or (3) that, although for economic reasons the enterprise cannot be established in a priority area, its production is of the import- substitution type. There is no longer any difference between an "approved investment" and any other invest- ment made by a nonresident in foreign currency insofar as his rights to t rans fer abroad the principal or the inter- est or profits on his investment are concerned. The d ifference does still exist as regards other benefits, such as income tax concessions and grants. Every investment in real estate (held for at least five years prior to November 1971), debentures registered at the stock exchange, or shares that was made in Israel after May 15, 1948 in foreign currency that was con- verted into Israel pounds as the law required, or that was made in Israel pounds derived from the conversion of foreign currency, or in State of Israel bonds that may be used for investment purposes upon ma tur i ty, entitles the nonresident or imm ig rant concerned (providing in the latter case that the investment was implemented before his settling permanen t ly in Israel) to transfer abroad the proceeds of the liquidation of his investment by purchas ing fore ign currency at the official exchange rate. (For imm ig ran ts, this right is limited to the first ten years of the ir residence in Israe l .) In respect of inves tmen ts made by nonres iden ts to which the above principle does not apply, the proceeds of liquidation must be credited to a Registered Account. An invest- ment made f rom monies in a Registered Account, or f rom amoun ts which the owner was legally obliged f r om the outset to deposit in a Registered Account, can on ly be l iqu ida ted by cred i t ing the proceeds and the income to a Registered Account. Normally, the Registered Account must be credited with every right 253 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL acc ru ing in Israel to a fo re ign res iden t, sub ject to the app roval of the Con t ro l ler of Foreign Exchange. Proceeds acc ru ing f rom the repa tr ia t ion or l iqu ida t ion of foreign assets held by residents are treated in the same way as proceeds f rom invisibles. Any resident may re ta in proper ty abroad, but not money, securities, or the income f rom proper ty; new imm i g r a n ts may re ta in l iqu id assets as well. Transfers abroad of a cap i tal na ture by residents o ther th an new imm ig ran ts are generally not permitted. Owners of TAMAM deposits are en t i t led to purchase fore ign securities registered at stock exchanges in speci- fied foreign countries. Foreign securities purchased to the debit of a TAMAM deposit can be sold abroad by their owners, or in Israel against fore ign currency to owners of other TAMAM or NATAD deposits. The proceeds of the sale can then be credited to the TAMAM account previously debited with the purchase. The owner of foreign securities bought through TAMAM or NATAD accounts is allowed to sell them also against Israel pounds, and the purchaser in his tu rn may sell them either against Israel pounds or against foreign currency (abroad or to holders of TAMAM or NATAD deposits); he is entitled to deposit the foreign currency proceeds in a NATAD account. This is the only manner in which NATAD accounts can be established. The holder of a NATAD account may draw on it to purchase foreign securities abroad, or to pay to a holder of a TAMAM or NATAD account foreign cur- rency for foreign securities. It is also permissible to purchase gold from monies in TAMAM and NATAD accounts, the procedure being the same. A general license allows authorized dealers to pur- chase real estate in Israel for nonresidents. Nonresidents may freely purchase shares, provided that purchases are financed with converted foreign currency; debentures, however, may be purchased by nonresidents only if they are quoted on the Tel Aviv stock exchange. Direct loans in any form are subject to licensing. Gold Residents, including private persons, may freely hold gold in any form either in Israel or abroad; purchases by private persons must be financed out of TAMAM or NATAD accounts, except for purchases of jewelry and articles containing a minor quantity of gold, such as watches. It is forbidden to trade in gold, to transfer it from place to place, or to take it out of Israel. Gold can be sold only to an authorized dealer and can be bought only from an authorized dealer. Imports of gold are permissible only if an import license is obtained. Imports of gold for industrial purposes are transacted by five importing wholesalers. These wholesalers may sell the gold only to purchasers registered with the Purchase Tax Administration. The latter checks these purchases by each manu fac tu rer against the gold content of products marked as "purchase tax paid" in order to 254 e l im ina te the possibility of sales of these quantities of gold on the market as bu l l ion. Not for Redistribution ITALY1 Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00142187 gram of fine gold per Italian Lira, corresponding to Lit 625 = SDR 1, and a central rate of Lit 581.500 = US$1 has been estab- lished, corresponding to Lit 631.343 = SDR 1. All exchange transactions, however, take place at fluctuat- ing rates in a dual exchange market. Current trans- actions are channeled through the official or ordinary exchange market (mercato valutario ordinario or mercato del conti valutari ordinari) and capital transac- tions through the financial exchange market (mercato finanziario or mercato dei conti valutari valutario finanziari); no announced margins are observed in either market. The closing rate for the U.S. dollar in the official market on March 1, 1973 was Lit 562.05 per US$1, and that in the Milan financial market was Lit 553.00 per US$1. The monetary authorities do not in principle inter- vene in the fo rwa rd exchange ma rke t; forward pre- miums and discounts are norma l ly left to the interplay of market forces, although the Bank of Italy (the cen- tral b ank) may from time to t ime offer the commercial banks certain swap facilities. Authorized banks are al- lowed to engage in spot exchange transactions in any currency, and in forward exchange transactions up to 360 days in U. S. dollars, Canad ian dollars, Japanese yen, and externally convertible European currencies,2 when dealing with other banks, or up to 180 days when dealing with nonbanks. The permissible amount of forward transactions against lire is subject to a limit on net transactions set ind iv idua l ly for each bank. Forward cover is freely permitted only for commercial transactions; cover in respect of financial transactions requires authorization. Italy forma l ly accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as f rom February 15, 1961. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the I ta l ian Exchange Office (Uff ic io I ta l iano dei Camb i) on the basis of ins t ruc t ions issued by the M in is try of For- eign Trade. All sales and purchases of exchange pass through banks authorized for this purpose. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Min- istry of F inance at the request of the Ministry of For- eign Trade. Certain impor ts and exports require the prior visa of the Na t ional Foreign Trade Ins t i tu te. Nonresident Accounts The main types of accounts in Italian lire which non- residents are allowed to ma in ta in w i th authorized banks in Italy are Foreign Accounts and Capital Accounts. The use of these accounts, and of Special Accounts for certain investments, is described below. 1. Foreign Accounts may be credited with transfers f rom other Foreign Accounts, with lire from authorized current payments, and with the proceeds f rom sales in the official market of U. S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, and externally convertible European currencies. They may be debited for purchases of any of these currencies in the official market, for transfers to any other Foreign Account, for payments to residents of Italy for current transactions, and for drawings in cash by the holder of the account or his delegates. 2. Capital Accounts may be credited with ( 1) the proceeds of sales of the above-mentioned convertible currencies in the f inanc ial marke t; (2) transfers from Special Accounts Under Law No. 43, f rom Special Accounts Under Law No. 211, and f rom other Capital Accounts; ( 3) the proceeds f rom the liquidation of foreign investments in Italy not made under the provi- sions of Law No. 211 of March 2, 1948 or Law No. 43 of February 7, 1956 (see be low ); (4) most loans in lire f rom residents to nonresidents; (5) all other per- mitted financial operations; and ( 6) interest on Capital Accounts. Capital Accounts may be debited for the purchase of convertible currencies in the financial mar- ket, for transfers to any other Capital Account or to Special Accounts Under Law No. 43, for the purchase of investments not made under Law No. 43, including purchases of personal property or real estate in Italy, for gifts, inheritances, loans in lire from nonresidents to residents, and all other permitted financial operations. 3. Special Accounts Under Law No. 43 of Feb- ruary 7, 1956 are accounts in the names of nonresidents who have invested in Italy convertible currencies or externally convertible European currencies in accord- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ance with the above-mentioned law. These accounts may be credited with the counter-value of convertible cur- rencies sold in Italy in the financial exchange market, with transfers from Capital Accounts, from other Spe- cial Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of investments that have been made in accordance with Law No. 43. They may be debited for purchases in the financial exchange market of the same currency that was originally sold and for investments in Italy, and balances on them may be transferred to Capital Accounts or to any other Special Account Under Law No. 43. Imports and Import Payments All imports of Rhodesian origin are prohibited. Practically all imports from other countries except Japan, mainland China, North Viet-Nam, and the CMEA countries are free of quantitative restriction; all goods, however, require a bank certificate for submis- sion to the customs authorities and sometimes also a license issued by the Ministry of Finance at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Commodities that still require individual licenses when imported from these other countries are included in a negative list (Tabella A Import).* Some items in the list require an import license only when originating in Israel or Yugoslavia. The general permission to import goods not included in the Tabella A Import applies to Egypt and Yugoslavia only if the goods both originate in and are shipped direct from the coun try concerned; in addi- tion, in respect of imports of raw cotton, rice, and crude petroleum f rom Egypt, the payee must reside in that country or in one of the European OECD countries. (Seventy per cent of the va lue of other imports f rom Egypt must be paid to creditors residing either in that country or in any OECD coun try, and 30 per cent must be paid in lire to Egypt's lire account with the Italian Exchange Office .) A more extensive negative list (Tabella B Import) contains those commodities which requ i re an ind iv idual license when o r ig in a t ing in and impo r ted f rom A lban ia, Bu lga r ia, m a in l and Ch ina, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Ge rmany, Hunga ry, Nor th Korea, Mongolia, Poland, Roman ia, the U. Foreign banknotes may be sold in the financial m a rk et on ly; settlements with travelers checks and credit cards take place at official market rates. Residents of I ta ly are free to buy and sell, through the Bank of I ta ly or the authorized banks, any foreign securities issued or payable abroad and quoted on foreign stock exchanges, and to deal in such securities among themselves against payment in lire. Such foreign securities, except securities of Lit 100,000 or less, have to be deposited w i th an Italian bank or with a bank abroad for account of an Italian bank. The purchase by residents of shares of fore ign financial ins t i tu t ions of any kind (including mutual f u n d s ), as well as con- vertible bonds issued by such institutions, requires prior approval by the Italian Exchange Office. In practice, however, a resident is able free ly to purchase shares of foreign funds that have received authorization from the M in is try of Foreign Trade to sell their shares in Italy, since that authorization is in fact valid also for the individual resident subscriber. Such authorization is given only to funds meeting certain requirements, including that of investing at least 50 per cent of their portfolio in Italian securities and that of setting up a branch office in Italy. Residents do not require authori- zation to purchase real estate in EEC countries. Special regu la t ions app ly to commerc ial credits and credits related to the pe r fo rmance of services. Advance paymen ts for impor ts may be made free ly if importa- tion is to take place w i th in 30 days; in all other cases, the prior approval of the M in i s t ry of Foreign Trade is requ i red. When p repaymen ts for imports exceed Lit 5 m i l l ion, an advance deposit of 5 per cent is required. Deferred paymen ts for imports are permitted freely if settlement is to take place, to the extent of at least 90 per cen t, w i th in 360 days a f ter impor ta t ion, and the balance w i th in 24 months a f t er importation; such paymen ts requ ire the prior approval of the Italian Exchange Office if the settlement is to take place between 12 mon ths and 24 mon ths a f ter importation. In all other cases, the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade is required. Advance paymen ts for exports may be received freely if exportation is to take place w i th in 360 days; in all other cases, such receipts require the prior approval of the I ta l ian Exchange Office. Deferred payments for exports are permitted freely if settlement is to take place to the extent of at least 90 per cent within 90 days a f ter exportation, and the balance within 24 months a f ter exportation; in all other cases, such receipts require the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Virtually identical regulations are in force for the permitted credit terms for imports and exports of services. In relations with EEC countries, the reciprocal granting of credits for commercial transactions or the performance of services, with a maturity longer than the time limits that banks are authorized to approve and up to five years, may be effected after examination of the documents by the Italian Exchange Office. Loans and credits (the latter only beyond a certain duration, generally 180-360 days) not connected with commercial transactions or with the performance of services require the approval of the Ministry of Foreign 259 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY Trade. However, f inanc ial loans may be granted to or by residents of EEC countries as indicated above. The net external position of the banks is subject to control by the Exchange Office. This control encom- passes ( 1) the spot position vis-a-vis nonresidents in foreign currencies and lire together; and (2) the over- all position, spot and forward combined, in all foreign currencies. Authorized banks are permitted to incur a net foreign liability position and are prohibited f rom maintaining a net foreign asset position. The major banks have agreed not to pay interest on nonresident lire accounts (Foreign Accounts on ly ). The export of Italian and foreign securities is per- mitted only when they are owned by nonresidents and have been purchased against U. S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japanese yen, or externally convertible Euro- pean currencies, or against f u n ds on a Foreign Account or a Capital Account. Gold All transactions in gold between residents and non- residents are settled in the official exchange market. Residents may freely hold and negotiate gold in any form in Italy, w i th the exception of unrefined gold imported under ministerial license for indus tr ial pur- poses. The monetary authorities may freely acquire unrefined gold abroad. Agent banks that have been authorized by the Ministry of the Treasury may acquire unrefined gold abroad upon submission of licenses issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade to Italian firms for industrial use.9 Imports of wrought and semi- manufactured gold, inc lud ing jewelry, are subject to licensing as are exports of wrought and sem imanu fac- tured gold other than jewelry. Commercial imports of articles containing a minor quan t i ty of gold, such as watches, are liberalized for most countries of origin. Imports of unrefined gold are subject to value-added tax at 12 per cent. Imports of gold coins for numis- matic purposes are subject to value-added tax at 18 per cent. Changes during 1972 January 15. The importation of certain goods origi- nating in A lban ia, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hunga ry, Poland, Roman ia, and the U. S. S. R. was liberalized. March 31. The Exchange Office changed its policy with respect to dollar swaps w i th resident banks by charging a p rem ium in favor of the Exchange Office, i.e., a p rem ium for the l i r a. (Th is policy was reversed on June 28 .) April 24. The Bank of Italy narrowed the exchange rate margins for the currencies of the other member countries of the EEC. The arrangements were designed to ensure that the max imum divergence f rom cross- 9 The supervision over imports of un re f ined gold was t igh tened in April 1973 and again in May. 260 parities between any two currencies of the member states of the EEC did not exceed 2.25 per cent. The Commission of the EEC granted authority to Italy, for a period of six months, to restrict imports from EEC countries of certain goods of Jap- anese origin, including automobiles, motorcycles, and television sets. (This authority was subsequently extended in amended form .) May 16. The Japanese yen was added to the list of conto valutario currencies. May 18. Imports of many goods originating in main- land China were liberalized. The degree of liberalization accorded to that country was approximately the same as that already enjoyed by Eastern European countries. (The same degree of liberalization was accorded to Eastern Germany in March 1973.) May 22. The prescribed terms for advance payments for imports (and services) were modified. Henceforth payment could be made up to 90 days prior to impor- tation (previously 30 days prior to impor ta t ion). May 29. Contracts between residents and nonresidents involving long-term leases on land became subject to prior authorization by the Ministry of Foreign Trade. June 23. The exchange market was closed. It reopened on June 28. June 27. The Is t i tu to Mobiliare I ta l iano ( IM I) was again permitted to borrow abroad at medium term. (Subsequently, foreign borowing operations were under- taken by IMI and several other public sector agencies, notably the Is t i tu to di Credito per le Imprese di Pub- blica Utilita ( the Public Utilities Credit In s t i tu t e ) .) June 27. The crediting of Italian banknotes and coins to Capital Accounts was prohibited. June 27. The intervention limits for sterling and Dan- ish kroner were suspended. (Those for the latter cur- rency were reinstated on October 18.) June 28. Italian banks, which previously were required to ma in ta in a balanced foreign position, were allowed to incur net foreign liability positions. June 30. Banks were instructed not to maintain net foreign asset positions and to apply to repayment of their swaps f rom the Exchange Office, on a daily basis, all foreign currency received f rom the repayment by their customers of foreign currency loans. August 2. The purchase by residents of convertible bonds issued by foreign financial institutions of any kind was made subject to the prior examination of applications by the Exchange Office (in line with Cir- cular No. A /237 of Janua ry 12, 1971). December 3. The Committee for Export Credit Insurance for the first time approved the implementa- tion of Law No. 131 of 1967, which provided for an insurance facility covering exporters against increases in international prices of raw materials. December 5. In order to discourage lira lending that might facilitate the financing of leads and lags, the Bank of Italy increased the interest rate charged to banks for fixed-maturity advances of 8, 15, or 22 days on securities from 3l/2 per cent to 5l/2 per cent. The penalties for banks applying for such advances three more times within 6 months of the first advance were maintained. December 5. The Exchange Office offered com- mercial banks three-month swap facilities under which, to the extent of any net external creditor position, they could, in order to comply with the obligation to maintain a balanced position, sell U. S. dollars to the Exchange Office at current market rates, with a guar- antee that repurchase could take place at the same exchange rate. NOTE. —The following changes took place early in 1973: January 1. A value-added tax came into effect. It replaced the cascade-type turnover tax. January 5. Borrowing and lending between residents of Italy and residents of Austria, in respect of imports of Austrian origin and exports to Austria, with ma tur- ities in excess of those which banks could approve but not in excess of five years, henceforth was permitted subject to prior examination of documents by the Exchange Office. January 22. The period normally allowed for advance payments for imports was reduced f rom 90 days to 30 days prior to importation; as a result, payments 31 days to 360 days (five years for EEC countries) prior to importation were subject to prior examination of documents by the Exchange Office. The period within which export proceeds must no rma l ly be collected was reduced from 360 days to 90 days af ter shipment; as a result, collection 91 days to 360 days ( f ive years for EEC countries) af ter exportation was subject to prior examination of documents by the Exchange Office. January 22. The period d u r i ng which authorized banks were permitted to retain export proceeds in for- eign exchange accounts (conti valutari) on behalf of the recipients was reduced f rom six mon ths to one month after collection. This was applicable also to foreign exchange accounts in the financial market (see below). ITALY January 22. The use for the financing of current noncommercial transactions of existing lines of credit obtained abroad henceforth was permitted by the Exchange Office only if repayment of each individual transaction was to take place within 180 days. January 22. A dual exchange market came into operation. Current transactions were to be channeled through the official exchange market, where IMF and EEC margins would continue to be observed, while capital transactions were to be settled in the financial exchange market, where quotations would be freely determined by supp ly and demand. The existing exchange control regulations, inc lud ing those of June 28, 1972 concerning Italian banknotes, were maintained (with the exceptions mentioned in the fol- lowing January 22 entries). Payments and receipts eligible for the official market included those in respect of the following: imports and exports of goods; transport and communications (freight, harbor dues and unloading charges, postal and cable charges, e tc .); charges for the services of intermediaries (bank charges and fees, payments to forwarding agents, payments to commodity dealers, etc .); contributions to expenses of branches, repre- sentative offices, news agencies; advertising expenses; construction, repairs, and modernization (buildings, roads, bridges, ports, ships, e tc .); insurance and rein- surance, including indemnifications, contributions, and annuities; pensions and remuneration for work (includ- ing prizes, authors' copyrights, contributions in news- papers and films, patents, e tc . ); expenses of travel and sojourn; payment of interest, dividends, etc.; and mis- cellaneous (emigrants' remittances, taxes, duties, mem- bership fees, contributions and subsidies, legal expenses, maintenance of real estate, etc .). Permitted debits to Capital Accounts (related to the financial marke t) included those in respect of the fol- lowing: conversion into foreign currency in the finan- cial market; t rans fer to a Special Account Under Law No. 43 of February 7, 1956 of lire stemming from foreign currency sold on the financial market for invest- ment in accordance w i th that law; amortization of loans in lire by nonresidents; donations and endow- ments; dowries; inheritances and bequests; capital and annuities certain owed by insu rance companies operat- ing abroad for life insurance policies; foreign invest- ments in Italy in securities and real estate; loans in lire f rom nonresidents to residents; other financial transactions allowed under the regulations in force; transfer to a domestic account (conto interno) when the holder of the account t rans fe r red his residence to I ta ly; and t rans fer to another Capital Account. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST Exchange system * No par value for the currency of Ivory Coast has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA Franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange trans- actions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de I'Afrique de TOuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02, free of commission charges. Exchange transactions relating to countries other than France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area take place in a dual exchange market, at rates based on par values and central rates in the official exchange market or at fluctuating rates in the financial f ranc market. Settlements eligible for the official exchange market are payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, and most other current payments, as well as all current payments by or in favor of domestic and foreign public authorities and public bodies. All other settlements with foreign coun- tries as well as all transactions in banknotes, take place through the financial franc market at freely fluctuating rates. The principal current payments and receipts channeled through the financial franc market are those relating to travel expenses, capital earnings, and work- ers' remittances. Exchange rates in the official market are based on par values and central rates; the effective parity relationship for the U. S. dollar in this market is CFAF 255.785 = US$1. With the exception of those relating to gold, Ivory Coast's exchange control measures do not apply in financial relations with (1) France and its Overseas Departments and Territories (except the French Terri- tory of the A fa rs and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Cameroon, the Central Afr ican Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, the Malagasy Republic, Mali, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Ivory Coast itself, are consid- ered foreign countries, and in principle financial rela- tions only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, the exchange rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02 was maintained, and the effective parity relationship for the U. S. dollar became CFAF 230.207 = US$1. The rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02 was also maintained on March 19, 1973 when new exchange rate ar- rangements between the French franc and certain other currencies came into e f fec t. aThe CFA f ranc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de I'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Dahomey, Ivory Coast, Mauritania, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 264 Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Sub- Directorate of External Finance and Credit of the Directorate of Public Accounts and the Treasury in the Ministry of Economy and Finance, which also super- vises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offer- ing for sale of foreign securities in Ivory Coast, foreign inwa rd direct investment, and all outward investment in foreign countries. The BCEAO is authorized to collect any information necessary to compile the balance of payments statistics, either direct or through the inter- mediary of banks, other financial institutions, the Postal Adm in is tra t ion, and notaries public. All exchange trans- actions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or the Postal Administration. Import and export licenses are issued by the Sub- Directorate for Licenses and Foreign Trade Regulations in the Directorate of Economic Affairs and External Economic Relations. Import attestations for liberalized commodities are made out by the importer himself. Prescription of Currency Ivory Coast is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle- ments with France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories, except that of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign or Financial Accounts in Francs. All settlements with Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO bank- notes may be credited to Financial Accounts when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Abidjan by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of such banknotes is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Certain imports from mainland China, Hong Kong, Japan, and Portugal are suspended. A few imports from all sources are prohibited (e.g., a specified type of coffee-husking machine and wheat flour) or subject to import license (e.g., sugar, paint, matches, and detergents). Imports of certain commodities, including rice, are linked to purchases of the domestic product. All other imports from countries in the French Franc Area may be made ©International Monetary Fund. V ir tua l ly all imports originating in EEC coun- tries other than France or shipped f rom those countries also are f ree f rom quan t i ta t ive restrictions and free of license; the exceptions are 16 items on a special list. As a rule, imports f rom non-EEC countries outside the French Franc Area require import licenses and may be made in accordance with an import program, which is determined annua l ly by the Directorate of Economic Affa irs and External Economic Relations. Under this program, sem iannual global quotas are established for imports f rom such countries and special quotas for imports f rom countries with which Ivory Coast main- tains b i la teral trade agreements.- The program also includes indicative quotas for the EEC countries and a quota for Hong Kong and Eastern European coun- tries. The quotas establish limits up to which import licenses may be issued, for specified commodities, to licensed importers and, in exceptional cases, to indus- trial or agricultural producers who are considered as end-users of the imported goods. Certain products, con- tained in separate liberalized lists, may be imported f ree ly f rom any source, f rom the fo rmer OEEC coun- tries, or f rom Canada and the Un i ted States, respec- tively. All import transac t ions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled w i th an au thor ized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000; transactions of lower value must be domiciled if a f inanc ial transaction is to be unde r taken before customs clearance. The import licenses or impo rt attestations entitle importers to pur- chase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before sh ipment if a documen tary credit is opened or eight days be fo re the payment is due if the commod- ities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Paymen ts to Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for invisibles to France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account coun tr ies in the French Franc Area are per- mitted f ree ly; those to other countries are subject to approval. Paymen ts for inv is ib les related to trade are perm i t ted f ree ly when the basic t rade transaction has been approved or does not requ ire au thor iza t ion. Trans- fers of income accruing to nonres iden ts in the fo rm of profits, d iv idends, and roya l t ies are also perm i t ted f ree ly when the basic transaction has been approved. IVORY COAST that the t rans fer takes place w i th in three months of the pay period. Travelers going to foreign countries may take out BCEAO banknotes up to CFAF 10,000. Trav- elers to other countries may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if going to a country that is not a member of the West Afr ican Monetary Union, the amount taken out must be declared to the customs if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers going to foreign countries may take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the equiva- lent of CFAF 25,000 if they made no currency declara- tion upon entry. Otherwise, they may take out the amount declared, after adjustment for any amounts con- verted into CFA francs or d rawn against a Foreign Account in Francs in Ivory Coast. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports are free of license and require a declaration only. Exports of agricultural commodities, however, require the visa of the Sub-Directorate for Licenses and For- eign Trade Regulations. Export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Opera- tions Account country must be surrendered within two months of the due date but not, in principle, more than 180 days af ter the arrival of the goods at their destina- tion. All export transactions relating to foreign coun- tries must be domiciled w i th an authorized bank when valued at CFAF 500,000 or more. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom transactions in invisibles with France, Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due from residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Resi- dent and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue ma in ta in ing an Operations Account w i th the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area; residents bringing in foreign banknotes or other foreign means of payment must sell them to an authorized bank w i th in eight days and must declare them to the customs upon entry. Capital All capital movements between Ivory Coast and Rhodesia are prohibited. Capital movements between Ivory Coast and France, Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are free of exchange control; capital t rans fe rs to all other coun- tries require exchange control approval, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted free ly. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST over borrowing abroad, over foreign inward direct investment, over all outward investment in foreign coun- tries, and over the issuing, advertising, or o f fe r ing for sale of foreign securities in Ivory Coast; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to payments or receipts. With the exception of those relating to for- eign securities, these control measures do not apply to relations w i th France and its Overseas Departments and Territories (except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, the other member coun- tries of the West A f r ican Mone tary Union, and those other countries whose bank of issue is l inked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institu- tions, and over all publicity aimed at placing f u n ds abroad or at subscribing to real estate bu i ld ing opera- tions abroad; these special controls do apply also to France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Ivory Coast require prior authorization by the Minister of Econ- omy and Finance.3 Foreign direct investments in Ivory Coast,4 must be declared to the Minister of Economy and Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects submitted to him. The liquidation of invest- ments, whether direct investments or not, in Ivory Coast or abroad must similarly be declared in advance to the Minister. Both the mak ing and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Ivory Coast investments abroad or foreign investments in Ivory Coast, must be reported to the Minister w i th in 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as invest- ments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct invest- ment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of for- eign securities in Ivory Coast requires prior authoriza- tion by the Minister of Economy and Finance, as do issues by Ivory Coast companies. Exempt from authori- zation, however, are operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Ivory Coast Government and (2) shares similar to securities whose issue, offering, or sale in Ivory Coast has previously been authorized. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this P Including those made through the intermediary of foreign compa- nies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Ivory Coast and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of compa- nies in Ivory Coast. 4 Including those made by companies in Ivory Coast that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Ivory Coast of foreign companies. 266 authorization: ( 1) loans constituting a direct invest- ment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indi- cated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports in to or exports from Ivory Coast, or by in te rna t ional t rad ing houses to finance international merchan t ing transactions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (4) loans other than those men- tioned above, when the total amount ou ts tand ing of these loans, inc lud ing the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 50 million for any one borrower, and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate. The repayment of loans not constituting a direct investment requires the special authorization of the Minister if the loan itself was sub- ject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad is subject to exchange control authori- zation. The lending of CFA francs to nonresidents for periods of up to two years, however, is freely permitted. Law No. 59-134 of September 3, 1959 provides tax and customs du ty benefits and other special privileges for new enterprises recognized as having pr ior i ty status. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any fo rm in Ivory Coast. Impor ts and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy and Finance, which is rarely granted. Exempt from this requirement are (1) im p o r ts and expor ts by the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac tured articles containing a minor quan t i ty of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated a r t ic les ); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold articles up to a weight of 250 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports and exports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1972 May 17. Following a similar measure taken in France on May 5, 1972, Order No. 1819 shifted a number of current transactions f rom the financial franc market to the official exchange market. The principal current payments and receipts that continued to be channeled through the financial franc market were travel expenses, capital earnings, and workers' remit- tances. The Order came into force retroactively on June 1, 1972. November 10. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA Exchange Rate System * The par va lue is 1.06641 grams of fine gold per Jamaica Dollar. However, no exchange transactions take place at the par va lue. Exchange rates against sterling are ma in ta ined w i th in 1 per cent e i ther side of the effec- tive pa r i ty of J$l = <£ stg. 0.50. In practice, the Bank of Jamaica's dealings against Jamaica dollars are con- fined to transactions in sterling and to purchases of U. S. and Canad ian banknotes; it deals in other curren- cies only against sterling. The Bank buys and sells ster- ling at par, plus a 0.75 per cent commission on the selling side. Exchange rates for other currencies (except the East Caribbean dollar, the Guyana dollar, and the Trinidad and Tobago dollar, which also have a fixed official relationship with sterling) are based on the buy- ing and selling rates for sterling in international mar- kets. The Bank of Jamaica sets daily official buying and selling rates for dealing with the banks in U. S. dollars and Canadian dollars against sterling on the basis of the previous day's closing quo ta t ions in New York; on December 30, 1972, the official buying and sell- ing rates for the U. S. dollar against sterling were US$2.3549 and US$2.3391, respectively. On the basis of these rates, the Bank also fixes daily rates at which commercial banks must deal with their customers in transactions up to J$25,000 involving Jamaica dollars against U. S. or Canadian dollars. The Bank of Jamaica is authorized by law to levy a commission charge of up to 34 of 1 per cent on inward and outward transfers of sterling; on December 30, 1972, these charges on dealings in sterling with the com- mercial banks were nil on inward transfers and 3/4 of 1 per cent on outward transfers. The commercial banks apply the same commission charges in dealing in ster- ling with their customers, with an additional charge of i/16 of 1 per cent on inward telegraphic transfers of less than J$ 1,000 and Vs of 1 per cent on inward trans- fers of less than this amount in the form of demand or sight items. The result is a selling rate of J$2.0150 per £ stg. 1 and buying rates of J$2.00 for transactions of more than J$ 1,000, J$ 1.99875 for telegraphic transfers of less than J$ 1,000, and J$ 1.9975 for demand or sight drafts of less than J$ 1,000. The Bank maintains fixed buying and selling rates Vs of 1 per cent either side of parity for the East Caribbean dollar, the Guyana dollar, and the Trinidad and Tobago dollar; for transactions in these currencies, the commercial banks charge a com- mission of 1A of 1 per cent either side of parity, buying * With e f fect from Janua ry 17, 1973 the Jamaica dollar ceased to float with sterling and the par value was changed to 0.900364 gram of fine gold per Jamaica dollar, corresponding to J$0.987013 = SDR 1 or J$0.909991 = US$1. Jamaica also availed itself of wider margins and announced that the U. S. dollar would be its intervention currency. Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, Jamaica on February 20 established a cen- tral rate of J$l = US$1.10, corresponding to 0.810328 gram of fine gold per Jamaica dollar or J$l.09668 = SDR 1. Jamaica continued to avail itself of wider margins. and selling. There is a "bourse" (interbank exchange ma rke t) in which all commercial banks participate and in which only U. S. dollars and Canadian dollars are traded against sterling. Jamaica fo rm a l ly accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as f rom February 22, 1963. Administration of Control The Bank of Jamaica administers exchange control on behalf of the Minister of Finance subject to certain limitations in respect of which the approval of the Min- ister is required. The commercial banks are designated as authorized dealers and have authority to provide for- eign exchange for imports up to J$ 10,000, and for basic travel allowances and certain other payments up to specified lesser amounts. Import licenses are issued by the Trade Administrator, who is responsible to the Min- ister of Commerce and Consumer Protection. Prescription of Currency Jamaica has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory for purposes of the U. K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U. K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. Payments to all countries may be made by crediting Jamaica dollars to an External Account or in any for- eign currency.1 Receipts from all countries must be received by debit of an External Account or in any foreign currency. Special regulations apply to settle- ments with Rhodesia, and all payments to Rhodesia require specific authorization. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts in Jamaica dollars may be held by persons who are regarded for exchange control pur- poses as normally permanently resident outside Jamaica. These accounts are fu r ther designated External Ac- counts, or Blocked Accounts. The commercial banks are empowered to open Exter- nal Accounts in Jamaica dollars for nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia. The funds on these accounts may be transferred freely between nonresidents. External Accounts may be credited with payments by residents of Jamaica approved by the exchange control author- ities, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from the sale to an authorized dealer of gold or foreign currencies. They may be debited for payments to residents of Jamaica, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for the purchase of foreign currencies. 1 All currencies other than the Jamaica dollar are considered foreign currencies. All foreign currencies have been designated as specified currencies. 267 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA Accounts which are credited with funds that may not be placed at the free disposal of nonresidents of Jamaica (including the proceeds f rom the sale of undeveloped land) are designated Blocked Accounts. Blocked funds may be invested in Jamaica dollar securities; the income f rom such securities is normally available for credit to an External Account. Funds originally held on a Blocked Account and the proceeds of securities purchased with blocked funds are normally available for credit to an External Account four years after the date of blocking. Applications for the release of funds in Blocked Accounts for use in Jamaica by the nonresident owner must be referred to the Bank of Jamaica. The assets of residents emigrating to countries outside Jamaica in excess of the prescribed settling-in allowance of J$ 10,000 are restricted for a period of four years. Imports and Import Payments Many goods may be imported freely under an open general license.2 Virtually all imports from CARIFTA countries are unrestricted. Imports originating in Rho- desia are prohibited and all imports originating in main- land China, the CMEA countries, South Africa, or Cuba require individual import licenses. A number of tariff items or groups of tariff items included in a special schedule of exceptions to the open general license are subject to individual licensing irrespective of country of origin unless ( for some of the items in this schedule) the goods originate in and are consigned from other CARIFTA countries (Antigua, Barbados, British Hon- duras, Dominica, Grenada, Guyana, Montserrat, St. Kitts-Nevis-Anguilla, St. Lucia, St. Vincent, or Trinidad and Tobago). The special schedule comprises ( 1) goods for which specific quotas are assigned to importers according to their past performance, e.g., certain types of footwear, cheese, rice, and various consumer dura- bles ( f or these items import licenses are granted by the Trade Administrator against allotted quo ta s ); (2) goods which are prohibited, e.g., certain automobiles, radios, television sets, canned milk, cement, cigars, citrus prod- ucts, cheap clothing, household detergents, sugar, and coffee; ( 3) goods the licensing of which depends upon local supply, e.g., poultry, eggs, and vegetables; and (4) goods licensed to meet the requirements of the tourist industry only ( inc lud ing some liquors and sports goods). Payments for imports equivalent to J$ 10,000 or more are subject to prior registration with the Bank of Jamaica and all payments for imports are subject to the licensing requirements, if any, being met, and the importer presenting a copy of the settlement invoice or other evidence of purchase and value, together with documentary evidence that the goods either have been shipped or are about to be shipped, or that the importer 2 The open general license applies to all countries except A lban ia, Bulgaria, ma in land Ch ina, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hung a ry, No r th Korea, Poland, Po r tugal (and associated terr i tor ies), Rhodesia, Roman ia, South A f r ica, U. S. S. R., and No r th Viet-Nam. Goods impo r ted u n d er the license must be consigned f rom one of the pe rm i t ted coun t r i es and m u st also o r i g i n a te in a p e rm i t t ed c o u n t r y. 268 is under contract to make prepayment up to six months prior to shipment; specific exchange control approval is required for advance payments preceding shipment by more than six months. Certain goods are subject to a 5 per cent consumption tax (2l/2 per cent on coloring ma ter ia ls), whether they are imported or manu fac tu red domestically. Where such goods are imported, the tax is collected at the port of entry and is calculated on the sum of the value accepted for customs, plus the customs du ty plus the tonnage tax. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles require the approval of the authorities. Except for transactions involving residents of Rhodesia, the following applies. With the exception of payments in respect of foreign travel, bona fide cur- rent payments are not restricted. Approval is granted freely for payments for all commercial transactions, when the application is supported by the appropriate documentary evidence. A basic exchange allocation of J$500 a person for each 12-month period commencing November 10, 1972 for foreign travel other than for business and professional reasons is made available automatically to residents by the authorized dealers. Additional amounts are granted in cases of hardship. Facilities for travel for business and professional reasons may be provided by authorized banks at the rate of J$60 a day for up to ten days a trip while applications for higher amounts are dealt with by the central bank. Expenses for hotel accommodations, meals en route, etc., that are settled in Jamaica in domestic currency must be deducted from the travel allocations. Author- ized dealers may, subject to the presentation of sup- porting evidence, approve payments for the follow- ing: refunds of income tax due to nonresidents; consular fees without limit, as well as transfers from the Ministry of External Affa irs to accounts in the names of embassies and their established staffs, High Commissioners, and diplomats; up to a limit of J$2,000 for ( 1) advertising and promotional expenses, (2) renewal and refund of premiums due to nonresident insurers, and ( 3) subscriptions to trade organizations; up to a limit of J$4,000 for commissions and expenses due by Jamaican firms to their agents and representa- tives and for serial rights in Jamaica of newspaper and magazine articles, photographs, strip cartoons, etc. Requests for additional amounts (except for travel) or for purposes for which there are no standard limits (e.g., remittances by charitable institutions) are approved if the authorities are satisfied that no capital flight is involved. Travelers going abroad may take with them Jamaica banknotes not exceeding J$20 and other banknotes not exceeding J$100. Nonresidents may take out the foreign currency notes they brought in. Exports and Export Proceeds All goods valued at not more than J$200 (f .o .b .) for g i f ts and J$500 ( f .o .b .) for other exports may be freely ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution exported by post or air express to any country not on the prohibited list.3 Where the value exceeds these fig- ures the goods may be exported to all countries except those on the prohibited list, but a specific license is required for the export of certain agricultural products, ammunition, explosives, firearms, antique furniture, ready-made garments, gold bullion, mineral and metal ores, and antique paintings. Exporters are required to surrender their exchange proceeds to authorized dealers within six months from the date of shipment. However, certain exporters may retain, with the approval of the exchange control authorities, an agreed portion of their proceeds to facilitate the import of items necessary for their operations; such retained export proceeds must not be sold to other nonbank residents. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts f rom invisibles in foreign currencies must be sold to an authorized dealer. Travelers to Jamaica may bring in Jamaica banknotes up to J$20 a traveler, and any amount of other banknotes; resident travelers are required to sell their holdings of foreign currencies to a local authorized dealer upon return. Capital Outflows of resident-owned capital are restricted, irrespective of their destination. Investment abroad by residents require the approval of the exchange control authorities and are not approved unless they result in tangible benefits for Jamaica. Residents must obtain prior approval from the Bank of Jamaica to make cash gifts, which are normally limited to J$200 in any 12- month period af ter November 10, 1972 from each donor, to nonresidents of Jamaica. With the exception of certain types of inves tment in real estate, all direct investments in Jamaica by non- residents are granted "approved status," under which the investor is given written assurance that he will be able to repatriate at any time his original investment plus any capital gain. In order to obtain approved status, the investor must register his investment with the Bank of Jamaica. Repatriation of investments in real estate is not permitted w i th in the period of five years following the sale of the investment if the investor failed to make any significant improvements on the land. Remittances of current items, such as profits and divi- dends, are permitted in fu ll when the application is supported by the appropriate set of accounts. Payments for amortization of, and interest on, foreign loans are permitted upon application to the ex- change control authorities. However, nonresidents are not normally permitted to take security in respect of loans made to Jama ican companies owned or controlled by them. Domestic bank credit to nonresidents of 3 The list comprises A lban ia, Bulgaria, mainland China, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hung a ry, No r th Korea, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, South A f r ica, U. S. S. R., and No r th Viet-Nam. Exports to these countries require specific licenses. In practice, no licenses are issued for exports to South A f r ica, and exports to Rho- desia are prohibited. JAMAICA Jamaica and to nonresident-controlled companies is subject to selective credit controls; for this purpose, firms are considered to be nonresident-controlled when the controlling interest is held beneficially, either directly or indirectly, by persons resident outside the Caribbean Free Trade Association. Such lending is subject to approval by the Bank of Jamaica; authorized dealers may, however, without reference to the exchange con- trol authorities, make loans or overdrafts to nonresi- dents of Jamaica up to J$2,000 for certain specified purposes. Authorized dealers may also without reference to the exchange control authorities make loans or over- drafts to resident companies or branches controlled by nonresidents up to J$20,000, provided that the borrower is not specifically precluded under some prior condi- tional permission from the exchange control authorities. Other requests are referred to the Bank of Jamaica. Repatriates taking up residence in the country of their nationality may transfer all their assets, with the exception of capital gains from the sale of undeveloped land; such gains are repatriable at the end of a five-year period from the date of the initial repatriation of the proceeds of the sale of other assets. Jamaican nationals emigrating are granted a settling-in allowance of the equivalent of J$ 10,000 at the official market rate of exchange; any assets in excess of the allowance are restricted for four years. Transfers to beneficiaries resident outside Jamaica under wills and intestacies are approved on the same terms as the transfer of the assets of Jamaican nationals emigrating, provided that all local indebtedness has been met. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Jamaica for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized in- dustrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not no rma l ly granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Repatriates of foreign nationality would still be per- mitted to take out all their assets when re turn ing to reside in their country of original domicile, but an exception would now be made for cap i tal gains f rom the sale of undeveloped land; such gains would be blocked for a period of five years from the date of the initial repatriation. Not for Redistribution JAPAN Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.00246853 gram of fine gold per Japanese Yen, corresponding to SDR 1 — ¥ 360. A central rate has been established of V 308.00 = US$1, corresponding to ¥ 334.4 = SDR 1, and Japan avails itself of wider margins of up to 2% per cent. The official limits for the U. S. dollar, the intervention cur- rency, which are set by the Ministry of Finance, are ¥ 314.93 (upper l im i t) and ¥ 301.07 ( lower l im i t ), per US$1; the exchange authorities will buy or sell exchange at rates within this range. Authorized banks may freely carry out spot and forward exchange trans- actions with nonresident banks and among themselves; their forward transactions with resident customers must have a permitted unde r ly ing transaction. Japan formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as f rom April 1, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the Min- istry of Finance, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (M IT I ), and the Bank of Japan as the Government's agent. However, most of the authority for approving normal payments is delegated to authorized banks referred to as foreign exchange banks. Import and export licensing is handled by MITI. Inward capital investments of a long-term character require the approval of the Minister of Finance and the com- petent minister (in some cases that of the Minister of Finance only) af ter deliberation in certain important cases by the Foreign Investment Council. Outward capi- tal investments require the approval of the Minister of Finance. Prescription of Currency Payments to all countries may be made in any cur- rency, including yen, and receipts also may be obtained in any currency. Settlements in yen with foreign coun- tries must be made through a Nonresident Free Yen Account. All paymen ts to Rhodesia require prior approval by the Minister of Finance or the Minister of In terna t ional Trade and Indus t ry; in many cases such payments are prohibited or restricted for security reasons. Nonresident Accounts There are two main nonres ident accounts, as described below. 1. Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. These accounts * Following the announcement on Feb rua ry 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, the Japanese Government decided, as a temporary measure, to allow the Japanese yen to float in the ma rke t; with effect f rom February 14, the market rate of the yen would not necessarily be conf ined w i th in the ma rg ins h i the r to observed. 272 may be opened by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan and may be credited with the yen pro- ceeds from exports of goods to Japan and f rom other authorized transactions, with yen proceeds from sales of all foreign currencies, with transfers f rom other Free Yen Accounts, with balances outstanding on December 31, 1970 on Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts (see be low ), and with the countervalue in yen of authorized outward payments. There are no restrictions on payments f rom these accounts, and bal- ances may be converted free ly into any foreign cur- rency. Marginal reserve requirements are applied against increases in each authorized bank's liabilities on Free Yen Accounts over the average level in a specified base period. 2. Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan. They may be credited with yen proceeds from transactions other than those which are authorized to be credited to Nonresident Free Yen Accounts. Permitted credits to Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts are limited ma in ly to proceeds f rom the sales of debenture and beneficiary certificates sold within six months f rom the date of validated acquisition. Bal- ances ou ts tand ing on December 31, 1970 were per- mitted to be transferred to Nonresident Free Yen Accounts or to be remitted abroad. Balances accrued after that date are not convertible into foreign cur- rencies, although remittances are permitted each year up to 30 per cent of the balance at the end of the previous year or the equivalent of ¥ 720,000, whichever is higher. Withdrawals f rom these accounts are author- ized for certain purposes, such as meeting the outlays involved in managing investments in Japan and the expenses of nonresidents staying in Japan. Transfers to other Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts may be made freely, thus enabling the ind iv idual account holder to repatriate his funds by selling them to another non- resident in return for fore ign currency, but there is no market for such funds in Japan. In addition, there are Foreign Investors' Deposit Accounts in which certain proceeds from investments liquidated by foreigners may be placed. Balances on these accounts may be used for remittances abroad or for making other investments under certain condi- tions. However, these accounts are of limited impor- tance, because proceeds from foreigners' liquidated investments may be remitted through Nonresident Free Yen Accounts without having been placed in Foreign Investors' Deposit Accounts. Funds remitted to Japan by nonresidents for portfolio investment are channeled through special accounts opened at foreign exchange banks in the names of Japanese securities dealers (For- eign Currencies Securities Special Accounts and Yen Securities Special Accoun ts). ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Imports and Import Payments With the exception of books and periodicals, imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Other imports are sub- ject either to individual licensing by the authorized banks or, if liberalized, to declaration to such banks. Most private imports are liberalized. There are two procedures for imports requiring payment in foreign currencies: (1) Under the Import Quota System (cov- ering imports of goods on the "negative list," which comprises 84 items, in terms of the four-digit Brussels nomenclature; 33 l of the 84 items on the "negative list" have been notified to the GATT as residual restric- tions while the other 51 items have been notified as falling under the national security, public health, and moral protection provisions of the GATT), the importer must first obtain from MITI an import quota, which is based on the quantitative principle. If the quota is granted, the importer receives an import quota certificate which entitles him to receive an import license from an authorized bank automatically upon application. Practically all import quota certif- icates are issued on a global basis, without regard to the country of origin or the currency of settlement, by MITI. (2) Under the Declaration System, imports are free of quan t i ta t ive restriction and licensing and require only a declaration by the importer to a foreign exchange bank. All items subject to the Declaration Sys- tem may be imported from any coun try except Rho- desia. Items under state trading include certain dairy products, certain cereals, salt, and raw and manu fac- tured tobacco. Payment for imported goods must be made under one of the "standard" methods of settlement for imports. When the settlement proposal is not in accord- ance with one of the "standard" methods (i.e., when certain advance payment is proposed or payment is to be made more than four months after customs clear- ance), prior approval of MITI must be obtained. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance or the Minister of Inter- national Trade and Industry. Paymen ts to other coun- tries for invisibles also require approval, but current payments are not restricted and most such payments are approved freely by authorized banks w i thout any limitation or within certain established limits. Payments for certain invisibles, inc lud ing paymen ts that exceed the established limits, are referred to the Bank of Japan for the purpose of capital control; they are automati- cally approved without undue delay, upon verification of the authenticity of the current transaction. Resi- dents may purchase fore ign currencies for paymen ts in connection with travel abroad without limit, subject only to verification by the foreign exchange bank of the genuineness of the trip. A traveler is permitted to 1 Reduced to 32 on April 19, 1973. JAPAN pay in yen or in foreign currency before departure, the cost of transportation to and from his destination and for all side trips. Residents may freely and at any time make payments abroad up to US$3,000 a remit- tance, for virtually any purpose other than import pay- ments, repayments on loans, and technical assistance payments, etc. Certain insurance and technical assist- ance contracts require approva l; but when a license for a contract has been granted, any payment resulting from the contract may be made freely. Settlements which are not made under a "standard" method require, in principle, individual approval; without such approval, payments for services, etc., may not be made more than three months before, or later than six months after, receipt of the services, etc. Both residents and nonresidents may take out freely ¥ 100,000 in Japanese currency. Subject to verification, i.e., upon oral declaration, a nonresident may take out freely foreign currencies up to the amount which he brought into Japan; w i thout verification the conversion into foreign currencies is limited to the equivalent of US$1,000. Exports and Export Proceeds With minor exceptions exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All exports to Iran, Iraq, and Nigeria require special authorization. All exports (except exports without exchange) must be registered with an authorized bank ("bank certification"). Licenses are not generally required, except for goods subject to the following restrictions: restrictions on cer- tain goods to control their export to communist coun- ries; - restrictions on goods in short supply in the domestic market (e.g., minerals, fertilizers, and staple foods); and restrictions designed to forestall the impo- sition of import restrictions by other countries (e.g., on sewing machines and certain textiles).3 Exports under processing and consignment sale contracts and exports for which settlement is not under the "standard" method also require individual licenses. Under the standard method of settlement for exports, the value of the exported goods must, in general, be settled by draw ing a bill of exchange payable within five months af ter sight or w i th in six months after ship- ment. There are no surrender requirements for fore ign currency earnings. The conversion in to yen of advance receipts in respect of exports, i.e., proceeds received before shipment, requires an ind iv idu al license when they exceed the equivalent of US$5,000. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts under the standard method of settlement may be accepted without a license. Capital Foreign investments in Japan are genera l ly subject to approval, ma in ly in accordance w i th the Law Concern- ing Foreign Inve s tment (Law No. 163 of May 10, 1950) or the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law (Law No. 228 of December 1, 1949). All acquisitions of stocks, bonds, deben tures, beneficiary certificates, and claims in the fo rm of loans by foreign investors are in principle subject to v a l id a t ion or license. However, acquisitions of stocks for por tfo l io invest- ment are automatically approved by the Bank of J ap an in cases where total fore ign pa r t ic ipa t ion in the stock of a corporation not classified as a restricted indu s t ry remains below 25 per cen t ,4 or to tal fore ign par t ic ipa- tion in the stock of a corporation classified as a restricted indu s t ry remains 15 per cent or less,4' f) and the proportion of the total capital of any corporation acquired by a single holder rema ins below 10 per cent.4 Acquisition of stocks for par t ic ipa t ion in man- agement is subject (except in the case of newly estab- lished companies in the liberalized industries or in certain circumstances when participation in manage- ment is obtained by the purchase of securities w i th in the percentage limits mentioned above) to ind iv idual screening by the competent ministers, but it is approved in principle if no adverse effect on the Japanese econ- omy is expected. All these acquisitions must be made against yen proceeds f rom the sale of foreign exchange or its equivalent, if the investor wishes to obtain remit- tance rights upon validation. Stocks in the form of stock dividends from earned surplus or revaluation of assets may be acquired freely, but application for remittance rights must be made within three months from the date of acquisition. At present, purchases by nonresidents of short-term government securities, of unlisted Japanese bonds and debentures with a matu- rity of one year or less, and of beneficiary certificates of Japanese bond investment trusts are not normally per- mitted. In the event of expropr ia t ion or compu lso ry sale of a foreign investment, the amount paid because of expropriation may be repatriated free ly. The remittance of the proceeds f rom the sale of vali- dated stocks ( sha re s ), as we ll as the t r an s f er abroad of earnings on fore ign inves tmen ts acquired with foreign currency, is perm i t ted. Proceeds f rom the sale of stocks, bonds, debentures, beneficiary certificates, etc., acquired with yen withdrawn from Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts may be deposited in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts, provided that the securities have been held for at least three years f rom the date of acquisition. Since October 1972 special rules have been in force which provide that the yen proceeds f rom sales of securities by nonresidents mu st w i th in one mon th of receipt be either reinvested in securities or converted into foreign currency for t rans fer abroad. Repayments of loans extended to residents f rom Nonresident Yen Deposit Accounts become remittable, subject to licensing by the Bank of Japan, beginning three years f rom the date of the loan. When foreign companies desire to establish a branch or a plant in Japan, they are required to inform the Ministry of Finance and MITI in advance through the Bank of Japan. When branches or plants established by foreign companies wish to bring in funds f rom their main offices abroad, they are required to obtain licenses. The branches established in accordance with approved procedures are permitted to remit their profits and principal abroad. Foreign direct inves tment in Japan genera l ly requires approval by the Minister of Finance and the competent minister (in some cases the approval of the Minister of Finance on ly) after deliberation (in certain impor- tant cases) by the Foreign Investment Council. Balances in these accounts could not be converted into yen un t il the contract for the purchase of the securities had been concluded, and the yen also had to be credited first to special accounts (Yen Securities Special Accounts). June 29. The ceiling on the free conversion into yen of advance export receipts was reduced from the equivalent of US$10,000 to US$5,000 for each export transaction. July 1. Imports of foreign technology were further liberalized, in part on Ju ly 1 and in part during the remainder of the year. Henceforth the import of all technology not related to electronic computers or petro- chemicals qualified for automatic validation. Technol- ogy imports relating to electronic computers would be liberalized not later than Ju ly 1, 1974 and those relat- ing to petrochemicals not later than Janua ry 1, 1973. (Previously, Japan had invoked OECD reservations relating to the import of technology in the sectors of aircraft, weapons, explosives, nuclear energy, space development, electronic computers, and petrochemicals.) July 1. The marginal reserve requirements against increases in balances in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts were increased f rom 25 per cent to 50 per cent and calculated on a new base (increases over the daily average of balances d u r i ng the period May 21 through J u ne 20, 1972). July 1. Residents other than ins t i tu t ional investors were allowed to buy and sell foreign securities from and to Japanese securities dealers, irrespective of whether the transac t ions were channe led through a stock exchange abroad. (Prev ious ly, such purchases and sales had to effected on stock exchanges abroad.) July 25. The first postwar bond issue in Japan by a fore ign gove rnment took place.
