September 25. The foreign currency lend ing system came into effect. September 30. The Bank of Japan abolished its remaining preferential export f inanc ing schemes (dis- counting of export bills under the "export usance bill system" and advance credit for exports under the "export advance bill system"). Previously, the prefer- ential rate of interest under these schemes had already been adjusted to the level of the official discount rate for commercial bills. All types of preferential export financing now were either suspended or entirely eliminated. October 5. The first public offer ing of foreign stocks for subscription in Japan took place. October 20. The Cabinet decided on a third yen defense program to achieve equilibrium in the balance of payments. The program envisaged, among other things, fur ther liberalization of imports, increases in import quotas, use of the Export Control Ordinance to restrain the growth of exports, increased economic cooperation with foreign countries, measures to restrict the acquisition of Japanese securities by nonresidents, and fur ther liberalization of inward direct investment. Certain remaining tax concessions to exporters would be abolished. (The Export Control Ordinance was first invoked with effect from January 1, 1973.) October 21. The acquisition of Japanese bonds and shares by nonresidents was restricted. First, all pur- chase transactions had to be made through authorized dealers in securities or through foreign exchange banks. Second, each individual securities dealer or foreign exchange bank was required to limit the acquisition for the account of nonresidents of Japanese bonds and shares to the amount of sales of such bonds and shares made for the account of nonresidents by the dealer or 278 bank concerned a f ter October 21, 1972. Exempt from these limitations were (1) the acquisition of shares for purposes of direct inves tmen t; (2) the acquisition of newly issued shares under a rights issue; and (3) acquisitions authorized pr ior to October 21. Further- more, for nonresidents' purchases of shares there was a "leeway" provision (so-called swing system) to the effect that these could du r ing six successive business days exceed nonresidents' sales of shares, up to the amount of the mon th ly average of sales hand led by the securities dealer or b ank concerned du r ing the previous three mon th s. (This "leeway" provision was revoked on February 5, 1973, when the use of the swing system became subject to approval by the Minister of Finance.) October 21. Medium-term and long-4erm foreign cur- rency lending abroad by commercial banks became subject to verification by the M in is try of Finance. October 23. In view of the increasing number of transactions in which used ships were exported and then utilized as chartered ships (mos t ly by the export- ers themse lves), all charter contracts involving ships and a i rc ra ft exported f rom Japan a f ter October 23 were made subject to verification by the Bank of Japan. October 27. Agreement was reached between the Government and organized business that the growth of exports of specified commodities (20 product groups) should be limited du r ing the period from September 1, 1972 to August 31, 1973 in order to reduce Japan's export su rp lus by US$1 billion on an annual basis. November 1. The interest rate charged for import financing by the Export-Import Bank of Japan was reduced by 1 percentage point, in implementation of the third yen defense program. November 18. The purchase by residents of securities issued by foreign institutions for collective investment (mu tual funds, etc.) was liberalized; these securities previously were excluded f rom the liberalization of out- ward portfolio investment that occurred on July 1, 1971. The new measure consisted of two parts: ( 1) The purchase by any resident of open-end type securities was f u l ly liberalized. (2) The purchase of closed-end type securities became subject to the same treatment as that of foreign common stocks. This meant that the purchase by residents other than institutional investors was liberalized only for securities listed or scheduled to be listed on a foreign stock exchange, while the purchase by institutional investors was liberalized irre- spective of whether the securities were listed, scheduled to be listed, or neither. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain i t em s2 f rom any source, some imports f rom Romania, and all imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Importers of tea must meet 80 per cent of their requirements, and those of cast iron or steel tubes 50 per cent of their requirements, f rom Indian sources. Imports should, in principle, enter the country through the port of Aqaba; goods that do not meet this requirement are subject to a penalty of 20 per cent of the c.i.f. value (10 per cent for certain food s tu f f s ). The Import Committee may grant exemptions from these rules on a case-by-case basis upon application. Capital Capital may be imported freely, but exports of capi- tal require approval and normally are not allowed. Current income resulting f rom nonresident investments in Jordan may be transferred abroad. Under the Law for the Encouragement of Investment, effective Octo- ber 16, 1972, profits f rom approved foreign investments may be remitted, without limitation, in the currency of the original investment or any other convertible currency approved by the Central Bank. Af ter two years repatriation of the capital is permitted in three equal annual installments in the same foreign currency in which the original investment was made. The Invest- ment Committee may approve more liberal provisions. All transactions under the investment law require the prior approval of the Central Bank. Import and export controls are administered by the Director of Trade and Supplies in the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry. The responsibility for issuing import and export licenses rests with the Director, to whom applications should be submitted by the importer or exporter in Kenya before orders are placed abroad or exports are shipped. Not for Redistribution KENYA may be used for approved domestic expenditures and for the purchase in Kenya of specified bonds issued by the Kenyan Government or by local authorities and officially quoted in K e n y a ;5 the redemption proceeds of these securities, which must have a life of five years at the time of acquisition, are transferable, and interest is freely transferable to nonresidents as and when it accrues. Imports and Import Payments Some imports from all sources are prohibited for reasons of public policy; imports of certain other goods are not being licensed. All imports f rom metropolitan Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. With certain exceptions, imports from Tanzania and Uganda are unrestricted, but many goods imported from these countries require a specific license unless they are of Tanzanian or Ugandan origin. Specific import licenses are required for all commodities origi- nating in Albania, Bulgaria, mainland China, Eastern Germany, Hungary, Iran, Iraq, Romania, or North Viet-Nam. Many goods may be freely imported from other sources under open general license, but others require a specific license. A number of commodi- ties may be imported only by or to the order of the Kenya National Trading Corporation. With minor exceptions, all private sector imports from countries other than Tanzania and Uganda require a foreign exchange allocation license issued by the Central Bank when their invoice value exceeds K Sh 2,000; applications must be submitted before firm orders are placed. In addition to the open general license for imports, there are five commodity lists for imports. For goods in Schedule A, specific import licenses, as well as exchange allocation licenses, are granted freely. For goods in Schedule B, no import licenses are issued. For goods in Schedule C, an exchange allocation permit is required in addition to a specific license. Goods in Schedules D and E are on open general license, but for those in Schedule D an exchange allocation permit is required and for those in Schedule E no foreign exchange is being allocated. Allocations in 1972 under Schedules C and D were about 75 per cent of each importer's average import bill for 1970 and 1971 for each S.I.T.C. Code category. When an exchange allocation license has been obtained, authorized banks provide exchange auto- matically for goods in Schedule A and for all goods under open general license that are not included in Schedules D and E; for all of these items, advance payment up to six months before delivery is permitted. For those in Schedules C and D, advance payment is not normally permitted. 5 Such securities must be payable in East African currency and they must not be redeemable earlier than five years f rom the date of acqu is i t ion. 284 Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are controlled. Authorized banks are empowered to approve specified categories of cur- rent payments without limitation or up to established limits; amounts above these limits as well as other cur- rent payments may be approved administratively, and most current payments are in fact unrestricted. Fees for education up to the equivalent of K Sh 14,000 a person for a fu ll scholastic year and fees for other specified purposes may be approved by an authorized bank upon production of evidence of debt. Facilities exist whereby nationals of countries other than Tanzania and Uganda who come to work in Kenya as employed persons (as well as certain categories of the self- employed, such as doctors and dentists) for not more than four years may remit abroad as savings up to 33% per cent of their monthly salaries but not more than K Sh 3,000 a mon th; in addition, they may remit funds to cover fam i ly maintenance, education expenses, etc., provided that their total remittances including savings do not exceed 50 per cent of their monthly salaries. Expatriates who have stayed for over four years in the Scheduled Territories6 may continue to effect remit- tances from salaries as above, but those who avail themselves of the facilities for remittance of savings from salaries are not entitled to exchange facilities upon emigration. Remittances to South A f r ica, other than those of certain pensions, are prohibited. The transfer of rents and dividends derived in whole or in part from property in Kenya owned by a nonresident is restricted. The basic allowance for travel outside the Scheduled Territories by adults holding round-trip tickets is K Sh 4,000 a person (K Sh 2,000 for children between 3 and 12 years of age) every two years, which may be taken out in fore ign banknotes.7 Holders of one-way tickets are entitled to a basic travel allowance of K Sh 2,000 for adults and K Sh 1,000 for children. The basic allowance is not available for travel to Rhodesia or South Afr ica. Travelers are not permitted to take out domestic currency notes. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency notes up to the amount they brought in upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain foods tuffs and agricultural products require licenses and may be subject to restriction in order to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Kenya. With the exception of expatriate employees who have opted for remittance of savings from salaries, persons leaving Kenya per- manently may transfer their assets up to the equivalent of K Sh 50,000 for each fam i ly un it if they take up residence in a country outside the Scheduled Territories; they may additionally every 12 months thereafter, dur- ing a period of five years, apply for the release of K Sh 20,000 from their Blocked Accounts. All remain- ing funds must be credited to a Blocked Account; they may then be invested in approved Scheduled Terri- tory securities, and redemption proceeds become transferab le, provided that redemption does not take place earlier than five years from the date of purchase. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Kenya, but to ensure eventual repatriation it is necessary to obtain from the Treasury a "certificate of approved enterprise" for the investment. A resident of Kenya may not send as a cash gift to a country other than Tanzania or Uganda more than K Sh 200 a year without specific exchange control approval. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Kenya for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require exchange control approval. The import of the following from all sources other than Tanzania and Uganda, and f rom Tanzania and Uganda when originat- ing in other countries is subject to individual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; goldsmiths' or silversmiths' wares, including set gems; bullion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Import licenses for gold jewelry are issued freely; those for gold bullion (ingots, bars, or sheets) are issued to goldsmiths only and are issued restrictively, while imports of gold coins are not being licensed. Changes during 1972 January 6. Measures were announced by Exchange Control Circular No. 1/1972 to restrict imports by the introduction of foreign exchange allocation permits. Advance import payments also were further restricted. The regulations would affect mainly consumer goods and some locally produced goods. No exchange would be allocated for items which could be produced locally and a range of nonessentials. For other specified imports, foreign exchange allocation permits would be granted for amounts up to 50 per cent of average indi- vidual import bills in 1970 and 1971 for each S.I.T.C. category. Advance payment for the latter goods would be approved only under exceptional circumstances. The open general license for imports was maintained, and there was no reclassification of goods from open general license to specific import license or vice versa, but five commodity lists were published, subject to the fo l low ing arrangements. For goods in Schedule A, specific import licenses, which would be issued freely, were required, and for- eign exchange would be issued freely against those licenses. For goods in Schedule B, no import licenses would be issued, and those already issued were declared invalid with effect f rom December 17, 1971. For goods in Schedule C, an exchange allocation permit was required in addition to a specific import license. Goods in Schedules D and E remained under open general license, but for those in Schedule D an exchange allo- cation permit was required and for those in Schedule E 285 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KENYA no fore ign exchange would be allocated. Authorized banks would continue to provide exchange automatically only for (1) goods in Schedule A and (2) all goods under open general license that were not specified in Schedules D and E. The number of prohibited imports went up f rom 90 to 152 (129 in Schedule B and 23 in Schedule E ). Allocations under Schedules C and D were initially set at 50 per cent of each importer's average import bill for 1970 and 1971 for each S.I.T.C. Code category. They were later increased to 75 per cent. Advance payment for imports, previously permitted up to six mon ths before delivery for all imports, would still be freely allowed for goods on Schedule A and those open general license items not included in Schedules D and E; for goods in Schedules C and D advance payment would be approved only in very exceptional cases and only a f ter the exchange allocation permit had been granted. The new requirements were made applicable to shipments af ter February 15, 1972 or such later date as provided for in a letter of credit already established when the regulations were announced. February 1. The requirement imposed on Decem- ber 16, 1971 that commercial banks maintain certain cash balances (a 5 per cent m in imum deposit against their net deposit liabilities) with the Central Bank (in addition to the required liquidity ra t io) was rescinded. The restrictions on credit to importers of consumer goods and the volume of installment purchase finance, introduced on July 26, 1971, were maintained. Com- mercial banks were informed that the additional avail- able credit must not be directed to the financing of imports, but must be used to increase advances generally to Africans, more particularly to those engaged in business and agricultural undertakings. March 15. The schedule of imports requiring specific import licenses and which could be imported only by the Kenya National Trading Corporation, was extended to cover tires and tubes of all kinds. April 14. Banks were requested to adopt a par- ticularly restrictive attitude toward loans and advances to importers of finished goods of luxury types, such as consumer durables and motorcars. The new level of importers' overdraft limits should come to bear an appropriate business relationship to their quotas for imports. May 8. The delegated authority allowing banks to approve applications for exchange for business travel was limited to (a) one application a year from each business firm or company engaged in the export busi- ness and (b) one application every two years from each firm or company engaged in the import business. Authorized banks could grant the equivalent of K Sh 450 a day for travel to the United States and Canada, and K Sh 300 a day for travel to all other countries outside the Scheduled Territories, subject in both cases to a limit of 25 days. Applications for exchange for any additional business trips had to be directed to the Central Bank. May 10. Restrictions were introduced on remittances of the proceeds of bequests to nonresident beneficiaries by persons who die as residents of Kenya. Hence- fo r th such beneficiaries could receive a max imum of K Sh 100,000 in five annual installments of K Sh 20,000. Furthermore, where some capital of the deceased's estate was held outside Kenya at the time of his death, the beneficiary was required to receive first the capital held abroad, and could withdraw the capital held in Kenya to make up only the deficit by which the capital held outside Kenya fe ll short of the permitted max imum. The balance in excess of K Sh 100,000 of an inheritance remained blocked and could be remitted only if the funds were invested in prescribed Kenyan Government bonds with a life to ma tur i ty of at least five years. Previously, the non- resident beneficiary could transfer at once all the capital left to him by the deceased. June 23. Kenya ceased to be a Scheduled Territory of the Sterling Area. Following the floating of sterling, Kenya maintained its par value in terms of gold. As a result, the Kenya shilling began to appreciate in terms of sterling. July 31. The buying and confirming commission in respect of imports into Kenya no longer was approved for remittance overseas when it exceeded 3 per cent. August 30. The Nonresident Sterling Area Accounts were merged into the External Accounts. The prescrip- tion of currency regulations were revised accordingly. December 1. It was announced that with effect from January 1, 1973 all imports had to be inspected before shipment, as a measure against overinvoicing. December 1. With minor exceptions, all private sector imports valued at over K Sh 2,000 required exchange control approval. Imports originating in Tanzania or Uganda were exempt. December 31. Not for Redistribution KHMER REPUBLIC Exchange Rate System No par va lue for the currency of the Khmer Repub- lic, the riel, has been agreed with the Fund. The exchange rate structure comprises a basic exchange rate and a preferen t ial rate. The basic or general rate for sales of foreign exchange is set twice weekly by the National Bank of Cambodia ( the central b a n k) in an exchange market referred to as "the new exchange marke t ," in the light of market conditions; on Decem- ber 31, 1972 the basic rate was KR 187 per US$1, selling; the National Bank buys foreign exchange at a rate 0.4 per cent below the selling rate. The preferen- tial exchange rate is applicable only to aid imports and related services procured direct from donor countries (o ther than imports under U. S. P.L. 480 ); on Decem- ber 31, 1972 the preferential rate was KR 131 per US$1. The appreciation of the preferential rate in terms of the basic rate is not permitted to exceed 30 per cent. An effective exchange rate of KR 55 = US$1 results from the payment of a subsidy on the basic rate and is applicable to government transfers to Khmer dip- lomatic, consular, and religious missions abroad and to transfers by students for the purchase of text books. On the supply side of the market all export proceeds and other foreign exchange receipts are subject to compulsory surrender. In addition to these receipts the market is also supplied with foreign exchange under certain aid programs. Exchange earnings from all permissible exports are channeled through the com- mercial banks to be converted at the exchange rate established by the National Bank for any given market day; commercial banks must sell all export proceeds to the National Bank through the foreign exchange market without delay. On the demand side, foreign exchange is purchased by commercial banks to finance all imports except for those that are either financed under the U. S. Commercial Import Program and Pub- lic Law 480 Programs or are made sans devises; in addition, all permissible payments for invisibles and capital are channeled through this market. Participation in the market is limited to authorized commercial banks which buy and sell foreign exchange in transactions w i th the National Bank; they act on behalf of customers only and are not allowed to main- ta in foreign exchange balances for trade purposes, except as these may arise in connection with their normal operations. Foreign exchange transactions of the Government and its departments and agencies are subject to the same conditions as transactions of the private sector, but are generally channeled through the National Bank. The National Bank of Cambodia maintains official quotations for 13 currencies. l These quotations all pro- vide for a spread of 0.4 per cent between the buy ing and selling ra te expressed in riels. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Na t ional Exchange Office, an autonomous agency within the National Bank; this office is empowered to authorize all operations related to settlements with foreign coun- tries, to foreign investments, and to nonresident accounts. The Ministry of Commerce is in charge of the administration of import and export controls. Prescription of Currency Settlements w i th five countries w i th wh ich the Khmer Republic has b i la teral paymen ts arrangements are made through b i la teral accounts. Those ma in ta ined for Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, and the U. S. S. R. are denominated in pounds sterling, and those for Bul- garia and Poland in U. S. dollars. Settlements with other countries take place in convertible currencies. Foreign inves tmen ts must be made in a currency acceptable to the Na t ional Bank. Profits on, and pro- ceeds from the liquidation of, foreign investments may be transferred abroad in the currency in which the inves tment was made. Nonresident Accounts The following categories of account may be ma in- tained for nonresidents: Foreigners' Accounts in Riels, Capital Accounts, Nonresident Accounts, and Foreign Currency Accounts. In addition, Khmer nationals stay- ing abroad temporarily but not recognized as nonresi- dents, and fore igners staying in the Khmer Republic but not recognized as residents, may maintain Internal Accounts of Nonresidents. There are separate regula- tions concerning nonresident accounts that may be used to finance transactions in the free trade area of Kompong-Som. Foreigners' Accounts in Riels may be opened, with- out permission, for foreigners residing outside the Khmer Republic. They are related to the country of residence of the account holder. They may be freely credited with (1) proceeds from the sale on the Phnom Penh exchange market of the currency (but not bank- notes) of the country of the account holder; (2) pay- ments for authorized imports (including incidental expenses) from the country of the account holder; (3) earnings on investments in the Khmer Republic and receipts from repayments on Khmer stocks and bonds and on other investments made in the Khmer Republic 1 Australian dollars, Belgian francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U .S. dollars. 287 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KHMER REPUBLIC after May 1956; and (4) interest paid by the banks on funds kept in the acounts. These accounts may be freely debited for normal expenses in the Khmer Repub- lic and, provided that it is quoted on the Phnom Penh market, for purchases of the currency of the country of the account holder (except in the form of bank- notes). Transfers between Foreigners' Accounts in Riels related to the same country may be made freely. Capital Accounts may be opened without permission. Subject to authorization, these accounts may be credited with (1) proceeds from the sale in the Khmer Republic of Khmer stocks and bonds; (2) proceeds from the sale in the Khmer Republic of participations in corporations other than by purchases of stocks and bonds; (3) contractual or advance repayments of Khmer stocks and bonds; (4) proceeds from the sale through an authorized notary of real estate or businesses located in the Khmer Republic and in the possession of a nonresident since before January 1, 1955 or acquired by him at a later date either through inheritance or with the permission of the National Exchange Office; (5) repayment of loans granted to residents prior to Janu- ary 1, 1955, or after that date with the approval of the National Exchange Office; and (6) transfers from another capital account related to the country of the account holder. Capital Accounts may be freely debited for (1) living expenses of the account holder or his fam i ly up to KR 1,000 a person a day, and up to a maximum of KR 50,000 monthly, and (2) expenses connected w i th the administration of foreign assets in the Khmer Republic (stocks and bonds, buildings, land, etc.). Subject to authorization from the National Exchange Office, these accounts may be debited for (1) purchases in the Khmer Republic of Khmer stocks and bonds; (2) subscriptions to, or increases in the capi- tal of, a Khmer firm; (3) purchases through an author- ized notary of title to real estate or businesses located in the Khmer Republic; (4) loans in riels to residents; (5) transfers to another capital account related to the coun try of the account holder; (6) living expenses in the Khmer Republic of the account holder's employees if the account is held by a firm (corporation, bank, etc.); and (7) g i f ts to individuals and to social, cultural, and religious associations. Nonresident Accounts may be opened only upon authorization. They may be freely debited for (1) taxes in the Khmer Republic, (2) miscellaneous accounting, correspondence expenses, etc., and (3) l iv ing expenses in the Khmer Republic of the account holder and his fam i ly. They may freely be credited with the proceeds f rom foreign currency sold on the Phnom Penh market and w i th interest on funds held in the account con- cerned. All other operations through these accounts are subject to individual licensing. Foreign Currency Accounts may be opened only upon au tho r iza t ion. They may be freely credited with foreign exchange transferred f rom abroad. Account holders may use balances on these accounts (1) to cover 288 expenses abroad, such as those related to travel, mis- sions, and the purchase of foreign merchandise, and (2) to cover expenses of any kind in the Khmer Repub- lic by converting balances on these accounts into riels on the Phnom Penh exchange market. Internal Accounts of Nonresidents may be opened only upon authorization. Balances on these accounts may not be used for transfers abroad. The accounts may be freely credited with (1) proceeds from the sale of foreign exchange on the Phnom Penh market; (2) transfers from Foreigners' Accounts in Riels; (3) wages, salaries, allowances, and payments for expenses of Khmer nationals employed by Khmer firms and tem- porarily residing abroad; (4) income earned in the Khmer Republic by account holders; (5) redeposits of previous withdrawals; and (6) repayment of loans granted to residents out of balances in such accounts. The accounts may be freely debited for (1) living expenses in the Khmer Republic of the account holder or his family, (2) administrative expenses related to the account holder's property in the Khmer Republic, and (3) loans to residents. All other operations through these accounts require authorization. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain commodities is prohibited for reasons of health or security and that of certain other goods for protective reasons. In view of the availability of substantial amounts of commercial aid resources, several important import commodities have been placed on an "exclusive list"; their importation is permitted only against commercial aid financing. The list includes tobacco leaves, cotton fibers, certain vegetable oils, wheat flour, and cotton thread under the U. S. P.L. 480 program, and some foodstuffs, rubber and rubber prod- ucts, petroleum, chemicals, timber and paper products, iron and steel, metals, cars and trucks, and U. S. equip- ment in general, under the U. S. Commercial Import Program (CIP). For all other permissible imports, including those eligible for CIP financing that are not on the "exclusive list," cash foreign exchange resources are provided without restrictions; they are referred to as general imports. General imports of up to US$500 for each ship- ment may be made freely when no foreign exchange purchase is involved (sans devises) and the goods are not intended for resale. All imports financed by foreign exchange purchases in the exchange market must be settled against irrevocable letters of credit opened by the commercial banks. Importers are required to submit their requests for purchases of foreign exchange to the commercial banks, accompanied by a payment in riels equal to the cost of the foreign exchange requested, calculated at the latest quotation for the currency con- cerned. A supplementary deposit in riels, the amount of which is varied from time to time, is also required; at the end of 1972 the supplementary deposit required was equivalent to 200 per cent of the cost of the for- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution eign exchange involved. Certain government agencies are exempt from the supplementary deposit require- ment. In their requests for exchange importers must state the most depreciated exchange rate they are pre- pared to pay. Twice weekly the National Bank con- siders the applications received and sets its selling rate. An importer's application is met in full at the current selling rate if his bid specified that rate or a less appre- ciated rate; if he has indicated a more appreciated rate than the one actually established, he will not be able to obtain exchange and his deposit is refunded. The supplementary deposits of successful bidders are refunded when the shipping documents are taken up at the bank where the letter of credit was opened. In order to facilitate the efficient utilization of avail- able commercial aid resources, preferential local cur- rency payment facilities have been extended to importers who are willing to finance imports through aid. The local currency cost of CIP imports is settled as follows: (1) in the case of purchases from the United States or from "Code 941" countries,2 the importer must pay 10 per cent of the import value in riels at the time the import application is approved by SONEXIM (Societe Nationale d'Exportation et d'lm- por ta t ion), 15 per cent at the time the order is placed, and the remainder at the time of the presentation of documents by the commercial bank; (2) where SONEXIM is buying directly from "Code 941" coun- tries, the importer must pay 25 per cent of the import value in riels at the time of delivery of the import certificate by SONEXIM and the remainder at the time of presentation of documents by the commercial bank. The 75 per cent due on presentation of the documents may be financed by commercial bank credits. In the case of imports from the United States, the credits are extended for a period of four months, while two-month credits are available for CIP imports f rom third countries. A preferential interest rate of 5 per cent is charged on these loans. Each importer is required to obtain an import busi- ness license. Importers are permitted to trade with for- eign countries only if they have assumed corporate s ta tus (societes anonymes). The equity cap i tal of such corporations should be at least KR 5 million; 51 per cent of the equity should be held by Khmer nationals and one third of board membership should be Khmer. Upon completion of the import transac t ion, import- ers are required to subm it proof that the foreign exchange has ac tua l ly been used to finance imports, and that the goods have arr ived and have been cleared th rough customs w i th f u ll payment of import du ty and other levies. Payments for Invisibles Importers include an estimate of the freight and insurance component of the cost of imports in their 2 Certain developing countries in Asia. KHMER REPUBLIC bids for foreign exchange for imports. If actual freight and insurance costs exceed the estimate, a separate bid for the additional amount must be submitted. Foreign exchange for freight and insurance for imports under U. S. P.L. 480 is also purchased on the "new exchange market." All other payments for invisibles require indi- vidual authorization, and only those transactions explicitly mentioned in the exchange control regulations are permitted. A foreigner working in the Khmer Republic and receiving a monthly salary exceeding KR 5,000 in Phnom Penh, or KR 3,500 in the provinces, may in principle t ran s fer up to 30 per cent of his net monthly salary —after payment of taxes —plus 15 per cent of his mon th ly salary if a dependent w i fe stays abroad, plus an additional 10 per cent if dependent children, parents, or grandparents stay abroad. (The additional percentage of transferab le income is 2 per cent for each legitimate child or dependent parent or grand- parent, with a max imum of 10 per cent of the net monthly income for each family .) Such transfers may not exceed the equivalent of KR 20,000 a worker a mon th. Transfer facilities are not granted for salaries and wages exempt from income tax. Overtime pay is considered transferable income only when it is received in payment for courses given in public educational insti- tutions. Women of foreign nationality married to Khmer nationals and work ing in the private sector are not permitted to transfer savings from salaries or wages to their country of origin. Foreign landlords domiciled in the Khmer Republic may t rans fer up to 30 per cent of the taxable portion of their income from rent, provided that the rent exceeds KR 5,000 for landlords living in Phnom Penh or KR 3,500 for landlords l iv ing in the provinces. For- eign landlords living abroad may t rans fer up to 20 per cent of the taxable portion of rent. Foreigners residing in the Khmer Republic, when leaving the coun try permanently, are permitted to transfer abroad, up to prescribed limits, savings out of their salaries earned in the Khmer Republic, provided that the savings have been regularly deposited with an authorized bank in the Khmer Republic. The transfer of the fu ll net profits f rom nonresident inves tmen ts made prior to May 31, 1956 is authorized, sub ject to proof that the inves tment was made with foreign currency other than the former Indo-Chinese piastre; otherwise, the t rans fer of profits on pre-1956 inves tmen ts is limited to 80 per cent and is permitted only if the inves tment is recognized as useful to the economic development of the Khmer Republic. Net profits that do not exceed 20 per cent of foreign investments made a f ter May 31, 1956 may be trans- ferred annua l ly. Khmer nationals s tudy ing abroad may receive monthly exchange allocations equivalent to up to US$108 for . Asian countries and up to US$ 126 for any other country, in addition to ins ta l la t ion, holiday, and cloth- 289 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KHMER REPUBLIC ing allowances. The allocation of foreign exchange for tour ist travel and business travel has been suspended. The export of Khmer cu r rency is prohibited and fo re ign tou r i s ts requ i re special au tho r iza t ion to recon- vert r ie ls i n to fo re ign cu r rency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exporters must obtain a n n u al registration licenses f rom the Ministry of Finance. Exports are classified into three groups: a prohibited list, a licensing list, and a f ree list. Prohibited exports comprise ma in ly goods whose exports have been banned for social and political reasons, while the purpose of the licensing list is to avoid shortages of supplies needed for domestic use. The exportation of rice and precious stones is reserved for state monopolies. All other commodities may be f ree ly exported, provided that the transactions are arranged through a commercial bank, which must issue an export certificate for each shipment. A Committee on Export Price Quotations sets weekly minimum export prices. A preferential interest rate of 10 per cent is available for export financing. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered. Approved hotels, airlines, and other organizations authorized to receive payment in foreign exchange are required to keep adequate records of such transactions and to surrender all receipts to the commercial banks at least once weekly. The import of Khmer currency is prohibited. Capital All capital transfers require ind iv idual licenses. No t ran s fer abroad of proceeds f rom the sale of property by a foreigner to a foreigner is permitted. Foreigners who sell their property to Khmer nationals and leave the Khmer Republic permanen t ly may transfer initially up to 20 per cent of the proceeds of the sale; up to 20 per cent of the remainder may be authorized for transfer annually, when the total amount involved is small. Funds representing the repayment of loans origi- na l ly granted in foreign currency may be considered transferable income. Since May 31, 1956, all foreign investments have been subject to authorization from the Ministry of Finance, which requires that a certain percentage of the capital of an enterprise should be reserved for Khmer participation and that its employees should be Khmer nationals. Only investments for the creation of activities recognized as useful to the economic develop- ment of the country and not involving monopoly or special privilege may be authorized. Proceeds f rom the liquidation of authorized investments made af ter May 31, 1956 may be transferred in yearly installments not exceeding 20 per cent of the total investment. Up to 10 per cent of the proceeds from the liquidation of 290 investment made prior to May 31, 1956 may be author- ized for t ran s fer every year. Foreign capital invested a f ter May 31, 1956 is guar- anteed the same tax trea tment that is applied to resident inves tmen ts; in addition, special incentives (partial exemption f rom duties and taxes on reinvested profits, and on equipment goods or raw ma ter ia ls imported dur- ing the first year of ope ra t ion) may be accorded to for- eign investment considered as excep t iona l ly u se ful to the Khmer economy. There is a guaran tee of 10-30 years against risks of na t iona l iza t ion or expropriation, and for a just and equ i tab le ind emn i ty in the event of na t iona l iza t ion or exp rop r ia t ion of inves tmen ts. Gold Residents may ho ld and acqu ire gold coins in the Khmer Repub l ic for num isma t ic purposes. W i th this exception, residents o ther t h an the mone tary authorities, SONEXIM, and authorized indu s t r ial users are not allowed to hold or acqu ire gold in any form other than jewe lry, at home or abroad. Impor ts and exports of gold in any fo rm other th an jewe lry require au thor iza- t ion by the Na t ional Bank; such au thor iza t ion is not no rma l ly gran ted except for imports and exports by or on beha lf of the mone tary au tho r i t ies and SONEXIM. Not for Redistribution KOREA Exchange Rate System * No par value for the Korean Won has been estab- lished with the Fund. Since March 22, 1965 there has been a fluctuating exchange rate determined in an exchange certificate market. On December 30, 1972 the buying and selling rates of the Bank of Korea for the U. S. dollar were W 398.40 and W 399.40, respec- tively, and the telegraphic transfer buying and selling rates of the foreign exchange banks were W 398.10 and W 399.70, respectively. Exchange certificates valid for 45 days are issued by the foreign exchange banks against all foreign exchange earnings in prescribed currencies surrendered by residents. All foreign exchange proceeds, however, may alternatively be exchanged for won at the buying rate posted by the foreign exchange banks. Exchange certificates are in principle required for all foreign exchange expenditures except for payments for imports financed under U. S. aid programs, and payments by commercial banks in connection with their banking transactions, etc. There is a limited forward exchange market restricted to exporters covering their export earnings; the fore ign exchange banks may in tu rn cover their fo rwa rd transactions with exporters by engaging in such transactions abroad. Administration of Control The Ministry of Finance is in charge of exchange control, subject to the approval of the Cabinet. It car- ries out policy with respect to prescription of currency and method of settlement, foreign exchange operations, payments for nonmerchandise transactions, and capital transactions and transfers. The Bank of Korea, as the Government's agent, executes the above functions in part; it regulates operations in the certificate market and is authorized to intervene in it. The Bank has also been delegated authority to control receipts and payments related to invisibles. The Korea Exchange Bank, whose capital is wholly subscribed by the Government and the Bank of Korea, has taken over from the latter all its international banking and foreign exchange business. The foreign exchange banks, as well as the branch offices in Korea of foreign banks, are authorized to deal in foreign exchange. The trade program for imports financed from Korea's own foreign exchange resources (KFX) is prepared by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Imports financed by foreign grants and loans are programed separately by the Economic Planning Board in consul- tation with the M in is try of Commerce and Industry, and import licenses are issued by the foreign exchange banks. * Following the announcement on Feb rua ry 12, 1973 that the U. S. do l lar was being deva lued, Korea ma in ta ined unchanged the exchange rate of US$1 = W 398.90. 292 Prescription of Currency All settlements between Korea and other countries are made in convertible currencies. Korea has a bilat- eral payments agreement with Viet-Nam, but no clear- ing account has been established. An arrangement with Indonesia provides for certain settlements to be effected through escrow accounts, but the account has not been established and no transactions have taken place under this arrangement. The proceeds of exports must be obtained in pre- scribed currencies.1 The methods of payment on account of other settlements require the approval of the Min- istry of Finance. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents and Korean workers abroad may main- tain foreign currency deposit accounts with foreign exchange banks. Remittances from such accounts and withdrawals in the form of currency notes upon depar- ture from Korea may, in general, be made freely. The approval of the bank where the account is held is required for remittances from balances that have accrued from remuneration for services in Korea, air or ship passage fares, or insurance premiums received in Korea, or from exchange deposited in accordance with a decision of the Ministry of Finance (except exchange registered at the customs on entry or remitted from abroad). The deposits may be disposed of by sale to a foreign exchange bank at the prevailing exchange rate, and they may be debited for salary payments to foreign employees. Foreign residents and nonresidents are permitted to hold time deposit accounts in U. S. dollars with the foreign exchange banks. Certain residents of Korean nationality, such as the airline and some insurance companies, may maintain current deposit accounts in foreign currencies with the foreign exchange banks. Companies registered to oper- ate in the Masan Free Export Zone may maintain cur- rent deposit accounts in foreign currencies with the foreign exchange bank w i th in the zone. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. All imports requ ire licenses; for certain imports (see below) licenses are issued upon application. No licenses are issued for any goods o r ig ina t ing in Cuba, ma in land China, Nor th Korea, or No r th Viet-Nam and for certain imports from all other countries. Imports are divided into three categories: those paid for w i th Korean foreign exchange (so-called KFX impo r ts ), those paid for with foreign 1 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution aid funds, and those financed by Japanese reparations (PAC impor ts). KFX imports are classified as auto- matic approval, restricted, or prohibited items. All commodities may be imported freely (i.e., applications for import licenses are automatically approved) unless they are in a list of restricted or prohibited commodi- ties. Automatic approval items (on December 31, 1972 these were 668 out of 1,312 basic items in the SITC classification) consist mainly of essential consumer goods not domestically produced and certain raw materials and capital goods.- Restricted items (571) in a negative list are subject to individual licenses. Pro- hibited items (73) are mainly luxury goods, items prohibited for reasons of public health or morals, and some domestically produced goods. Imports of raw materials for the production of exports are normally approved automatically, irrespective of their classifica- tion. Foreign aid imports are classified as either auto- matic approval items or restricted items. In principle, no commodities imported w i th foreign aid funds are included among the KFX imports, but in exceptional cases payment for imports usually financed with aid funds may be made with KFX exchange. For purposes of licensing imports from specified countries, the posi- tion of Korea's balance of trade with the country con- cerned is taken into account. Import licenses are granted only to registered traders; to maintain the status of a registered trader, a minimum value of US$300,000 of exports is required each year for ordinary exporters. The commercial terms of payment on which imports may be contracted are regulated, and advance import deposits are required for most categories of imports by the private sector; these are met, for KFX imports, by deposit of exchange certificates and /or local currency at the time of applying for import licenses. The exchange certificate deposits are, in effect, advance pay- ments offset against the import settlement; the won equivalent of any amount of deposit in excess of the import settlement is repaid to the importer at the time of the release of the relative bill of lading. Imports by the private sector under U. S. aid programs are subject to prior won cash payments of part of the import set- tlement, and imports with Japanese Property and Claims Funds (PAC imports) are subject to prior payments of part of the import settlement in exchange certificates. Advance deposits for KFX imports range between 5 per cent and 200 per cent according to the nature of the import and the commercial terms of payment; the rates are 100-200 per cent for imports against sight letters of credit, 5 per cent to 40 per cent for docu- ments against acceptance ( D / A) imports, and 20 per cent to 60 per cent for imports on a documents against payment ( D / P) basis and bonded warehouse transac- tion (BWT) terms. Advance deposits for KFX imports 2 Some automatic approval items require the prior approval of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry when imported from Japan. KOREA of raw materials for exports are 100 per cent, except for imports for stockpiling and documents against pay- ment and documents against acceptance imports, Which are subject to a 10 per cent advance deposit. Imports of equipment and facilities for export industries financed with domestic loans in foreign exchange are not subject to advance deposits; payment (in exchange certificates) of 10 per cent of the import value is required upon the release of bills of lading, with the balance of the pay- ment to be settled in accordance with the terms of the loan. The Ministry of Finance has authority to apply to any import commodity that it deems nonessential a special customs ta r i f f, which provides for an additional tax of 70 per cent or 90 per cent of the differential between estimated wholesale value of the commodity and import price plus normal profit. The authority has been invoked in respect of a number of commodities. Furthermore, the Government may alter import duty rates administratively by up to 50 percentage points. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require individual licenses. Payments for invisibles connected with foreign trade transactions and for certain other items, such as bank- ing charges, insurance premiums, communication fees, and periodicals, are licensed automatically. There are certain standard allocations for business travel. In addi- tion, exporters are authorized to use exchange earnings up to an amount of US$2,000 a month for the expenses of their overseas branches; the authorization is US$3,000 a month if exports to the country concerned exceed US$1 million and US$5,000 a month if exports to the coun try concerned exceed US$5 million. All residents departing for travel abroad may purchase for- eign exchange up to the equivalent of US$30 a day; they may purchase an additional US$100 for each trip for extra expenses. Students studying abroad may receive a mon th ly living allowance of up to US$300. Foreign and Korean currency notes may not be exported without special permission. Nonresident foreigners need not register foreign exchange in specified currencies that they bring into Korea and, when departing, they may reconvert unused won notes into U. S. dollars up to US$200, subject to conf irma t ion of the original sale of exchange (up to US$50 w i thout such conf irma t ion). Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Cuba, mainland China, North Korea, Rhodesia, and North Viet-Nam are prohibited, as are exports of certain goods (such as raw cotton, platinum ores, wood charcoal, pulp, and waste paper) to all other countries. Certain exports require individual licenses. All other exports may be made freely under an auto- matic approval procedure. The export proceeds in for- eign exchange must either be surrendered to a foreign 293 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KOREA exchange bank at the market rate or be exchanged into equ iva lent fo re ign exchange certificates.^ Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds derived f rom invisibles must either be sold to a foreign exchange bank or be exchanged for equ iva lent exchange certificates. The import of Korean currency notes requires special authorization. Travelers may bring with them any amount of foreign exchange. Capital All capital remittances require approval. Foreign capital investment, loans from abroad, and imports of capital goods on a long-term basis can secure a guaran- tee of repayment and repatriation under the Foreign Capital Inducement Law. No limits are placed on con- version and remittance of legitimate profits and divi- dends, and up to 20 per cent of the original capital invested plus any reinvestment may be repatriated each year, two years from the commencement of operations in Korea. Gold Certain commemorative gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. By virtue of Law No. 233 of December 23, 1951 residents may freely buy, hold, and sell gold in any form in Korea. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry consti- tu t ing the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and author- ized industrial users, and there have been no imports or exports since 1965. The leading producer of gold, a government-owned company, may be required to sell gold to the Bank of Korea at US$38 an ounce. Otherwise, domestic produc- tion may be disposed of in the free market. The free market price at public gold auctions was about W 881.06 a gram at the end of 1972. Changes during 1972 January 1. The foreign exchange budget for 1972 went into effect. The new am endm ent came in to effect on J anu a ry 22, 1973. December 29. The foreign exchange budget for 1973 was adopted. It was based on three general principles: ( 1) the capacity to repay foreign debts was to be increased by balancing the supp ly and demand for for- eign exchange; (2) higher priority was to be given to the expansion of export industries; and ( 3) nonessential imports and paymen ts for invisibles were to be re- stricted, but not to the extent of obstructing the effi- cient supply of raw materials and of goods required for stable economic growth. Guidelines on the expendi- tures side inc luded: ( 1) an unchanged ceiling of US$235 million for D/A imports and one of US$480 million for imports on a shipper's usance basis; (2) importers would in principle be required to contract on an f.o.b. basis and use Korean-flag vessels; (3) the criteria for permission to travel abroad would be adjusted so as to reduce nonessential travel expendi- ture; (4) t rans fe rs of film rentals would not be per- mitted to exceed an amount fixed by the Minister of Finance; (5) agency commissions on imports and exports would not normally be allowed to exceed 5 per cent of the invoiced import or export value; and (6) so as to improve the foreign debt structure, certain bank loans and commercial loans were to be repaid ahead of schedule. 295 ©International Monetary Fund. Kuwait does not avail itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Kuwait quotes daily buying and selling rates for sterling and U .S. dollars; on December 30, 1972 these were KD 0.76875 buying, and KD 0.76985 selling, respec- tively, for sterling, and KD 0.32750 buying, and KD 0.32800 selling, respectively, for U. S. dollars. On April 5, 1963, Kuwait notified the Fund that it was prepared to accept formally the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment. Administration of Control There is no exchange control and residents and non- residents may freely purchase and sell foreign cur- rencies in Kuwait. Dealings in the currencies of Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa, however, are prohibited. General and individual import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. The limited control over exports is administered by the Customs and Ports Administration of the Ministry of Finance and Oil. Prescription of Currency Kuwait has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U. K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U. K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. There are no prescription of currency requirements. All settlements with Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may freely open accounts in Kuwaiti dinars and foreign currencies. The use of such accounts is not restricted. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for all private imports other than foods tuffs; licenses are issued freely, except for wheat, flour, and asbestos pipe. Registered importers handling a variety of commodities may obtain a gen- eral license valid for one year. Other importers must obtain specific licenses for individual commodities, which are also valid for one year. All imports from Israel, inc lud ing imports of Israeli manu fac tu re and those that contain Israeli materials or are manu fac tu red * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, Kuwa it maintained the par value of its currency in terms of gold and availed itself of wider margins. The effective parity relationship for the U. S. dollar became KD 0.296053 = US$1. 296 by companies financed by Israeli capital, and all imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are pro- hibited. Imports of a few items (mainly oxygen, cer- tain steel pipes, alcoholic beverages, and used trucks and buses not using gasoline for fuel and over ten years old) are prohibited f rom all sources. To be registered, the importer must be either a Kuwaiti citizen or a firm in which all partners are Kuwaitis or a shareholding or limited liability company in which Kuwaitis own at least 51 per cent of all stock. Commercial imports normally are limited to registered importers. Imports from any permitted source may be paid for freely. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa. There are no limitations on the export of domestic or foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of live sheep and poultry are prohibited, and those of certain other items, such as sugar and fats, may be either licensed or prohibited in time of emergency or shortage in Kuwait. Exports of arms, ammunition, and scrap metal require licenses. Licenses are not required for other exports or re-exports. All exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports, except that these must not accrue in Israel pounds, Portuguese escudos, Rhodesian cur- rency, or South African rand; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered, and they may be dis- posed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles No requirements are attached to the use or dis- posal of receipts in any currency other than Israel pounds, Portuguese escudos, Rhodesian currency, or South African rand. Travelers entering Kuwait may bring with them any amount in Kuwaiti or other bank- notes except Israel, Portuguese, Rhodesian, or South A f r ican currency. Capital There are no exchange control obligations on the transfer to Kuwait of resident or nonresident capital in any currency. Government agreement is necessary for the participation of nonresident capital in corporations in Kuwa i t, and a license is required for the establish- ment and operation of industries in Kuwait; except for petroleum companies, 51 per cent of ownership of ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution new Kuwaiti companies must be held by Kuwaiti nationals. No restrictions are imposed on outward capital pay- ments by residents or nonresidents to other countries except Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa. A number of international bond issues have been placed in Kuwait, some of which were denominated in Kuwaiti dinars. Gold The monetary authorities and merchants registered with the Ministry of Commerce and Industry may import and export gold in any form, provided that such gold is not less than 18-carat fine; gold jewelry, however, cannot be imported or sold unless it is prop- erly hallmarked. Kuwaiti nationals may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Other residents may, on arrival or departure, bring in and take out their hold- ings of gold in any form, without restriction or license. Raw material imports by export indus tr ies and by firms benefiting f rom investment incentives are exempt f rom advance import deposit requirements. An exporter may, however, be permitted to make a prior surrender of only 40 per cent of export value, the rema in ing 40 per cent being due in a max imum of ten days f rom the settlement of the transaction; a commer- cial bank's guaran tee may be accepted by the National Bank in lieu of the rema in ing 40 per cent. Should an exporter be paid in a currency other than U. S. dollars, French francs, or pounds sterling, he must exchange the part that is subject to surrender into one of the accept- able currencies. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange converted by foreign embassies, missions, representatives, and institutions to cover their official expenses in Laos must be surrendered at the offi- cial rate. All other receipts from invisibles may be re- tained by the recipient. There are no regulations limiting the import of foreign or domestic banknotes by trav- elers. Capital Under the Investment Law of February 1970, various incentives are available to foreign investors in Laos. Capital inflow is free from exchange control regulations and the foreign exchange need not be surrendered; cap- ital ou tf low is subject to the 40 per cent exchange tax but is not restricted. Not for Redistribution LEBANON Exchange Rate System All transactions take place at the free market rate, which for the U. S. dollar on December 30, 1972 was LL 3.0105 per US$1. There also exists a "provisional legal parity" of LL 3.08 = US$1; this is used only for (1) the valuation of the gold and foreign exchange components in the balance sheet of the Bank of Leba- non and of the Government's foreign exchange receipts and (2) the calculation of duties and taxes levied on amounts invoiced or expressed in foreign currency, particularly customs duties.1 There are no restrictions on foreign payments. Prescription of Currency In general, no requirements are imposed on exchange payments abroad or receipts in Lebanon. Some transac- tions with certain countries with which Lebanon has payments agreements 2 specifying the method or channel of payment may be made through specific accounts. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few goods from any source and all imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. All imports of arms and imports valued at over LL 500 of certain other commodities ( inc lud ing wheat, barley, beet and cane sugar, menthol, leather bags, ladies' dresses, industrial machinery, olive oil, molasses, brushes, poul- try, gasoline, kerosene, and liquid gas) that are for the most part produced locally are subject to prior licens- ing. Import licenses are also required for all machinery for the installation or expansion of manu fac tu r ing plants. Import licenses for raw and refined sugar are conditional on purchases of domestic sugar. All other commodities may be imported freely without license. Exchange to pay for imports may be obtained freely through the free market. A municipalities tax of 3.5 per cent is levied on the value of all goods imported by sea or air and a stamp tax of 1.2 per cent is applicable to all imports except gold and banknotes. A surcharge of 10 per cent of the applicable import duty is levied on specified tex- tiles and garments. Payments for Invisibles No restrictions are placed on payments for invisibles. Exchange may be obtained freely through the free market. 1 The "provisional legal parity" is defined by law in terms of a U. S. dollar equivalent to 0.888671 g ram of fine gold. No legisla- tion has yet been passed to take the new par value of the U. S. dollar into account. 2 Czechoslovakia, Egypt, Eastern Germany, Poland, and Romania. There is also an inoperative payments agreement with Guinea. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of a few goods (scraps of i ron, cast iron, lead, and t in) to any country, re-exports of certain goods to any destination, and all exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports valued at over LL 200 of a few items —such as livestock, wheat and wheat products, barley, apples, Egyptian cotton, newsprint, petroleum and petroleum products, indus t r ial and agri- cultural machines and equipment, and certain metals— to any country and all products intended for export to North Korea require export licenses. Exports of apples to Arab countries are limited to a specified monthly quota. Re-exports to Nor th Korea are subject to prior clearance by the Ministry of National Economy. Exchange receipts f rom exports may be re ta ined, used, or sold freely in the free market. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles may be retained, used, or sold freely in the free market. Capital There are no limitations on capital payments or receipts. Exchange may be obtained or sold freely through the free market. Gold Residents may freely hold gold in any form at home or abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any form with residents and nonresidents at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form are freely per- mitted and do not require a license. However, the import, export, and domestic sale of foreign gold coins that no longer are legal tender must be covered by a certificate ind ica t ing the gold content and weight and issued by the Office for the Protection of the Consumer. Following the application of exchange control by the United Kingdom to the Overseas Sterling Area countries except Ire land, South Afr ica's exchange con- trol regulations were amended. The regulations ceased to distinguish between Sterling Area and non-S ter l ing Area countries. Instead, they now distinguished between the Rand Currency Area (consisting of South Africa and Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland) and the Non- resident Area; the la t ter was defined in two ways: (a) in the application of the Securities Control Notices it consisted of all countries outside South A f r ica and (b) for all other purposes it consisted of all countries outside the Rand Currency Area (and thus excluded Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland). A South African resident was defined as a person, whether of South Afr ican or any other na t iona l i ty, who has taken up residence in, or is domiciled in, the Republic of South Africa. A nonresident was defined in two ways: (a) in the application of the Securities Control Notices, as a person whose normal place of residence or domicile is outside the Republic of South Africa and (b) for all other purposes, as a person whose normal place of resi- dence or domicile is outside the Rand Currency Area. Thus, residents of Botswana, Lesotho, and Swaziland continued to be regarded as nonresidents for purposes of control over transactions in securities. Not for Redistribution LIBERIA Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.818513 gram of fine gold per Liberian Dollar, corresponding to $1.08571 = SDR 1 or $ 1 = US$ 1. U .S. currency is in circulation along with Liberian coinage. Official accounts are kept in dollars and cents. There are no restrictions on foreign exchange transactions. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments There is no general system of import control. A few items (e.g., arms and ammunition, explosives, used clothing, and Pharmaceuticals) require prior licenses; no imports of shotgun shells are permitted at present and only certain types of cement are imported. Also, imports of certain goods (e.g., obscene literature and narcotics other than for medicinal purposes) and all imports from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. In practice, meat is imported primarily by the Liberian Supply Corporation and petroleum and petroleum products only by the Liberian Refining Company. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Export licenses are required for precious metals, precious stones, ivory, agricultural products other than rubber, and certain other items, such as arms, ammunition, and explosives. Licenses are issued freely; they serve mainly to enforce taxation or, for agricultural products, to assure certification of quality and origin and to safeguard the monopoly of the * Fo l low ing the announ c em ent on Feb rua ry 12, 1973 that the U. The surren- der of the proceeds of exports is not required, and exchange receipts are freely disposable. An export tax is levied on diamonds. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for or receipts from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or non- residents. Under an Investment Incentive Code, enter- prises undertaking new investment projects may be granted five-year to ten-year tax exemption and tariff exemptions on construction materials, raw materials, and capital goods to be used in manufacturing opera- tions. Other possible benefits include tariff protection, subject to approval of the legislature. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form are subject to licenses issued by the Minister of Finance; import licenses are issued freely but export licenses are granted restrictively. Under the Gold Agreement of 1958, the Bank of Monrovia, acting on behalf of the Government, purchases unrefined gold from local producers at US$34.00 a troy ounce, gross weight. Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC Exchange Rate System * The par va lue is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Libyan Dinar, corresponding to LD 0.357143 = SDR 1 or LD 0.328947 = US$1, and the Libyan Arab Repub- lic avails itself of wider margins. The U. S. dollar is the intervention currency. The Central Bank of Libya publishes daily buy ing and selling rates for 14 currencies. l It deals with commercial banks only in pounds sterling and U. S. dollars, at rates fixed daily. The Central Bank of Libya's rates for the U. S. dollar on December 31, 1972 were LD 0.32901 buying, and LD 0.33066 selling, per US$1; for the pound sterling the buying and selling rates were LD 0.77239 and LD 0.77627, respectively, per £ stg. 1. The com- mercial banks are permitted to buy or sell other curren- cies against pounds sterling and U. S. dollars through their foreign correspondents. The commercial banks' buying and selling rates for currencies other than ster- ling and U. S. dollars are based on quotations in Lon- don, New York, and other centers abroad. They may not deal among themselves in foreign currencies. Neither authorized banks nor importers or exporters are allowed to enter into forward commitments in foreign cur- rencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Central Bank of Libya, which has delegated some of its powers to the authorized banks. Policy relating to import and export licensing is determined by the Ministry of Economy. Import and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Economy; for certain imports the approval of another Ministry (Interior, Health, Agriculture and Agrarian Reform, or Defense) is required. Imports of petroleum and petroleum products, certain cereals, flour, tea, sugar, salt, tobacco, cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, and a n um b er of other commodities are a government monopoly. Imports of unprocessed gold are confined to the Central Bank of Libya. Prescription of Currency Settlements with other countries are made in conver- tible currencies, usually U. S. dollars or pounds sterling. All settlements with Israel, Mozambique, Portugal, Rho- desia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Import transac t ions are governed by Law No. 63 305 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB REPUBLIC of 1971. Most imports are under open general license and do not require an ind iv idual import license. The import of some items, inc lud ing alcoholic beverages and narcotics, is prohibited. Imports of pe t ro leum and petroleum products, sugar, salt, tea, rice, barley, wheat, flour, olive oil, tobacco, cigars, cigarettes, and c igare t te paper are subject to gove rnment monopo ly; they may be imported only by the Na t ional Oil Corporation, the National Supplies Corporation, or the Tobacco General Company. The Cen tral Bank of Libya has a monopo ly over the import of unwo rked gold. All imports f rom Israel, Mozambique, Po r tuga l, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Exchange permits required for imports are readily granted by the authorized banks, provided that there is a firm contract and any necessary import license has been obtained and, if the import is to be made on a letter of credit basis, that a marine insurance policy from an insurance company in the Libyan Arab Repub- lic is submitted before the letter of credit is established. However, no letter of credit in respect of the import of consumer durable goods may be opened by an author- ized bank without obtaining a cash margin of 25 per cent of the import price. Importers must submit to the bank granting the exchange permit, within two months of customs clearance, a customs declaration confirming clearance and stating the valuation. The approval of the Exchange Control Department of the Central Bank of Libya is required for advance payments. Deferred pay- ments (for up to 90 days after customs clearance) and payments for consignment shipments may be approved by the authorized banks. Imports are subject to customs duty and customs sur- charges totaling 15 per cent of the applicable customs duty. Payments for Invisibles The authorized banks are empowered to approve applications by residents to remit foreign exchange up to LD 100 in a calendar year for meeting genuine per- sonal commitments abroad of a noncommercial nature, including fam i ly assistance and gifts. They may also approve transfers abroad of up to LD 1,320 a year for each student (plus tuition fees, an allowance for books, etc.) for educational purposes as well as allocations for travel as indicated below. Remittances from non- resident accounts may be approved by authorized banks up to certain limits (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). All other payments for invisibles, as well as payments in excess of the approval authority delegated to the banks, require licenses from the Cen- tral Bank of Libya. Applications are considered on their merits. Persons leaving the country may take with them Libyan currency notes not exceeding a total of LD 20 (LD 10 for children under 12); these may not be spent or exchanged outside the Libyan Arab Republic, but are 306 intended for immed ia te expenses in the Libyan Arab Republic upon re turn to the country. Residents leaving for personal travel abroad, inc lud ing tourist travel, may, in add i t ion, take out fore ign exchange in the form of foreign currency notes, travelers checks, and letters of credit not exceeding a total va lue of LD 300 in a cal- endar year as a basic travel allowance; the exchange may be obtained from any authorized bank in the Libyan Arab Republic. Children under 12 years of age are allowed one ha lf of th is amoun t. Amoun ts in excess of the above may be granted in special circumstances. Pilgrims are en t i t led to a special quota of LD 300 in addition to the basic travel allowance. For business travel, residents may take out the equ iva lent of LD 500 a tr ip, subject to a max imum of LD 2,500 in any cal- endar year. All fares may be settled in L ibyan d ina rs in the L ibyan A rab Repub l ic. Temporary residents may take out any travelers checks or fore ign currency notes which they had previously b rought in and declared to the customs. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are only required for commodities which are not of Libyan origin. Export proceeds must be received through an au thor ized bank w i th in six months of shipment. Exports of nonmone ta ry gold (other than for processing abroad), vegetable oils, and scrap metals are prohibited. All exports to Israel, Mozambique, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Travelers checks or foreign currency notes may be cashed only at an authorized bank or at an exchange office licensed by the Central Bank of Libya. Travelers entering the Libyan Arab Republic may bring with them Libyan currency notes, not exceeding a total of LD 20, and other currency notes, travelers checks, letters of credit, securities, coupons, and other negotiable instruments in unlimited amounts. Capital Many aspects of the activities of oil companies oper- ating in the Libyan Arab Republic are governed by Petroleum Law No. 25 of 1955, as amended. It sells bars to domestic goldsmiths in limited quantities, to meet genuine commercial needs, at prices announced f rom t ime to t ime; at the end of 1972 this price was LD 805 a kilogram .3 Provided that a license is obtained f rom the Ministry of Economy, gold- sm i ths may have such gold processed abroad, after which it must be reimported. Bars purchased from the Central Bank of Libya must be melted and processed before they can be sold to the public.
