Gold Domestic transactions in nonmone ta ry gold are lim- ited to purchases of gold bars by licensed goldsmiths or m anu f a c tu r e r s. With th is excep t ion, residents may f ree ly purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Mexico or abroad. The Bank of Mexico does not buy or sell gold in transactions w i th p r iva te banks, individ- uals, or firms. There is a 15 per cent tax on "first hand" sales of new ly mined gold. Producers of gold under- tak ing not to sell it at prices exceeding international quotations plus no rmal opera t ing costs are eligible for a subsidy correspond ing to the f u ll 15 per cent tax when selling new ly m ined gold in Mexico to private banks reselling such gold to licensed goldsmiths or manu fac tu re rs in Mexico. Exports of gold are prohib- ited unless they are made by the Bank of Mexico. Imports of gold are perm i t ted and when licensed by the Bank of Mex ico are f ree of customs du ty. Changes during 1972 Du r ing the year a number of commodities were added to those r equ i r ing an import license. January 7. Specific duties on most imports of machin- ery and electrical equipment were eliminated and ad valorem duties on those commodities were lowered and un if ied at 20 per cent. Official valuation was set at Mex$5 per k i logram. Direct importers of machinery and equ ipment not produced domestically could claim a un i fo rm 65 per cent exemption f rom duties, reducing the effective du ty to 7 per cent of official valuation. January 3. Deposit banks resumed dealings in gold coins, which had been suspended since August 16, 1971. April 12. The Ministry of Finance and Public Credit issued two sets of regulations concerning foreign finan- cial institutions operating in Mexico. These regulated the representation in Mexico of foreign financial insti- tutions and the registration of fore ign financial institu- tions established outside Mexico. Foreign banks were required to submit to the Ministry of Finance applica- tions for both registration and establishment of repre- sentative agencies in Mexico. The activities of regis- tered fore ign financial institutions and their representa- tive agencies became subject to surveillance and to cer- tain limitations, including a prohibition f rom engaging, directly or through third parties, in any operation to attract funds f rom the public, whether by accepting deposits or by issuing securities. The preferential 10 per cent rate of withholding tax on interest collected f rom Mexican residents by foreign financial institutions located outside Mexico was henceforth reserved for institutions duly registered with the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit, while for nonregistered institutions the rate would be 20 per cent. MEXICO May 10. The par value of the peso was changed f rom 0.0710937 gram of fine gold to 0.0654810 gram of fine gold per peso. The new par va lue replaced the central rate of Mex$12 .50 = US$1. The parity relation- ship for the U. S. do l lar remained unchanged at Mex$ 12.50 = US$1. July 3. A new reserve requ i rement system was intro- duced for demand deposits in fore ign currency received by banks in the no r th e rn border areas. The marginal reserve requ i rement was reduced f rom 80 per cent to 40 per cent. July 20. To promote indus t r ial decentralization and p r iva te inves tment in less developed areas fiscal incen- tives were o f fe red to certain investments with Mexican ma jor i ty pa r t ic ipa t ion, at least 60 per cent national con- tent in the to tal va lue of production, and a level of remittances abroad of no more than 3 per cent of annual sales. July 25. The Bank of Mexico issued a circular which essentially served to consolidate the existing regulations concerning fore ign exchange, gold, silver, payments under reciprocal credit agreements, foreign financing, and fore ign trade. A general permission was granted for a large number of operations, inc lud ing the receipt of medium-term loans f rom fo re ign banks to finance exports and imports as well as inven tor ies of exportable goods, the endorse- ment of med ium - te rm credits granted by foreign con- tractors to Mexican importers, and, provided their ma- tur i t ies conformed to certain norms, the receipt or endorsement of fore ign credits to finance imports of capital goods. A general permission also was granted to receive deposits f rom, or to sell Mexican securities to, foreign residents other than banks, provided such obligations are registered in the name of a specific person and do not exceed Mex$5 million per person. However, liabili- ties of this type contracted vis-a-vis foreign banks or financial institutions required a specific authorization. "Foreign residents" were defined as firms or individuals domiciled outside the territory of Mexico, regardless of the ir citizenship. July 28. Mexico became a permanent observer of the Andean Group countries. In October, Mexico's status became that of a "working partner." August 13. A scheme of incentives was put into effect to promote the establishment of commercial cen- ters in the northern border zones. In order to qualify, at least half of the goods sold in the commercial center had to be of domestic origin, and imported commodi- ties had to be sold at prices similar to the retail prices prevailing on the U. S. side of the border. October 25. Automobile makers were required to use at least 60 per cent domestically produced components and parts in domestically sold automobiles and at least 40 per cent in exported automobiles. From 1973 to 335 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO 1979 the export-to-import ratio of automobile manufac- turers was to increase f rom 30 per cent to 100 per cent. All companies making auto parts were required to have at least 60 per cent Mexican capital. October 31. The scope of the border industries pro- gram, which originally covered industries within 20 kilometers of the border, was expanded considerably, to include industries established in nonindustrialized areas and along the shores. The administrative regula- tion of export and import transactions under the pro- gram was eased; temporary imports as well as tempo- rary exports were facilitated by a reduction in admin- istrative procedures. November 6. A bill was introduced to regulate the use of foreign technology, patents, and trademarks. Companies domiciled in Mexico would be required to register with a National Register of Technology Trans- fer in the Ministry of Industry and Commerce all agree- ments on the use of foreign trademarks and patents and all forms of technical assistance. Registration could be refused under certain circumstances. (The resulting law came into operation early in 1973.) November 7. A government-controlled company, TABAMEX, was established which was given a monop- oly of the cultivation, distribution, and export of tobacco. December 18. Certain changes in taxation were an- nounced, to become effective on January 1, 1973. The withholding tax on interest earned by registered foreign financial institutions was increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. The income tax on fixed-income securi- ties of the banking system was modified to increase rates on bearer securities and administration contracts while rates on nom ina t ive administration contracts were maintained. December 26. A bill providing for a Foreign Invest- ment Law was introduced. The Law would regulate foreign investment in Mexico, in part by consolidating existing legislation, and create a National Foreign Investment Register in the Department of Industry and Commerce, as well as a National Foreign Investment Commission. Applications by foreign companies or indi- viduals to acquire more than 25 per cent of a Mexican company's capital, or over 49 per cent of its fixed assets, would require authorization by the Commission. Foreign participation would, in principle, be limited to 49 per cent even in previously unrestricted activities, but the commission would be empowered to grant exceptions for investment in certain areas and economic sectors. All shares held in Mexican companies by for- eigners must be nominative, and existing bearer shares in companies with ma jor i ty foreign capital must, within 180 days of the Law coming into force, be converted into nominative shares. An investment would be re- garded as foreign also when made by Mexican compa- nies in which a majority of the capital is foreign owned, or by Mexican businesses in which foreigners have the right to control their management. (The Law came into operation in mid-1973.) 336 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.175610 gram of fine gold per Moroccan Dirham, corresponding to DH 5.06049 = SDR 1 or DH 4.66097 = US$1, and Morocco avails itself of wider margins. The rate of the dirham in rela- tion to the French commercial franc is fixed at DH 1 = F 1.09755 or DH 0.9111=F 1; the Bank of Morocco quotes daily buy ing and selling rates for the French financial franc. The Bank of Morocco's buying and selling rates for the "convertible currencies" it nego- tiates x are based on quotations in the leading foreign exchange markets abroad. The rates of the Bank of Morocco for the U. S. dollar on December 30, 1972 were DH 4.6550 buying, and DH 4.6764 selling, per US$1. All sales and purchases of foreign currency are cen- tralized in the Bank of Morocco, but the authorized banks are permitted to ma r ry (o f f se t) their purchases and sales on behalf of their pr iva te customers in each currency separately. The authorized banks must pur- chase from or sell to the Bank of Morocco each day, at the rates communicated to them by the Bank, the balances of the ir purchases and sales in each cur- rency; compensation between banks is not permitted so that no foreign exchange market exists in Morocco. The Bank of Morocco makes its own purchases and sales of foreign currency in exchange markets abroad. The Bank of Morocco also establishes buying and sell- ing rates for transactions with travelers in banknotes, travelers checks, and letters of credit expressed in French francs, CFA francs, and the "convertible cur- rencies"; the authorized banks sell to the Bank of Morocco their excess holdings of banknotes and replen- ish them at the Bank whenever necessary. Forward exchange transactions are not permitted. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Exchange Office, an agency under the Ministry of Finance. This Office has delegated the execution of certain exchange control measures to authorized banks. Import certificates and export licenses are issued by the M in is t ry of Com- merce; they must be countersigned by the Moroccan Exchange Office. Import comm i tmen ts for liberalized goods are signed by the impo r ter h im se l f; they do not require the visa of the Exchange Office unless the country of or ig in of the goods is not the coun try of shipment, or the goods are bought on a c.i.f. basis. A part of the port of Tangier is designated as a free trade zone and is exempt from taxation and from trade, customs, and exchange control. Prescription of Currency Morocco's regulations still make a distinction between the French Franc Area and the so-called area of con- vertibility, but Morocco does apply exchange control also to transactions with the former.2 For prescription of currency purposes, countries are classified as follows: (1) the French Franc Area countries; (2) the payments agreement group, comprising countries with which Morocco maintains bilateral payments agreements;3 and (3) all other countries, the so-called area of converti- bility. Settlements w i th the French Franc Area are made in French francs or, with the exception of settlements for imports, in d i rhams through French Franc Area Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, be- low); certain settlements with Algeria and Tunisia, how- ever, are made in dirhams, Algerian dinars, and Tuni- sian dinars through special accounts at the three central banks. Settlements with the payments agreement group are made by debiting or crediting the payments agree- ments accounts established for this purpose. Imports originating in countries in the area of convertibility may be paid for only in "convertible currencies" negotiated by the Bank of Morocco (see foo tno te 1 ). Other settle- ments with countries in the area of convertibility may be made only in "convertible currencies" negotiated by the Bank of Morocco or through Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams. When settlements between Morocco and the French Franc Area take place in French francs, these must be purchased f rom or sold to the Bank of Morocco; it applies the parity rate of DH 0.9111 = F 1 when the transaction passes through the French official exchange market, and its daily quotation for the financial French f r anc when the transaction passes through the financial market in France. Nonresident Accounts The various types of nonresident accounts are as follows: 1. French Franc Area Accounts are held in Moroccan currency by residents of countries of the French Franc Area. Transfers between French Franc Area Accoun ts may be made free ly. 2. Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are reserved for residents of countries in the so-called area of convertibility. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized payments due to residents of countries in the area of convertibility (but not in respect of impor ts or related invisibles) and with d irhams obtained f rom the sale to the Bank of Morocco of "converti- ble currencies" negotiated by it, excluding banknotes. Payments Agreement Accounts are held by the Bank of Morocco for central banks (or similar institu- tions) of the countries with which Morocco maintains bilateral payments agreements (see footnote 3 ); they are used only for settlements with these countries, including settlements for impor ts and exports. 4. Capital Accounts, which may be held by any non- resident, are credited with funds that may not be trans- ferred abroad. Transfers between Capital Accounts related to countries in the same currency group (the area of convertibility, the French Franc Area) or related to the same country in the payments agreement group are permitted freely. Subject to certain limitations, they may be debited without prior approval for purchases of Moroccan securities on the Casablanca stock exchange; for subscriptions to capital increases of Moroccan com- panies whose shares are quoted on the Casablanca stock exchange; for subscriptions at the time of issue to long- term or short-term securities with a fixed yield issued by a public Moroccan entity; for custody charges and commissions on securities; and for payment of the costs of maintenance, repairs, real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate located in Morocco. Capital Accounts may also be debited freely for purchases of specified 4 per cent, ten-year government bonds; interest and redemp- tion proceeds are transferable, and the bonds are freely negotiable between nonresidents. All other operations through Capital Accounts require individual approval. These include purchases on the Casablanca stock exchange of non-Moroccan securities; purchases of Moroccan securities not quoted in Casablanca or of participation in a Moroccan firm; subscriptions to either; investments of any k ind, inc lud ing purchases of busi- nesses or business bu i ld ings; lending to residents; pay- ment of local expenses du r ing the holder's stay in Morocco; and g if ts to social, cultural, or religious in- s t i tu t ions. 5. Suspense Accounts are used for holding nonresi- dent funds not available for credit to any of the accounts mentioned above. Balances on these accounts may be used freely to pay taxes due to the Moroccan authorities, but all other debits to these accounts require approval. 6. Two Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are held by the Bank of Morocco for the Central Bank of Algeria and the Central Bank of Tunisia. Specified transactions between Morocco and the two other coun- tries concerned are settled through these accounts. Imports and Import Payments Imports are admitted in accordance with an annual General Import Program. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports are divided into three categories applicable to all countries. Goods in List A are liberal- ized. Goods in List B are restricted, in some cases by a global quo ta, or are subject to state trad ing; for a large number of List B items, no quota is fixed and impor ts are approved according to need (SB i tem s ). In princi- ple, the impo r ta t ion of goods in List C is not permitted. To import goods in List A, the importer signs an import commitment (engagement d'importation), which does not requ ire adm in is t ra t ive app roval unless the goods are imported from a country other than that of origin or are purchased on a c. i. f. basis,5 but for goods in List B, an import license (autorisation d'importation or certificat d'importation) must be obtained. For all imports the import title —import certificate or import commitment —must be domiciled (registered) with an authorized bank, which may make payments upon submission of the required documents. Import cer- tificates require the visa of the Exchange Office before the foreign exchange is made available. Import com- mitments require this visa only when the country of origin and the country of shipment of the goods con- cerned differ or when imports are contracted for on a c. i. f. basis. Import certificates must be domiciled within a period of 15 days from the date that the Exchange Office approves the license. Import commitments must be domiciled at the time of their subscription. Special procedures are applicable to specified imports financed by foreign aid or loans. Most imports from countries in the payments agree- ment group are made in accordance with the quotas established in the respective trade agreements. Imports can also be licensed under compensation transactions. Payments for Invisibles Payments for most current invisibles are authorized by the Exchange Office upon presentation of the neces- sary justification; in several instances the approval 4 Imports f rom the French Franc Area, unless covered by special credit arrangemen ts, must be paid for with "commercial" French f rancs purchased from the Bank of Morocco. 5 C.i.f. imports of List A goods require prior exchange control approval. 338 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution authority has been delegated to the banks. The author- ized banks are permitted to make payments and settle expenses incidental to the commercial transaction cov- ered by the relevant import or export documents. Earn- ings after tax on approved nonresident investments in Morocco are transferable to the investor's country of residence. The transfer of dividends on nonresident- owned shares of Moroccan companies hav ing their main office in Morocco has been delegated to the authorized banks by the Exchange Office, provided that the shares are quoted on the Casablanca stock exchange and that the Exchange Office has approved the amount of the dividend to be distributed; the transfer of other divi- dends requires specific approval by the Exchange Office. Undistributed profits remain transferab le indefinitely. Some payments are subject to limitations. A foreign employee may transfer to his country of origin, subject to the approval of the Exchange Office, 50 per cent of his monthly wages or salary if his family does not reside in Morocco, or 30 per cent if he is single or his family lives in Morocco. The same percentages of their monthly earnings may be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in professions, subject (except for the medical and related professions) to a limit of DH 12,000 a year.6 Subject to a m o n t h ly l im it of DH 300, the same percentages of earnings may also be transferred by for- eign nationals engaged in agricultural, industrial, or commercial activities, or in skilled craf ts. An alloca- tion of foreign exchange equivalent to DH 100 a person a year is granted to residents of any nationality for travel abroad, provided that they do not make peri- odic t ran s fe rs abroad. There is a special allocation for pilgrimages. Residents of foreign nationality may acquire exchange for tourist travel up to the equivalent of DH 5,000 for each passport a year by selling to an authorized bank a corresponding amount in foreign exchange (other than banknotes) from their own for- eign assets not subject to surrender requirements. For business travel by persons other than exporters a stand- ard allowance of DH 150 a day is granted; exporters may be granted up to DH 200 a day for up to 60 days a year, up to a limit of 1 per cent of the foreign exchange surrendered during the preceding year. The allocation issued for business travel may be added to the allocation issued for tourist travel. For study abroad, a monthly allocation of foreign exchange up to DH 500-700 is granted, provided that no comparable educational facilities are available in Morocco. For family maintenance, there is a monthly allocation of DH 250-300. Travelers are not permitted to take out Moroccan banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are proh ib i ted. Most exports 8 For all wages, salaries, and professional earnings, monthly trans- fers which exceed by more than DH 100 the amount transferred in June 1972 require prior authorization by the Exchange Office. MOROCCO may be made freely, although export licenses are required for a few items. All fruits, fresh vegetables, canned goods, raw cotton, and cotton by-products may be exported on ly by a state trading agency, the Office of Marketing and Export (Office de Commercialisation et d'Exportation —OCE). That Office also is in charge of wine exports. All exporters must sign an undertaking to repatriate and surrender the foreign exchange proceeds of their exports. The surrender of the proceeds to the exporter's bank must take place within one month from the date the payment is due. The date on which the payment is due is the ma tur i ty date fixed in the commercial con- tract; this date must not be set, in principle, more than 90 days after the date of arrival of the merchandise at the place of destination. When the bank receiving the funds that represent the proceeds from exports receives the advice of credit in foreign currency from abroad, it must surrender the foreign exchange immediately to the Bank of Morocco. Proceeds from Invisibles Residents of Moroccan nationality and Moroccan companies must repatriate exchange receipts accruing from all their noncommercial claims and surrender them to an authorized bank. Other residents must surrender noncommercial receipts only if the receipts result from current transactions, and only when they accrue in for- eign currencies other than those of the French Franc Area; Moroccans working abroad must surrender such currencies within one month of re-entry, but are per- mitted, when leaving again, to repurchase 15 per cent of the amount surrendered (the currencies so purchased may also include French francs). The importation of Moroccan banknotes is prohibited. Nonresident travel- ers may bring in freely foreign banknotes, which need not be declared upon entry. Resident travelers also may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes, but these must be surrendered within 15 days of re-entry. Capital Residents of Moroccan nationality, as well as com- panies established in Morocco, are obliged to declare to the Exchange Office all foreign-held assets exceeding DH 250, and to repatriate and surrender certain of these assets. The disposal of other foreign-held assets requires permission. The transfer of capital abroad by residents must be approved. Remittances in respect of the assets of emigrants and transfers of gifts are not normally approved. Exchange allocations for the transfer of inheritances are limited to DH 35,000 per bene- ficiary. Those for the transfer of their assets by repatri- ates vary with the length of their stay in Morocco, from DH 35,000 a family with previous residence of 3 to 5 years to DH 100,000 a family where the period of resi- dence has been 15 to 25 years. Foreign investments in Morocco must be approved by 339 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO the Exchange Office. Foreign investments approved by the Investment Committee are granted various tax and customs tariff benefits and investment bonuses similar to those granted to domestic investments, in accordance with measures put into effect on February 10, 1961; all new investments that have been approved by, and registered with, the Exchange Office are automatically granted a guarantee of repatriation of the proceeds from liquidation of the investment, when the investment has been financed either with convertible currencies or in conformity with the rules governing settlements with other countries. The guarantee of repatriation is freely transferable either between all nonresidents (if the investment has been financed with convertible cur- rencies) or between nonresidents resident in the same country or currency area (if the investment has been financed with other currencies). Proceeds from the liquidation of other investments are credited to Capi- tal Accounts. Certain government bonds acquired with funds from Capital Accounts are freely negotiable between non- residents. All other transactions in securities involving nonresident interests, as well as the import and export of securities, require approval. Banks are not normally permitted to engage in short- term borrowing abroad. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Morocco for numismatic or investment purposes. Ten different types of foreign gold coins are traded on the Casablanca stock exchange, which does not, however, deal in gold bars or ingots. Imports and exports of gold are prohibited unless authorized by the Warranty Office in the Directorate of Customs and Indirect Taxes, which derives its approval authority from the Minister of Finance. Every year the Minister of Finance fixes a quota for the importation of gold ingots, which is then allocated among jewelers and other users. Gold in the form of coins, ingots, or bars is free from import duty and import taxes. Not for Redistribution NEPAL Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.0808408 gram of fine gold per Nepalese Rupee, corresponding to NRs 10.9929 = SDR 1 or NRs 10.1250 = US$1, and Nepal avails itself of wider margins. The Nepal Rastra Bank (the central bank) maintains fixed buying and selling rates for U. S. dollars and Indian rupees as follows: NRs 10.10-10.20 per US$1, and NRs 139.00-139.15 per 100 Indian rupees; fixed buying and selling rates are also quoted for Burmese kyats, deutsche mark, Swiss francs, Japanese yen, and seven other currencies. The Bank also quotes buying and selling rates for sterling; these are based on daily spot rates against the U. S. dollar in London. Most of Nepal's foreign ex- change transactions are in terms of Indian rupees. Resi- dents may freely purchase Indian rupees f rom Nepalese banks and they may hold any amount of Indian notes and coins, but the Indian rupee is not legal tender. Administration of Control A Foreign Exchange Committee, consisting of repre- sentatives f rom the Nepal Rastra Bank and the Minis- tries of Finance, Foreign Affairs, and Industry and Commerce, prepares an annual foreign exchange budget for foreign currencies other than the Indian rupee and excluding transactions with the clearing countries. Per- mission is required from the Ministry of Finance for all foreign payments, except paymen ts for certain specified invisibles that require authorization from the Nepal Rastra Bank. Import licensing is the responsibility of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. All exchange trans- actions with countries other than India must be settled through authorized dealers, i.e., the Nepal Bank Ltd. and the Rastriya Vanijya Bank. Within Nepal there are 58 additional authorized dealers licensed to purchase foreign currencies; any sale of such currencies other than Indian rupees is subject to the prior approval of the Nepal Rastra Bank. Certain import and export trans- actions, mainly with payments agreement countries, are conducted through a state trading agency, the National Trading Ltd. All trade transactions w i th Bulgaria and Poland are effected by or for the account of the Government. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements apply to outgoing payments to countries with which no payments agreement is in force and these may be made in the foreign currency supplied by the Nepal Rastra Bank. The proceeds of exports to India are obtained in Indian * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, Nepal on February 20 established a central rate of NRs 12.7390 = SDR 1, corresponding to NRs 10.56 = US$1. The pa r i ty rate for the Ind ian rupee was maintained at NRs 139.10 per 100 Indian rupees. or Nepalese rupees; the proceeds of exports to other countries must be received in any of the convertible currencies quoted by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Nepal has bilateral payments agreements with Bulgaria, mainland China, Pakistan, and Poland; payments between Nepal and these countries must be made through special accounts. The agreement with Pakistan is inoperative. Nonresident Accounts The Nepal Rastra Bank permits nonresidents other than Indian nationals upon request to open "convertible rupee accounts" with Nepalese banks, the balances of which may be freely transferred abroad. Indian nationals are allowed to open current accounts in Indian rupees with Nepalese banks. Foreign currencies brought into or received in Nepal by nonresidents, which are converted into Nepalese rupees and deposited with a Nepalese bank, may be reconverted for transfer out of the country, subject to prior permission of the Nepal Rastra Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports of goods except those originating in India (other than alcoholic beverages, tobacco, and most tobacco products) or the Tibet region require import licenses f rom the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. Imports of vegetables, vegetable oil, margarine, animal fa t, beef, arms and ammunition, explosives, chemicals to be used for explosives, and wireless transmitters are prohibited. Under the Trade and Transit Treaty of August 13, 1971, Nepal and India agreed to freedom of trade between themselves in Nepalese and Indian goods; Indian goods may be imported freely, and imports of all commodities subject to excise duty in India benefit f rom reimbursement of tax by the Gov- ernment of India to the Government of Nepal. With the exception noted below, applications to the Ministry of Finance for foreign exchange to pay for imports from countries other than India are considered on their merits; any application must, however, be in accordance with the annual foreign exchange budget. Exporters entitled to import goods with exporters' exchange entitlements are, within the limits of their entitlement, granted a license automatically for goods specified by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below). Certain imports from all sources are subject to import surcharges. Payments for Invisibles Payments to India may be made freely in Indian rupees, but for purchases of Rs 500 or over the purpose of the payment must be indicated. Payments for freight and insurance are given the same treatment as the related import payments. 341 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEPAL For travel to countries other than India for medical treatment, foreign exchange is allowed up to the equiva- lent of US$1,000 at a time; students studying at their own expense in these countries are allowed up to US$2,160 a year for board and lodging, while payments for tuition fees are allowed as required. Payments for other invisibles depend on the essentiality of the transac- tion and the availability of foreign exchange. Nepalese and Indian currency may be taken out freely to India by Nepalese and Ind ian nationals only; the export of these currencies to countries other than India is pro- hibited. Foreign banknotes other than Indian banknotes may not be taken out by residents without permission. Nonresidents may take out the unchanged amount of any foreign banknotes they brought in; however, non- residents other than Indian na t iona ls may not take out Nepalese or Ind ian bankno tes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of old coins, gold and silver, and coins and jewe lry made of these metals, cows, buffaloes, and rhi- noceros horns are prohibited. The re-export to India of non-Nepalese goods is not perm i t ted, and re-exports to any destination of goods imported from India are prohibited. All other goods may be exported freely. The exchange proceeds of exports, except Indian rupees, must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official buying rate of exchange, within six months of shipment. The exporter receives f rom the Nepal Rastra Bank an exporters' exchange entitlement corresponding to a specified pro- portion of his export proceeds in foreign currencies other than Indian rupees; the entitlement may be used to obtain exchange at the official rate for the import of goods specified by the Ministry of Industry and Com- merce. Although entitlements forma l ly are nontrans- ferable, transfers do take place indirectly through the advance sale of goods to be imported under this system. Exporters engaged in bilateral trade, i.e., those selling to countries with which Nepal maintains payments agreements, are granted entitlements corresponding to 100 per cent of their export earnings; 40 per cent may be used for imports of their choice from the partner country concerned and the remaining 60 per cent must be used to import specified commodities from the part- ner country concerned. When exports are made to con- vertible currency countries, exchange entitlements are granted as follows: 20 per cent for raw jute; 40 per cent for musk, bristles, and human hair; 50 per cent for hessian; 70 per cent for timber; 80 per cent for rice and wooden or bamboo goods; 90 per cent for straw board, stainless steel goods, and synthetic clothes; and 60 per cent for all other goods. Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Indian rupees, foreign exchange proceeds derived from transactions in invisibles must 342 be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an author- ized bank at the official rate of exchange. Nepalese and Indian currency may be brought in from India only, and by Nepalese and Indian nationals only; the import of these currencies f rom countries other than India is prohibited. Nonresidents other than Indian nationals are not allowed to bring in Nepalese or Indian bank- notes. Other foreign banknotes may be brought in freely by residents and nonresidents, but residents must declare any foreign banknotes they bring in. Capital No conditions are laid down concerning receipts and remittances in respect of capital transactions, but offi- cial exchange is not normally provided for capital remit- tances by Nepalese nationals. Nepalese citizens, whether resident in Nepal or not, are prohibited from making any type of investment in foreign countries except invest- ment specifically exempted by government notice pub- lished in the Official Gazette; the exemptions include the purchase and sale of insurance policies abroad, investments abroad by any banking or financial institu- tion incorporated in Nepal, and the purchase of shares of foreign companies under a rights issue. Foreign investors in Nepal who obtain an investment guarantee may remit yearly profits of up to 25 per cent of the total profit on the foreign capital invested and, in any one year, up to 10 per cent of the principal; if the exchange situation permits, profits in excess of 25 per cent are remittable. Industrial enterprises capitalized at US$50,000 or more may be wholly owned by nonresi- dents. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nepal. Imports for industrial and handicraft use f rom India, at Indian gold prices, are free of license. No import licenses for gold are issued under the exporters' exchange entitlement scheme. Imports of gold f rom any coun try other than India require a license and are subject to an import duty of NRs 53.20 a troy ounce; such imports are not normally allowed. Exports of gold may be made only by the monetary authorities and require prior approval by the Ministry of Finance. Domestic dealings in gold do not require a license but are subject to sales tax of 10 per cent. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS Exchange Rate System* The par value is 0.245489 gram of fine gold per Netherlands Guilder. The Netherlands has established a central rate of f. 3.2447 = US$1, corresponding to f. 3.52282 = SDR 1, and avails itself of wider margins. The intervention currency is the U. S. dollar. Margins of approximately 2% per cent either side of the central rate or the cross-parity are maintained for the U. S. dol- lar, the Danish krone, the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Italian lira, and the Norwegian krone, and margins of ll/z per cent either side of the cross-parity for the Belgian franc and, by implication, the Luxem- bourg franc (BF/Lux F 100 = f. 7.24007). The official limits for the U. S. dollar are f. 3.17%6 buying and f. 3.31% selling, per US$1, at which rates the exchange authorities stand ready to deal; the rate for the U. S. dollar fluctuates in the exchange market between these limits. Market rates for currencies other than those mentioned above vary between limits that result from combining the official limits for the U. S. dollar main- tained by the Netherlands and such limits in force in the country of the other currency concerned.1 Authorized banks are freely permitted to buy and sell convertible currencies and inconvertible currencies, both spot and forward, against convertible currencies, including guilders on Convertible Guilder Accounts, and inconvertible currencies; they are free to deal with residents and nonresidents, whether banks or nonbanks. Forward exchange contracts are not limited as to delivery period nor is an underlying transaction required. Residents are permitted to conclude spot transactions w i th other residents, in c lud ing au thor ized banks, and they may conclude forward transactions for any period with authorized banks. Nonbank residents are free to hold foreign currency accounts at home and on applica- tion are permitted to hold such accounts (normally demand deposits only) in their own names with banks abroad. The Kingdom of the Netherlands formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory All transactions with the Netherlands Antilles and Surinam are subject to exchange control, although they are generally permitted freely. Vis-a-vis any third coun- tries with which payments agreements might be in force, the Netherlands, the Netherlands Antilles, and Surinam constitute the Netherlands Monetary Area. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Netherlands Bank on behalf of the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Finance, Economic Affairs, and Agriculture. Import and export licensing are handled by the Central Import- Export Agency (CDIU) and the delegated offices, under directives from the Directorate-General for Foreign Economic Relations. Invisibles and capital transactions are licensed by the Netherlands Bank, as are transit trade transactions, except those in strategic goods and scrap, which are licensed by the CDIU.2 All commercial banks of any importance are authorized to handle foreign exchange transactions within the scope of general and special licenses granted by the licensing authorities. Prescription of Currency Payments to nonresidents, if eligible for transfer abroad, must be made through an authorized bank, either in guilders to the credit of a nonresident guilder account held with an authorized bank in the Nether- lands or to the debit of the authorized bank's currency holdings abroad. There are special regulations, however, for settlements with nonresidents in respect of officially listed guilder bonds (see section on Capital, below). Since there are no bilateral payments agreements, all foreign countries are included in the "convertible guilder area." Payments to countries in the convertible guilder area may be made in any foreign currency or in guil- ders to the credit of any nonresident account. Receipts from countries in the convertible guilder area may be obtained in any convertible currency or in guilders to the debit of a Convertible Guilder Account (see section on Nonresident Accounts, below); however, receipts may also be collected in other currencies, provided that the amounts received are deposited with the Netherlands Bank or an authorized bank. - Me rchan t ing t ran sac t ions i n v o l v i ng Rhodesia are p r o h i b i t e d. Most other transactions are freely permitted by v ir tue of general licenses granted to registered transit traders. The only merchanting transac- tions still subject to a specific license are purchases and sales of strategic goods and, w i th in the EEC, of scrap. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Payments between residents may be made freely in any foreign currency, provided that the amount involved is debited to a foreign currency account in the Nether- lands or abroad and is credited to a foreign currency account in the name of the beneficiary with an author- ized bank in the Netherlands. Nonresident Accounts The main categories of nonresident guilder accounts are as follows: 3 1. Convertible Guilder Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident. They may be credited with transfers from other Convertible Guilder Accounts, with permitted payments by residents of the Netherlands to residents of countries of the convertible guilder area, with proceeds from the sale of gold or convertible cur- rencies, and with Netherlands notes and coins remitted or deposited by nonresidents. They may be debited for payments to residents for exports and services rendered to any country and for other permitted transactions, including purchases of foreign currencies. Convertible Guilder Accounts may not be debited for the purchase of officially listed guilder bonds, Netherlands treasury paper, or guilder bank acceptances; they may not be credited with interest on demand deposits.4 Balances on these accounts may be transferred to any other non- resident account except O-Guilder Accounts. No time deposits may be established on Convertible Guilder Accounts. 2. O-Guilder Accounts. These accounts may be held by any nonresident and by those authorized banks and stockbrokers that have been designated authorized depositories. The accounts may be freely credited with (1) the guilder proceeds from the sale of officially listed guilder bonds by nonresidents to residents, and (2) amounts transferred from other O-Guilder Accounts. They may be freely debited for (1) purchases of offi- cially listed guilder bonds by nonresidents f rom residents, (2) amounts transferred to other O-Guilder Accounts, and (3) transfers to Convertible Guilder Accounts. Holders of O-guilders may free ly sell these to other nonresidents or to resident banks and stockbrokers, for foreign currency or convertible guilders. 3 Cer ta in balances and secur i t ies deposits be long ing to non re s iden ts residing in Indones ia are des igna ted W-accounts and W-deposits, respectively; t h e ir disposal must be licensed by the N e th e r l ands B a n k. With e f fect f rom May 7 the commission was set at zero per cent. NETHERLANDS Imports and Import Payments Imports from the Belgian-Luxembourg Economic Union are free from import licenses. Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Import licenses are required for imports originating in Hong Kong, Japan, and state trading countries, and for the import of goods of un- known origin. In addition, import licenses are required for a limited number of products mainly from the agricultural and textile sectors. Except for imports from Rhodesia, practically all imports that require an import license are free from quantitative restriction. Most imports f rom Eastern European countries are formally liberalized. Commodities corresponding to some 19 tariff headings or subheadings are subject to quantita- tive restriction when originating in Japan. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports; common EEC regulations are also applied to imports from non- EEC countries of most other agricultural and live- stock products. Certain agricultural imports of non- Benelux EEC origin or originating in third countries are subject to compensatory levies. Payments for imports may be made freely, provided that the method of payment conforms with the general prescription of currency regulations. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of imports of commodi- ties,5 but they require prior approval from the Nether- lands Bank to accept credit for periods in excess of those traditional in the trade concerned; such permis- sion is not normally granted. Payments for Invisibles Payments abroad for invisibles are permitted freely. Exchange for travel is provided in any currency and up to any amount, and the entire amount may be taken, if the traveler wishes, in Netherlands banknotes. A resi- dent traveling abroad may in addition have any further amounts remitted to him through banking channels. Exchange purchased for travel purposes must not be spent for other purposes; it may be used for purchases for personal use, however. Payments for interest, divi- dends, and contractual amortization due to nonresidents are permitted freely by crediting the appropriate non- resident account. The export of domestic or foreign banknotes by resi- dent travelers is not subject to limitation. Nonresidents may export all unutilized negotiable instruments and for- eign and Netherlands banknotes and coins which they have imported or have obtained in the Netherlands by drawing on their accounts or exchanging other curren- cies. The export of Netherlands silver coins by travelers is limited to f. 25 a person a trip; this limit is not appli- cable to 10-guilder coins.6 5 Commodities are so defined as to exclude gold. 6 With e f fect from January 1, 1973 silver coins ceased to be legal tender and the l im i ta t ion was revoked. 345 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS Exports and Export Proceeds Virtually all exports to Rhodesia are prohibited; those which are permitted require an export license. For exports to other countries, export licenses are required only for a number of commodities, mostly of a strategic character, and for some agricultural prod- ucts and scrap. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of ex- ports of commodities (see footnote 5 ), but they require prior permission f rom the Netherlands Bank to accept payment in advance of delivery where such advance payments are not traditional in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. The surrender of export proceeds is not obligatory, but any surrender that is made must be at the official rate. The collection of export proceeds through an authorized bank is obligatory. A license may be obtained to hold a fore ign currency account with a bank abroad, to which ac- count export proceeds may be credited. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts f r om inv is ib les must be collected th rough an au thor ized b ank but need not be su r rende red and may instead be credited to fo re ign currency accounts. A license may be obtained upon application to hold a fore ign cu r rency account with a bank abroad, to which account proceeds f rom invisibles may be credited. For incoming exchange exceeding f. 500 de- rived f rom current invisibles, the recipient must indicate to an authorized bank the na tu re of the unde r ly ing transaction, as well as the amount and currency received. Nonresidents may bring into the Ne the r lands un- l im i ted amoun ts in Ne the r lands bankno tes, fo re ign bank- notes, and negotiable ins trumen ts. These may be sold on ly to an authorized bank, to an authorized exchange office, or, in the case of fore ign banknotes, to an authorized depository, or they may be used to pay tour- ist expenses in the Netherlands. Residents are obliged to bring back to the Ne ther lands any unu t i l ized portion of the banknotes and coins that they took with them on the ir ou tward j o u r n e y; there is no l im i ta t ion on the amount in Ne ther lands or fore ign bankno tes and coins that they may b r ing in. Capital Inward and outward capital transfers and the shift- ing of foreign-owned capital within the Netherlands from one asset to another are subject to control, but general licenses have been granted for many types of capital transaction. Borrowing and lending abroad by bank and nonbank residents (with the exception of specified bank ing operations and of the granting of credit in respect of imports or exports of commodities) are restricted for reasons of capital market policy and, as far as borrowing is concerned, either to control the contracting of foreign debt by local authorities or for reasons of monetary and reserve policy. Apart from 346 guilder issues on the Netherlands capital market (see be low), most lending to nonresidents is liberally per- mitted. Borrowing abroad by nonbank residents is at present restricted in principle to amounts used for investments abroad (which is considered to include the purchase of ships and a ircraft abroad). Borrowing from nonresident banks by private industry and other non- bank residents is not normally permitted, and loans from other nonresident sources (except suppliers' credits with a maturity customary in the trade con- cerned) are subject to individual approval; licenses for borrowing abroad f rom nonbank nonresidents are granted on application, provided that the funds are used for direct investment abroad or for lending to nonresidents, but the Netherlands Bank in principle does not permit nonbank residents to take up financial credits abroad. There is a general license for loans up to f. 100,000 taken up by residents from nonresidents, provided that a resident in any calendar year does not borrow more than f. 100,000 from the same non- resident. A similar license has been issued for lending to nonresidents. Furthermore, a general license permits authorized banks to grant loans for up to 12 months to nonbank nonresidents and for any period to non- resident banks; authorized banks are on application granted licenses to lend to nonbank nonresidents for periods in excess of 12 months. Special regulations exist for borrowing and lending between head offices (in the Netherlands or abroad) of multinational com- panies and their branches and subsidiaries; at present, the Netherlands Bank does not permit financial loans to be taken up abroad w i th in a multinational company, except by resident subsidiaries located in regions where industrialization is being promoted by means of pre- miums. Nonbank residents are not normally permitted to purchase foreign treasury bills or other foreign short- term instruments. Nonresidents' purchases of Nether- lands treasury paper and guilder bank acceptances are prohibited. Capital transactions, whether freely per- mitted or not, must be notified to the Balance of Pay- ments Department of the Netherlands Bank; this is true also of all import credit in excess of one year and of advance payments in excess of f. 250,000 to be received for exports. Capital issues in the Netherlands on behalf of non- residents are restricted. During the last ten years, inter- national financial institutions and the authorities of the nonmetropolitan areas of the Kingdom of the Nether- lands have been the only nonresidents allowed to make bond issues denominated in guilders. Such issues are individually licensed by the Netherlands Bank in accordance with the prospects for the domestic capital market and the balance of payments. The Netherlands Bank, subject to certain conditions, allows nonresidents access to the debt certificate sector of the domestic capital market ( the market for onderhandse licensed to lead syndicates for the issue of med ium- term Euro-guilder notes, wh ich, if issued by nonresi- dents, may be acquired by nonresidents only and the proceeds of which must not be spent in the Nether- lands.7 Unless special permission to the con trary is obtained from the Ne the r lands B ank, authorized banks' foreign liabilities must not exceed the ir fore ign claims, i.e., they are not allowed to m a in t a in a negative net ex- ternal position. In observing th is regu la t ion, each bank has a leeway of f. 5 m i l l ion; the calculation of the net foreign position is based on the fore ign position in all currencies, in c lud ing guilders, and on the sum of short-term and long-term assets and liabilities. Sub- ject to this limitation, banks may f ree ly accept demand deposits from nonresidents, in domestic or foreign cur- rency, as well as time deposits in foreign currency. However, subject to m inor exemptions for physical persons, banks are prohibited f rom pay ing interest on nonresident-held guilder demand deposits and f rom accepting gu i lder t ime deposits from nonresidents.8 New capital inves tmen ts in the Netherlands by non- residents are in general permitted. Inward direct invest- ment is freely permitted and local borrowing by non- resident-owned or nonresident-controlled companies for use in the Netherlands also is freely permitted. The transfer abroad of the proceeds f rom the sale or liqui- dation of nonresident investments in indus tr ial enter- prises and other businesses established in the Nether- lands is freely permitted. Nonresidents may freely purchase real estate in the Netherlands for personal use or investment. Direct investment abroad by residents is authorized on application. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in officially listed guilder bonds ( inc lud ing mortgage bonds and "interest savings letters" but excluding guilder notes) are subject to special regulations. Trading in such bonds is unrestricted but nonresidents' purchases from residents must be financed with O-guilders (see Nonresident Accounts, above); nonresidents selling such bonds to residents may receive payment by credit either to an O-Guilder Account or to a Convertible Guilder Account. Accrued interest and brokerage on bonds purchased and sold must be settled in the same manner as the principal sum, as must stamp duty on transactions in the secondary market. Authorized banks and stockbrokers may freely deal in O-guilders among themselves and with nonresidents. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in foreign securities and domestic securities other than listed gu i lder bonds take place at official market rates and, with m inor exceptions, are unrestricted; the regu- lations concerning securities are not applicable to treasury bills. Residents may free ly purchase officially listed securities abroad, w i th the exception of guilder- denom ina ted Euro-bonds and medium-term Euro- gu i lder notes issued by nonresidents; foreign bonds denominated in guilders or otherwise linked to the pa r i ty of the guilder may be purchased free ly only when listed on the Ams te rdam stock exchange. Domes- tic and foreign securities held abroad by a resident are subject to a deposit requirement, but the Nether- lands B a nk grants exemptions on application; securi- ties held in the Netherlands are not subject to deposit. Residents may f ree ly purchase real estate abroad. G i f ts and donations to nonresidents are free.9 Emi- grants may export any amount in foreign and domes- tic currency. They acquire the status of nonresidents upon leaving the Netherlands, provided that they have declared their intention to settle abroad for more than three years, and may upon depar ture have remitted to them their total assets in the Netherlands. Gold The Ne the r lands Bank engages in gold transactions on ly w i th mone ta ry au tho r i t ies and in terna t ional f inan- cial in s t i tu t ion s. Imports and exports of gold require neither exchange licenses nor import and export licenses. There is a free gold ma rket in Ams te rdam. Changes during 1972 During the year, a considerable number of issues of Euro-guilder notes took place. Their amount in- creased from about f. 975 million in 1971 to about f. 1,275 million in 1972. The premium of the O-guilder reached a peak of 8Vi per cent on July 19, 1972. January 1. The stamp tax on foreign issues in the Netherlands of shares and guilder bonds was abolished. January 24. Payments in respect of insurance con- tracts ( l i fe insurance, damage insurance, and reinsur- ance) were included in the exchange control definition of current payments. As a result, such payments to nonresidents, whether they were current or capital pay- ments, were fu l ly liberalized and residents could with- out a license enter into agreements with nonresidents (in any currency) from which such payments could arise. For purposes of entering into insurance and reinsurance agreements, the representatives, branches, and agents of foreign insurance companies were put on an equal footing with domestic insurers; the "insur- ance accounts" in the names of foreign insurance com- panies had to be closed prior to March 1, 1972. February 9. The Netherlands Bank offered swap facilities to authorized banks under which it bought U. S. dollars spot against sales for delivery in one or three months. This policy was discontinued after a few days. March 7. The system of ceilings on domestic bank credit, which had been applied since Janua ry 1969, was suspended. It was abolished on Ju ly 20. March 9. General license No. PL 419, which in its amended form still allowed nonresidents to place guil- ders on time deposit with domestic banks, was revoked. (The license had been amended on June 1, 1971 to revoke the general permission allowing the sale to non- residents of domestic treasury paper and guilder bank acceptances against payment to the debit of Convertible Guilder Accounts.) Expiring time deposits could not be renewed ( inc lud ing "savings accounts," "savings deposits," and "reinvestment accounts," unless held by physical persons; these could continue to receive interest on balances up to f. 25,000 by virtue of a general license issued on March 14). March 9. The payment of interest on guilder demand deposits held by nonresidents was prohibited. (A par- tial prohibition had been in effect since May 21, 1971.) Balances held by physical persons were by a general license of March 14 exempted up to f. 25,000 each 10 Increased to 16 per cent w i th effect f rom J a n u a ry 1, 1973. 348 (f. 10,000 each for "interest giro accounts" and "salary accounts"). April 17. The Netherlands Bank announced that until further notice, and subject to certain unspecified quantitative limits, it was prepared to license the granting to nonresidents of guilder loans when made available outside the normal stock exchange or issue channels (loans in the form of debt certificates or onderhandse leningen). Final maturities should be at least ten years and amortization should take place in at least five annual installments. The proceeds, unlike those of Euro-guilder notes, could in part be spent in the Netherlands. No limitations were imposed with respect to the purposes for which such loans could be granted, but no licenses were issued for loans to foreign local authorities. Previously, nonresidents had not been allowed access to the market for onderhandse leningen. April 24. Narrower margins (up to 2V4 per cent either side of cross-parities) were observed for the cur- rencies of member countries of the EEC. Borrowing by resident subsidiaries and branches from nonresident head offices, which previ- ously was licensed either for three years fixed or, subject to equal annual repayments, for five years, was restricted to borrowing for at least five years fixed and with a head office participation of at least 50 per cent. July 17. Nonbank residents required a license to take up credits related to imports of goods when their maturity was in excess of traditional terms in the trade concerned. The existing notification requirement was maintained for contracts not requiring a license but in which the credit term exceeded one year. July 17. Nonbank residents required a license to accept payments in advance of delivery in respect of exports of goods when such advance payments were not traditional in the trade concerned. The existing notification requirement was maintained for contracts not requiring a license but in which the credit term exceeded one year. In addition, traditional advance payments now had to be notified to the Netherlands Bank, irrespective of the credit term, when their com- bined amount exceeded f. 250,000. July 17. The Netherlands Bank ceased in principle to issue licenses allowing nonbank residents to take up financial credits abroad, including long-term loans extended within a multinational corporation. Hence- forth, borrowing from nonresident head offices nor- mally was permitted only to resident subsidiaries located in regions where industrialization is being promoted by means of premiums. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles are not restricted. For most types of cu r rent invisibles remittances may be made freely th rough the authorized banks. Licenses are required, however, for the purchase of travel ex- change in excess of Ant. f. 200 a person for each day to be spent abroad and for certain personal rem i t tances in excess of Ant. f. 2,500 each or in excess of Ant. f. 10,000 a person a year. Such licenses are freely granted when no illegal capital t rans fer seems to be involved. For payments representing interest on loans or net income from other investments, and for amortiza- tion of loans or depreciation of direct investments, licenses are granted on application, subject to verifica- tion of the facts. Nonresidents may take w i th them on departure any foreign currency which they brought in on arrival. The export of Netherlands Antilles banknotes is limited to An t. f. 200 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses, which are usually granted. Capital Foreign investment in the Ne the r lands An t i l les requires a license, which is, in general, granted if the investment is in the economic and social interest of the islands; the Inves tment Incentives Program, as amended, provides for du ty - f ree entry of many commodities as well as tax fac i l i t ies. New industrial companies pr imar i ly engaged in exporting may be granted nonresident status by the central bank, which confers on the company concerned exemption f rom exchange control (except in its transactions w i th res iden ts), inc lud ing exemption from the requirement of surrendering their foreign currency receipts. Such exemption may also be granted to investment companies, pa tent holding companies, sh ipp ing companies, and insurance companies. Ou tward flows of resident-owned capital are subject to control, and certain capital transactions by or on behalf of residents are restricted. Life insurance con- tracts between residents and foreign insurance compa- nies for a m in imum term of ten years are licensed freely up to an amount which is fixed annua l ly, de- pending on the foreign exchange position. Investment by residents in real estate situated abroad requires a license. Investment in foreign securities (i.e., securities issued outside the Netherlands Antilles or payable or optionally payable in the currency of a country other than the Ne ther lands Antilles) requires a license only when exceeding Ant. f. 2,500 a transaction or Ant. f. 10,000 a person a year. Investments by residents in officially quoted foreign securities (other than shares in mu tual funds, investment in these not being per- m i t ted) are licensed freely up to amounts fixed annually, depending on the foreign exchange position. In consid- ering applications by such residents as pension funds and other institutional investors, the central bank takes into account the merits of each case and, in particular, the limited opportunity for domestic investment; the bank may exert moral suasion, however, to discourage excessive outflows of resident-owned capital. Author- ized banks may freely borrow foreign currency abroad from nonresidents (including residents w i th nonresident s ta tus ), or accept foreign currency deposits from non- residents, for relending to nonresidents or redeposit abroad; their borrowing f rom nonresidents for relending to residents is restricted for monetary policy reasons NETHERLANDS ANTILLES and banks requ i re central bank approval to incur a net foreign liability position. Nonresidents are not normally permitted to acquire balances in Netherlands Antilles guilders. Local borrowing in domestic currency by non- residents ( inc lud ing resident companies regarded as nonresidents for exchange control purposes) is re- stricted. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in the Ne ther lands Antilles for num isma t ic and investment purposes; authorized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and w i th other residents. Resi- dents other than the mone tary au thor i t ies and authorized industrial users are not allowed without special permis- sion to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Changes during 1972 January 3. The import into Aruba, Bonaire, and Curacao of a wide range of commodities required a license except when for personal use and valued at Ant. f. 100 or less. They included many foods tuffs, Pharmaceuticals, cigarettes, alcoholic beverages, cement, and new passenger automobiles. Licenses were issued only to firms holding an operating permit. January 10. Licenses issued by the central bank ceased to be required for imports of passenger auto- mobiles valued at over US$5,000. March 17. It was announced that with effect from April 1 the tax on sales of foreign exchange and on credits of domestic currency to nonresident accounts was being changed to a uniform rate of %0 of 1 per cent; previously, the tax was expressed in cents per currency unit (e.g., An t. f. 0.015 per US$1) and hence varied slightly for d ifferent currencies. Furthermore, banks would have to specify the tax separately rather than including it in the exchange rates they quoted to the public. March 22. The central bank issued a written sum- mary of directives concerning exchange licenses, to enter into effect on April 1. No significant changes in exchange policy were involved. The directives were intended essentially as guidelines incorporating certain earlier oral directives to banks. Also, additional forms were introduced on which applications in writing had to be made for individual exchange licenses; previously the latter had often been granted by telephone and subse- quently confirmed on a form. Individual licenses only were required where the size and /or nature of the transaction could have a significant impact on the level 351 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS ANTILLES or composition of the exchange reserves. Residents and nonresidents could freely take out or bring in domestic banknotes up to Ant. f. 200 a person a trip. Payments and transfers in respect of current interna- tional transactions remained unrestricted. Capital trans- actions that required an individual license when exceed- ing Ant. f. 2,500 per transaction or Ant. f. 10,000 a per- son a year included gifts, disbursements of inheritances, and purchases and sales of foreign securities. April 14. Residents of the islands of Saba, St. Eusta- tius, and St. Maarten could freely open accounts in U. S. dollars with local banks. Such accounts could not be used, however, for settlements with persons or firms established in Aruba, Bonaire, or Curasao. April 14. Banks established in St. Maarten could freely credit domestic currency to accounts in the names of residents of the French part of the island, but no such account could show a total balance in excess of Ant. f. 10,000 unless the approval of the central bank was obtained. May 2. Additional w r i t ten directives concerning ex- change licenses were issued. These provided that all bank credit in domestic currency to nonresidents (in- cluding residents treated as nonresidents for exchange control purposes) henceforth required the prior ap- proval of the central bank. Banks no longer required prior approval to open domestic currency accounts for nonresidents with initial balances of Ant. f. 10,000 or less, provided that they were confident the nonresident concerned had a legitimate interest in the Netherlands Antilles. Such accounts could be used for demand de- posits, savings deposits, or time deposits. Payments by residents to the credit of such accounts were subject to the exchange tax. The tax was also levied on balances on resident accounts when transferred to nonresident guilder accounts in the name of the same holder. May 2. Local bank credit in domestic currency to non- residents (including residents treated as nonresidents for exchange control purposes), which already was sub- ject to individual license, henceforth was restricted. September 30. The central bank issued certain clari- fications concerning the above-mentioned measure of September 1. For purposes of that directive, invest- ment and finance companies established in the Nether- lands Antilles but effecting all operations abroad were considered nonresidents. However, administration and trust offices established and effectively operating in the Netherlands Antilles and industrial and other firms operating there were considered residents even if they had been declared nonresidents for exchange control purposes. Except for the Australian dollar, the Fiji dollar, and the Western Samoa tala, the rates for spot transactions in other currencies quoted by the New Zealand trading (commercial) banks, including the pound sterling, are based on the closing buying and selling rates of the previous day in London. The trading banks are permitted to conclude with their customers forward exchange contracts in U. S. and Canadian dollars and sterling for up to 12 months to cover trade transactions. S. dollars are concluded at the relative spot rates, adjusted with a loading of US$0.0018 a month on contracts covering exports. Forward contracts covering imports are concluded at spot rates. The Reserve Bank provides a facility whereby trading banks may obtain day-to-day cover for their net positions in these cur- rencies, spot and forward. Contracts in other currencies may be covered through the London or New York foreign exchange markets, against sterling or U. S. dollars. Most contractual obligations incurred in the ordinary course of business also are normally approved, but each remittance requires approval and new com- mitments such as royalty agreements with overseas licensors or overseas borrowing require the prior consent of the Reserve Bank. A New Zealand resident owning over- seas securities is free to sell them to overseas residents for any foreign currency, which may be reinvested in other overseas securities, surrendered, or retained at the disposal of the New Zealand resident. With limited exceptions, sales of overseas securities by one New Zealand resident to another may be made only in exchange for other overseas securities or for any over- seas currency. Overseas securities that may be traded between New Zealand residents in exchange for New Zealand currency are those of any overseas country which were registered in the names of New Zealand residents on June 16, 1966 and for which scrip or other documents evidencing title were issued; the purchaser must lodge the share scrip with an approved depository (i.e., the Reserve Bank of New Zealand). These securi- ties may also be sold for any overseas currency, in which case the proceeds must immediately be remitted to New Zealand through the banking system or rein- vested in other overseas securities within three months and the resulting scrip deposited.
