Not for Redistribution Exports and Export Proceeds The Banco Minero del Peru has a monopoly over the export of precious metals, uncut precious stones, and pearls, and the Empresa M ine ra del Peru (M INEROPERU) has a monopoly over all other min- eral exports. Coffee exports are controlled by EPSA. All exports are subject to license to assure the neces- sary supply of export proceeds to the certificate market. Export proceeds must be received in U. S. dollars. Traditional exports must be sold against an irrevocable letter of credit confirmed by a bank established in Peru; the latter must surrender the foreign exchange proceeds within ten working days of payment. In special cases, and with the authorization of the Central Reserve Bank and the Directorate of Foreign Trade, exports may be sold against sight draf ts, provided that payment is received within 180 days of shipment. Ex- porters of non t rad i t ional exports are granted transfer- able tax credit certificates equivalent to 15-30 per cent of the c.i.f. va lue (of the f.o.b. value when the goods are shipped in fore ign vesse ls). These certificates may be used by the exporter in payment of his tax obliga- tions or may be sold to other taxpayers, who may use them for the same purpose. Proceeds from Invisibles Public sector entities must surrender their fu ll receipts at the certificate rate. All other receipts from invisibles must be sold in the d ra ft market. Travelers may not bring in more than S/. 1,000 in Peruvian currency. Capital All outward capital transfers require prior approval. In addition to government payments, certain capital payments on pr iva te account may be effected through the certificate market. The use of exchange certificates may be authorized for the amortization of foreign loans contracted by the private sector, provided that the for- eign exchange proceeds of the loan have been surren- dered to the Central Reserve Bank. Where such debt was contracted before October 9, 1967, certificate exchange may be allotted by the Central Reserve Bank only to public u t i l i ty enterprises, to earners of foreign exchange, for payment of debts to international organi- zations, and for payments of debts guaranteed by the State. The proceeds of all foreign loans received after June 17, 1971 must be converted in the certificate market; amortization and service payments in respect of these loans are also settled through the certificate market. Payments in connection with all other loans that were not channeled through the certificate market before June 17, 1971 must be transferred through the draft market. Foreign investment in Peru is governed by Decree- Law No. 18900 of June 30, 1971, which ratified the Andean Common Market's policy on the treatment of PERU foreign capital, by Decree-Law No. 18999 of October 19, 1971, and by Decree-Law No. 19232, Decree-Law No. 19307, Decree-Law No. 19971, and the legislation ru l- ing the Peruv ian exchange system. All foreign investments in Peru requ i re the prior approval of the competent authorities w i th a view to channeling such investments to projects considered essential for the coun try's devel- opment. If they wish to enjoy for the ir p roduc ts the ad- vantages der iv ing from the du ty-free program of the Cartagena Agreemen t, foreign companies incorporated in Peru as at December 30, 1970, have to agree, within a period of 3 years, to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in such companies so as to transfer them to mixed or national companies du r ing a maxi- mum period of 15 years following the entering into effect of this regime. For this purpose, mixed com- panies are defined as those in which national investors hold between 51 per cent and 80 per cent of the capital, while national companies are those in which at least 80 per cent of the capital is owned by national investors. Upon expiration of the 3-year period, the participation of national investors in the capital of an enterprise has to amount to not less than 15 per cent; this participation must increase to at least 45 per cent after 10 years and to at least 51 per cent at the end of the 15-year period. In the case of foreign com- panies established in Peru af ter June 30, 1971, the 15 per cent participation by national investors must be secured at the time of the initiation of production. For- eign investments in firms engaged in basic industries and in those which export at least 80 per cent of their production to countries outside the Andean Common Market are exempt from the gradual transfer require- ment to mixed companies; however, these enterprises do not benefit from the duty-free program of the Cartagena Agreement. Investment in the mining sector is governed by the General Mining Law (Decree-Law No. 18880) of June 8, 1971, which replaced the Mining Code of May 12, 1950. Companies holding mining concessions may enter into mining contracts with the Government pro- viding for special incentives and guarantees or may constitute mixed enterprises with government partici- pation of at least 25 per cent. Under the regime of mining contracts, the Government may grant to mining concessionaires initiating large-scale investment pro- grams tax incentives and guaranteed availability of foreign exchange for transfers of (a) recovery of investment; (b) interest payments if the rate does not exceed the prime rate prevailing in the financial market from which the loans originate; (c) payments for justi- fied services; and (d) reasonable profit remittances, together with guaranteed access to the most favorable exchange rate. Mixed mining enterprises may receive all the benefits and incentives which may be granted by special contract and, in addition, special tax reductions. 383 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU Gold The marketing of precious metals and their import and export are governed by Decree-Law No. 18882 of June 15, 1971 and Supreme Decree No. 065-71-EF of the same date. The import and export of precious metals and stones are the monopoly of the Banco Minero del Peru. All imports and exports of gold are settled in the certificate market. The authorities do not make foreign exchange available for imports of gold other than by the monetary authorities and by authorized industrial and professional users. Domes- tic sales and purchases of gold may be carried out by industrial and professional users, provided that they hold licenses issued by the Banco Minero del Peru, but only MINEROPERU is authorized to make the initial purchase of newly mined gold and other precious metals. Residents traveling abroad may not take out jewelry valued at over S/. 50,000 unless it has been registered with the customs (S/. 15,000 for trips to bordering countries). Changes during 1972 During 1972, the buying and selling rates in both exchange markets remained unchanged. A large num- ber of commodities were added to the National Register of Manufactured Products. January 6. Decree-Law No. 19262 amended the General Industrial Law on those points where the original text conflicted with the Andean Pact rules on foreign investments. January 11. Decree-Law No. 19266 extended until April 10, 1972 the deadline for the declaration, repa- triation, and surrender of foreign assets held at home or abroad. January 25. Decree-Law No. 19271 made the impor- tation of many goods subject to prior authorization by the Ministry of Agriculture or the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. February 10. Supreme Decree No. 023-72-EF added a wide range of commodities to the list of prohibited imports. These included cheese, fruits, beer, cider, wines, cigars, stationery products, certain skins and hides, and toys. April 25. Supreme Decree No. 070-72-EF provided that the approval of the competent sectoral ministry was required before the Banco de la Nacion could authorize the conversion into foreign currency, for transfer abroad, of the liquidation proceeds of assets in Peru owned by nonresident foreigners. May 10. Supreme Decree No. 076-72-EF approved the statutes of the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector. June 21. Supreme Resolution No. 408-72-IC/DS provided for the establishment of a commission to study the means for detecting and penalizing the illegal 384 transfer of foreign exchange in connection with the purchase and sale of goods and services abroad. July 11. Supreme Decree No. 032-72-IC/DS entitled exporters of handicraft articles to a tax credit on the same basis as exporters of nontraditional manufactures. July 11. Supreme Decree No. 142-72-EF provided that the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector would henceforth approve the sale of annual amounts of foreign exchange for all private sector imports that, on the basis of importers' annual import requests, had obtained the prior authorization of the competent sectoral ministries. The Board would also adjust the amounts of foreign exchange it made avail- able for imports so as to take into account any addi- tional import authorizations issued by these ministries during the course of the year. August 1. Decree-Law No. 19491 provided that exports of nontraditional agricultural commodities were to be given incentives similar to those granted to non- traditional manufactures. August 7. The use of suppliers' credit became manda- tory for imports of capital goods valued at over US$10,000. Only 20 per cent of the f.o.b. invoice value of such imports could be paid in cash; the remainder had to be settled in installments, with the prescribed minimum period (af ter final shipment) for the first and the last installment ranging from three months and two years after shipment for goods valued at US$10,001 to US$50,000 to 12 months and five years af ter ship- ment for goods valued at US$400,001 to US$1 million. Imports of machinery and equipment valued at over US$1 million were subject to special payment sched- ules approved by the Board for Foreign Transactions of the Private Sector. Such imports valued at US$10,000 or less could be freely arranged between importer and exporter. October 1. By virtue of Supreme Resolution No. 0208-72-PE of September 21, the export of fish meal and fish oil was suspended. (The suspension was lifted on March 21, 1973 by Supreme Resolution No. 0033-73-PE.) October 12. Decree-Law No. 19568 introduced an export credit guarantee system, to be administered by the Banco de la Nacion. November 15. Supreme Decree No. 275-72-EF cen- tralized in the High Committee of the External Debt the approval authority for the contracting of external loans by the public sector. The Committee was to be set up and chaired by the Minister of Economy and Finance. November 28. Supreme Decree No. 284-72-EF implemented Decree-Law No. 19568. November 28. Decree-Law No. 19625 established in the Industrial Bank a Fund for Nontraditional Exports. This Fund's operations were to include the direct ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU financing of nontraditional exports, the extension of credit to financial intermediaries for the financing of such exports, and the opening of lines of credit in favor of foreign entities for the import of Peruvian nontradi- tional exports. November 28. Decree-Law No. 19620 replaced (with effect from January 1, 1973) the stamp taxes on goods and services with a single ad valorem tax, levied at various rates, on production, imports, exports, whole- saling, and services. The standard rate on exports would be 3 per cent, with a reduced rate of 2 per cent for refined and unrefined minerals and a full exemption for nontraditional exports. The standard rate on imports would be 15 per cent, with a reduced rate of 1 per cent for some essentials and a rate of 25 per cent for some luxury goods, and a full exemption for certain food and livestock items. The rate applicable to inter- national air fares would be 7 per cent for first class or 3 per cent for economy class. December 12. Decree-Law No. 19832 transferred the control of coffee exports to EPSA. December 27. Decree-Law No. 19863 amended the Industrial Law and postponed from December 31, 1972 to June 30, 1974 the date by which foreign-owned industrial companies must sign contracts with the State setting out the terms for their transformation into mixed-capital or national companies. December 31. Decree-Law No. 19852 of Decem- ber 26 introduced a new customs tariff using the cus- toms nomenclature of the Andean Group. The ad valorem import tax of 2 per cent and the 10 per cent import surcharge were consolidated with the existing ad valorem rates. 385 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES Exchange Rate System * The par va lue is 0.227864 gram of fine gold per Philippine Peso. All exchange t ransac t ions take place in a free marke t. The Bankers' Association establishes daily a "guiding rate"; d u r i ng 1972 th is rate depreciated f rom P 6.435 to about P 6.78 per U. S. dollar. In spot transactions w i th their customers, commercial banks are required by the Association to observe certain mar- gins. The max imum and m in imum spot buy ing rates are % per cent and 1 per cent below the guiding rate, respectively. The m in imum and max imum spot selling rates are % per cent and H4 per cent above the guid- ing rate, respectively. The Central Bank, wh ich is not governed by the Association's t r ad ing rules, makes its own purchases and sales of foreign exchange w i th in the above marg ins required by the Association. Neither the Central Bank nor the commercial banks quote curren- cies other than the U. S. dollar. Interbank trading takes place at the Foreign Exchange Trading Center (FOREX ), where the Central Bank f rom time to time acts as a buyer or supplier. D ifferent effective exchange rates arise f rom a stabilization tax of 6 per cent or 4 per cent on proceeds f rom specified major exports. Administration of Control Exchange regulations are administered by the Central Bank. The Central Bank issues circulars and memo- randa to the authorized agent banks on the basis of policy decisions reached by the Monetary Board. Cer- tain new foreign direct or portfolio investment in the Philippines requires the prior approval of the Board of Investments. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements for outgoing payments, but all exchange proceeds from exports must be obtained in Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Nether- lands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, or U. S. dollars. Most payments and transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Bank accounts denominated in pesos may be opened in the name of nonresidents, whether individual or cor- porate, without prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresident accounts are permitted to be credited only with the proceeds from inward remittances of foreign exchange or convertible foreign currencies and with peso income from, or peso proceeds of conversion of, properties (real or personal) located in the Philippines belonging to nonresidents. Nonresident accounts may be freely debited for peso withdrawals. However, with- * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, the authorities decided to maintain the rate for the U. S. dollar at about-P 6.78. 386 drawals from nonresident accounts for t rans fer abroad are subject to ind iv idual application with supporting evidence, and to established limits where applicable, such as in the case of emigrants. Both residents and nonres iden ts may under certain circumstances ma in ta in foreign currency accounts with authorized agent banks in the Philippines (see section on Proceeds f rom Invisibles, be low). Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia and South Afr ica are pro- hibited. Imports of certain agricultural commodities f rom any source are prohibited for protective reasons. There are no other quan t i ta t ive restrictions on imports (o ther th an imports of go ld ); however, payment for imports of specified commodities is subject to prior approval of the Cen tral Bank. Such approval is granted on a case-by-case basis for commodities classified under three consumer goods categories (unclassified, semiun- classified, and nonessential consumer goods) or for com- pletely knocked-down parts for automobile assembly plants. Paymen ts for imports of certain other commodi- ties (wheat, raw cotton, leaf tobacco, and tallow) are permitted only if they are financed through certain offi- cial credit arrangements. Payments for imports of non- agricultural machinery and equipment in excess of US$50,000 a month by importers other than certified export-oriented firms are allowed only if prescribed certification from the Board of Investments (BOI) has been obtained. As a method of payment, commodities may be imported against letters of credit, on a documents against acceptance (D /A) basis, or under open account (O /A) arrangements. The use of the D/A and O/A procedures is limited mainly to firms with a history of importing under these arrangements prior to February 21, 1970 and to such others as may be approved by the Central Bank. Unless arrangements for such terms of credit are made, imports in excess of US$100 must be covered by letters of credit opened on or before the day of shipment. Imports financed by importers' own foreign exchange or not involving payments from the Philippines (so-called no-dollar imports) are allowed subject to prescribed conditions. Such permissible no-dollar imports are exempt from the requirement of opening letters of credit. At the request of an authorized agent bank or other financial institution, a firm may be "watch listed" by the Central Bank for arrears on its loan repayment commitments. A firm thus "watch listed" may not open import letters of credit without the approval of the Central Bank, which will allow the opening of letters of credit only a f ter a schedule for the repayment of overdue obligations has been agreed upon. Further- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution more, it is the practice of certain authorized agent banks to require a 100 per cent deposit against the opening of letters of credit, compared with 50 per cent in normal cases. Payments for Invisibles Virtually all paymen ts to Rhodesia are prohibited. In principle, all other payments are permitted, w i thout prior approval of the Central Bank, provided that amounts of more than US$100 are substantiated by documentary evidence regarding the purpose and the amount applied for. However, there are certain limits established by the Central Bank for purchases of for- eign exchange for travel abroad by residents, remit- tances for educational expenses, ma in tenance and expenses of dependents abroad of residents, remittances of profits, dividends, and interest, royalties, and film and other rentals (see be low). Exchange for travel abroad is made available as follows: ( 1) US$25 a day, up to a maximum of US$750 a trip (for exporters an additional representation allowance of US$500) for each person for business or professional travel; (2) US$500 a year for each adult resident for nonbusiness travel to A f r ica, North and South America, Australia, Europe, Japan, the Middle East, and New Zealand; and (3) US$200 a year for each adult resident for non- business travel to Guam, Hong Kong, Okinawa, the Republic of China, or any other neighboring country. Foreign travel by Philippine citizens, however, is not normally permitted. The following limits apply to exchange for educa- tional expenses abroad: for studies in the United States, US$250 a month for living and other out-of-school expenses, plus the cost of tuition, books, laboratory fees, and other school charges; for studies in Australia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand, US$200 a month; and for studies in other areas, US$150 a month. Any scholarship allowances are deducted from these amounts. Remittances for educational expenses and student maintenance abroad are allowed only to stu- dents working for a degree at duly accredited colleges or universities. The following limits apply for remittances to depend- ents of residents: US$250 a month for each dependent living in the United States; US$200 a month for each dependent living in Australia, Europe, Japan, and New Zealand; and US$100 a month for each dependent liv- ing in other areas. The maintenance allowances for dependents are allowed only for close relatives under certain conditions prescribed by the Central Bank. Remittances of profits and dividends (net of taxes) accruing to nonresidents are permitted in full for invest- ments in resident companies engaged in projects approved by the Board of Investments or in export- oriented industries. Export-oriented firms whose opera- tions include logging are certified as not fully export oriented if log exports exceed 20 per cent of total export earnings. For such firms, net profit remittances PHILIPPINES are allowed to the extent of (a) 100 per cent of the nonresident share in net proceeds pertaining to non- logging operations and (b) 25 per cent of the nonresi- dent share of net profits pertaining to logging opera- tions. For other industries, remittances of profits and dividends in fu ll are also permitted, provided that resident companies either do not avail themselves of domestic credit resources or are controlled by Philip- pine residents. In all other cases, remittances of profits and dividends accruing to nonresidents are allowed up to an amount of 25 per cent of their equity participa- tion (net of taxes). Remittances of royalties or rentals on patents, trade- marks, and copyrights are permitted up to 50 per cent of the royalties or rentals incurred during the year, provided that the royalties do not exceed 5 per cent of the wholesale price of the commodity which is manu- factured locally under the royalty contract. Remittances of the producer's shares of earnings made on motion- picture films and rentals on television films are per- mitted up to 50 per cent of the shares or rentals. Foreign exchange within the above l im i ts may be purchased, without prior approval of the Central Bank, for current payments for invisibles administratively withheld prior to November 26, 1969. Applications for certain invisibles for which no basic allowance has been set are considered on their merits by the Central Bank. No person may take out or export from the Philip- pines foreign currency or any other foreign exchange except as authorized by the Central Bank. Residents may take out, as part of their travel allowance, up to US$100 in foreign banknotes. Nonresident travelers may take out any amount of foreign currency that they had previously brought in and declared, minus any amounts converted into pesos. Resident and nonresi- dent travelers require prior authorization from the Central Bank to take out more than P 500 in domestic currency, of which not more than P 5 may consist of domestic silver and/or nickel coins. Citizens of the Philippines and permanent resident aliens, when travel- ing abroad, must pay a travel tax of P 400 for first- class ship or plane tickets or P 300 for any other ticket. Exempt are, among others, foreign diplomatic staff and Filipino muslims making their first pilgrim- age to Mecca. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia of petroleum products and mili- tary equipment and supplies are prohibited. Exports of certain strategic materials and items deemed essential for industrialization and economic development are also prohibited. Otherwise, exports are generally not restricted, but they are regulated to ensure that the foreign exchange proceeds are surrendered to an author- ized agent of the Central Bank. Authorized agent banks issue the necessary export permits upon registration of the exporter's report of foreign sales; reports of foreign 387 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PHILIPPINES sales for copra and coconut oil, however, are approved for registration only by the Central Bank. Banks must sell to the Central Bank 10 per cent of their exchange receipts from export bills. As a general rule, no commodity may be exported unless it is covered by a draft drawn in one of the prescribed currencies and unless collection of the pro- ceeds will be undertaken by an authorized agent bank; however, payment by means of telegraphic transfer, check, or mail transfer may be allowed. Payments for exports on a cash, collection, or consignment basis must be arranged through an authorized agent bank, which must specifically contract with the exporter to buy the exchange proceeds. No shipment of exports will be allowed by the customs unless a certificate is issued by a bank stating that payment has been received or arranged by the bank. Proceeds from exports must be received in the prescribed currencies within 30 days from the date of shipment (or within such period as may be established in special cases) and surrendered to the agent bank within 3 business days of receipt. An irrevocable letter of credit is required for exports of scrap metals, copra, and coconut oil, and for all exports to Guam, Hong Kong, the Republic of China, Indonesia, and Japan. Exports of perishable commodi- ties to Hong Kong require prepayment. Under an "export deduction" scheme, export-oriented industries are allowed, subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank, to use a part of their export pro- ceeds for the repayment of the loans obtained for their imports of machinery, equipment, raw materials, and other requirements. A stabilization tax is levied on the proceeds from major exports. The rate is 6 per cent for logs, copra, centrifugal sugar, and copper ore and concentrates, and 4 per cent on gold, molasses, coconut oil, dessicated co- conut, iron ore and concentrates, chromite ore and con- centrates, copra meal or cake, unmanufac tured abaca, unmanufac tured tobacco, veneer core and sheets, ply- wood, lumber, canned pineapples, bunker fuel oil, bananas, portland cement, and petroleum pitch and residues. All other commodities whose total f.o.b. export value has not exceeded US$5 million in any calendar year since May 1, 1970 are exempt from this tax. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be sold within three business days by the recipient to an authorized agent bank. Philippine nationals employed abroad are per- mitted to open U. S. dollar deposit accounts with the Central Bank or authorized agent banks, in which they may retain any U. S. dollars they remit to the Philip- pines. To be eligible for credit to such accounts at the Central Bank, earn ings must be transferred through Ph i l ipp ine d ip loma t ic or consular establishments. Under a foreign currency deposit scheme, inward remittances by residents or nonresidents of foreign currencies for 388 deposit in numbered foreign currency accounts are exempt from surrender requirements, provided that the remittances do not represent current earnings or income of residents nor payments by nonresidents pur- suant to con trac tual obligations. Balances in such accounts are free ly transferable abroad. Travelers may freely bring in any amount of foreign currency and up to 9 500 in domestic currency, of which not more than P 50 may consist of Philippine coins. Capital All inward and outward capital movements, with the exception of certain transactions related to financing of international trade (see below), are subject to the prior and specific approval of the Central Bank. Vir- tually all paymen ts and transfers to Rhodesia are pro- hibited. For the purpose of the approval of new inward foreign investments (in kind or in cash) as well as new foreign borrowings, preference is given to projects approved by the Board of Investments (BOI), export- oriented industries, and other (nonexport-oriented) industries not utilizing domestic credit resources. There are certain restrictions on sales of foreign exchange for the repatriation of foreign direct investments, depending upon the category of industry where the investment is made. Investments in BOI-approved industries and in nonexport-oriented industries not utilizing domestic credit resources may be repatriated in five equal annual installments beg inn ing two years after the commence- ment of production. Repatriation of investment in export-oriented industries may start one year after the commencement of production; however, annual install- ments may not exceed net foreign exchange earnings. Investments in all other industries may be repatriated in ten equal installments beg inn ing two years after the commencement of production, if previously approved by and registered with the Central Bank. Commercial banks may not receive credit from abroad other than credit arising from normal international trade transactions. Residents may obtain suppliers' credits from abroad provided that repayment terms are within the limits prescribed by the Central Bank. The ma tur i ty may not be less than 5 years for amounts up to $250,000, not less than 8 years for amounts between $250,000 and $500,000, and not less than 12 years for amounts greater than $500,000. For export industries, amounts exceeding $500,000 are approved if the credit has a ma tur i ty of at least 8 years, inclusive of a 3-year grace period on repayment of principal. Interest rates may not be more than 2 per cent above the prime rate of the lending country. Applications are not approved if the proposed project expands capacity in an industry deemed to be overcrowded, or for firms which are in arrears with government financial institutions. Sales of foreign exchange for amortization of loans are per- mitted in accordance with the terms of loan contracts approved by the Central Bank. The same applies for loan contracts registered with the Central Bank prior ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution to November 26, 1969. For those not fa l l ing under these two categories, prior approval by the Central Bank is required for sales of foreign exchange for repayment of loans. Emigrants may repatriate up to US$5,000, subject to verification by the Central Bank. The remaining liquid assets may be withdrawn in five years beginning one year from emigration. Except as otherwise specifically authorized, resident persons, firms, or corporations may not enter into any contract or transaction which may involve settlement in fore ign exchange, or involving any assets belonging to them expressed in foreign currencies or payable or deliverable abroad. This restriction also applies to con- tracts or transactions involving assets within the Philip- pines belonging to a nonresident person, firm, or cor- poration, and to their exportation or importation. Detailed regulations are in force concerning transactions in securities between residents and nonresidents. Under the Investment Incentives Act of 1967, all investors in enterprises registered with the Board of Investments are guaranteed the right to repatriate their investments, and to remit earnings thereon and sums needed to meet payments of principal and interest on foreign loans; they are also guaranteed freedom from expropriation and requisition. There are different arrangements for "pioneer investments" and "preferred investments"; the former are granted certain incentives over and above those given to preferred investments. Normally, enterprises owned or controlled by for- eigners are permitted to operate only in "pioneer areas of investment," and normally at least 60 per cent of the vo t ing capital stock of registered enterprises in "preferred areas of investment" (mainly investments related to the exploitation of export-oriented natural resources and the manu fac tu r ing of import substitutes) must be owned by Philippine nationals. By virtue of the Laurel-Langley Agreement, U. S. citizens, corporations, and associations are given the same status for this pur- pose as Philippine citizens un t il July 1974. Under the Foreign Investment Law of 1968, new enterprises in which investment by non-Filipinos exceeds 30 per cent and which are not covered by the Investment Incentives Act must obtain authority from the Board of Investments in order to engage in any economic activity in the Philippines. If purchases of shares of common stock by foreign nationals would reduce Philippine ownership in a firm to less than 30 per cent, permission from the Board must first be obtained. Gold Producers of gold must sell their entire output to the Central Bank at the equivalent of US$38 an ounce (calculated at P 3.90 per U. S. dollar) to be eligible for assistance under the Gold Industry Assistance Act (Republic Act No. 3089, as amended by Republic Act PHILIPPINES No. 6364 of August 5, 1971), irrespective of whether this gold is a by-product or the principal or only product of their operations. However, gold producers who wish to take advantage of the floating exchange rate (the "guiding rate") in lieu of the subsidy must export their gold production, subject to prior licensing by the Central Bank.1 Residents other than the mone- tary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to purchase gold abroad in any form other than jewelry. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Central Bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Circular No. 340, pu rsuant to Monetary Board Resolution No. 629, established new guidelines for fore ign exchange trad ing. It required all interbank foreign exchange transactions to be conducted in the FOREX. Transactions must be made at rates agreed between the buyer and seller banks but kept within 4y2 per cent above or below the guiding rate. The gu id ing rate for the t rad ing day would be posted daily by the Central Bank, and would be the weighted average of all spot exchange rates du r ing the previous day (or the last day when transactions took p lace). April 13. The Central Bank ins truc ted the Philippine National Bank and the Development Bank of the Philip- pines to acqu ire exchange for rice impor ts and for debt servicing, respectively, in the FOREX. Previously, the Central Bank had made direct exchange sales to them for these purposes. April 24. Central Bank Circular No. 343 was issued to implement Republic Act No. 6426, the Foreign Currency Deposit Act. The Act, revoking all legislation inconsistent with any of its provisions, authorized designated Philippine commercial banks and Philippine branches of foreign banks to accept deposits in foreign currencies that were acceptable as part of the country's international reserves, and to accept such foreign cur- rencies in trus t. Banks could issue and discount certifi- cates to evidence such deposits, accept these deposits as collateral for loans, and pay interest in foreign currency on such deposits up to a maximum of 14 per cent per annum. Banks were required to hold 100 per cent foreign currency cover against these deposit liabilities, of which at least 15 per cent must be in the form of a foreign currency deposit with the Central Bank. Cover could also consist of foreign currency loans and short-term foreign currency securi- ties; the former could, subject to Monetary Board guidelines, be extended also to domestic firms, provided these were export oriented or registered with the BOI. Interest on foreign currency deposits was payable in foreign currency and, when earned by nonresidents, exempt from income tax. April 26. The guiding peso-dollar rate, which had been stabilized at P 6.435 = US$1 un t il early April, was again stabilized, at the ruling level of P 6.78 = US$1. April 28. Previously, peso sales proceeds could not be converted into foreign exchange either for redeposit or for remittance abroad. July 28. Monetary Board Resolution No. 1350 eased the rules that had restricted D /A and O /A payments for imports. Imports on these terms now were permitted to producer firms as follows: (a) those with a history of regular D/A and O/A imports as of February 21, 1970; (b) those established after this date and author- ized by the Monetary Board to import end-use require- ments; (c) those without a history of D /A and O /A imports prior to February 21, 1970 but certified by the Central Bank as export oriented, registered with the Board of Investments, or being franchised public utility concerns. Permitted payment terms under D/A and O/A arrangements remained limited to 360 days. A central rate of Esc 27.25000 per US$1 has been established, corresponding to Esc 29.5857 = SDR 1, and Portugal avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Portugal observes limits for the U. S. dollar of Esc 26.637 buying, and Esc 27.863 selling, per U. S. dollar. Exchange rates for the other cur- rencies quoted by the Bank of Po r tug a lI are based on the re la t ive exchange rates in the in te rna t ional exchange markets; the Bank of Portugal's quoted rates are for dealings w i th the pub l ic only, and its sales to the commercial banks are made at 0.2 per cent below the quoted rates. Neither the Bank of Portugal nor the commercial banks charge buying and selling commissions but there is a tax of 0.15 per cent on all sales of foreign exchange. For settlements with coun- tries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agree- ments,2 the U. S. dollar rate applies to transactions in ''agreement dollars" (for Greece, Israel, and Turkey) and the pound sterling rate to transactions in "agree- ment pounds sterling" (for Po land ), while fixed exchange rates apply to other agreement currencies. Authorized banks may deal in foreign exchange with the Bank of Portugal. They are also normally allowed to deal in foreign exchange w i th banks abroad at the rates prevailing in the Portuguese foreign exchange marke t, but they are not expected to solicit such transactions in foreign marke ts and may be required to j u s t i fy the amounts of their sales of escudos to nonresidents. They are not allowed to buy and sell foreign exchange among themselves, or to enter in to arbitrage operations in foreign markets. In dealing with their customers, the authorized banks buy and sell foreign exchange in convertible currencies for their own account; their purchases and sales of b i la te ral agreement currencies are made for the account of the Bank of Portugal. Purchases and sales of unquo ted currencies can only be made through an authorized bank ac t ing on a commission basis. Banks are required to obtain the prior approval of the Bank of Portugal to accept deposits in fo re ign currencies from residents or nonresidents and to obtain shor t- term credits abroad. The banks may use the ir foreign exchange holdings for all au thor ized purposes, but the M in i s t ry of Finance may set limits on their foreign exchange resources and * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. Capital held abroad by residents in the form of foreign exchange that is not subject to surrender requirements may be transferred to other residents through authorized commercial banks at official rates of exchange. Decree-Law No. 44699 of 1963 fo rb ids direct transactions in foreign exchange between resi- dents who are private persons. There is no forward exchange ma rke t, but authorized banks may enter into forward transac t ions w i th ind i- vidual customers: the exchange rates may not be higher than the spot buy ing rate or lower than the spot selling rate of the same date, but the size of the com- mission is not prescribed. The commercial banks may cover open positions by entering into swap t ransac t ions with the Bank of Portugal. The escudos issued in the overseas territories are at par w i th the metropolitan escudo. The parity for the Macao pataca is Esc 4.75 = pataca 1. Interterritorial payments are subject to transfer charges collected by the credit institutions concerned which may not exceed 0.6 per cent; this l im it is 0.3 per cent for payments resu l t ing from transactions in foreign currencies and settled through another overseas te r r i to ry or through metropolitan Portugal. In te r te r r i to r ial paymen ts are also subject to a service charge of l/> of 1 per cent in favor of the Exchange Fund of the overseas province con- cerned; 3 for paymen ts between two overseas provinces this charge is divided between the two Exchange Funds concerned. In add i t ion, Interterritorial paymen ts wh ich require the direct in terven t ion of the Bank of Portugal as agent of either the interterritorial clearing system or the territorial payments system are subject to a service charge of 0.15 per cent payable to the Bank of Portugal. Exchange Control Territory Portugal and the Portuguese overseas territories (Angola, Cape Verde Islands, Macao, Mozambique, Portuguese Guinea, Principe, Sao Tome, and T imor) constitute a single exchange control territory, the Por- tuguese Monetary Area or Escudo Area. Within the Escudo Area, interterritorial paymen ts are subject to exchange control (except in Macao); they may be made directly through commerc ial banks or channe led th rough special accounts m a in t a in ed by the Bank of Portugal (which is reserve bank of the Escudo Area, agent of the clearing system, and agent of the Mone tary Fund 3 For Macao, which has no Exchange Fund, the Banco Nacional U l t rama r ino is the bank of issue. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution of the Area) and the Exchange Funds of the individual overseas territories (either under the interterritorial payments system or the interterritorial clearing system). Decree-Law No. 41,403 of November 1957 and Decree-Law No. 44,016 of November 1961 provide that the foreign exchange regulations of metropolitan Portugal shall be applied in the overseas territories, subject to any local adjustments that may be neces- sary. Current payments from metropolitan Portugal to the overseas territories are in principle unrestricted, as are current payments to metropolitan Portugal from most of the overseas territories. In Angola and Mozam- bique, however, transactions involving payments to metropolitan Portugal as well as to foreign countries are subject at present to a system of priorities. Administration of Control Exchange controls are administered by the Bank of Portugal on behalf of the Ministry of Finance, with the assistance of the commercial banks authorized for this purpose. Trade control policy is formulated by the Commis- sion of Economic Coordination in the Ministry of Econ- omy. A Directorate-General of Commerce in the Ministry of Economy administers the trade controls; import and export licenses ("bulletins") are issued by the Foreign Trade Division, operating within the office of the Directorate-General, or by other executive departments duly authorized. Licenses for imports of certain goods included in the negative list are issued by the economic coordination departments within the Ministry of Economy. Practically all foreign trade trans- actions are subject to registration with the Ministry of Economy. Prescription of Currency Transactions with countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements may be settled in any of the currencies quoted by the Bank of Por- tugal (see footnote 1), or, for Portuguese exports, in escudos to the debit of a Demand Foreign Account in Escudos (see section on Nonresident Accounts, below). Transactions with countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements (see footnote 2) are settled through clearing accounts maintained in U. S. dollars (for Greece, Israel, and Turkey), in pounds sterling ( for Po land ), or in escudos or the currency of the pa r tner country (for Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, and Hunga ry ). In exceptional cases, pay- ments to nonresidents may be made by crediting escudos to a nonresident account, subject to prior approval by the Bank of Portugal. Payments between the overseas territories and foreign countries may be made either direct through the authorized banks of the territories concerned, or by means of the interterritorial clearing system, through metropolitan Portugal or another over- seas territory. Within the Escudo Area, payments to PORTUGAL metropolitan Portugal must be made in metropolitan escudos, while payments to the overseas territories may be made either in metropolitan escudos or in the cur- rency of the creditor country. Nonresident Accounts The main categories of nonresident accounts are described below. "Foreign Accounts in Escudos" in the name of persons resident or domiciled in countries with which Portugal does not have bilateral payments agreements or arrangements: These accounts are divided into (1) "Time Foreign Accounts in Escudos," for which the opening, debiting, and crediting are subject to special advance authorization of the Bank of Portugal, and (2) "Demand Foreign Accounts in Escudos," which may be opened, debited, and credited without prior authorization of the Bank of Portugal for (a) payments for transactions expressed in escudos and duly author- ized in that currency, for imports and exports of goods, services, and capital between metropolitan Portugal and foreign countries,4 (b) purchases or sales of escudos against the foreign currencies quoted by the Bank of Portugal,5 (c) purchases or sales of foreign currencies quoted by the Bank of Portugal against escudos, and (d) transfers between these accounts. For all other debit and credit operations, authorization of the Bank of Portugal is required. The granting of credit in the form of overdrafts on the above accounts requires the authorization of the Bank of Portugal and for amounts exceeding Esc 50 million with a maturity exceeding one year the approval of the Ministry of Finance is also required. "Foreign Accounts in Escudos" in the name of per- sons resident or domiciled in countries with which Portugal has bilateral payments agreements or arrange- ments: These accounts are opened, debited, and credited according to instructions issued by the Bank of Por- tugal. There are also provisions for resident and nonresi- dent accounts in foreign currencies, but these accounts are of limited importance. Imports and import Payments Imports of certain products are prohibited, m a in ly for reasons of health, public order, and the preven t ion of trade frauds. Any physical or juridical entity may be an importer; importers must be certified by the Cor- poration of Commerce and must pay income taxes regularly. Most imports consigned f rom and o r ig ina t ing in the Portuguese overseas territories are free of restric- 4 However, the intent of the monetary directives in force is to exclude the escudo f rom payments to nonresidents, and the Bank of Portugal authorizes such paymen ts in escudos on ly in exceptional cases. 5 Sales of escudos are subject to the proviso that the commercial bank concerned may be required to inform the Bank of Portugal of the nature of the transaction for which escudos are required. 393 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL tion. A registration procedure is applied, however, for payment control purposes, and certificates of origin are required to ensure that goods o r ig ina t ing in foreign countries do not en ter Portugal via overseas territories. Cer ta in products, such as cotton and some oilseed products, may be imported freely f rom the Portuguese overseas territories a f ter local indus tr ial demand has been satisfied, but are subject to quantitative restric- tions when imported f rom third countries. Special regu- lations are applied to sugar; imports f rom foreign coun- tries take place only if supplies from overseas territories are insufficient. Almost all imports f rom outside the Portuguese Mone tary Area are effected on the basis of "bulletins." For imports free of quan t i ta t ive restriction, the bulletin serves a s ta t is t ical purpose and enables the importer to obtain the necessary foreign exchange as specified in the bulletin. For imports subject to restriction, the bulletin is equ iva lent to an import license. The validity of the bulletin is normally 90 days, but extensions are often granted. Payments for imports already cleared through customs require the approval of the Bank of Portugal when made a f ter the validity of the bulle- tin. Payments beyond one year after customs clearance always require the approval of the Bank of Portugal. Goods not on the so-called negative list may be imported freely f rom most countries that are members of the GATT. The negative list includes certain food- stuffs, other agricultural products, certain natural or manufac tured raw materials, some textile fibers, and a small number of finished products, including motor vehicles; the items on the negative list are subject to quantitative restrictions for protective reasons or under special regimes. A somewhat more extensive negative list applies to Japan. The GATT liberalization does not apply to Ghana, India, and Nigeria; imports f rom these GATT members of goods liberalized if imported from other GATT countries are subject to individual authori- zation, which is granted on the merits of the case. Nonliberalized imports f rom countries that are GATT members are admitted either under global or bilateral quotas or under individual authorization. All imports f rom countries that are not members of the GATT are based on individual authorizations; imports from Eastern European countries are generally licensed restrictively or in accordance with bilateral agreements. There are bilateral quotas for specified agricultural imports from certain EFTA countries. Imports of non- liberalized industrial products, except for certain pro- tected steel products and automobiles, are free of quantitative restriction when originating in EFTA coun- tries. Special legislation provides that automobiles must be assembled in Portugal. Imports of passenger cars are allowed up to 75 units (for EFTA countries 150 units) a year for each producer,6 while imports of 6 With effect from January 1, 1973, the regime for imports from non-EFTA countries was modified. Imports of fu l ly assembled passenger automobiles of non-EFTA origin were limited to 15 units 394 commercial vehicles for special purposes are free of restrictions. Imports of completely knocked-down vehi- cles from EFTA countries are free of restrictions, and allocations for imports f rom other GATT coun tr ies are available under special open licenses, subject to the use of certain m in imum percentages of domestic com- ponents. Payments for Invisibles Payments to the Portuguese overseas territories for cu r rent invisibles may be made f ree ly through autho- rized banks. Such paymen ts to fo re ign coun t r ies are also generally free of quan t i ta t ive restrictions, but for most transactions ceilings are specified for amoun ts of foreign exchange that authorized banks may grant freely. For payments to coun tr ies w i th which Po r tugal does not have bilateral paymen ts agreements, the authorized banks may grant any amount of fore ign exchange for expenditures inc iden tal to trade; up to the equ iva lent of Esc 50,000 a person a year for tou r i sm; 7 and up to the equivalent of Esc 100,000 for most transac t ions in invisibles not mentioned above, inc lud ing income on imported capital. For paymen ts to countries w i th which Portugal has b i la te ral paymen ts agreemen ts, the autho- rized banks may effect freely paymen ts for invisibles listed in the respective paymen ts agreements. Applica- tion must be made to the Bank of Portugal for exchange for payments of items not referred to above and for paymen ts in excess of the above-mentioned limits. Travelers may take out freely domestic and foreign banknotes and foreign coins for their travel expenses; exports of notes and coins for other purposes require authorization from the Bank of Portugal. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports and re-exports are effected on the basis of "bulletins" (similar to the import bu l le t ins). Export bulletins for exports to Angola and Mozamb ique are issued only on evidence that the importer has already obtained an import bulletin. For exports to other over- seas provinces and to foreign countries, export bu l le t ins are issued freely, with few exceptions; the pr imary pur- pose of this procedure is to enforce the prescription of currency and surrender regulations. The export of a few domestically produced goods is restricted, ma in ly to assure adequate supplies to domestic industries and to avoid depletion of local resources. Baggage and exports and re-exports of merchandise whose va lue does not exceed Esc 2,500 do not require a bu l le t in as long as they are not expressly excluded from this exemption. Exporters are required to sell to an authorized bank, for each producer per year for those makes not assembled in Portugal and, for other makes, to 2 per cent of the number of automobiles of the same make that were assembled in Portugal in the preceding year. 7 Upon verification of the genuineness of the transac t ion, the Bank of Portugal authorizes the equivalent of Esc 20,125 a person a trip. ©International Monetary Fund. The Bank of Po r tugal may, however, authorize the deduction of commission expenses abroad, and freight, insurance, or other charges p e r t a in ing to exports, from the to tal am o u nt of the export proceeds subject to sur- render. Proceeds from Invisibles Por tuguese residents may receive f ree ly paymen ts for inv is ib les from residents of countries with which Por- tugal does not have b i la teral paymen ts agreements. Also, paymen ts f rom res iden ts of countries with which Por tugal does have paymen ts agreements may be received f ree ly for inv is ib les listed in the payments agreements. Rece ip ts on account of all other inv is ib les require au tho r iza t ion by the Bank of Portugal, which is granted w i thout restriction once the proposed operation proves to be real and l ic i t. Receipts f rom invisibles must be surrendered. Travelers may b r i ng in f ree ly domestic and foreign banknotes and coins for their travel expenses; imports of notes and coins for other purposes require authorization f rom the Bank of Por tuga l. Authorized banks are not permitted to receive or to pay out domestic or foreign banknotes or coins for the settlement of external trans- actions. Capital Capital transfers between Portugal and its overseas territories are subject to prior authorization by the Bank of Portugal; approval is also required from the authori- ties of the territory concerned. When the amount exceeds Esc 50 million, the approval of the Minister of Finance and of the Minister of Overseas Territories is required. For most types of transactions, however, authorization to export from Portugal (and to import into the overseas territory) is granted freely whenever the transaction is found to be a bona fide one. With the exception of certain personal imports and exports of capital up to Esc 100,000, all capital move- ments between Portugal and other countries require prior approval by the Bank of Portugal; for transactions in excess of Esc 50 million whose maturity exceeds one year, the approval of the Minister of Finance is also required. Foreign investments in Portugal by residents of coun- tries that are members of or associated w i th the OECD, EFTA, IMF, or IBRD are authorized freely if they involve activities that are of recognized interest for Por- tugal's development and provided that no speculative operation in real estate is involved. Certain activities, however, are reserved for enterprises having a majority of Portuguese capital; these include defense, public utilities, oil ref in ing, and fishing. Furthermore, Decree PORTUGAL No. 393 /70 specifies cer ta in indus t r ies in wh ich any domestic or fo re ign inves tment is sub ject to prior au thor iza t ion. The t ran s fer abroad of the f u ll proceeds from the l iqu ida t ion of foreign inves tment which origi- nated in a bona fide inwa rd capital movement f rom OECD, EFTA, IMF, or IBRD coun tr ies is authorized w i thout restriction. Foreign credits from OECD coun t r ies w i th a m a tu r i ty of up to five years are liberalized when a Portuguese resident participates in the unde r ly ing commercial or service transac t ion. The acceptance of other fore ign credits is no rma l ly pe rm i t ted. The repayment of foreign credits and loans th at or ig ina ted in a bona fide inward capital movement is always authorized. Inves tmen ts outside the Portuguese Monetary Area by residents of Portugal are authorized on ly when the capital involved is not considered ind ispensab le for the na t ional economic deve lopmen t. In practice, au thor iza- tion is gran ted on ly for small investments and for the improvement or enlargement of ex is t ing Portuguese investments. Residents of Portugal may reinvest in securities, w i th in t ime limits fixed by the au thor i t ies, the proceeds of the sale of other securities in an OECD coun t ry. They may also transfer such proceeds to other residents, provided that the proceeds do not belong to a Portu- guese credit institution and that their owner is not under an obligation to surrender them to such an ins t i tu t ion. Arbitrage operations in foreign securities carried out by residents of Portugal involving two other OECD coun- tries or between Portugal and an OECD country are authorized freely; but if a transfer of foreign exchange to or from Portugal is involved, a prior authorization is required. Transfers by Portuguese nationals or by foreigners resident in Portugal who em igra te to any other OECD country are authorized au toma t ica l ly up to Esc 100,000 annua l ly for a fam i ly and larger amounts may be granted on the merits of the case. Transfers by foreign nationals who have been resident in Portugal are authorized up to Esc 500,000 a year for a fam i ly when they return to their country of origin. Transfers on account of fam i ly loans, bequests, inheritances, and dowries to other OECD countries are usually authorized automatically up to Esc 500,000; for higher amounts, annual transfers up to Esc 500,000 are authorized. For bequests and inheritances, the legator or the deceased person must have been a resident of Portugal and the legatee or heir a resident of an OECD coun try at the time of death. G i f ts to relatives resident in OECD coun- tries are authorized when their value does not exceed Esc 28,750 a year. Transfers to OECD countries in respect of life insur- ance policies due from Portuguese insurers are author- ized in favor of the beneficiary when their value does not exceed Esc 500,000 for a capital sum, a reduced value, or an annu i ty certain, and Esc 50,000 for a sur- render value. 395 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PORTUGAL Capital movements and transfers of assets in excess of the limits mentioned, or not enumerated in the pre- ceding paragraphs, or involving countries other than those mentioned above, are authorized on the merits of each case. The net foreign asset positions of authorized banks must not exceed 5 per cent of their current liabilities in domestic currency. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold in any form in Portugal, and there is a free gold market. The purchase or sale of coined or uncoined gold, when carried out between metropolitan Portugal and foreign countries, is subject to special advance authorization from the Bank of Portugal whenever a resident of metropolitan Por- tugal takes part in the transaction or has an interest in it. The import, export, or re-export of coined or uncoined gold is also subject to special advance autho- rization f rom the Bank of Portugal. Licensing of imports is relatively liberal but import authorizations for indus- trial gold are granted only to commercial banks and the Association of Industrial Users of Gold. Domestic sales of gold and of gold coins that are not legal tender are subject to a transaction tax of 20 per cent. There is a free market for gold in Macao, in which both residents of Macao and nonresidents who are not resident in the Portuguese Monetary Area may freely trade among themselves in bars, leaves, and coins; settlement must take place in patacas or U. S. dollars. In Macao, the Government sets overall limits for imports of gold in any form other than jewelry; authority to carry out such imports is delegated to a concessionary enterprise for a two-year period. Imports and exports of gold, unless made by or on behalf of the Macao monetary authorities, require licenses issued by the Commissioner for Economy. Changes during 1972 During the year, the system of priorities for outward payments and imports, the introduction of which in Angola and Mozambique was provided for by legisla- tion enacted in December 1971, was fur ther elaborated. In each of these territories a foreign exchange budget was adopted; in principle, these budgets did not dis- tinguish between Portuguese territories and foreign countries. February 12. Mozambique published priorities estab- lished by a decision of the same date for imports, cur- rent transactions in invisibles, and private capital trans- actions. For certain first-priority imports (equipment for production or development), minimum supplier credit terms of three years were prescribed. (Similar priorities had been established in Angola on Novem- ber 6, 1971 by Decree-Law No. 478/71 and were pub- lished on January 20, 1972.) March 31. Portugal ceased to invoke Article XXXV of the GATT in respect of Japan. On April 1 a new trade agreement with Japan came into force. April 24. A ministerial order specified the conditions for the granting of guarantees (avales) for export credits and prefinancing, under the terms of Decree-Law No. 47908 of September 7, 1967. May 12. Decree-Law No. 157/72 was published, which modified the existing regulations concerning imports of passenger automobiles of non-EFTA origin with effect f rom Janua ry 1, 1973. May 20. Decree No. 173/72 introduced regulations (implementing Decree-Law No. 478/71 of Novem- ber 6, 1971) with regard to payments and exchange operations in and between Portuguese overseas terri- tories. (In Metropolitan Portugal, corresponding imple- menting regulations had been introduced by Decree-Law No. 550/71 of December 15, 1971.) May 31. Limits were imposed on the foreign cur- rency balances held by authorized banks. June 6. Private capital import and export transactions in continental Portugal and the adjacent islands, when corresponding to certain personal capital movements and not exceeding Esc 100,000, were exempted f rom special prior approval by the Bank of Portugal. July 22. A free trade agreement with the EEC was signed, to come into effect on January 1, 1973. July 24. No par value has been established. The Qa tar /Dubai Currency Board buys and sells sterling at no more than Vi of 1 per cent either side of the middle rate for sterling based on the current London market rate for the U. S. dollar; on December 31, 1972, the buying and selling rates for sterling were QDR 10.3502 and QDR 10.2472 per <£ stg. 1, respectively. The commercial banks' exchange rates for currencies other than sterling are based on Qatar's rates for sterling and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against sterling. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an exchange control authority in Qatar. Import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Finance and Petroleum. Prescription of Currency The use of the currencies of Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa is prohibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force, but in practice pay- ments to and from Sterling Area countries usually are made in Sterling Area currencies. Qatar is a member of the Sterling Area, although it has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U. K. Exchange Control Act, 1947. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, and alcoholic beverages, firearms, am- mun i t ion, and certain drugs are subject to licensing requirements for reasons of health, morals, and security. Otherwise, imports into Qatar are not restricted. Only Qatar nationals are allowed to engage in import busi- ness. There are no restrictions on payments for per- mitted imports. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. All other commodities may be exported freely. There are no requirements attached to receipts f rom exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be * Fo l low ing the announcement on Feb rua ry 12, 1973 th at the U. S. dollar was being deva lued, the gold con tent of the Qa ta r /Dubai r iyal was m a i n t a i n ed un ch ang ed. 1 Qatar became a member of the In te rna t ional Mon e t a ry Fund on September 8, 1972. 2 Dubai is a con s t i tuent member of the Un i ted A rab Emirates. repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of freely regardless of the currency involved. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments must not be made to or received f rom Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. Otherwise there are no limitations on payments for and proceeds f rom invisibles. Banks are required to obtain permission from the Ministry of Finance and Petroleum for all remit- tances in excess of QDR 50,000. The Ministry's ap- proval is also required for transfers outside the Sterling Area for educational expenses in excess of QDR 35,000 a person a year and for travel expenses outside the Sterling Area in excess of QDR 3,500 a person a trip; all bona fide applications are approved. Capital Banks are required to obtain permission f rom the Ministry of Finance for all remittances in excess of QDR 50,000. No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents, although payments must not be made to or received from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. There are, however, certain restrictions on foreign direct investment in the industrial and banking sectors. Decree-Law No. 4 (March 1970) stipulates that no foreign bank entering business in Qatar after January 1970 shall have more than one branch in Qatar and that all foreign bank branches shall make available QDR 5 million to be deposited without interest with the Qatar National Bank. The law also requires every foreign bank branch to invest at least 50 per cent of its deposits in Qatar. Foreign participation in certain industrial enterprises is prohibited unless Qataris con- trol at least a majority of the shares. Gold The monetary authorities and all other residents and nonresidents, including private persons, may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. They may also, without a license and w i thout payment of customs duties or tax, import and export gold in any form. Transactions in- volving Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are, how- ever, prohibited. Changes during 1972 February 22. The leu is officially defined as equ iva lent to 0.148112 gram of fine gold, yielding offi- cial rates as at December 31, 1972 of lei 5.53 per U. S. dollar (lei 6 per SDR) and lei 6.67 per ruble. There is no exchange marke t. The Na t ional Bank of Roman ia quotes rates also for certain other currencies; quotations are based on the gold definition for the leu and the par va lues or official rates of the currencies concerned. For exchange rate purposes, payments for insurance and t ranspo r ta t ion connected with trade are considered as trade transactions. Some non trade transactions are carried out at the official rate plus a prem ium of 189.33 per cent, resu l t ing in a rate of lei 16 per US$1. For non trade transac t ions with some socialist coun t r ie s2 exchange rates are established by special agreements. Administration of Control Foreign trade is a state monopoly. Import and export transactions are effected by authorized industrial cen- trals, producing enterprises, and foreign trade enter- prises, and are subject to import and export licenses granted by the Ministry of Foreign Trade. In the issuing of licenses, the provisions of the foreign trade plan and of existing trade agreements are taken into account. Foreign currency proceeds f rom exports are sold to the Roman ian Bank for Foreign Trade; foreign currency required for import payments is purchased from that Bank. Exchange control is administered by the National Bank and the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade. Prescription of Currency Payments to and f rom countries with which Romania has bilateral paymen ts agreements are made in cur- rencies and in accordance with the procedures set forth in those agreements.3 If no agreement exists, settlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Imports and Exports Import and export plans are drawn up by the pro- ducing enterprises. On the basis of these plans, the fore ign trade plan for the national economy as a whole specifies the main import and export products indi- vidually and establishes global quotas for other groups of products and for unspecified items. The foreign trade plan is not divided by countries but, according to the manner of settlement of exchange payments and receipts, it distinguishes between the clearing area and the convertible currency area. Export proceeds must be sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade. However, there is an incentive sys- tem for enterprises which receive more foreign exchange than anticipated. In such cases the exporting enter- prises may either retain the surplus foreign exchange in excess of the quota due or convert the full amount of the actual foreign exchange receipts into lei and receive a premium in lei. In the former case, the enter- prise has the right either to utilize the surplus foreign exchange to make additional imports, or to keep the amount concerned with the Bank in an interest-bearing account. Both the conversion and the reconversion are carried out at the official rate. The foreign exchange surplus may be used only for imports. If the surplus foreign exchange earnings are in a convertible currency, the exporting enterprise may convert the amount con- cerned into any convertible currency. Invisibles All transactions in invisibles not connected with for- eign trade transactions require general or individual authorization given by the Ministry of Finance. For most categories of payments in respect of invisibles, foreign exchange is made available automatically once the transaction has been authorized. For travel outside socialist countries an exchange allocation is provided up to the equivalent of US$70 a trip for each adult person for one trip a year. In addition, tourist agencies may organize group or individual trips payable in lei in amounts the equivalent of which may exceed the maxi- mum allocations of foreign exchange. Receipts from transactions in invisibles must be sold to the Romanian Bank for Foreign Trade, and the foreign currency required for payments in respect of such transactions is bought from the same bank. Receipts in foreign cur- rencies f rom travelers are converted at lei 16 per US$1. The import and export of Romanian notes and coins by travelers is prohibited. Not for Redistribution ROMANIA ward transfers of funds belonging to resident physical persons are not normally permitted. For certain estab- lished categories, such as inheritances, reciprocal agree- ments have been concluded with a number of countries providing for automatic authorization of transfers of specified amounts to and from Romania. A new Foreign Trade Law (Law No. 1 of March 1971) provides for the possibility of the establishment of joint ventures abroad by Romanian economic organizations; foreigners are also allowed to invest capital in joint ventures in Romania, up to 49 per cent of the total capital of the company concerned. The Law guarantees the repatria- tion in foreign currency of the capital and the transfer in foreign currency of profits after taxes. By agree- ment the accounts of joint ventures may be kept in an agreed currency. Foreign physical and juridical persons may keep in bank accounts in Romania their legally owned foreign currency or lei funds; balances in foreign exchange accounts are transferable abroad. Romanian nationals working abroad may hold their foreign currency savings in accounts opened with Romanian banks and use these funds for payments in Romania or abroad. Gold Only the National Bank of the Socialist Republic of Romania has authority to purchase or sell gold in any manner, at home or abroad. The Bank, in turn, author- izes certain juridical persons to hold gold, to use it, and to engage in gold transactions, in accordance with the law. The ownership by physical persons, for domestic and personal use, of jewelry and of artistic and cultural objects of gold, is not restricted. Changes during 1972 June 16. Not for Redistribution RWANDA Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.00888671 gram of fine gold per Rwanda Franc, corresponding to RF 100 = SDR 1 or RF 92.1053 = US$1, and Rwanda avails itself of wider margins. The National Bank of Rwanda (the central bank) has established fixed buy ing and selling rates for banks for the U. S. dollar and for certain other cur- rencies; * those for the U. S. dollar are RF 92.11 buying and RF 94.18 selling. The authorized banks, acting for the account of the National Bank, must deal at or within these rates with the pub l ic but are permitted to charge a fee of RWANDA imports and exports; for transfers of the salaries or wages ( a f t er income tax and a f ter deduction ot RF 25,000 a mon th) of foreign nationals employed in Rwanda under contract; for transfers of the net earned income of foreign nationals who are self-employed or are engaged in a profession or established as inde- pendent traders; and for salaries of fore igners traveling abroad on leave. Paymen ts in respect of transport charges on imports and exports cannot be made until imported goods have been cleared through customs or after the exchange proceeds from exports have been surrendered. Net profits and dividends due to non- residents may in principle be remitted abroad in fu l l, subject to the right of the National Bank to prescribe their t rans fer in installments. Nonresidents may transfer their net income f rom rents ( a f t er deduction of taxes and a provision of 20 per cent for ma in tenance ), and residents of foreign nationality may remit two thirds of such net income; the National Bank, however, may limit the amounts so transferable. Residents may freely purchase tickets for travel abroad in Rwanda francs, with the exception that the prior approval of the central bank may be required when certain travel by persons of foreign nationality is involved. Purchases of foreign exchange for travel pur- poses are authorized on an ad hoc basis. Remittances for payments for certain other invisibles may also be authorized on an ad hoc basis. Travelers may take out domestic banknotes up to RF 5,000. Residents require authorization by the National Bank to take out foreign banknotes. Non- resident travelers may take out any amount in foreign banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. All exports, except trade samples, baggage and household effects of travelers, and merchandise valued at less than RF 20,000, are subject to a prior declaration entitled Declaration of Collection of For- eign Exchange (Model E ). Declarations for all exports must be presented to the National Bank through an authorized bank, for certification. A Declaration is valid for a period of three months, but extensions may be granted by the National Bank, which also reserves the right to determine the conditions for certification. For exports to Burundi, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda, and Zaire, payment must be collected not later than 30 days after the goods have left the country; for exports to all other countries, this period is 120 days, except for min- erals shipped abroad for refining, for which the period is 180 days. All exchange proceeds f rom exports must be surrendered to an authorized bank within 8 days from their collection. 402 Proceeds from Invisibles All receipts f rom invisibles of RF 5,000 or more must be surrendered to the authorized banks within 8 days f rom their collection. Commercial banks are not permitted to import or export domestic banknotes. Gold Residents may purchase, ho ld, and sell gold coins in Rwanda for numismatic purposes only.
