The validity of the Emergency Decree for the Protection of the Currency of October 8, 1971 was by referendum extended until October 1974. The Decree conferred powers on the Federal Government to take any special measures it might consider essential to con- duct a monetary policy adapted to the country's general interest, notably in order to limit the undesirable inflow of foreign capital funds and to induce their outflow. They included the power to impose negative interest rates on foreign funds and to declare the gentleman's agreements, which so far had been negotiated with the large banks, to be b ind ing on all credit ins t i tu t ions. June 23. Following the floating of sterling, the National Bank suspended its intervention in the exchange market. Intervention was resumed on Ju ly 3. June 26. The Federal Governmen t, invok ing for the first time the Federal Decree for the Protection of the Currency of October 8, 1971, took two emergency meas- ures that were to rema in in force un t il October 1974 if not terminated earlier. All juridical acts aiming at the acquisition of real estate in Switzerland (or rights to the use of such real estate) by physical or jur id ical persons resident abroad (having their domicile or registered office abroad) were prohibited by a Federal Decree (which came into force on June 2 7 ), and dealers in securities (including banks) and other financial intermediaries were instructed by a Federal Ordinance (which also came into force on June 27) to abstain f rom investing foreign funds in domestic securities, foreign securities denominated in Swiss francs, bearer savings books of Swiss banks, and mortgages on Swiss real estate. Domestic securities were 450 def ined as any securities issued by a Swiss debtor and any securities denom ina ted in Swiss f rancs issued by a foreign debtor. Nonresidents selling Swiss securities in Switzerland could reinvest the proceeds in Swiss secu- rities, but only w i th in the "investment quota" of the securities dealer receiving the proceeds (see be low ). Under both measures a d is t inc t ion was made between alien nonres iden ts and nonres iden ts of Swiss nationality. Nonres iden ts were defined so as to include ( 1) the estab- lishments abroad of a Swiss en terpr ise, and (2) physical or ju r id ical persons hav ing the ir domicile or registered office in Liechtenstein; Liechtenstein was considered a foreign country. For purposes of the acquisition of Swiss real estate, fore ign na t iona ls l iv ing in Switzerland were considered residents if they had a residence perm it or otherwise if they had lived there w i th permission and w i thout in te r rup t ion for at least five years; exemptions f r om the proh ib i t ion could on ly be g ran ted by the Fed- eral Depar tment of Justice. For purposes of investment in Swiss securities, fo re ign f u n ds were def ined as means of payment, balances, and other assets belonging to for- eigners, whe ther denom ina ted in Swiss francs or foreign currency; fore igners were defined as (1) physical persons of fore ign na t iona l i ty residing abroad, (2) jur id ical per- sons and firms having the ir registered office abroad, and (3) juridical persons and firms hav ing their registered office in Sw i tzer land but controlled f rom abroad and either not engaged in business in Switzerland or engaged in the acquisition of Swiss securities or of mortgages on Swiss real estate. Exemptions f rom the prohibition on the investment of foreign funds in Swiss real estate included: (1) the acqui- sition of real estate used as premises for a commercial or indus tr ial firm; (2) the acquisition of real estate used by Swiss branches of fore ign insurance companies as cover for the ir ma thema t ical reserves; (3) any acquisi- tion by Swiss citizens domiciled abroad; and (4) acquisi- tions for public purposes by fo re ign governmen ts and international organizations (not their staff or employees). Under some of these exemptions, the authorization of the canton concerned was required but could not be w i thhe ld. No exemption was gran ted in regions con- sidered worthy of preservation or regions where the proportion of real estate purchases by fore igners was considered excessive. The Na t ional Bank issued c la r i fy ing guidelines for the imp lemen ta t ion of the Federal Ord inance of June 26. Swiss citizens living abroad were not con- sidered foreigners, nor were international organizations having a registered office in Switzerland (or their staff and emp loyees ). Foreign-owned companies in Switzer- land were treated as foreign if they had no economic activities in Switzerland or if their purpose was the acquisition of securities or mortgages. The place of domicile or registered office was to be determined in accordance w i th Articles 23-26 and Article 56 of the Civil Code. Establishments in Switzerland of foreign firms were not considered fore ign but could only acquire goods and securities in Switzerland to the extent that these covered their current operating requirements. Such acquisition required National Bank approval when it served to expand those establishments, and the Bank's approval was also needed for acquisitions aimed at the creation of an establishment in Switzerland by a foreign firm, or when foreigners for similar purposes wished to establish a firm in Switzerland. A Federal Ordinance made the raising or renewal abroad of credit, whether in domestic or for- eign currency, by resident physical and juridical persons other than banks subject to prior authorization by the National Bank; such approval was also needed to change the terms of an existing foreign credit. There was an exemption for credits of up to Sw F 1 million a debtor a year and for credits representing customary credit terms or advance payments for current commer- cial transactions.12 The acceptance of monies was treated as the taking up of a credit if there was a repayment obligation. Credit extended within a multinational com- pany (i.e.,between the constituent parts of a single enter- prise) was treated as credit granted by an autonomous firm. Swiss affili- ates of foreign firms were considered residents, but for- eign affiliates of Swiss firms were treated as nonresidents. Clarifications were provided about roll-over credits, interest rate changes on existing credits, credits between the constituent parts of a multinational corporation, and credit terms "customary in the trade concerned.") July 5. A Federal Ordinance placed the marginal reserve requirements against increases in banks' foreign liabilities, which had rested on a gentleman's agreement, on a statutory basis and modified these requirements.13 The National Bank was empowered to impose a mini- mum reserve requirement of up to 90 per cent on the growth in liabilities since July 31, 1971 vis-a-vis non- residents (Swiss francs and foreign currency combined) of all banks and financial institutions with a balance sheet total of Sw F 20 million or more. The minimum reserves were to be paid for the first time on the increase in foreign funds between July 31, 1971 and June 30, 1972. Unlike the August 16, 1971 agreement, the new arrangements did not provide for an automatic offsetting of any increases in foreign currency and Swiss f ranc claims on nonresidents. The Na t ional Bank was authorized, however, to allow banks to deduct all or part of the growth in their foreign currency placements abroad af ter the "reference date" (July 31, 1971); in doing so, the National Bank could take into account for- ward purchases and sales of foreign currencies against Swiss francs. The Bank was empowered to apply the reserve requirement also to any increases in "fiduciary" funds handled by the banks on behalf of nonresidents. The reserves had to be held in noninterest-bearing accounts at the National Bank which, however, could allow banks to purchase U. S. dollars f rom it with these funds. In setting the percentage or percentages of the reserve requirement, the National Bank had to take into account the liquidity of the banking system; it was authorized to set d i f fe rent rates for d ifferent balance sheet items. New reserve requirements became effective on July 21 (see be low). Liechtenstein was considered a foreign coun try for the purposes of this Ordinance. July 10. For domestic funds, the maximum requirements that could be imposed were 12 per cent on the level of demand or time deposits held by banks and 40 per cent on their increase over the level of domestic credit that was permissible on July 31, 1971; 12 per cent on the level of other sight deposits and 40 per cent on their increase; 9 per cent on the level of other time deposits and 30 per cent on their increase; and 2 per cent on the level of savings deposits and cash certificates with a maturity under five years, and 5 per cent on their increase. For foreign funds, the maximums were twice those for domestic funds. (By the end of the year these powers had not been invoked. Not for Redistribution SYRIAN ARAB REPUBLIC Exchange Rate System * On July 29, 1947, a par value for the Syrian Pound was established by the Syrian Arab Republic w i th the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There are two exchange markets, the official ma rket and the free or "parallel" market w i th a nom ina l ly fluctuating rate. There are fixed official rates of LS 3.80 buy ing and LS 3.82 selling, per US$1; official market rates for other currencies are quoted by the Exchange Office on the basis of the fixed rates for the U. S. dollar and the market rates for the currencies concerned in interna- t ional centers. The parallel ma rket rates have been pegged since February 1970 (except, for noncommer- cial transactions only, dur ing the period June-September 1972) at LS 4.30 buy ing, and LS 4.32 selling, per US$1; these rates continued in force on December 30, 1972. In practice, the parallel market rate for the U. S. dollar is set by the Commercial Bank of Syria in consultation with the Exchange Office. The official market rate applies to receipts f rom exports of cotton and crude petroleum and from oil pipeline royalties, and, temporarily and exceptionally, to the expenditures of the Syrian diplomatic corps and embassies abroad and of official delegations sent abroad at the expense of the State, as well as the cost of study, training, and teaching abroad. 1 The parallel market rate applies to all other transactions. The Commercial Bank of Syria charges a commission of 2Ao of 1 per cent on sales or purchases of foreign exchange. Administration of Control Policy with regard to imports and exports is deter- mined by the Government through the Ministry of Economy and Foreign Trade. Under an agreement between the Central Bank of Syria and the Administra- tive Committee of the Exchange Office, all transactions of the Exchange Office are carried out through the Cen- tral Bank. Import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Economy and Foreign Trade, and exchange licenses for invisibles and capital transactions are issued by the Exchange Office. Authorized commercial banks deal in foreign exchange both in the official and the free market. They open letters of credit or accept bills for collection only with the prior approval of the Exchange Office. At present there is only one authorized bank, the Commer- * Following the announcement on Feb rua ry 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being deva lued, the Syrian Arab Republic with effect from February 18 changed the buy ing and selling rates for the U. S. dollar in the parallel ma rket to LS 4.00 buy ing, and LS 4.05 selling per US$1. In the official market the selling rate was changed to LS 3.85 per US$1, while the buy ing rate was maintained unchanged at LS 3.80 per US$1. 1 Certain paymen ts due on old import contracts licensed at the off ic ial rate may still be made at the off ic ial rate. 454 cial Bank of Syria, which has been au thor ized by the Exchange Office to open letters of credit and accept bills for collection w i thout prior approva l, provided that certain cond i t ions are f u l f i l l e d. Prescription of Currency The Exchange Office is empowered to prescribe the currencies to be ob ta ined for exports. The current requirement is that proceeds of exports to all countries except those w i th which the Syrian A rab Republic has bilateral paymen ts agreements 2 be obtained in the cur- rency of the coun t ry to wh ich the goods are exported if it is an "acceptable" cu r r en cy ,3 or in any other con- vertible currency, at the exporter's choice. Proceeds f rom exports to certain neighboring coun t r ies may be obtained in bankno tes issued by the coun t ry concerned; these countries are Cyprus, the Gu lf states, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwa i t, Lebanon, Saudi Arab ia, Turkey, the Yemen Arab Republic, and the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen. Prescription of currency requ iremen ts are not applied to outgoing payments. All payments to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Nonres ident accounts in Syrian pounds may be held by nonres iden ts 4 and may be credited with the proceeds of foreign currencies sold to the authorized bank and with payments for goods. They may be debited to pay for Syrian exports to the coun t ry of the account holder or, w i th the prior approval of the Exchange Office, to other countries, and for expenses in the Syrian Arab Republic. Transfers abroad f rom these accounts require the prior approval of the Exchange Office, which is granted freely. Res iden ts and nonres iden ts may also keep accounts in fore ign currencies in the Syrian Arab Republic, but only if these accounts result f rom an inflow of capital; t rans fe rs abroad f rom these accounts are made freely. Temporary resident accounts may be opened in the name of nonresidents temporarily resident in the Syrian Arab Republic. Perm i t ted credits include the local currency proceeds of foreign currency brought in through the parallel market and amounts correspond- ing to import payments that are not transferred. Debits for local expenditures are completely free, and debits for certain expenditures abroad also are permitted. 2 Bu lgar ia, ma in land China, Cuba, Eastern Ge rmany, Egypt, Hungary, Nor th Korea, Poland, Romania, Spain, Sri Lanka, U. Not for Redistribution Imports and Import Payments Imports of commod i t ies or ig ina t ing in Israel, Rho- desia, or South Afr ica are prohibited. Many basic com- modities ( inc lud ing green coffee, tea, rice, tobacco, salt, paper, iron and steel, and agr icu l tural m a ch in e ry) are imported only by state t r ad ing agencies ( inc lud ing the successor o rgan iza t ions to SIMEX, par t icu lar ly the Gen- eral O rgan iza t ion for Trade and A r t isan Products — GOTA) or, for the ir own account, by certain other official agencies. Imports of some other commodities are reserved for "unions of industries." Imports are divided in to three ma in categories: ( 1) imports proh ib i ted by decree and specified in a Prohibited List, which com- prises mostly goods that are produced domestically, in- cluding some textile produc ts; (2) imports on a Sus- pended List, which comprises some less essential goods which are tempo ra r i ly not admitted either for balance of paymen ts reasons or for protective reasons; and ( 3) all imports not inc luded in the above two lists. Certain suspended imports may be acquired in paymen ts agree- ment countries th rough compensation transactions invo lv ing the export of Syrian indus tr ial or mineral products. V i r tua l ly all impor ts must be made direct from the coun try of origin, w i thout the intermediary of any firm conducting a business established outside the Syrian Arab Republic; the Ministry of Economy and Foreign Trade has the au thor i ty, however, to per- mit certain goods to be imported f rom countries other than the coun t ry of origin. Certain consumer goods that do not appear on a special list cannot be imported f rom the Federal Republic of Germany, the United Kingdom, or the United States unless it is shown that the price is lower and the qua l i ty higher than that of comparable products offered by other suppliers. All perm i t ted imports, except those made by state t rad ing agencies, require ind iv idual import licenses before the placing of orders. The state t rad ing agencies may conclude impo rt transac t ions and have the goods shipped before an import license is gran ted; the license must be obtained, however, be fo re customs clearance. Goods included in the Suspended List may be imported only under ce r ta in conditions of domestic need, under special ind iv idual license f rom the Ministry of Economy and Foreign Trade, and w i th the prior approval of the M in is try of Indus t ry or the M in is t ry of Supply. Certain imports (not on the Suspended or Prohibited Lists) from Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, and Saudi Arabia are not subject to license, in accordance with the Arab Common Market Agreement or the bilateral agreements of the Syrian Arab Republic w i th some of these coun- tries. These imports include all agr icu l tural commodities, livestock, and some industrial products. Syrian citizens, whether resident in the Syrian Arab Republic or abroad, are entitled to import specified raw materials, capital goods, consumer goods, and spare parts, provided that imports are paid for with their own foreign exchange held abroad; to obtain import licenses, SYRIAN ARAB REPUBLIC wh ich cannot exceed the va lue of LS 100,000 (except for capital goods), the impor ter must provide evidence of his foreign exchange ho ld ings abroad on Decem- ber 31, 1970. Import licenses are granted free ly to importers who have obtained fo r e ign suppliers' credit of at least 365 days. Licenses to import specified con- sumer goods, raw ma te r ia ls, and semifinished goods, up to a va lue of LS 12,000 for a six-month period, are freely gran ted to t rade rs and industrialists whose activity is certified by the Chamber of Commerce or by the Chamber of Indus try. Impor ts by parcel post of any goods that are neither prohibited nor suspended are per- m i t ted w i thout a license, provided th at each parcel is valued at LS 250 or less. There is a tax of 2 per cent on the issue of import licenses, except for government imports and imports of certain essential items, inc lud ing raw materials, petro- leum, and petroleum products. In add i t ion, there are the fo l low ing taxes on impor ts which are collected by the customs: (1) a statistical tax of 4 per cent, (2) a consumption tax of 4 per cent for all imports for which the ta r i ff ra te is more than 1 per cent, (3) a defense tax of 10 per cent of the t a r i f f, (4) a school tax of 10 per cent of the consumption tax plus 2 per cent of the t a r i f f, (5) a harbor tax of 3 per cent of the ta r i ff for goods transferred by ships through Syrian harbors (most commodities can be imported only through Syrian har- bo r s ), and (6) an ocean tax of %o of 1 per cent of the value of imports for all goods transferred by ship in any harbor, including those of neighboring countries. Payments for imports may be made by letters of credit, time d ra f ts, or bills for collection, or by credit- ing a nonresident account or a temporary resident account. The importer submits to the Commercial Bank of Syria the import license and the pro forma invoice. The Commercial Bank of Syria then opens the letters of credit or accepts the bills for collection. Approval by the Exchange Office is curren t ly not required. Cer- tain delays may occur in the provision of foreign exchange for imports on a collection basis. Payments for Invisibles The insurance for imports under documentary credit must be effected locally. All payments for invisi- bles, except those for Syrian diplomatic missions and delegations abroad and for study and teaching abroad, must be made through the parallel market. Residents trave l ing abroad may take with them for- eign exchange purchased at the parallel market rate as follows: for travel to Lebanon, the equivalent of LS 100 a trip; for travel to Jordan, LS 250 a trip; for travel to other Arab countries (except Algeria, the Libyan Arab Republic, Morocco, the Sudan, and Tunisia) and to Cyprus and Turkey, LS 500 a tr ip; and for travel to other countries (including Algeria, the Libyan Arab Republic, Morocco, the Sudan, and Tun is ia ), the equivalent of LS 1,250 a trip. For children under ten 455 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SYRIAN ARAB REPUBLIC years of age, the allowances are 50 per cent of these amounts. For travel to payments agreement countries, 50 per cent of the travel allocation must be taken up through the clearing account concerned. Travelers to Iraq, Jordan, and other countries of the Arab Common Market may, instead of taking up the above-mentioned travel allocations in foreign currency, export Syrian currency up to the amount of the allowance to which they are entitled. On departure, residents of Syrian nationality must pay an exit tax of LS 11.50 a person. Fixed allocations at the free market rate also exist for other invisibles, as follows: 60 per cent of the salaries received by foreign technicians and experts employed in the Syrian Arab Republic; 50 per cent of the salaries of personnel of foreign diplomatic and international missions in the Syrian Arab Republic; up to LS 3,000 a stockholder a year for dividends accruing to nonresi- dents f rom Syrian securities; and LS 250 a person a month for private donations and charities. In all cases, applications for additional amounts must be submitted for approval to the Exchange Office. Nonresidents leaving the country are permitted to take out foreign exchange and Syrian currency within the limit of the declaration they have made when enter- ing the Syrian Arab Republic; the amount of Syrian cur- rency taken out may not exceed LS 100. For additional amounts, the approval of the Exchange Office is required. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of wheat, cotton, cottonseed, barley, and their derivatives are nationalized and are made by the Cereals Office or the Cotton Authority. Exports of certain other commodities are also reserved for government agencies, state trading agencies, or specified companies. Exports of a few goods to any country and all exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Exports of the main export products and of all goods of foreign origin require licenses. For all other exports, licenses are not required. For all private exports, however, a repatriation commitment must be executed in which the exporter undertakes to bring the proceeds to the Syrian Arab Republic and surrender them to the Commercial Bank of Syria within six months a f ter the date of export. The proceeds of exports of cotton and crude petroleum must be surrendered to the Exchange Office at the official buying rate. The proceeds of other exports must be surrendered by sale at the parallel market rate. Certain manu fac tu red exports receive subsidies from the Fund for the Development of Exports of Industrial Products. Exports of cotton are subject to an export tax of l2l/2 per cent ad valorem. All exports of agricultural products ( inc lud ing cotton) are subject to an ad valorem agricultural tax of 10 per cent. All the above taxes are collected by the customs. 456 Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles, inc lud ing tour ism and the local expenditures of oil companies (but not roya l t ies ), must be sold in the parallel ma rke t. Nonresidents enter- ing the Syrian Arab Republic are permitted to bring in unlimited fore ign exchange in any form, provided that they present a wr i t ten s ta tement of the amount upon en t ry; this statement is required only when the traveler intends to take out the foreign exchange he brought in. Nonresidents are permitted to br ing in not more than LS 100 in Syrian currency. Capital All inward and ou tward capital transfers, except cer- ta in payments for Syrian d ip loma t ic missions and dele- gations abroad, take place through the parallel market. Imports of capital in the fo rm of foreign exchange are free for private individuals, whether residents or nonresidents. The export of capital requires the approval of the Exchange Office. Special facilities for investment of Arab capital in the Syrian Arab Republic are provided by Legislative Decree No. 348 of Decem- ber 29, 1969. Other facilities perm i t t ing residents and nonresidents of any na t iona l i ty to open foreign currency accounts in the Syrian Arab Republic with imported funds are based on Decree No. 779 of April 1, 1970 and Order No. 191 of April 23, 1970. Neither type of facility is applicable to funds received over clearing accounts or by diplomatic and UN missions and their staffs. Gold Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold in the Syrian Arab Republic w i thout restriction. The domestic negotiation of gold takes place at free market prices that are in line w i th world free market prices. Imports and exports of gold are free from import or export licensing. Import payments, however, require the approval of the Exchange Office, wh ich is gran ted only for imports for industrial use or for re-export. Export proceeds are subject to surrender. Changes during 1972 During 1972 the buy ing and selling rates in both exchange markets were kept unchanged, except dur ing the period June-September, when the rate for the Syrian pound in Beirut appreciated above the parallel market rate and the Commercial Bank of Syria temporarily lowered its parallel market buying rate to a level close to the Beirut rate, but for noncommercial transactions only. Not for Redistribution TANZANIA Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.114592 gram of fine gold per Tanzan ia Shilling, corresponding to T Sh 7.75509 = SDR 1 or T Sh 7.14286 = US$1, and Tanzania avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Tanzania deals with the Government and with authorized banks in Kenya and Uganda shillings (except Uganda bank- notes) against Tanzania shillings at par. East African shillings which have ceased to be legal tender, may still be exchanged at par by ho lders in Tanzan ia at all com- mercial banks. Administration of Control The Minister for Finance has delegated the admin- istration of exchange control to the Bank of Tanzan ia. Authority for approving normal import payments, many payments in respect of current invisibles, and some capital payments is delegated by the Bank of Tanzania to the two authorized banks, the National Bank of Commerce and the People's Bank of Zanzibar. On the mainland, import control is administered by the Imports Controller in the Bank of Tanzania and export control by the Exports Controller in the Min- istry of Commerce and Industries. The responsibility for issuing specific import and export licenses rests with the Controllers, to whom applications should be submitted by the importer or exporter in Tanzania before orders are placed abroad or exports are shipped. Import applications for most commodities, however, must be submitted through the State Trading Corpora- tion or require the endorsement of another state trad- ing agency. Zanzibar administers an independent system of foreign trade controls; all imports and the principal exports are made by the state trading agencies (Bizanje and the Zanzibar State Trading Corporation). Prescription of Currency Tanzania has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory under the terms of the U. K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U. K. exchange control regu- lations considers to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Payments to residents of countries in the Sterling Area may be made in Tanzania shillings to the credit of a Sterling Area Account in Tanzania or in any other Sterling Area cu r rency ;l receipts from such countries must be obtained in Tan- zania shillings from a Sterling Area Account in Tan- zania or in any other Sterling Area currency. Nonresident Accounts Sterling Area Accounts are held by residents of other Sterling Area countries. They may be credited freely w i th all au thor ized paymen ts to such Sterling Area coun- tries by residents of Tanzan ia, w i th t rans fe rs from other Sterling Area Accoun ts, and w i th the proceeds from sales to an authorized dealer in Tanzan ia of pounds sterling or any other Sterling Area currency. Provided that the permission of the appropriate exchange control authorities in a Sterling Area coun try has been ob ta ined, Sterling Area Accounts may exceptionally be debited for transfers to External Accoun ts in Tanzania or elsewhere in the Sterling Area, and for purchases in Tanzan ia of any non-Sterling Area currency from an authorized dealer. Accounts in Tanzania sh i l l ings held by residents of countries outside the Sterling Area other than Rhodesia with authorized banks in Tanzan ia are, w i th exchange control approval, designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments to such countries by residents of Tanzania, w i th transfers from other External Accounts, and w i th the proceeds f rom sales of any non-Sterling Area currency (other than Rhodesian currency) by nonresidents of the Sterling Area to authorized dealers. Imports and Import Payments Some impo r ts to the ma in land f rom all sources are proh ib i ted for reasons of health or security. Certain other impo r ts are not being licensed. Imports originat- ing in Kenya and Uganda are unrestricted but some require specific licenses and others may only be imported by the State Trading Corporation or on its behalf. When imported by private traders, goods other than those listed in the First Schedule of the Open General License of 1972 (which may be imported freely, irrespective of country of origin) require specific import licenses. Goods listed in the Second, Third, Fourth, F if th, and Sixth Schedules may be imported without specific licenses by the agency to which they have been assigned, which for many goods is the State Trading Corporation. All imports to the ma in land from Zanzibar require a specific license when the goods originate outside Zanzibar. All imports from South A f r ica, me t ropo l i tan Portugal, and Rhodesia are prohibited. All imports in to Zanz ibar are made by government agencies. T rans fer taxes are levied on a range of manufac tured goods when imported f rom and originating in Kenya. For some of these commodities, the tax is applicable also when they are imported from and originate in Uganda. Most imports, irrespective of their origin, are subject to sales tax at 10 per cent, 15 per cent, or 20 per cent of the c.i.f. va lue plus import duty. Advance payments for imports are allowed in excep- t ional circumstances only, exchange for import pay- ments norma l ly not being granted until after customs clearance. Most suppliers' credit requires the prior approval of the Bank of Tanzania. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are con- trolled. Authorized banks are empowered to approve TANZANIA specified categories of current payments up to estab- lished limits; amoun ts above these limits may be approved adm in is tra t ive ly by the Bank of Tanzania. The approval of the M in is ter for Finance is required where the transfer is proposed of income in excess of T Sh 1 million f rom nonresident-owned investments.3 Facilities exist whereby imm igrant noncitizens work- ing in Tanzan ia und er contract in salaried employment and w i th a firm comm i tment to leave Tanzania even- tua l ly may throughout their period of employment remit abroad up to 33V^ per cent of their monthly salary uncomm i t ted to cover fam i ly ma in tenance, sav- ings, etc. Applications to remit in excess of 33!/3 per cent of salary or in excess of T Sh 3,000 a month are considered on their merits by the Bank of Tanzania. Specified categories of expatriate employees may remit the total amount of the ir salaries. Persons mak ing uncomm i t ted remittances under these arrangements are not entitled to emigration facilities (see section on Capital, below). There is a basic allowance for travel to countries outside East Afr ica of T Sh 2,000 a person every three years for persons aged 12 or older; half of this amount is available to children aged 3 to 11 years. Travelers to destinations in border countries (Bu rund i, Ethiopia, Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Rwanda, Somalia, the Sudan, Uganda, Zaire, and Zamb ia) are restricted to T Sh 500 a year (T Sh 250 for children of 3 to 11 yea r s ). The use made of the allocation for travel to border countries is set off against the basic tourist allow- ance for travel to other countries. Applications for business, education, and health travel have to be referred to the Bank of Tanzania. Resident travelers are allowed to take out T Sh 100 in domestic currency. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency notes, travelers checks, and letters of credit up to the amount they brought in upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to South A f r ica, Portugal, all Portuguese territories, and Rhodesia are prohibited. On the main- land, exports of products dea lt with by state t rad ing organizations and of certain other products are subject to controls and, if there is a local shortage, may be restricted. Other goods may be exported without license. All principal exports of Zanzibar are sold abroad by the Zanzibar State Trading Corporation. Re-exports from Zanzibar are prohibited. Export proceeds must be collected in specified cur- rencies (see footnote 2) w i th in six mon ths from the date of exportation and must be surrendered. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see foo tno te 2) must be sold to an authorized bank upon 3 With e f fect f rom Janua ry 1, 1973, rem i t tances abroad of p ro f i ts and dividends, which had been suspended since mid-1970, were resumed. 459 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TANZANIA their collection. Travelers may bring in freely foreign currency notes; the import of Tanzania shilling notes must not exceed T Sh 100 in value for each re turn ing traveler. Capital Capital transfers to all countries are subject to con- trol by the Bank of Tanzania and are restricted. Specified capital transfers up to established amounts to all countries are approved by authorized banks; all other capital transfers require individual exchange con- trol approval. Persons leaving Tanzania permanently who have been resident in Tanzania for four years immediately prior to the date of application and who have not been availing themselves of the facility of making uncommitted remittances of savings may trans- fer their assets up to the equivalent of T Sh 20,000 for each household. All remaining funds must be cred- ited to a Blocked Account or otherwise brought under control; they may then be invested in approved Tan- zanian securities or placed on bank deposit. Income from such investments is transferable upon accrual, and redemption proceeds become transferable upon matu- rity of the securities but not less than five years from the date of purchase. Furthermore, any assets in excess of the initial emigration allowance of T Sh 20,000 are remittable in yearly installments of T Sh 20,000 each, after which any remaining amount will be considered for repatriation. Gifts to nonresidents require the prior approval of the Bank of Tanzania. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Tanzania, but to ensure eventual repatriation it is advisable to have the investment recognized by the Bank of Tanzania or to obtain a certificate of approved enterprise in terms of the Foreign Investment (Protection) Act, 1963. Foreign and domestic invest- ment in specified types of production require approval under the East Afr ican Licensing Ordinance. All imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by nonresidents of Tanzanian securities f rom residents on a recognized East African stock exchange, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income f rom such securities is remittable, as are the proceeds on resale. Purchases of securities outside Tan- zania by residents are not normally permitted. All loans or overdraf ts from residents to nonresidents or to foreign-controlled resident bodies require exchange control approval by the Bank of Tanzania. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Tan- zania for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of 460 gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler are subject to individual licensing. Licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the mone tary authorities, industrial users, and producers of newly mined gold; imports are limited to an overall import quota. Changes during 1972 January 2. The Bank of Tanzania announced that imports would be restricted in line with the new eco- nomic austerity program. January 3. The initial emigration allowance for per- sons leaving Tanzania permanently was reduced f rom T Sh 50,000 to T Sh 20,000 for each household. January 3 and 8. The Bank of Tanzania issued two Notices to Importers setting out revised import regula- tions under the Open General License, 1971. A Fourth Schedule was added to the Open General License, which specified items that could be imported only by or on behalf of the State Trading Corporation, unless the importation of any such goods had been confined to another Corporation. February 1. Government Notice No. 19 amended the First Schedule to the Open General License, 1971 by the addition of certain parts and accessories. March L The Imports Control Ordinance of Febru- ary 28 (Government Notice No. 47) was published. It contained the Open General License, 1972 and revoked the Open General License, 1971. The new Open General License contained seven schedules. The importation of all goods originating in Kenya or Uganda was authorized under the Open General License. Goods listed in the First Schedule could freely be imported, irrespective of the country of origin. Goods listed in the Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Schedules normally could be imported only by or on behalf of specified agencies or organiza- tions; for many goods the prescribed agency was the State Trading Corporation. The Seventh Schedule speci- fied the licensing procedure for goods subject to an import license and the normally prescribed payments procedure for goods covered by the Open General License. March 3. Exchange Control Circular No. 202 with- drew, with effect from February 18, 1972, the authority given to authorized dealers by Circular No. 109 to effect advance payments for imports. Henceforth, pay- ment for imports could only be made after the goods had been cleared through customs, and the establish- ment of import letters of credit required the prior approval of the Bank of Tanzania. Where importers failed to have their suppliers ship the requisite goods on these conditions, importers had to show that alter- native sources had been unsuccessfully sought before they could request the Bank of Tanzania to authorize any advance payment. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution The Circular also withdrew the authority granted to authorized dealers by Circular No. I ll to effect pay- ment for motor vehicles under home delivery arrange- ments. The Bank of Tanzania would not entertain any application for home delivery cars. June 1. Private sector imports were regulated in accordance with a foreign exchange plan. June 23. Tanzania ceased to be a Scheduled Terri- tory for the purposes of the U. K. Exchange Control Act, 1947. November 1. Exchange Control Circular No. 203 announced that with effect from December 1 imports would be subject to preshipment quality and quantity inspection and price comparison by the General Super- intendence Company Ltd. Importers would be required to produce a Clean Report of Findings before payment for imports could be made. Exempt f rom preshipment inspection and price com- parison were the following: (1) Gold, precious stones, objects of art, explosives, ammun i t ion, weapons, live TANZANIA animals, and fresh fruits and vegetables. (2) Goods procured by the East African Community or its statu- tory corporations. ( 3) Goods procured by the Zanzibar Government or other Zanzibar based importers for direct importation into Zanzibar. (4) Commodities imported from Kenya, Uganda, mainland China, Iraq, North Korea, the Seychelles, and any other country that the Bank of Tanzania might specify. (5) Consign- ments with a value in pro forma invoice of less than T Sh 10,000. (6) Commodities procured by inter- national tender. (7) Commodities procured through the Crown Agents for Overseas Governments and Administrations, London. (8) Commodities involving no payment for the goods to be imported into Tanzania, such as household and personal effects (including a used motor vehicle), gifts, and supplies for diplomatic missions and United Nations organizations. November 1. There is an Exchange Equalization Fund which limits its operations to spot transac t ions in U. S. do l la rs with commercial banks. As at Decem- ber 30, 1972, the buy ing and selling rates of the Exchange Equalization Fund for spot exchange trans- actions w i th banks in U. S. dollars were B 20.875 buy ing, and B 20.90 selling, per US$1; the authorized banks' rates were B 20.855 buy ing, and B 21.00 selling, per US$1. The authorized banks' rates for sterling are based on their buying and selling rates for the U. S. dollar and the New York rates for sterling. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Thailand on behalf of the M in is try of Finance; the Bank delegates responsibility for most transac t ions to author- ized agents (i.e., authorized banks and authorized com- panies) and to authorized persons. All incoming exchange must be sold to an authorized agent. All out- going payments are subject to approval (given auto- matically for bona fide commercial transactions and other current paymen ts ). Impor ts of gold require a license issued by the M in is try of Finance. Certain other imports and a few exports are subject to licensing by the Ministry of Economic A f fa i rs. Prescription of Currency There are no special requirements concerning the cur- rency to be used for settlements with fo re ign countries; payments are made largely in sterling and related cur- rencies or in U. S. dollars. Nonresident Accounts There are two types of nonresident accounts: Trans- ferable Accounts and Blocked Accounts. In principle, transfers of baht to and from nonresident accounts require approval; approval is not required, however, when the account is held for fore ign diplomatic entities, international organizations stationed in Thailand, or Thai nationals temporarily abroad. Transferable Accounts may be credited freely with the proceeds from sales to authorized banks of foreign currency transferred f rom abroad, with amounts transferred f rom other Transfera- ble Accounts, and with funds eligible for remittance abroad in foreign currency. Imports and Import Payments Most commodities may be impor ted free ly; but import licenses are required for some commodities, and the import of certain other items is proh ib i ted. All imports of goods o r ig ina t ing in or shipped f rom Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports of tea lea f, tea dust, and coffee are subject to a requ irement that the importer purchase a proportionate quan t i ty of the same type of goods pro- duced in Tha i land. Import licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia. Payments for imports may be approved by authorized banks upon submission of documen ts; the specific approval of the Bank of Tha i land, which is given for all bona fide transactions, is required for advance pay- ments in excess of US$1,400 and for opening revolving letters of credit or letters of credit with an exp iry date exceeding n ine months. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on paymen ts and transfers for current international transactions. Payments for invisibles require au tho r iza t ion, wh ich is usually given by an authorized bank or otherwise by the Bank of Thailand; exchange is provided freely and promptly. Cargo insurance prem iums due to foreign insurers may be remitted in foreign exchange; if they are paid in baht to an agent or branch office of an insurance company registered abroad, they may be remitted as earned income af ter taxes. The t rans fer of profits and dividends is permitted freely by the Bank of Thailand. Apart from foreign travel, fam i ly maintenance abroad, and educa- tional expenses abroad, authorized agents are permitted to approve applications for exchange without supporting documents, provided that each payment does not exceed the equivalent of US$140. Capital All ou tward t ran s fe rs of cap i ta l, inc lud ing prem iums on l i fe insurance policies, by residents or nonres iden ts are subject to approval. Gold Residents may hold and negotiate domestically gold jewe lry, gold coins, and unworked gold. Imports and exports of gold other th an jewe lry are subject to the fo l low ing arrangemen ts, unless they are effected by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. Commercial imports of gold in any fo rm are restricted and require a license issued by the M in is try of Finance. For gold bullion, the Ministry periodically fixes an authorized quan t i ty of imports; the quota for the two-year period beg inn ing February 4, 1971 is 480,000 troy ounces. A bidding system operates under which the importer o f fe r ing the highest p rem ium by tender is awarded a license as sole importer of the authorized quan t i ty for a certain period. In addition to this prem ium, wh ich accrues to the Governmen t, the importer is requ ired to pay to the Ministry of Finance a fee at the ra te of US$1.75 per troy ounce of gold. The fee is payable in baht at the par value. Exports of gold bu l l ion are pro- hibited, while those of gold o rnamen ts, when not made by fore ign tourists and exceeding B 5,000 in value, require a certificate of exportation in addition to the export entry, for presentation to the customs, but bear no export du ty or taxes. Foreign tourists may w i thout a certificate of exportation take out gold ornaments up to any va lue. The Promotion of Industrial Investment Act of February 10, 1962 was superseded by Notice No. 227 of the Na t ional Executive Council. The field of promotion was expanded but those entitled to pro- motion must be limited companies or cooperatives, so as to pave the way for the establishment of public com- panies. Certain additional incentives were also granted. November 26. The National Executive Council issued Notice No. 281 laying down rules and regulations governing alien business participation. Businesses under control were classified into three lists. Aliens could not start a new business covered by Lists A or B unless authorized by decree. Aliens could undertake new busi- ness covered by List C if permission was granted by the Director-General of the Commercial Registration Department. Aliens operating businesses prior to the enforcement of this notice and wishing to continue their businesses were required to obtain a certificate f rom the Director- General. Permission could be granted subject to the following conditions: (1) Businesses mentioned in List A could be continued for another two years, af ter which Thai ownership must be increased to a specified ratio of total capital or the business must be liquidated; and (2) The operation of businesses in Lists B and C could be continued indefinitely, but annual production and sales could not be increased by more than 30 per cent, and branches could not be opened w i thout authoriza- tion. 464 ©International Monetary Fund. Payments for Invisibles Certain payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Pay- ments for invisibles to France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transac- tion has been approved or does not require authoriza- tion. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. For tourist travel, residents traveling to countries other than France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a trip for any number of trips a year (CFAF 87,500 for children under t e n ); any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remaining after re turn to Togo must be surrendered within eight days of re-entry. For business travel, there is a special allocation of the equivalent of CFAF 20,000 a day, subject to a maximum of CFAF 400,000 a trip. The transfer of the entire net salary of a foreigner working in Togo is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, pro- vided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Direct inves tmen ts are defined as investments imp ly ing control of a company or enterprise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. Not for Redistribution TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.444335 gram of fine gold per Trinidad and Tobago dollar, corresponding to TT$2 = SDR 1 or TT$ 1.84211 = US$1, and Trinidad and Tobago avails itself of wider margins. No transactions take place at the par value, however. A fixed relation- ship w i th sterling is maintained of TT$4.80 = <£ stg. 1, and all transactions except those in sterling and cur- rencies directly linked to sterling take place at fluctuat- ing rates. The Central Bank quotes daily rates at which it stands ready to deal with the commercial banks in certain foreign currencies as well as the rates at which the commercial banks must operate with the public in these currencies in transactions not exceeding TT$ 100,000.! For transactions in excess of TT$ 100,000 the commercial banks are required to quote rates to the pub l ic not less favorab le than those fixed by the Central Bank for smaller transactions. Foreign exchange trans- actions th rough the Central Bank are for amounts of TT$25,000 and above and are subject to exchange charges up to a max imum of 1 per cent on inward and outward transfers; at present the rates charged by the Central Bank to commercial banks are Vz of 1 per cent on outward t rans fe rs and nil on inward transfers. Ster- ling exchange transactions through commercial banks are subject to va ry ing exchange charges according to the amount and mode of transfer. The banks maintain fixed exchange rates of TT$4.80 = £1 and EC$4.80 = <£! (see below) and charge commissions of % of 1 per cent and V ie of 1 per cent, respectively, for sales and purchases of telegraphic transfers of £50,000 or more. The Cen t ral Bank's buy ing and selling rates for the U .S. do l lar on December 30, 1972 (inclusive of exchange charges) were TT$204.43 and TT$205.49 per US$100. Notes issued by the East Caribbean Currency Au tho r i ty (East Caribbean dollars) and the central banks of Jamaica and Guyana are not legal tender in Trinidad and Tobago, but as a result of an arrange- ment with the monetary authorities in those areas the notes are purchased by the mone tary au tho r i t ies at par and are repa tr ia ted by them in re turn for reciprocity of t rea tment w i th respect to notes of the Central Bank of Trinidad and Tobago. The Central Bank has delegated its exchange control authority with respect to import payments to certain officials of the Ministry of Industry and Com- merce and with respect to payments up to specified amounts for certain current invisibles to authorized banks. Short-term credit transactions, such as the gran t ing of credit, loan, or ove rd ra ft facilities by resident banks to nonresidents and local nonresident-controlled companies, are also subject to control. Prescription of Currency Trinidad and Tobago has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U. K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U. K. exchange control regula- tions con t inues to be regarded as a country of the Over- seas Sterling Area. In practice, settlements with resi- dents of other parts of the Sterling Area may be made only in sterling or other Sterling Area currencies. Nonresident Accounts There are two types of nonres ident accoun ts: Exter- nal Accoun ts and Blocked Accounts/5 External Accounts may be opened by commercial banks for nonres iden ts of Trinidad and Tobago. The import regu la t ions include proh ib i t ion or string- ent con tro l, state t rad ing, ind iv idual licensing, and open general license arrangemen ts. (1) Some of the main imports that are prohibited or are subject to s t r ingent con trol are cosmetics, saccharin, coffee and cocoa beans, mechan ical gamb l ing devices, beer in con ta ine rs other than ten ounce glass bottles and cans, and complete passenger automobiles. Fire- arms, amm u n i t i o n, narcotics, and certain other goods are either proh ib i ted or r ig id ly controlled for secur i ty and hea l th reasons. (2) Cer ta in produc ts covered by the Ag r icu l tu ral Ma rke t ing Protocol of the Car ibbean Free Trade Asso- ciation (CAR I FTA ), as we ll as imported rice in bulk are the only commodities sub ject to state trading. This rice is norma l ly imported f rom Guy ana under govern- ment contracts, at agreed prices.7 (3) All commodities other than those specified under (1) and (2) above are imported under either an indi- v idual license or an open general license arrangement. As indicated below, the scope of the arrangement depends on the coun tr ies from wh ich the commodities are impor ted. (a) Imports from Albania, Bulgaria, mainland China, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Romania, Yugoslavia, and the U. S. S. R. All imports f rom these countries require a specific license. In practice, licenses are granted freely for imports from Czechoslovakia, Poland, and Yugoslavia of commodities not on the "negative" list mentioned under (b) below. For the other countries in this group, licenses are granted only for essential goods. (b) Imports from all other countries except Rho- desia and South Africa. For imports from these coun- tries, a "negative" list is published which lists all goods subject to ind iv idual licensing. (Specific licenses are usually not required for the importation of such goods, however, when they qualify for preferential treatment within the CARIFTA, of which Trinidad and Tobago is a member.) All other goods may be imported under open general license. The "negative" list comprises over 400 tar iff items. Licenses for these items may be issued by the M in i s t ry of Indus try and Commerce, depend ing on the supply position of the domestic indus t ry. Whenever restrictions are applied on imports from countries other than those under (a) above, no discrimi- nation is practiced because of the coun try of origin or the currency involved, w i th the exception that CARIFTA comm i tmen ts are taken into account. Payments for all imports require an exchange license. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles require the specific approval of the authorities. Applications for foreign exchange must be supported by appropriate documen- tary evidence. As a matter of policy, no restrictions are imposed on payments for current international transactions, except where paymen ts to Rhodesia and South A f r i ca are con- cerned. U n d er a u t h o r i ty delegated by the Governmen t, the authorized banks may approve applications for fo re ign exchange w i th in prescribed l im i ts for certain invisibles. When add i t ional amounts are needed, the approval of the au thor i t ies is required and this is granted provided that unau tho r ized capital transfers are not involved. The basic a l lowance for tourist travel is TT$2,000 a person a year.* Residents and nonresidents may take out Trinidad and Tobago notes up to the equivalent of TT$50. Travelers who are regarded as residents of Trinidad and Tobago may export pa rt or all of the ir basic travel allowance (TT$2,000) in fore ign cu r rency notes. Non- residents visiting Trinidad and Tobago may, on de- pa r tu re, take out fo re ign cu r rency notes up to the amount b rought in by them. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited and no licenses are issued for exports to South Africa. Exports of cer- tain listed goods require an individual license. The list includes some foodstuffs, arms and explosives, animals, gold, and petroleum and petroleum products produced in Trinidad and Tobago, as well as specified products (about 40 tar iff items) not produced there. Exports of all other commodities are permitted by an open general license. General licenses have been issued to permit petroleum companies to export without specific licenses. Export proceeds received in foreign currencies must be surrendered, but exporters of certain goods, notably petroleum, may be authorized to retain abroad a por- tion of their proceeds. In practice, the petroleum com- panies operating in Trinidad and Tobago repatriate for- eign exchange to the extent of their local currency needs. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from current invisibles received in foreign currencies must be surrendered. Insurance, shipping, and similar companies operating in Trinidad and Tobago are usually authorized to maintain operating accounts for receipts and expenditures in foreign cur- rency which are inherent parts of their businesses. Residents and nonresidents may bring in Trinidad and Tobago currency notes up to the equivalent of TT$50. Foreign currency notes may be imported freely by residents and nonresidents. Capital Capital transfers from Trinidad and Tobago require approval and generally are restricted. However, repay- ment of commercial credits and transfers of legacies are permitted freely, and gifts to nonresidents and emi- gration allowances are approved up to specified limits. Fur thermore, as a matter of policy, capital transfers to other CARIFTA countries are permitted liberally. For transactions in securities, 14 authorized deposi- tories have been appointed in Trinidad and Tobago. Restrictions are placed on the import and export of all securities other than securities expressed in Trinidad and Tobago dollars. Con trac tual amo r t iza t ion on sterling securities is per- mitted, and also on mortgages and other loans if the original borrowing occurred prior to September 1939 or was subsequently approved by the exchange control authorities. Proceeds from the sale of securities or other invest- ments owned by nonresidents of Trinidad and Tobago may not ordinarily be transferred and are eligible for credit only to a Blocked Account (see section on Non- resident Accounts, above); however, approval is often given to residents to purchase such assets. Nonresident capital invested in Trinidad and Tobago after Janu- ary 1950 may be repatriated together with capital gains, provided that the investment has been approved by the Government. Residents may t ran s fer prescribed securities to per- sons resident outside Trinidad and Tobago, with the prior approval of the exchange control authorities, pro- vided that the full proceeds of sale are received in for- eign currency or sterling from an External Account in any other part of the Sterling Area. Foreign exchange is not normally provided for portfolio investment by residents in foreign securities, but when securities are sold or redeemed in a market outside Trinidad and Tobago, the proceeds may either be brought in and sold to an authorized dealer at the official market rate of exchange, or, with the prior approval of the exchange control authorities, be invested outside Trinidad and Tobago in similar securities. Nonresidents may sell local securities, provided that the proceeds are credited to a Blocked Account or are reinvested in other local securities which are either irre- deemable or not redeemable within four years from the date of purchase. The laws of Trinidad and Tobago do not discriminate between nationals and foreigners in the formation and operation of companies in that country. Foreigners are 471 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TRINIDAD AND TOBAGO required, however, to obtain a license under the Aliens (Landholding) Ordinance in order to hold interest in real estate or to hold shares in local companies. Pros- pective foreign investors must obtain approval for their project from the authorities in Trinidad and Tobago in order to be able to repatriate capital and capital gains. The proposed project must satisfy the authorities that it will be either a net earner or a net saver of any cur- rency other than the Trinidad and Tobago dollar (not necessarily the original currency of investment), or alternatively, that if any loss is involved it can be justi- fied in terms of other benefits to the country. Since 1950, the Government has enacted basic incen- tive legislation designed to attract domestic and foreign investment in manufacturing and in import-substitution industries. This provides for the granting of certain concessions to industries declared to be pioneer indus- tries, i.e., industries which have not previously existed in Trinidad and Tobago or which are not being con- ducted on a commercial scale, or any industry for which there are favorab le prospects for f u t u re development. Every pioneer manufacturer is entitled to temporary relief from import duties and taxes and to other privi- leges. The proceeds (including capital gains) realized from part or all of a direct capital investment made after January 1, 1950 by a nonresident of Trinidad and Tobago in an approved project may, if desired, be repatriated at any time. The investment may have been, or may be, made in one or more of the following ways: in foreign currency (including sterling) appropriate to the investor's country of residence; in sterling eligible for remittance to the nonresident investor; or in goods and services supplied f rom the country of the investor. This right to repatriate funds is, however, subject to the following conditions: (a) The right will not normally apply to the pur- chase of shares on a stock exchange unless this pur- chase formed an integral part of an approved capital investment project. (b) When an investment did not require permission under the exchange control regulations, e.g., when it was made through a local branch, the right will be allowed only if the investor obtained exchange control approval of his project at the time the investment was made. There are limitations on the extent to which banks may g rant finance to nonresident ind iv idua ls and firms (o ther than residents of other CARIFTA countries) and to nonres iden t-con tro l led local companies. Such companies are normally required to raise any local capital needed to supplement the ir assets by issuing either shares or bonds to residents of Trinidad and Tobago. Each commercial bank must ma in ta in the mon th ly average of its net foreign exchange position w i th in a specified quan t i ta t ive ceiling. 472 Gold Gold is defined by the Exchange Control Act, 1970 as gold coin and bu l l ion. The regulations provide that, except w i th specific exemptions and permissions granted by the M in i s ter of Finance: (1) one pa r ty to every transaction in gold between residents must be an author- ized bank; (2) gold held by residents must be surren- dered to an authorized bank; and (3) gold may not be taken or sent out of Trinidad and Tobago. Residents are permitted in appropriate cases, however, to pur- chase, hold, or sell gold coins in Trinidad and Tobago for numismatic purposes. Control on the import and export of gold is adminis- tered by the M in is t ry of Indu s t ry and Commerce by regulations scheduled und er the Trade Ordinance, 1958. Imports of gold jewe l ry are on open general license, but imports of gold other than jewe lry are subject to specific import licenses issued by the Ministry of Indu s t ry and Commerce; such licenses are not normally issued except to the monetary authorities and author- ized indus t r ial users. Exports of gold, whether jewelry or otherwise, are subject to specific export licenses issued by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce; such licenses for gold other than jewelry are not normally gran ted except to the mone tary authorities. Imports of un re f ined gold are subject to import du ty at 5 per cent (p r e f e r en t i al d u t y) or 15 per cent (general duty), and those of pa r t ly worked gold at 15 per cent (preferential du ty) or 25 per cent (general duty). Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Central Bank, inc lud ing the au thor iza t ion of paymen ts for impo r ts and invisibles; some au tho r i ty is delegated to the authorized banks. Trade control is administered by the Trade Division of the M in i s t ry of Economic A f fa i r s, wh ich establishes import quotas and issues import and export licenses. Suppliers' credits are screened by the Directorate-General of External F inance in the M in i s t ry of Finance. Prescription of Currency For payment purposes, countries are classified as fol- lows: ( 1) the bilateral group, comprising countries with which Tunisia has concluded bilateral payments agree- ments (Bulgaria, mainland China, Czechoslovakia, Egypt, Eastern Germany, Hungary, India, Poland, Ro- mania, and the U. S. S. R.) and (2) the area of con- vertibility, comprising all other countries. Settlements with countries in the bilateral group are made in clear- ing dollars with Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Egypt, East- ern Germany, Hungary, Poland, and Romania, in rupees with India, in Tunisian dinars with the U. S. S. R., and in Swiss agreement francs with main- land China; settlements with countries in the area of convertibility are generally made in convertible cur- rencies quoted by the Central Bank (see footnote 1) or in Tunisian dinars through the accounts of residents of those countries. Payments for imports must normally be made, in accordance with the foregoing, on the basis of the country of origin. Certain settlements between Tunisia and Morocco may be effected through accounts at the two central banks. Under a triangular compensa- tion agreement with Bulgaria and India, settlements are cleared through a Special Account at the Bank of Bul- garia.
