Imports and Import Payments All impor ts f rom Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited, and the fo l low ing does not apply to these countries. Import licenses are required for all impo r ts except those on importers' cards or import certificates and im- ports under an a n n u al import au thor iza t ion. All import applications must be submitted for the approval (avis technique) of the competent ministry or government agency. The prior approval of the Ministry of Finance is required for all imports, irrespective of origin, that are financed with suppliers' credits. Import licenses must be approved by the Trade Division of the Minis- try of Economic Affa irs and by the Central Bank, which authorizes the corresponding payment. Imports f rom the French Franc Area, other than those covered by bilateral or global quotas or by an import prohibi- tion, are in principle free f rom licensing and require only a payments authorization from the Central Bank. In practice, however, all applications for payments authorizations are submitted by the Central Bank to the Trade Control Division for prior endorsement. Certain imports are regulated by arrangements which apply to all countries: (1) "Prohibited" imports may be licensed in exceptional circumstances, at the discre- tion of the authorities. (2) Some 25 commodities or groups of commodities are licensed against annual global quotas. (3) Certain spare parts and a few other commodities may be imported free of license against TUNISIA the presentation of an importer's card, up to D 500 a year for each importer. (4) Some 200 listed commodi- ties or groups of commodities, may be imported freely and without license by industrialists, traders, crafts- men, and fa rme rs for their own use, against the com- pletion of an "import certificate." (5) Imports required by manu fac tu re rs for their own use are licensed under annual import authorizations. Bilateral quotas are fixed annua l ly for certain imports f rom France not covered by any of the five arrange- ments outlined above. Imports under these quotas require licenses. The quotas cover such goods as per- fume ry and cosmetics, toilet soap, clothing, air condi- tioners, washing and drying machines, and motor cars. In addition, special procedures apply to certain other imports from France that are affected by Tunisia's Association Agreement with the EEC; such commodi- ties also require a license when imported from France (see below). All other imports f rom France, and all imports from other countries in the French Franc Area unless cov- ered by one of the five procedures outlined above, require only a payments authorization from the Central Bank which, in principle, is issued freely but in prac- tice is not issued without the prior endorsement of the Trade Control Division. Certain imports from Algeria are admitted freely and are exempt from customs duty. All imports not covered by one of the arrange- ments described above, when originating in countries ou ts ide the French Franc Area w i th wh ich Tunisia does not ma in ta in bilateral paymen ts agreements, are regulated as follows (subject to fu r ther special arrange- men ts that apply to imports from EEC coun tr ies): impo rt licenses for goods included in a liberalized list are in principle issued freely, wh i le all other goods are licensed w i th in quo tas under bilateral trade agreements, or on a more discretionary basis when originating in countries with which no agreement is in force.2 In addition to the above arrangements, there are cer- ta in special procedures for impor ts of specified goods o r ig ina t ing in member countries of the EEC. Imports from countries w i th wh ich Tunisia ma in- ta ins bilateral p a ym e n ts agreemen ts are licensed within b i l a t e r a l ly agreed quo ta limits unless the goods are among the few for wh i ch global quo tas have been set. Imports of specified commodities are licensed in such a manner as to ensure the utilization of tied foreign aid. Cer ta in commod i t ies are imported under state trad- ing. These inc lude goods subject to government monop- olies, e.g., tobacco, matches, p lay ing cards, and imports f rom the United States under U. S. P.L. 480. In addi- t ion, cer ta in gove rnment agencies, of which the ma in one is the Office du Commerce, have been granted a monopoly over the import of commod i t ies fa l l ing w i th in * Countries with which bilateral trade agreements are in force i n c l u de most Eu rop e an OECD coun tr ies, in add i t ion to the countries w i th w h i ch p a ym e n ts agreemen ts have been conc luded (see section on P r e s c r i p t i on of C u r r e n c y, above ). 475 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TUNISIA their sphere of activity (coffee, tea, sugar, specified fruits, etc.). Moreover, certain other commodities, such as timber, paper, and certain metallurgical products, may be imported only by importers who are members of an importers' association. Imports by such associa- tions and by state agencies are subject to the same licensing arrangements as those applicable to private imports. To obtain an import license, importers must be listed in the commercial register and must have received a code number. All import documents involving payments must be domiciled (registered) with an authorized bank. In addition to customs duties, a number of import taxes are applied. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require the approval of the Central Bank; for some invisibles th is authority has been delegated to the authorized banks. Payments for a number of current invisibles are approved freely, provided that they are properly docu- mented. These include various payments related to inter- national trade (e.g., port services, wa rehous ing, com- missions, brokerage, and charges and profits related to transit operations) and paymen ts for processing, repair, assembly, royalties, patents and trademarks, taxes, fines, and court expenses, as well as payments of interest and amortization arising from contractual obligations to nonresidents. Approval is also given for remittances of profits and dividends due to nonresidents. Indus t r ial and export companies are permitted to d is tr ibu te d iv idends to their shareholders free ly, and commercial companies up to 10 per cent of their paid-up capital and reserves, pro- vided that over 50 per cent of the share capital of such companies is owned by residents. These companies require only the approval of the Central Bank for the rem i t tance of d iv idends; such approval is given promp t ly. All companies not mee t ing the above criteria require first the prior approval of the Central Bank for the dis- tr ibu t ion of d iv idends. Once such approval is obtained, the au tho r iza t ion to remit the profits abroad is also given promp t ly. In addition, exporters ho ld ing balances on EFAC accounts (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below) may use these free ly for expenditures abroad in connection w i th pa r t ic ipa t ion in in te rna t ional trade fairs, and for customs du t ies and other expenses related to sh ipment of exports to France. Exporters as well as hotel owners may use EFAC balances freely for pub- l i c i ty expenses abroad, and up to f ixed l im i ts (see below) for certain other expenses. Enterprises pro- ducing for export may freely make certain payments for invisibles. Paymen ts for ce r ta in other cu r rent invisibles are approved up to fixed l im i ts. Residents t rave l ing abroad as tou r is ts are en t i t led once a year to an exchange allo- cation equ iva lent to D 50 a person (D 25 for children 476 under t en ). The allocation may be taken up in the form of foreign banknotes, the export of which is sub- ject to the authorization of the Central Bank. Foreign exchange is also sold for living expenses of Tunisians s tudy ing abroad, up to the equ iva lent of D 50 a month for s tudy in France, and up to D 57 a mon th for other countries ( for study in the United States, amounts in excess of the latter allocation are authorized on a case- by-case bas is). These amoun ts are additional to the cost of tu i t ion fees. Exporters and hotel owners holding EFAC accounts may use such balances up to the equiv- alent of D 1,000 a year for business travel abroad; the use of excess amounts by exporters may be approved by the Central Bank in certain circumstances, depend- ing on the magnitude of their exports. Foreign nationals employed in Tunisia by private or semipublic com- panies may t rans fer up to 50 per cent of their monthly wages or salaries, subject to a max imum of D 100 a mon th if their fam i ly lives in Tunisia or D 150 a month if they do not have their fam i ly w i th them. Foreign experts employed by the public sector may transfer abroad 50 per cent of their monthly salaries. The export of Tunisian banknotes is prohibited. The reconversion of domestic banknotes by nonresident travelers is restricted to 30 per cent of the amount of foreign currency previously sold, subject to a maximum of D 100. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel, Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Exports to other par ts of the French Franc Area and liberalized exports not exceed- ing D 50 to other countries do not require a license. All other exports require export licenses. The export of wine is the monopoly of the Office du Vin and the export of cereals is the monopoly of the Office des Cereales. The export of olive oil is the monopoly of the Office National de 1'Huile. For all exports, with the exception noted below, exporters must give an under- taking to repatriate the exchange proceeds; the repatria- tion must ordinarily take place within 15 days from the date payment is due and in any event within 100 days from the date of shipment unless otherwise allowed by the Central Bank. Exporters and hotel owners may have credited to special EFAC (Exportations-Frais Acces- soires) accounts the equivalent in dinars of a part of their export proceeds. For exporters the limits are 4 per cent if export proceeds are repatriated more than 30 days after shipment of the merchandise, and 6 per cent if repatriation occurs within 30 days following shipment. Exporters' balances on EFAC accounts are not subject to limitation. For hotel owners, credits are limited to 2 per cent of their foreign exchange pro- ceeds, and cannot exceed D 1,000 a year. Balances in EFAC accounts may be used fu l ly for specified pay- ments abroad. The accounts may be maintained in con- vertible or bilateral dinars, depending on the currency surrendered. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Under the provisions of Law No. 27-38 of April 27, 1972, nonresident manufacturing enterprises (i.e., enter- prises whose capital is held by nonresidents and has been constituted to the extent of at least 66 per cent through the import of convertible currencies) pro- ducing exclusively for export are exempt from the requirement of repatriation and surrender of export proceeds. Proceeds from Invisibles Residents must repatriate and surrender all amounts derived from services rendered to persons resident abroad, inc lud ing residents of the French Franc Area, and also all other income or proceeds from invisibles received from countries outside the French Franc Area. However, Tunisian na t iona ls who are working abroad may retain the coun terva lue of their foreign currency earnings in convertible dinar accounts. Foreign bank- notes and coins (except gold coins) may be brought in freely but must be declared upon entry. The import of Tunisian banknotes is prohibited. Capital All nonresidents, inc lud ing residents of o ther coun- tries of the French Franc Area, who wish to invest in Tunisia are required to obtain the prior approval of the Tun is ian authorities in order to secure the gua ran tee for the t rans fer of pr inc ipal of, and cu r rent earnings f rom, such inves tmen ts. Foreign inves tment in Tunisia may obtain certain benefits provided for by the Investment Code (Law No. 69-35) of J u ne 26, 1969. These include a number of tax facilities as well as a guarantee of the right to repatriate capital and to transfer profits. Furthermore, Law No. 27-38 of April 27, 1972 provides for various special benefits for nonresident manufacturing enter- prises, including an exemption from the repatriation requirement in respect of export proceeds. All fore ign na t iona ls who have been residents of Tun is ia may upon leaving Tunisia permanen t ly have their domestic b ank balances credited to Suspense Accounts; the same applies to all proceeds f rom the liquidation of fo re ign inves tmen ts not covered by a t rans fer gu a r an t ee (e.g., personal real es ta te ). The con- version in to foreign exchange of the amoun ts deposited is then authorized, after verification, up to D 4,000. All cap i tal t rans fe rs by Tun is ian na t iona ls require the approval of the Central Bank. The purchase by Tun is ian res iden ts of fore ign securities on foreign stock exchanges is, in pr inc ip le, forb idden; in some instances, au tho r iza t ion is granted for a resident to subscribe abroad to a share issue by an enterprise in which he is a lready a shareholder. Gold Five gold coins issued for commemorative purposes are legal tender. Residents may hold and acquire gold TUNISIA coins in Tunisia for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the mone tary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. By virtue of Law No. 63-46 of December 19, 1963, the Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of gold in any form other than jewelry and over the sale of unworked gold to domestic indus- trial users, jewelers, hand icraft workers, and dentists. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Central Bank; such licenses are not normally granted. Changes during 1972 February 4. Notice No. 116 increased the number of goods that could be imported under the "import certificate" procedure and provided that this procedure henceforth could be used also by traders, craftsmen, and farmers. February 4. Global quotas for imports from all sources were announced for 1972. February 22. Two import quota lists for 1972 were published, one for imports originating in any EEC country (including France), and the other for imports originating in France. April 27. Law No. 72-38 introduced special incen- tives to export oriented manufacturing industries, addi- tional to those provided by the Investment Code. Enter- prises producing exclusively for export became eligible for certain tax and customs duty exemptions and tax reductions. Nonresident manufacturing enterprises (i.e., those whose capital is held by nonresidents and has been constituted to the extent of at least 66 per cent through the import of convertible currencies) were exempted from the requirement of repatriation and surrender of the proceeds from exports, income, and services rendered; however, all payments made by them in Tunisia, had to be effected through Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dinars. Eligible resident enter- prises remained subject to the repatriation and sur- render requirements but could freely make payments and transfers abroad that were related to their produc- tion and to the distribution of dividends to nonresident shareholders. Eligible enterprises could freely import any goods necessary for their production but remained subject to the foreign trade formalities insofar as their sales in Tunisia were concerned. Exports to payments agreement countries were not eligible for the above privileges. Certain tax facilities were also introduced for enterprises exporting part of their production. May 9. Notice No. 117 modified the regulations governing nonresident accounts. Those relating to the French Franc Area (EZF Accounts and IZF Accounts) were abolished. Henceforth the regulations distinguished between Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dinars, For- eign Accounts in Bilateral Dinars, and Foreign Accounts in Foreign Currencies. 477 ©International Monetary Fund. June 26. A special payments arrangement between the Bank of Morocco and the Central Bank of Tunisia was signed. It came into operation on July 1. June 30. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Ministry of Finance. Trade control is the responsibility of the Min- istry of Commerce which is also in charge of the prep- aration of import programs. The Ministry, or the Central Bank on the advice of the Ministry, allocates foreign exchange; certain fore ign exchange allocations for imports require prior approval of the competent ministry, even if the commodity is included in the liberalized lists. The Central Bank issues import licenses on ins truc t ions of the M in is try of Commerce. Export registration is carried out by professional organizations (the Exporters Union, the Chambers of Commerce, of Indus try, and of Commerce and Indus try) according to the instructions of the Ministry of Commerce; export licenses are issued by the M in is try, which may delegate * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. Import and export licenses for gold, however, are issued by the Ministry of Finance. Prescription of Currency Settlements w i th countries with which Turkey has bilateral payments agreements 2 are made in accordance w i th the terms of the re levant agreement. Certain com- mercial settlements w i th the other members of the Regional Cooperation for Development (Iran and Paki- s tan) are made th rough special accounts denominated in U. S. dollars. Settlements w i th other countries are made in convertible currencies. Residents and nonresi- dents are perm i t ted to open accounts in Turkey that are denom ina ted in convertible Turkish liras. Imports and Import Payments Impor ts f rom Rhodesia are prohibited; imports of old, used and reconditioned, defective, substandard, soiled, or poor-quality goods are forbidden, except with the authorization of the Ministry of Commerce. All commercial imports require import licenses, which are valid for five months, and, generally, goods must be cleared through the customs within five months. Import licenses are issued to registered importers (import m e r ch an t s ), industrialists (manu fac tu re rs importing for the ir own needs ), state economic enterprises, and gov- e rnment departments. Private individuals and corporate bodies are required to secure an "importer's certificate" issued by the M in is try of Commerce before sub- m i t t ing applications through the authorized banks for licenses to import goods for commercial purposes. The importer's tax status is taken into consideration when g ran t ing such certificates. However, exporters, mine operators, shipowners, building contractors who have undertaken the construction of state establish- ments, tourist establishments, and registered manufac- turers are not required to secure an "importer's cer- tificate" for imports to be used exclusively for their own needs; a certificate establishing their qualification is issued by the respective public authority, i.e., the Chambers of Commerce and Industry, the Exporters Union, or the Ministry of Tourism and Information. Most goods are imported in accordance with the pro- visions of import programs, which are planned for one year. The import programs, which include commodities financed w i th funds from the U. S. Agency for Inter- national Development (A ID ), classify imports in two categories: (1) an annual list of liberalized goods, con- sisting of two parts (lists I and I I ), for which import licenses are issued freely; and (2) a list of goods sub- ject to global quotas published annually. The list of liberalized goods and the list of global quotas apply, in principle, only to imports f rom coun tr ies other than those with which Turkey has bilateral paymen ts ag reemen ts ;3 goods not included in either of these two import lists may not be imported under the bilateral quotas. For some goods on the lib- eralized and global quota lists, importers have the option of applying for exchange allocations f rom U. S. AID funds for orders exceeding US$10,000 in value; there are no goods on these lists, however, that may be imported only with U. S. AID funds and only from the United States. Certain imports f rom member coun- tries of the EEC are included in a list of liberalized items consolidated to the EEC and are free of quantita- tive restriction; most of the items on this 'list are included in liberalized lists I and II, while the remain- der is included in the quota list. Applications for import licenses for goods on the liberalized lists may be submitted at any time to author- ized banks, which transfer them to the Ministry of Commerce for examination and prepare the import licenses and fo rwa rd these to the Central Bank for approval on the Ministry's instructions. For certain liberalized goods, the prior approval of the ministry concerned is also required. There are special arrange- ments administered by the Ministry of Commerce to fac i l i ta te pr ior i ty allocation of foreign exchange for imports of raw materials and supplementary materials required for export production. The list of import quotas contains quotas for regis- tered importers and for industrialists. Quotas for indus- trialists are allocated annu a l ly and for importers semi- annua l ly. Imports on the quota list can be subdivided in to two broad categories —imports which do not, and imports which do, require a permit f rom a specified public body. Foreign exchange allocations for quota imports w i th in the quan t i ta t ive limit established for each quota item are made by the Central Bank for imports not requ i r ing a permit, and by the Ministry of Commerce (on the advice of the responsible author- i t y) for those requiring a permit. Some of the quota imports also require a certificate confirming that the articles are not manu fac tu red by local indus t ry and do not exist in the local market in sufficient quan t i ty and qua l i ty; the required certificate is the responsibility of the Ministry of Industry and Technology, which may delegate au tho r i ty to the Chambers of Commerce and Indus t ry. Allocations against quotas in the first cate- gory are distributed by semester; applications must be 3 When perm i t t ing imports of goods on the liberalized or quota lists from nonagreemen t, non-OECD countries, the Ministry of Commerce takes the ba lance of t rade and paymen ts w i th these coun tr ies in to ac- count. No single importer may apply for more than 20 per c e n t4 of half of the quota set for any par t icu lar commodity; exceptions are possible when this amount does not cover the price of one unit. Upon examination of applications, the Ministry of Commerce instructs the Central Bank to issue a foreign exchange allocation letter valid for four months, and an import license must be secured f rom the Central Bank within the period of va l id i ty of the foreign exchange allocation letter. Applications for quota imports requiring a permit f rom a specified public au tho r i ty must be submitted to the responsible body each semester by importers and each year by industrialists. Upon examination of the application, the Ministry of Commerce instructs the responsible body to issue a foreign exchange allocation ("certificate of need") valid for four months but not longer than one mon th beyond the period of effective- ness of the quota list. An import license must then be secured f rom the Central Bank dur ing the period of va l id i ty of the certificate of need. Impor ts are to be made at the best ruling world market prices. For this purpose a certificate must be obtained from the Office of Price Registration and Con- trol af ter issuance of the import license or the certificate of need. However, pub l ic sector imports of goods on liberalization list I may be authorized by the Central Bank w i thout a price con fo rm i ty certificate. The import license permits the necessary foreign exchange payment to be made. Payments for imports may be made against letters of credit, documents, or goods (i.e., upon customs c learance). However, for imports on liberalized list I and for those financed f rom U. S. AID fund s, payments may be made only against a letter of credit. When the payment is to be made against a letter of credit, registered importers and industrialists are required to prepay in local cur- rency, at the time of application for an import license, the equivalent of the foreign exchange for which they have applied. For payments against documents or against goods for global quota list imports, importers and industrialists are required to prepay half of the value of the imports w i th the application for an import license. Importers are required to make the foreign exchange transfer w i th in four months from the date of the import license for payments against documents and w i th in two mon ths f rom the date of customs clearance for payments against goods. Imports f rom bilateral agreement countries are sub- ject to separate quotas. These are established only for commodities that appear on the liberalization or global quota lists. TURKEY authorized to conclude agreements to dispose of goods acquired through supporting purchases made by the State. Imports without an allocation of foreign exchange may be permitted by the customs authorities, the Cen- tral Bank, or the Ministry of Finance, under certain conditions. Travelers domiciled in Turkey may bring in for personal or professional (but noncommercial) use goods and machinery with a limit of LT 2,500,8 in addi- tion to personal effects. Separate limits and conditions apply to imports of goods for personal use, and of pro- fessional instruments and machines, by persons having resided abroad for employment or study; these limits and conditions va ry with the stay abroad and with the transfer to Turkey of foreign exchange. Companies or cooperatives formed in Turkey by residents temporarily working abroad may import investment goods to the extent of the foreign exchange invested. In addition to personal effects, foreign tourists may import goods and machinery for their personal or family use. Foreign contractors may temporarily import machin- ery, vehicles, and scientific instruments without request- ing an allocation of foreign exchange, provided that the goods are proved to be necessary for their operations in Turkey and may not be imported on a temporary basis under the relevant customs regulations. Foreign companies established in Turkey may import spare parts not intended for new investments without requesting an allocation of foreign exchange, provided that the goods are necessary for their operations. All such imports require the permission of the exchange control authori- ties. Goods imported on these terms must not be sold to third parties in Turkey. Import of an automobile 9 without payment of for- eign exchange may be permitted by the Central Bank or the Ministry of Finance, provided that certain conditions are met relating to residence abroad and to remittance and sale to authorized banks in Turkey of foreign exchange. Automobiles imported without a foreign exchange allocation may be sold to residents by the Turkish nationals who have imported them. Foreign diplomats in Turkey may sell their automobiles to Turkish residents provided that the necessary import duties are paid at the time of the sale, that Turkish diplomats in the seller's coun try are granted reciprocal privileges, and that pro- ceeds from such sales are not transferred abroad. For- eign officials, other than diplomats, may not sell to Turkish nationals any automobiles imported duty free under special agreements. Other foreign nationals resi- dent in Turkey may import automobiles under certain conditions, but they must be exported after three years; however, this three-year period may be extended, and the Ministry of Finance may also permit the sale of such cars to the State Supply Office or to nonprofit orga- 8 Increased to LT 3,000 on February 1, 1973. 9 Automobiles are not included in the import program. 481 ©International Monetary Fund. In addition to customs du ty, imported goods are sub- ject to the fo l low ing charges: ( 1) a customs surcharge of 15 per cent of the applicable customs d u t y; (2) a s tamp du ty of 10 per cent of the declared value;10 ( 3) a quay du ty of 5 per cent on the sum of c.i.f. value, customs du ty, customs surcharge, s tamp du ty, and cus- toms clearance expenses; and (4) a production tax rang ing genera l ly f rom 10 per cent to 75 per cent on the sum of c . i . f. va lue, customs du ty, customs surcharge, stamp du ty, customs c lea r ing expenses, and quay du ty. The quay d u ty is not payab le on goods imported by air. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles require exchange licenses which usually are issued by the Central Bank. These are granted liberally for the fo l low ing purposes, provided that applications are accompanied by specified docu- ments: payments related to trade ( inc lud ing sh ipp ing cos ts), subscriptions to newspapers and periodicals, pur- chases of books, payments for registration fees, adver- tising expenses, consulate income, payments by the Government, paymen ts by the Post Office Adm in is t ra- tion and similar state institutions, banks' commissions and expenses, a proportion of insurance companies' payments, specified technical assistance, repair and assembly expenses, and legal fees for commercial trans- actions. The transfer of income related to foreign investments approved under the Law for the Encourage- ment of Foreign Investment is permitted free ly. Interest on long-term loans and credits extended by nonresidents to enterprises in Turkey (including those of an agricul- tural na tu re) may be granted transferab i l i ty between foreign nationals both in Turkey and abroad. Turkish citizens are not allowed to leave the country without hav ing obtained an allocation of exchange for travel, but th is does not apply to fore ign nationals resid- ing in Turkey. Tourist travel is restricted to one trip a person a year, except for travel to Cyprus. The allow- ance of exchange for tourist travel is up to the equiva- lent of US$400 a calendar year; travelers are not allowed to leave the country unless they are carrying at least the equivalent of US$200 in foreign exchange (US$110 for persons under 18 years of age, the pur- chase of this amount not being manda to ry ). Turkish citizens traveling to Cyprus may obtain an exchange allocation equivalent to up to US$400 on request; this does not affect their right to claim the tourist travel allowance. Under an export tax rebate scheme, direct and indi- rect taxes paid are re funded when manu fac tu res or produc ts are exported. There are basically four rates of r e fund: 5, 15, 25, and 30 per cent of specified direct and indirect taxes.15 However, 10 percentage points more in tax re funds is granted to exporters who sell more than US$1.2 million of goods benef i t ing from a re fund. Reduced rates of re fund apply for certain goods when exported to bilateral payments agreement countries, and other goods exported to these countries do not qualify for a tax re fund. In addition, va ry ing provisional rates of r e fund not exceeding 10 per cent were introduced pending final classification of some commodities. The tax re fund must not exceed the amount of indirect taxes and charges actually paid. The amounts deposited plus the interest can be w i thdrawn at any time. For- eign travelers w i sh ing to take out articles with a value exceeding LT 2,000 must show proof that they have converted fore ign exchange to cover the portion of the cost exceeding this limit. The import of Turkish banknotes and coins by trav- elers (whe ther of Turkish or foreign na t iona l i ty) is limited to LT 100. The import of fore ign currency by travelers is unres tr ic ted. Capital Foreign investments in Turkey require approval. Capital transfers abroad by residents and capital trans- actions between residents and nonresidents are subject to the approval of the exchange control authorities. Residents are not normally permitted to acquire foreign securities or real estate. With the exception of certain investments made in accordance w i th the provisions of the Law for the En- couragement of Foreign Investments (No. 6224) or the Petroleum Law (No. 6326 ), foreign companies and contractors who wish to do business in Turkey must import the required capital and operating funds in the form of foreign exchange, although under certain conditions blocked funds may be used for investment in the tourist indus try. Borrowing in Turkish liras by such foreign companies and contractors is subject to quotas set by the Ministry of F inance in accordance with their equity capital in Turkey. Blocked f u n ds are those accrued or accruing to non- residents but not transferable under the existing ex- change control regulations. These include the sales proceeds of real estate situated in Turkey and owned by nonresident physical or juridical persons, insofar as the property is not covered by Law No. 6224 or Law No. 6326. Except for approved investments, non- residents may not convert into foreign currency any assets or balances owned by them, or earnings accruing to them; all earnings are blocked but if, at the end of the calendar year, such earnings are less than LT 5,000, the amount involved is deblocked. Subject to individual permission, blocked assets and balances may be utilized w i th in Turkey, e.g., for the payment of taxes, insurance, and ma in tenance and repair of property; and for living expenses of up to LT 4,500 a month for each beneficiary for owners of such funds or their authorized representatives, and up to LT 2,500 for certain relatives. They may not, however, be utilized as business capital except for investment in the tourist industry. Normally, such blocked funds may not be transferred to others except by legal succession. The investment of blocked funds in the tourist industry is subject to the following conditions: (1) there must be a contribution in new foreign exchange or imported equipment equal to at least 50 per cent of the blocked 483 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution TURKEY funds to be used and (2) the investor must undertake not to request transfer for at least five years of that part of the capital financed by means of the blocked funds. Blocked f u n ds used in this manner are considered as foreign capital imported under the Law for the En- cou ragement of Foreign Investments. Balances on nonresident accounts established at the Central Bank in accordance w i th the Paris Agreement on Commercial Debts Owed by Residents of Turkey (1959) may be used either partially or wholly by the creditors for investment or to pay expenses in Turkey at any time pr ior to the date, established under the Agreement, when the balances may be t rans fe r red. The use of these balances for investment purposes is subject to the provisions of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments. However, invested funds and income related thereto may not be transferred abroad before the transfer date established under the Agree- ment, except for investment in the export industries or in other industries earn ing foreign exchange; in such instances the equivalent of up to 25 per cent of the investment may be transferred annually. Foreign capital invested in Turkey under the terms of the Law for the Encouragement of Foreign Investments is accorded preferential treatment, provided that the enterprise in which the investment is to be made is deemed to contribute to the economic development of the country, or will operate in a field of activity open to Turkish pr iva te enterprise and will not entail monopoly or special privilege. Under this law, all or part of the invested capital or fore ign loans may be remitted abroad in the original currency of the capital. Upon application, the M in is t ry of Finance guaran tees the t rans fer of divi- dends and of the proceeds f rom the sale or liquidation of shares or stock cer t if ica tes registered on the books of companies established under the law. Such registered shares or stock certificates are freely transferab le between fore ign nationals, both in Turkey and abroad, and between foreign nationals and residents. The trans- fer guaran tees pass on to the new owner, provided that his name is no t if ied to the M in is t ry of Finance; if the shares or stock certificates are sold to a resident, how- ever, they must be presented to the M in is t ry of Finance for cancellation of the guarantees. The capital and interest on long-term loans and credits extended by non- residents to enterprises in Turkey ( inc lud ing those of an ag r icu l tu ral cha rac te r) may be accorded the same trans- fer benef i ts. Foreign capital imported under the Petro- leum Law is accorded add i t ional p re fe ren t ial t rea tmen t. By v ir tue of a policy statement of December 1971, Turkish par t ic ipa t ion in new foreign inves tmen ts no longer is subject to a m in imum of 51 per cent. In addi- tion to inves tmen ts under Law No. 6224, foreign invest- ments outside the petroleum sector may be made "under the monetary regulations," in which case the investor does not enjoy any t rans fer facilities for earnings or liquidation proceeds. Transac t ions in securities, inc lud ing their export and 484 import, require approval when nonresident interests are involved. Banks have been granted certain general permissions allowing them to borrow convertible currencies from nonresidents for relending to nonresidents. Most bor- rowing from nonresidents by residents other than banks requires individual approval.16 Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Turkey for num isma t ic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other than jewe l ry, at home or abroad; any unworked gold held in Turkey, however, may be pre- sented for m in t ing by the State M in t. Imports and exports of gold in any fo rm other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally g ran ted except for imports and exports by or on beha lf of the mone ta ry au tho r i t ies and indus- t r ial users. Changes during 1972 January 4. The 1972 import program was published, accompanied by substantial modifications of import regulations. Imports under the program were expected to amount to US$1,300 million during the year, of which US$570 million was under the liberalization lists (US$455 million in 1971) and US$400 million was under the quota list (US$270 million in 1971). Some 44 tariff positions were added to the liberalized import lists. Other modifications aimed at reducing administra- tive delays in the operation of the import system. Price control procedures were substantially eased, notably by an exemption f rom price control for certain industrial imports and permission for ex post control for certain other commodities. Quotas for industrialists would be allocated on a yearly basis rather than semiannually, in order to facilitate production planning. The utilization period of foreign exchange allocation letters was raised from two months to four months. There was no change in the guarantee deposit rates. January 12. For the importation by the public sector of goods under liberalization list I, the Central Bank was authorized to issue import permits without requir- ing a price conform i ty certificate. January 24. Several manu fac tu res, including speci- fied textiles, metal goods, and chemicals, were added to the list of items that could be exported on nine-month credit terms (aga inst payment in a convertible currency and subject to a bank gua ran tee ). Under this facility, the foreign exchange proceeds could be repatriated up to nine months a f ter shipment. February 12. A credit facility was created for the growers of six traditional export commodities, viz., cot- 16 On Janua ry 3, 1973 such approval norma l ly became subject to the condition that the borrower must pay into a special fund any interest ra te d i f fe ren t ial compared with similar borrowing in Turkey. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ton, grapes, figs, olive oil, hazelnuts, and pistachio nuts. February 14. Several items were added to the list of commodities eligible for a 5 per cent tax rebate when exported. February 14. The export regime for 1972 was announced. It incorporated certain changes designed to secure more speedy and efficient procedures. A special expeditious approval procedure, formerly applied only to perishable goods, was extended to some 70 per cent of total exports. Indicative export prices would continue to be set by the Ministry of Commerce but the authority to approve export applications at prices in excess of these prices was delegated to professional organizations. Price control procedures for fu tu re sales were also simplified; whereas price conformity was previously sought at the time of exportation, it was now to be sought only at the time the export contract was entered into. A more permissive approach was to be adopted in extending the time period of export permits. Finally, export licenses would in fu tu re be required only for exports to bilateral countries (ra ther than to all non- OECD countries) and for all exports of a few com- modities specified in the export list. February 16. The 1972 import quota for private sec- tor investments was increased by US$150 million. March 3. The formalities for imports under the pri- vate sector investment quota were eased. March 12. The facility for exports on a credit basis, under which exchange proceeds could be repatriated up to nine months af ter shipment, was again expanded in coverage. All industrial products (except foodstuffs, liquor, and sultanas) eligible for tax rebates could henceforth be exported on a credit basis against a bank guarantee. March 12. The Ministry of Commerce announced that all industrial products eligible for tax rebates could henceforth be exported on a nine-month credit basis, subject to a bank guaran tee and provided that export proceeds were received in convertible currencies. March 14. The import entitlement of returning expa- triate workers and professionals af ter a two-year stay abroad was raised from LT 12,000 to LT 20,000 for TURKEY professional equipment and machinery. Furthermore, the additional entitlement for each month in excess of a two-year stay abroad was raised from LT 500 to LT 1,000. June 6. The Ministy of Industry and Technology pub- lished a decree listing production sectors and investment fields to be given the benefit of 100 per cent customs tax exemption. This decree, superseding all previous regulations, became effective immediately. July 3. In view of the floating of the pound sterling, new official buy ing and selling rates for sterling were established. These rates were not modified until Novem- ber 1. July 13. Commissions for certain services relating to imports (services provided by commercial agents, bro- kers, distributors, e tc .), when earned by Turkish nation- als, had to be repatriated to Turkey in foreign exchange, with certain exceptions. July 19. The Regulatory and Reserve Import Quota, earmarked for inves tment imports, was increased by US$60 million. July 27. Marginal reserves had to be deposited with the Central Bank against accounts in convertible Turk ish liras opened by residents or nonresidents. Fur- thermore, certain changes were made in the terms and interest rates for such accounts held by nonresidents. (With effect f rom J anu a ry 3, 1973, foreign physical and ju r id ical persons not resident or established in Turkey could no longer open or credit demand accounts in con- vertible Turk ish liras, a l though existing balances could be ma in ta ined; w i th effect from April 3, 1973, such for- eign persons had to liquidate their time deposits ma in- tained in convertible Turkish liras.) The Bank of Uganda does not deal in foreign cu r renc ie sT other than sterling, U. S. dollars, and deutsche ma rk; its rate for the U. S. dollar is fixed and its rates for sterling and deutsche mark are based on the previous day's London rates against the U. S. dollar. Authorized commercial banks in Uganda deal in all specified currencies 2 and base their rates on the previous day's closing rates against the U. S. dollar in London, except for Kenya and Tan- zania shillings, which are dealt in at par. East African shillings (which have ceased to be legal tender) may be exchanged at par at the Bank of Uganda and the authorized banks. The latter may freely deal forward with customers in sterling, U. S. dollars, and other cur- rencies, provided that there is an underlying approved import or export contract and that the term of the forward contract does not exceed three months; con- tracts for longer periods require exchange control approval. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Uganda on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Import and export control is administered by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry under the External Trade Act and by the Bank of Uganda. The Minister of Commerce and Industry has powers to prohibit imports and exports. The State Trading Corporation has the sole right to the import and export of specified commodities. Together with Kenya and Tanzania, Uganda is part of the East African currency area but exchange control is applied to both Kenya and Tanzania. Prescription of Currency Uganda has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory under the terms of the U. K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U. K. exchange control regu- lations continues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Sterling Area. Imports and Import Payments All permitted imports require approval by the Bank of Uganda. Monthly allocations of foreign exchange for imports are limited to a total of U Sh 100 million. Some imports from all sources are prohibited for rea- sons of public policy; imports prohibited for other reasons include cotton fabrics, electrical home refrig- erators, transistor radios, and matches. All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited and imports from Portuguese-controlled territories in Africa are not being licensed. All goods originating in mainland China must be imported through the inter- mediary of the State Trading Corporation. Imports normally must be purchased direct from the country of origin. Some imports of manufactured goods from Kenya and Tanzania are subject to transfer taxes. Documentary evidence showing that the goods have been imported into Uganda must be forwarded to the exchange control authorities within six months. Pay- ments for nonessential imports are made after arrival of the goods, but advance payment is permitted for essential goods. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are subject to approval by the Bank of Uganda and those to Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. The basic allowance for travel outside Uganda is the equivalent of U Sh 2,000 a person every three years, which may be taken out in foreign banknotes. The allowance is available for travel to any country except Kenya and Tanzania, for which normally holiday facilities of up to U Sh 500 a person a year are available, and Rho- UGANDA desia and South Africa, for which no allocation is granted. Salaried noncitizens recruited from outside East Africa may obtain allocations for travel outside East Africa at the time of their overseas leave. No foreign exchange is released for nursery, primary, and secondary education abroad except for children of diplomats, technical assistance personnel, nonnationals working in Uganda on overseas terms, nonnational missionaries, and other special cases. Facilities exist whereby salaried foreign nationals may during their stay in Uganda remit to their country of origin up to 33Y3 per cent of their gross monthly earnings, to cover family maintenance, savings, etc., provided that they are on a contract of employment with includes a firm commitment to leave Uganda upon expiry of the contract. The export of Uganda banknotes and coins by travelers is prohibited, except that travelers to Kenya and Tanzania may take out U Sh 100 in Uganda currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain foods tu f fs and agricultural products require licenses and may be subject to restriction in order to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Uganda. Other goods may be exported w i thout licenses. All exports to Israel, South Africa, the Portuguese terri- tories in Africa, and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds in specified currencies (see foot- note 2) must be collected within six months of expor- tation and offered to an authorized bank in Uganda for conversion into Uganda shillings. Coffee is subject to export duty, and an export tax of 40 per cent ad valorem is levied on copper and copper alloys sold at a price in excess of <£ stg. 400 a ton. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts f rom invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 2) must be sold to an authorized bank. The import of Uganda bankno tes and coins by travelers is prohibited, except that travelers f rom Kenya and Tan- zania may bring in U Sh 100 each. Travelers may freely b r ing in foreign currency notes and foreign cur- rency travelers checks. Capital Capital t rans fe rs to all countries are restricted and those to Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. Residents of Uganda, however, may be granted exemp- tions f rom the deposit and surrender requirements in respect of foreign assets for specified Sterling Area assets held prior to June 11, 1965. Capital transfers require individual exchange control approval. Residents of Uganda leaving permanently may normally transfer their assets up to the equivalent 487 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA of U Sh 50,000; for certain persons who have been ordered to leave this allocation is U Sh 1,000. The allowance is reduced by the amount of insurance premiums remitted after 1965 outside the facilities for remittance of savings. A further transfer of up to the equivalent of U Sh 20,000 upon each anniversary of the emigrant's departure is allowed. All remaining funds must be credited to a Blocked Account and may either be invested in certain approved securities or held on deposit with a bank in Uganda; such funds become transferable after five years. The income from such investments is transferable also during the period when the funds are blocked. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Uganda; but to secure guaranteed repatriation, it is necessary to obtain "approved status" for the investment in terms of the Foreign Investments (Pro- tection) Act, 1964, which in normal circumstances is given freely. Foreign and domestic investment in speci- fied types of production require approval under the East A f r ican Indus tr ial Licensing Act and the Uganda Licensing Act, 1969. Dividends and profits due to nonresidents from normal trading operations and dis- tributed by companies operating in Uganda are in principle transferable. All imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by non- residents of Ugandan securities, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manne r. The income f rom such securities is rem i t tab le, and the proceeds on resale are no rma l ly remittable also. Purchases of securities outside Uganda by residents are not normally per- m i t ted. A res ident of Uganda may not send, as a g if t, to any coun try more th an U Sh 100 a year w i thout specific exchange control approval. Not for Redistribution UNITED ARAB EMIRATES1 Exchange Rate System The United Arab Emirates has not yet issued its own currency. The currencies in use are the Bahrain Dinar and the Qa ta r /Dubai Riyal. These are defined as equivalent to 1.86621 and 0.186621 gram of fine gold, respectively, corresponding to BD 1 = US$2.28 and QDR 1 = US$0.228. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an exchange control authority in the United Arab Emi- rates. The United Arab Emirates is part of the Sterling Area, although it has ceased to be a Scheduled Terri- tory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947. The United Kingdom issues annual guidelines to com- mercial banks with respect to certain types of settle- ments with nonresidents of the Sterling Area; their implementation is not necessarily identical in Abu Dhabi and Dubai. Import and export licenses are issued by the Federal Ministry of Finance, Economy, and Industry. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel are prohibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force, but settlements with Sterling Area countries usua l ly take place in sterling, and settlements with other countries normally in External Account sterling or in convertible non-Sterling Area currencies. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Israel are prohibited, as are imports of products manu fac tu red by foreign companies black- listed by the A rab League. Imports of a few commod- ities are prohibited f rom all sources for moral, health, or security reasons. Virtually all other commodities may be freely imported without an import license. There are no restrictions on the availability of foreign exchange for payments in respect of permitted imports. Payments for Invisibles Under present guidelines, banks norma l ly ensure that expatriates' salary remittances to countries outside the 1 The Un i ted A rab Em i ra tes became a member of the In te rna t ional Mone ta ry Fund on September 22, 1972. The seven fede ra ted s ta tes of the Un i ted A r ab Em i ra tes a re Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Sha r jah, A jm a n, Umm al Qa iwan, Ras a l -Kha imah, and Fu ja i rah. Sterling Area are l im i ted to 75 per cent of net earn- ings. All other paymen ts for current invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel. Travelers may take out any amount in Bahra in dinar notes, Qa ta r /Dubai riyal notes, or any other banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. Virtually all com- modities may be exported freely, w i thout an export license, to any other destination. There are no require- ments attached to receipts f rom exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surrendered, and they may be disposed of f ree ly, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no requirements attached to receipts from cu r rent invisibles. Travelers may bring in any amount in Bahrain dinar notes, Qa ta r /Dubai riyal notes, or any other banknotes. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or paymen ts by residents or nonresi- dents, and no guidelines to commercial banks are in force at present with respect to capital transfers to Sterling Area or non-Sterling Area countries. Trans- actions and settlements involving Israel, however, are prohibited. Profits on foreign capital invested in the United Arab Emirates may be remitted freely. Gold Residents and nonresidents, including private per- sons, may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any fo rm, at home or abroad. They may also, w i thout a license and w i thout payment of any customs duties or tax, import and export gold in any form. Transactions involving Israel, however, are prohibited. Exchange Control Territory Although exchange control is not imposed on trans- actions with residents of the Scheduled Territories, con- trol is exercised over the acquisition by residents of the United K ingdom of foreign currency securities f rom residents of o ther Scheduled Territories. In the applica- tion of exchange control to the rest of the world, the non-Scheduled Territories for adm in is tra t ive purposes are divided as follows: ( 1) the other member countries of the EEC; (2) the Overseas Sterling Area, i.e., the countries other than the Republic of Ireland and Gibral- tar which as at June 22, 1972 were treated as Scheduled Te r r i to r ies ;5 ( 3) Rhodesia; and (4) all other countries. Administration of Control Exchange control in the United Kingdom is admin- istered by the Bank of England on behalf of the U. K. Treasury. However, practically all commercial banks are authorized to approve most current paymen ts requ i r ing exchange control permission. The licensing of imports and exports is handled by the Department of Trade and Industry. Prescription of Currency Receipts f rom Scheduled Territories may be in ster- ling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; those f rom other countries with the exception of Rhodesia must be in sterling f rom an External Account or in any foreign currency (other than Rhodesian cu r rency ), which must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless permis- sion has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Nonresident Accounts The sterling accounts of residents of other Scheduled Territories are treated in the same way as those of resi- dents of the United Kingdom. Thus, for transfers between Scheduled Territories no U. K. exchange con- trol permission is required; for paymen ts to other coun- tries by residents of any Scheduled Territory, the author- ized banks are required to ensure that the payment has the approval of the exchange control au tho r i ty in the territory concerned. External Accounts. With the exception of Rhodesian Accounts and the Rhodesian Special Account (see be low ), the sterling accounts of nonresidents with banks in the United K ingdom, i.e., those of residents of coun- tries outside the Scheduled Territories, are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized paymen ts by residents of Scheduled Territories, with t rans fe rs f rom other External Accounts, with the proceeds f rom sales of gold or foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency ( inc lud ing bankno te s ), and with s ter l ing bankno tes mailed f rom outside the Scheduled Territories. The Rhodesian Special Account. This is an account operated by the Rhodesia Pensions Office staff in Lon- don and maintained w i th the Standard Bank, London. Pensions and associated payments due to beneficiaries in Rhodesia f rom residents of the Scheduled Territories and the Overseas Sterling Area, and pensions due f rom Rhodesia to residents of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, and most parts of the Overseas Sterling Area are normally settled through this account. Corresponding transfers f rom Rhodesian Accounts in the names of ind iv idua ls to the Rhodesian Special Account are freely perm i t ted. Permission is not nor- mally given for paymen ts of any other na ture to be credited to the Rhodesian Special Account. Subject to specific approval by the Bank of England, any balance on the Special Account may be used to meet the cost of permitted exports to Rhodesia f rom the Scheduled Ter- ritories and the Overseas Sterling Area and of services provided by residents of the Scheduled Territories and the Overseas Sterling Area for account of persons resi- dent in Rhodesia. For such projects ("super-criterion projects"), official exchange may be made available up to £250,000 or 50 per cent of the total investment, whichever is larger; any balance must be financed by foreign cur- rency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the export free of payment of capital equipment and stock- in-trade form ing an integral part of the investment, by the issue or transfer of shares to nonresidents on appro- priate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas sub- sidiary's current account indebtedness to the U. K. par- ent company, or by approved profit retention. Direct investment other than for super-criterion projects is considered on the basis that its capital cost should not fall directly upon the U. K. official fore ign exchange reserves at least un t il an equivalent amount has been received in the United Kingdom by way of benefits arising f rom the investments; such investments can normally be financed by foreign currency borrowing, the use of investment currency, the export free of pay- ment of capital equipment and stock-in-trade fo rm ing an integral pa rt of the investment, by the issue or trans- fer of shares to nonresidents on appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U. K. parent company, or by approved prof it retention. For all approved projects outside the Overseas Sterling Area, the permitted pro- portion of retained foreign currency earnings normally is one third of net earnings af ter taxes, applied on a global basis where more than one subsidiary is involved. The same rules apply to direct investment in non-Sched- uled Territories that are member countries of the EEC, with the exception that official exchange up to £1 million a project a year can be used to finance all new approved direct investments in member countries of the European Economic Community. Purchases of marke tab le for- eign currency securities with investment currency are freely permitted by v i r tue of certain general permissions granted to banks, stockbrokers, and other authorized depositories. Purchases f rom other residents may also be effected with sterling on a U. K. stock exchange (sterling prices reflect the p reva i l ing investment cur- rency p r em i um ). The purchase by U. (As an exception to this rule, residents tempo ra r i ly employed in the Over- seas Sterling Area or member countries of the EEC may be authorized to purchase necessary accommoda- tion at current official market rates of exchange.) Approval is norma l ly limited to one property a fam i ly, and purchases of investment currency are norma l ly limited to reasonable amounts. All proceeds f rom the realization, redemption, or ma tu r i ty of sterling capital assets ( inc lud ing direct in- vestments) owned by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories other than residents of Rhodesia are remit- table at the official rate of exchange. Payments to non- resident beneficiaries are authorized freely in respect of inheritances due f rom the estates of deceased residents; so also are capital paymen ts under life and other insur- ance policies taken up by nonresidents with resident insurance companies. Residents of the United Kingdom who leave with the intention of residing for at least three years in a country outside the Scheduled Territories and apply to t rans fer their assets are, on their departure f rom the United Kingdom, regarded for exchange control pu r- poses as nonresidents, and, w i th the following excep- tions, their assets are treated accordingly. For em igra t ion to the Overseas Sterling Area, the basic settling-in allowance is £20,000 (w i th a simi- lar concession for those tak ing up emp loymen t ), also available at the official rate of exchange, and holdings of fore ign currency securities are exportable. Under certain permissions delegated to authorized depositories, transactions in securities of all types may generally be carried out free ly between residents of the United Kingdom, except that transactions in Rhodesian securities may only be effected on a recognized stock exchange in the United K ingdom. Residents are nor- mally perm i t ted, subject to certain conditions, to sell foreign cu r rency securities outside the Scheduled Terri- tories, and, a f ter 25 per cent of the proceeds has been sold to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange where appropr ia te (see above ), to reinvest the balance of the exchange proceeds (investment cur- r en cy) in o ther m a rk e t ab le fore ign cu r rency securities, UNITED KINGDOM or to sell the exchange to other residents for such invest- ments or for certain approved direct investments outside the Scheduled Territories. When fore ign currency se- curities expressed in currencies other than Overseas Sterling Area currencies are sold on a U. K. stock ex- change for sterling, an amount of investment currency in the form of foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the sale proceeds must be purchased in the investment currency market for resale to an authorized bank at the official market rate of exchange. Professional dealers mak ing a "book" may on application be exempt f rom the 25 per cent requirement in respect of transactions on the "book." Investment currency held for a continuous period of 6 months ceases to be inves tment currency unless an amount of investment currency in the f o rm of fore ign currency (o ther than Rhodesian cu r rency) equivalent to 25 per cent of the amount held is, at the end of the 6-month period, sold to an authorized bank at the cur- rent market rate in the official foreign exchange market, except for certain authorities for the purchase of pri- vate property outside the Scheduled Territories where investment currency may be retained for up to 18 months w i thout the 25 per cent requirement being im- posed. Investment currency may only be retained as investment currency for a max imum of 12 months, af ter which period any amount remaining must be offered for sale to an authorized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange market.18 Professional security managers on the ir own behalf and for clients are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency for the purpose of making po r t fo l io investments in marke tab le foreign currency securities. U. K. jobbers and other security dealers may, with permission, arrange day-to-day borrowing of for- eign currency, whether f rom U. K. banks or f rom non- residents, to finance a "book" in foreign currency securities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesian residents may buy sterling securities on a recognized stock exchange in the United Kingdom against payment in foreign currency or in sterling f rom an External Account. Securities so purchased may be exported f rom the United Kingdom. Foreign currency securities may be bought and sold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories on a stock exchange in the United Kingdom for settlement in foreign currency or, in certain circumstances, for settlement in sterling with- out the benefit of the investment currency premium. Nonresidents must obtain permission to buy securities in the United Kingdom other than on a stock exchange, whe ther or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Nonres iden ts other than Rhodesian residents may sell sterling securities in the United Kingdom for External Account sterling and freely transfer the pro- ceeds abroad at official market rates. All transactions in securities by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia require the specific approval of the Bank of England. Warrants issued by registrars, company secretaries, and paying agents in respect of capital paymen ts on matured securities registered in the names of nonresi- dents other than Rhodesian residents may be dispatched freely to addressees outside the Scheduled Territories, and these wa r ran ts may be paid by crediting sterling to an External Account. Authorized banks may freely accept foreign cur- rencies from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories for deposit; such deposits may be re-lent to other non- residents or switched into sterling and made available to domestic borrowers. Individual ceilings are set on each bank's overall open position in foreign currencies and on the amount of spot assets which may be held against forward liabilities in foreign currencies. The Bank of England has authority to call for differential Special Deposits, but this authority has not so far been invoked. Gold Residents of the United Kingdom may freely buy, hold, or sell domestic and foreign gold coins. With this exception, residents of the United Kingdom other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not permitted to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, whether at home or abroad, unless they are specifically or generally permitted to do so; permission is granted restrictively and is generally limited to established genuine domestic requirements for industrial and professional purposes (including the manufac ture of gold medals, medallions, etc.). The Mint from time to time strikes gold sovereigns. Although legal tender, these do not circulate in the 498 United Kingdom. Gold coins which are legal tender have also been issued in Jersey and the Isle of Man. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal coin which is for the time being current in the United King- dom or which, having been current there, has at any time af ter May 16, 1969 ceased to be so. The import by any resident of the United Kingdom of gold bullion, gold coins, and gold medals, medallions, tablets or other pieces in pictorial relief or bearing in- scriptions is on Open General License, f r om all sources except Rhodesia, but the holding of, or dealing with, bullion is subject to restrictions, as stated above. The export of gold bullion and all gold coins requires prior exchange control approval. Au tho r i ty has been given to authorized dealers in gold to issue licenses in respect of exports of gold bu l l ion and coin purchased by any non-Scheduled Territory resident in the London gold market against payment in External Account sterling or foreign cu r rency. A license is requ ired from the Depar tment of Trade and Indu s t ry for the export of gold jewe l ry, etc., con ta in ing d iamonds. The export of gold in m anu f a c tu r ed fo rm over 100 years old and valued at £2,000 and over also requires a license f rom the Depar tment of Trade and Indus try. Manu fac tu res of gold other than medals, medallions, tablets or other pieces in pictorial relief or bearing in- scriptions may be impor ted w i thout quan t i ta t ive restric- tion under Open General License f rom all sources except Rhodesia. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are free ly traded among (1) authorized dealers in gold, (2) any nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories, and (3) residents of the Overseas Sterling Area who are sellers of new production. The U. K. authorities do not intervene in the market as either buyers or sellers. A commission of 1A of 1 per cent is charged on all purchases; there is no commission on sales. The market operates on a spot cash basis. Authorized banks may not enter into forward transactions in gold without prior permission f rom the Bank of England. Banks may not finance purchases of gold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories by lending foreign exchange or by accepting gold as collateral for advances in foreign currencies or External Account sterling to nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories. Membership negotiations w i th the EEC were completed. Among the special arrangemen ts agreed upon were the following. The United Kingdom would comply over a five-year trans i t ional period from accession w i th the obligations of the EEC Council Di- rectives of May 11, 1960 and December 18, 1962 cov- ering capital movemen ts. Dur ing the first two years a f t er accession, the Un i ted K ingdom would remove restrictions on direct inves tmen ts made by U. K. resi- dents in EEC countries and, to the extent that restric- tions applied, on l iqu ida t ions of direct investments in those coun tr ies by persons resident in the United King- dom; the relaxations would be in troduced in two stages, the first on accession and the second by the end of the second year the rea f te r. Th i r ty mon ths at the latest a f ter accession, the United K ingdom would liberalize the following personal capital transac t ions to EEC member countries: t rans fe rs of capital belonging to persons resi- dent in the United Kingdom who are emigrating; g if ts, endowments, and dowries; succession duties; and real estate inves tmen ts other than those connected with freedom of movement for workers, which would be liberalized f rom the date of accession. By the end of the transitional period, the United K ingdom would liber- alize por tfo l io investment in securities in accordance with the obligations. January 25. The European Communities Bill was published. Part I laid down the constitutional frame- work to give effect to Community law in the United Kingdom. Royal Assent was given on October 17. February 11. Bangladesh was listed as a separate Scheduled Territory. March 8. A supplementary import quota of 5,000 tons for bananas f rom the Dollar Area was established. A fu r th er supplementary quota of 5,000 tons was estab- lished in April. March 16. The Bank of England was prepared to consider specific applications by U. K. exporters ten- UNITED KINGDOM der ing for overseas contracts expressed in fore ign cur- rencies for fo rwa rd exchange cover between the date of submission and the date of ad jud ica t ion in respect of the amount of a tender or the cost of fo re ign com- ponents included in a tender price. March 16. New a r rangemen ts for fixed-rate med ium- term and long-term export and shipbuilding finance were in troduced. The clearing banks would provide fi- nance up to an amount equivalent to 18 per cent of their current account deposits (prev ious ly 10 per cent of gross depos i ts), and advances in excess of the agreed amount would be refinanced by the ECGD and the De- partment of Trade and Indus try (previously the Bank of Eng land ). The rate of interest for export finance was lowered f rom 6l/2 per cent to 6 per cent, except for ships, the fixed rate for which remained at 7 per cent. March 21. It was announced that a value-added tax would be introduced in Apr il 1973 w i th a single rate, provisionally fixed at 10 per cent. March 22. The vo lun tary program of restraint on investment in developed Overseas Sterling Area coun- tries was terminated. Under this program, introduced on May 3, 1966, companies planning direct investments in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, and the Re- public of Ireland had been asked to consult the Bank of England about the financing of projects costing more than <£25,000 (and, on consultation, to agree to post- ponement or to methods of finance, normally appro- priate overseas borrowing, that would protect the United Kingdom's foreign exchange reserves), and investment institutions had been asked to refra in f rom adding to their portfolio holdings of securities in the four countries. March 22. The Treasury ceased to insure the exchange risk for fore ign currency borrow ing by nationalized industries and local authorities. (Since July 1971, cover had been restricted to borrowing for peri- ods of ten years and over.) On March 6, 1973 this fac i l i ty was restored. March 22. Subject to a limit of <£! million a pro- ject a year, official exchange was made available for all new approved direct investments in member countries of the EEC, Denmark, and Norway. (Previously, offi- cial exchange for direct investment in all countries out- side the Sterling Area was allowed up to £250,000 or 50 per cent of total cost for "super-criterion projects," and more stringent rules applied to other projects.) The relaxation would not be applied retroactively; thus the early repayment of foreign currency borrowing already taken and applied to existing projects would not be per- mitted. It was officially estimated that 90 per cent of all new investment projects in the enlarged EEC and over 50 per cent by value were likely to be eligible for finance entirely at official rates of exchange.
