April 1. Open licensing for imports of butter was continued for 1972/73 from all sources except Rhodesia and licenses were to be issued freely for near-butters. Imports of cheddar and cheddar-type cheese also con- tinued to be permitted without quantitative restrictions; the voluntary restraint arrangement with the principal suppliers remained in being but continued suspended. April 1. Bacon import quotas for the year 1972/73 were reduced by 10,340 tons compared with the pre- vious year. April 14. It was announced that unlimited sterling borrowing in the United Kingdom would normally be allowed by U. K. companies in which any nonresidents had less than a controlling interest, except by companies which were purely vehicles for portfolio investment. Previously, such companies had been required to finance their fixed assets from nonresident sources at least in proportion to the nonresident equity interest. April 18. The British Solomon Islands, Brunei, and the United Arab Emirates, all previously included by definition in the list of Scheduled Territories, were inc luded by name. April 27. The vo lun tary scheme restricting sterling financing of silver stocks held by members of the Lon- don Bullion Market and the London Metal Exchange was suspended. The request to banks to observe restraint in their silver transactions was w i thdrawn at the same time. May 1. The United Kingdom commenced participation in the EEC "narrower margin" arrangements of April 24 designed to ensure that the max imum divergence f rom cross-parities between any two currencies of the 500 member states of the EEC did not exceed 21A per cent. The Bank of England, which previously quoted buying and selling rates only for sterling against the U. S. dollar, was prepared to deal with authorized banks in certain continental European currencies (those of EEC members and the Danish krone) at published official rates of exchange for spot telegraphic transfers up to the time each day that the counterpart central banks concerned ceased their dealing operations in their own markets; the official buying and selling rates for tele- graphic transfers in U. S. dollars on New York remained unchanged. On May 23, these intervention arrangements were extended to the Norwegian krone. The United Kingdom withdrew on June 23. May 22. Unpasteurized frozen grapefru it juice con- centrate was placed on the Open General Import License for import from the Dollar Area. May 26. Special provisions were introduced for residents of the United Kingdom intending to take up established residence and employment in member countries of the EEC, Denmark, and Norway. The Bank of England was prepared to consider applica- tions from such persons wishing to be regarded as resident in their new country of employment, to trans- fer upon departure sterling assets in excess of the normal emigration allowance of £5,000 to their new established country of residence, at the official rate of exchange. The Bank of England was also prepared to consider applications for special exchange provisions from residents of the United Kingdom taking up temporary employment in those countries, including provision for settling-in expenses and unforeseen cur- rent expenditure. May 31. U. K. residents who were, or were to. be, temporarily employed in the EEC, Denmark, or Nor- way, were permitted to purchase foreign currency at the current market rate in the official exchange market and remit the funds to the country concerned to meet the cost of accommodation, i.e., to purchase property for private use. Previously, investment currency normally had to be used. June 6. The authority to authorized banks to lend sterling to nonresident account holders for the purchase of a house or flat in the United Kingdom for the account holder's own occupation and for certain other personal payments in the United Kingdom was raised f rom £10,000 to £25,000. June 19. Specified items inc lud ing fabrics and cloth- ing were placed on the Open General Impo rt License for import from the Eastern Area. June 23. The Government announced tha t, as a temporary measure, sterling would be allowed to float. For the time being the market rate for sterling would not necessarily be confined w i th in announced limits either in respect of the U. S. dollar or in respect of EEC currencies. It was the Government's intention to ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution return as soon as conditions would permit to the ma in- tenance of normal IMF margins around parity and participation in the special EEC currency arrangements. The Bank of England suspended all intervention rates. June 23. The exchange market was closed. It reopened on June 27 with the Bank of England no longer ma in ta in ing official dealing limits. The pound began to depreciate in terms of the U. S. dollar, the middle rate for which had been <£! = US$2.6057. June 23. As a fu r ther precaution against fresh spec- ulative outflows, since the market rates for many Ster- ling Area currencies were no longer necessarily linked to sterling, an extension of exchange control was announced. Exchange control was introduced between the United Kingdom (including the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man) and the countries of the Sterling Area other than the Republic of Ireland (the Republic of Ireland took parallel action) and controls, and in certain cases restrictions, were imposed on resident capital outflows from the United Kingdom to other Overseas Sterling Area countries. Current payments to these countries would not be restricted. (Transitional arrangements were made to allow all payments due under contracts issued or entered into before June 23.) Accordingly, the Scheduled Territories were re- defined as the United Kingdom (including the Chan- nel Islands and the Isle of Man) and the Republic of Ireland (Gibraltar was readmitted to the Scheduled Territories on Janua ry 1, 1973); the External Account Area henceforth comprised all other countries except Rhodesia. (Previously, the Scheduled Territories were all Sterling Area territories and the External Account Area consisted of all non-Sterling Area countries except Rhodesia.) As a result, all persons, firms, or companies resident in non-scheduled Territories with the Overseas Ster- ling Area (i.e., countries that had now ceased to be Scheduled Territories) were to be regarded as nonresi- dents of the Scheduled Territories, so that all payments to, or on behalf of, or for the credit of, such persons required permission; all currencies of the countries con- cerned became foreign currencies, whereas previously foreign currencies were confined to non-Sterling Area currencies; and securities payable or optionally payable in the currencies of the countries concerned became foreign currency securities. Sterling securities hence- forth were defined as securities payable solely in the currencies of the Republic of Ireland or the United Kingdom (or, since January 1, 1973, in Gibraltar cur- rency ). June 23. Detailed regulations implementing the new exchange control principles were issued. Inward and outward direct investment involving the fo rmer Sched- uled Territories (i.e., the non-Scheduled Territories in the Overseas Sterling A rea) now required individual approval. Portfolio investment in securities expressed UNITED KINGDOM in the currencies of those countries had to be financed in the same way as investment in any other foreign currency security, i.e., normally with investment cur- rency or borrowed foreign currency. Purchases of land and property for private use by U. K. residents also required individual approval and had to be financed with investment currency. Insurers in the United King- dom could no longer issue to residents of the United Kingdom or the Republic of Ireland annuities and life and endowment policies expressed in the currencies of the former Scheduled Territories. Export proceeds in such currencies normally had to be collected within six mon ths of shipment and offered for sale to an authorized bank. Advance paymen ts for imports from the countries concerned required Bank of England app rova l. Authorized banks' positions in the currencies of these countries became subject to the l im i ta t ions pre- viously applicable only to non-Sterling Area currencies. Borrowing in their currencies became subject to approval and to the "five-year rule" restricting the borrowing of foreign currency by nonbank residents to a m in imum period of five years when intended for con- version into sterling for use in the United Kingdom. Residents ho ld ing accounts in the currencies of the countries concerned had to offer these for sale to an authorized bank, unless otherwise permitted by the Bank of England. The basic exchange allocations for travel were also now applicable to travel to these coun- tries. Residents of the United Kingdom required per- mission to set up, or add to, a trust or make a settle- ment in favor of, residents of these countries. New or increased sterling loans and overdrafts to bodies cor- porate and branches resident in the United Kingdom or the Republic of Ireland and controlled by persons resi- dent in the countries concerned required permission. The existing sterling accounts with U. K. banks of per- sons resident in those countries were to be redesignated External Accounts, and such accounts maintained with bu i ld ing societies, savings banks, etc., were to be redesignated "nonresident accounts." The restrictions on payments f rom the accounts in the United Kingdom of residents of Hong Kong and on securities held in the United Kingdom for such persons were to be abolished; their purpose had been to ensure that residents of other parts of the Sterling Area did not have access to Hong Kong's free exchange marke t. The new rules for residents of the Overseas Sterling Area differed in a number of respects from those apply- ing to residents of other countries of the External Ac- count Area. The following were the main differences: (i) While new direct investments in Overseas Sterling Area countries now required Bank of England approval, such approval normally would not be withheld and there would be no restrictions on the amount of foreign exchange to be purchased at the current official market rate for any approved project, provided that the invest- 501 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM ment was not of a portfolio nature and the finance required was to be employed wholly within non-Sched- uled Territories that were part of the Overseas Sterling Area, ( i i) Existing sterling loan and overdraft facilities given to companies and branches in the United King- dom and the Republic of Ireland which were controlled by residents of Overseas Sterling Area countries could continue without formality, and applications for new or increased facilities would be dealt with by the Bank of England under the same rules applied to EEC-controlled companies, i.e., they would normally be allowed, (iii) U. K. banks could make sterling credit available to their branches and to customers in Overseas Sterling Area countries under existing lines of credit. They could also grant new facilities to residents of these countries as if they were still Scheduled Territories, provided, how- ever, that the facilities were linked to the movement of goods, ( iv) Trade between Overseas Sterling Area coun- tries and non-Sterling Area countries could continue to be financed in sterling, while sterling finance for trade between other External Account countries remained prohibited, (v) While the same rules would apply to Overseas Sterling Area securities as to other foreign currency securities, so that their purchase by U. K. resi- dents must normally be made with investment currency, there would be no requirement to exchange 25 per cent of the foreign currency proceeds of disposal for sterling at the official market rate of exchange, provided the securities were payable solely in the currency of an Overseas Sterling Area country or payable in such a currency and sterling; the whole of such proceeds could be reinvested or sold in the investment currency market, (v i) Emigrants to Overseas Sterling Area countries would in general be permitted to transfer immediately through the official market sterling capital assets up to £20,000 a family, while the ceiling for other External Account countries remained at £5,000. Special con- sideration would be given to those who had already made firm arrangements to emigrate, and to those tak- ing up employment in an Overseas Sterling Area coun- try, (v i i) The normal limit on cash gifts by U. K. resi- dents to Overseas Sterling Area countries would be £1,000 a donor a year, while that for other External Account countries remained at £300. June 23. The requirement that exchange control forms be completed for payments for invisibles in excess of £250 was amended to cover only payments in excess of £1,000. June 28. Authorized depositories were allowed to ar- range settlement in sterling in respect of transactions in Overseas Sterling Area securities in the United Kingdom on behalf of nonresidents at prices which excluded the investment currency premium. June 30. The Control of Payments (Hong Kong) (Revocation) Directions 1972 came into operation. These revoked the Treasury Direction (Hong Kong) 502 1950, which regulated the use of Hong Kong assets in the United Kingdom. Hong Kong No. 1 and No. 2 Accounts were redesignated External Accounts, and U. K. banks no longer were required to request the sub- mission of a permit from the Hong Kong exchange control authorities before allowing the debiting of such accounts, as was previously required for debits to Hong Kong No. 2 Accounts. July 17. Restrictions on coal exports were lifted. July 19. The Treasury issued a statement clarifying the position of the Sterling Area in the light of the extension of exchange control to the Overseas Sterling Area. The Sterling Area could be regarded as compris- ing the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, and all other countries of the Overseas Sterling Area (i.e., all other countries and territories that prior to June 23 were either listed or administratively treated as Sched- uled Territories). It was also stated that for all Sterling Area countries to which exchange control now applied the rules were identical. July 19. The Overseas Investment and Export Guar- antees Act became operational. The ECGD announced that U. K. firms could obtain insurance cover against the noncommercial risks of expropriation, war damage, or restrictions on remittances, for new overseas direct investments of U. K. origin. July 25. To enable certain trust business to be com- pleted without delay, a number of general exchange control permissions were given relating to transactions involving foreign currency securities and beneficiaries in the Scheduled Territories and to be effected for vol- un tary consideration under settlements and trusts or in the course of administering estates. A general permis- sion was also given for the transfer of such securities by residents of the United Kingdom, by way of gift, to residents in the Scheduled Territories. All the permis- sions were conditional but the conditions did not include the "25 per cent requirement." August 18. The requirement for completion of exchange control fo rms for payments for imports in excess of £2,000 was amended to cover only payments in excess of £5,000. The same increase was made in the limit relating to exchange control copies of customs entries. Form E ceased to be required where the terms of a forward exchange contract were to be extended. August 31. The London Stock Exchange began to make available a daily dollar premium conversion factor that could serve to convert the sterling prices quoted for Overseas Sterling Area foreign currency securities, which include the investment currency premium, into the ster- ling equivalent net of that premium. September 5. Since securities payable or optionally payable in the currencies of non-Scheduled Territories that are part of the Overseas Sterling Area had on June 23 become foreign currency securities, restrictions ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution imposed on such securities under Section 40 of the Exchange Control Act, 1947 in accordance with Bank of England Notice EC 29 (re la t ing to the restriction of sterling assets upon emigration) were revoked. The securities concerned could be made freely available to the owners in their country of residence, but could not be sold for sterling in the United Kingdom for the benefit of the investment currency prem ium. September 11. Restrictions were imposed on the export of iron and steel scrap. September 19. Exchange control regulations govern- ing insurance were amended. In particular, an authority was given to banks to approve applications by insurers, other than members of the British Insurance Associa- tion, or by brokers, other than Lloyd's brokers, to make reinsurance paymen ts to residents of the Scheduled Ter- ritories in foreign currency without limit and to non- residents up to a limit of £500 in any one month in respect of each reinsurance contract. Authority was also given for members of the British Insurance Association and of Lloyd's to grant sterling loans not exceeding £25,000 to nonresidents for the purchase of a house or flat in the United Kingdom for the borrower's own occupation; to give and renew certain types of guaran- tees; and to make paymen ts in implementation thereof. September 26. Banks were no longer required to enter transfers of £5,000 or over between the External Accounts of residents of different countries on sched- ules of multilateral sterling transfers. October 1. Exports f rom Hong Kong to the United Kingdom of woven polyester/cotton fabrics and made- up goods became subject to agreed export restraints similar to those provided for under the existing cotton agreement between the United Kingdom and Hong Kong. October 13. A new "minimum lending rate," deter- mined by a fixed formula from the average discount rate for treasury bills established by the weekly tender, replaced the existing "bank rate" as the Bank of Eng- land's minimum rate for lending to the money market. October 24. The exchange control concessions intro- duced on March 22 and May 26 were withdrawn inso- far as they related to Norway and residents of Norway. October 31. The Bank of England addressed to banks and finance houses a memorandum concerning the appli- cation of d i f fe ren t ial Special Deposits on overseas deposits. All banks and finance houses affected by the proposals subsequently gave an assurance that they would abide by the arrangements set out in the memo- randum. The scheme provided for a uniform rate of call for Special Deposits to be applied to any increase from a specified starting date in each bank's eligible overseas liabilities, mainly its overseas sterling deposits. Calls could be made at the same time as, or separately from, a uniform rate of call applied to the total of each bank's eligible liabilities. The scheme also allowed the authorities to exempt from a general call each bank's UNITED KINGDOM overseas deposits outstanding or to make the call at a lower rate than on the remainder of their eligible liabil- ities. For the purpose of differential calls, overseas deposits would consist of overseas customers' sterling deposits with an original ma tu r i ty of two years or less, any net liability in sterling of U. K. banks to their overseas offices, and any net liability in other currencies. Where a d ifferen t ial call was made, sterling certificates of deposit (which are bearer documents subject to exchange control) would be classified as being held by U. K. residents and would therefore be subject to the rate imposed under a general call. Parallel arrange- ments for d ifferen t ial calls would apply to institutions maintaining public sector lending ratios. (By the end of 1972, no calls for d ifferen t ial deposits had been made.) November 6. The United Kingdom and Norway agreed to continue until the end of 1973 their mutual industrial free trade arrangements. November 9. Banks were reminded that funds origi- nating from an External Account and due to a resident of the Scheduled Territories were not eligible for credit to another External Account except where a general or specific permission had been given. November 9. Banks were advised that for administra- tive purposes the non-Scheduled Territories were divided as follows: ( 1) the existing EEC members plus Den- mark; (2) the Overseas Sterling Area, i.e., the countries which as at June 22, 1972 were treated as Scheduled Territories; (3) Rhodesia; and (4) all other countries. November 13. It was announced that import quotas on some Japanese cotton and pottery goods were being lifted altogether or increased. November 13. Small increases were made in the amounts which may, with the permission of the Bank of England, be transferred to Rhodesia for humani- tarian or hardship reasons. Limits on the release of Suspense Account monies for living expenses of Rho- desian visitors to the United Kingdom were also raised, and some fu r ther relaxation measures were announced, particularly with respect to cash gifts to relatives living in Rhodesia, the ma tur i ty proceeds of endowment assur- ance policies, and transfers in respect of education out- side the United Kingdom. Permitted charitable remit- tances, etc., would no longer be directly linked to the rate of sterling remittances made in 1965. November 16. In the context of entry into the EEC, some modifications of the Bank of England's rules on banking mergers and participations were announced. Among other things, EEC banks would be treated in the same way as British banks for the purpose of par- ticipations in British banks; each proposal, which would have to be acceptable to all parties concerned, would be considered on its individual merits, although the authorities' attitude elsewhere in the EEC to participa- tions by British banks might also be taken into account. 503 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM The liberal practice in relation to the establishment by third-country banks of branches or subsidiaries in Lon- don would continue and the attitude to participations by third-country banks would remain unchanged. November 20. The States of Jersey issued five com- memorative gold coins which were legal tender. November 23. Arrangements were announced for the maintenance of limitations on cotton textile imports into the countries acceding to the EEC in January 1973 (including the United Kingdom) at approximately the same level (with appropriate allowance for growth) as under bilateral arrangements currently existing between the importing and exporting countries concerned. November 24. Under the terms of the Sterling Guar- antee Agreements concluded with individual Overseas Sterling Area countries, the United Kingdom became liable to make up the difference between the old par va lue of £1 = US$2.40 and the middle rate of <£! = US$2.3506 at which sterling closed on November 23. The arrangement was that compensation would be nec- essary if the middle s ter l ing /U. S. dollar rate in London remained below its old lower limit of US$2.3760 for 30 consecutive days. The agreements applied to those Sterling Area members which in September 1968 under- took to keep a fixed m in imum proportion of their offi- cial reserves in sterling in return for a U. K. guarantee in terms of the U. S. dollar on any official sterling held in excess of 10 per cent of total reserves. Since the agreements had been concluded in a regime of fixed rates, consultations were started on the techniques for settlements under floating rates. (The terms of the guar- antee were disclosed on November 9.) November 29. General permissions for insurers in the United Kingdom to export foreign currency assurance policies were expanded in scope. General permission was also given for postal orders up to a value of £50 to be exported for specified purposes to countries in the Overseas Sterling Area: settlement of debts up to £50; payment for goods not exceeding £50 in value imported in to the Un i ted Kingdom; remittances to dependents; maintenance payments under court orders; and personal cash gifts of up to £50. December 14. General permission was given to allow personal representatives administering the estates of deceased residents of the Un i ted Kingdom to transfer certain securities w i thout exchange control formality to those beneficiaries with addresses in the Scheduled Territories. December 15. It was announced that conditions were not yet regarded as appropriate for a re turn to a fixed parity by the date of accession to the EEC, but that sterling would return to a fixed par i ty as soon as cir- cumstances permitted. December 22. The United Kingdom gave notice of termination of its trade agreement with South Africa. The agreement expired on Janua ry 31, 1973. 504 December 30. The United Kingdom gave notice of termination of its trade agreements with Australia, Can- ada, India, and New Zealand. These agreements, includ- ing the remaining provisions of the Ottawa Agreement of 1932, expired on January 31, 1973. December 31. The United Kingdom gave notice of termination of its trade agreement with Pakistan. The agreement expired on Janua ry 31, 1973. December 31. The United Kingdom ceased to be a member of EFTA. NOTE.—The fo l low ing changes took place on Janu- ary 1, 1973: January 1. The United Kingdom became a member of the EEC. The Anglo-Irish Free Trade Agreement remained in force. January 1. Gibraltar was reinstated as a Scheduled Territory under the Exchange Control Act, 1947. January 1. Additional goods could be imported from the Eastern Area under the Open General Import License. Most had been on Open Individual License. January 1. Licensing arrangements for cotton yarn and woven cotton textiles from restricted sources were modified. For goods exported on or after this date there would be no global quota, and cotton yarn and woven cotton textiles f rom all restricted sources would be imported under country quotas. (Imports from those Mediterranean countries which had agreements with the EEC would, no later than April 1, 1973, enter the United Kingdom free of quota restrictions.) January 1. An Open General License came into effect which eliminated quan t i ta t ive restrictions on exports to other EEC countries of certain nonferrous materials. Another Open General License dealt with exports to all destinations except Rhodesia of certain iron and steel scrap; the existing arrangements for export con- trols on iron and steel scrap were extended. January 1. The ECGD offered increased credit insur- ance cover (up to 40 per cent of the main contract) and widened financial facilities for exporters' subcon- tracts placed in member countries of the EEC. January 1. The remaining quantitative restrictions on imports of industrial goods of EEC origin were removed, as were those on certain agricultural products originating in member countries of the enlarged EEC. (Most remaining restrictions on agricultural products from these sources were removed on February 1, 1973.) Quantitative restrictions on imports of certain ju te goods f rom Austria, Finland, Iceland, Portugal, Sweden, and Switzerland also were removed. January 1. The United Kingdom gave notice of ter- mination with effect f rom February 1, 1973 of the U. K. Bacon Market Sharing Understanding. January 1. The Bank of England's new rules on mergers and participations in the banking field came into operation (see November 16, 1972, above). ©International Monetary Fund. The converti- bility of the U. S. dollar into gold and other reserve assets has been suspended and exchange rates are not maintained within any stipulated margin f rom parity. There are no restrictions on foreign payments, except those imposed for security reasons on transactions involving the authorities or nationals of Cuba, North Korea, and Nor th Viet-Nam, and those imposed pur- suant to UN Security Council Resolutions Nos. 232 and 253 on any transfer of funds to, or on behalf of, or for the benefit of, any person in Rhodesia (includ- ing the authorities th e r eo f ), unless the funds are in payment of imports of strategic and critical materials of Rhodesian origin. The United States forma l ly notified the Fund on December 10, 1946 that it was prepared to accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control The Treasury Department deals with license applica- tions involving financial or commercial transactions directly or indirectly with Cuba, Nor th Korea, Rhodesia, and North Viet-Nam, or their nationals, as specified under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations, the Cuban Assets Control Regulations, and the Rhodesian Sanc- tions Regulations. It also deals with license applications involving the blocked accounts in the United States of mainland China under the Foreign Assets Control Reg- ulations. The Foreign Direct Investment Program (FDIP) is administered by the Office of Foreign Direct Investments in the Department of Commerce. The Fed- eral Reserve Board administers the Voluntary Foreign Credit Restraint Program for banks and other financial institutions (VFCRP ). The Bureau of Customs of the Treasury Department administers import quotas; such quotas, however, are generally established and allocated by other agencies. Import quotas on specified dairy products are administered by the Department of Agri- culture through the issuance of import licenses. The import quotas on sugar are allotted among eligible exporting countries in accordance with a statutory for- mula administered by the Department of Agriculture and are prorated among eligible importers under regu- lations administered by that Department. The anticipated change in the par va lue of the dollar was reflected in international markets at once. petroleum products are issued by the Department of the Interior. For items subject to export control, the Department of Commerce is, in general, the responsible authority. Imports and Import Payments The importation of merchandise, as well as payment therefor, is prohibited under Treasury regulations, unless licensed, if such merchandise is of Cuban, North Korean, or North Vietnamese origin, or, unless the goods are strategic and critical materials, if the mer- chandise is of Rhodesian origin. Import quotas are in effect, pursuant to Section 22 of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, as amended, for cotton, certain cotton waste, and certain semiprocessed cotton products, wheat and wheat products, most dairy products, and peanuts. Import quotas established by the Sugar Act are in effect for sugar and confectionery. With the exception of the import quotas for peanuts, certain cotton and cotton products, and butter oil, the quotas above, including those for sugar, are on a country-of-production basis. The United States is a party to the Long-Term Cotton Textiles Arrangement, which authorizes importing countries to request export- ing countries to limit or restrain exports of cotton tex- tiles under specified conditions, and, if the exporting country does not accede, to impose an import quota. The United States has concluded comprehensive bilat- eral agreements under the Long-Term Cotton Textile Agreement governing imports of cotton textiles, and agreements on man-made and woolen textiles have been reached with the main supplying countries. Global quotas are imposed on imports of crude petroleum and certain petroleum products. As at the end of 1972, imports of asphalt into Customs Districts I-IV (east of the Rocky Mountains) and of residual fuel oil for burning into District I (New England and the East Coast region) were virtually unrestricted.1 Imports of fresh, frozen, or chilled beef, veal, and mutton are governed by bilateral agreements as an alternative to mandatory quotas under the Meat Import Act of 1964; in June 1972, however, all meat quotas were sus- pended. The t rans fer of f u n ds to Rhodesia for most pur- poses other than payment for imports of strategic and critical materials (see section on Exchange Rate System, above) is permitted only under license. Exports and Export Proceeds Munitions can be exported only under license issued by the Office of Mun i t ions Control in the Department of State. Licenses are not granted for exports of arms and ammunition to South Africa. Most exports to Rhodesia require licenses and generally no licenses are issued except for food and human i ta r ian items. All exports (except phonograph records, pub l ica t ions, and, to Cuba, limited g ift pa rce ls) to Cuba, No r th Korea, and North Viet-Nam, are subject to individual vali- dated licenses. Exports of designated strategic materials and equipment to all other countries (except Canada) also require ind iv idual validated licenses. For m a ny commodities, when exported to Western European countries, Australia, or Japan, single distribution licenses may be obtained to cover a f u ll year's shipments. The licensing requirements applicable to Poland and Romania are less restrictive than those applicable to other Eastern European countries (except Yugos lav ia). Exports of certain commodities to all destinations have f rom time to time been subject to control for reasons of short supply. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except that they are pro- hibited to and from Cuba, Nor th Korea, Nor th Viet- Nam, and Rhodesia. Individuals leaving or en ter ing the country with more than US$5,000 in domestic or foreign currency, travelers checks, money orders, and/ or bearer-form negotiable securities must declare these to the customs at the point of exit or entry. Capital Incoming or outgoing capital payments by residents or nonresidents are not subject to exchange control. However, as noted above, there are restrictions on cer- tain transactions with or involving Cuba, Nor th Korea, North Viet-Nam, and Rhodesia, and there are certain reporting requirements for travelers entering or leaving the country (as well as corresponding reporting require- ments for shipment of currency or bearer assets through the mails). Domestic sales of jewelry, includ- ing gold jewelry, are subject to excise duty at the rate of 15 per cent, while domestic sales of gold in any other form, including rare gold coins, are free of fiscal charges. The use of the international reserve assets of the United States has been limited to settlement of outstand- ing obligations and, in cooperation with the Interna- tional Monetary Fund, to other situations that might arise in which such use could contribute to international monetary stability and the interests of the United States. Changes during 1972 January 1. The fifth and final stage of the Kennedy Round tariff reductions came into effect. January 1. Increased quotas for oil imports into states east of the Rocky Mountains came into effect. One third of the increase was allocated to Canadian suppliers. January 1. Quantitative restrictions were imposed on imports of certain confectionery products. January 1. Legislation came into force which in effect terminated the ban on the importation of strategic and critical materials from Rhodesia. January 3. A three-year agreement with Japan was signed (retroactive to October 1, 1971) concerning exports to the United States of man-made fiber and wool textile products. Similar five-year agreements were signed with Korea, and three-year agreements with the Republic of China, Hong Kong, and Macao. Furthermore, a multilateral agreement covering trade in these products was signed with the Republic of China, Korea, and Hong Kong. January 10. The Treasury announced that U. S. gold producers, dealers, and refiners were not subject to the domestic price guidelines; the quoted U. S. market price of gold was permitted to reflect changes in gold prices on the London market. January 19. The President announced that the United States would not extend bilateral aid to countries that failed to pay adequate compensation for expropriated U. S. investments and that it would withhold support for fresh assistance to be supplied to such countries by international institutions which relied heavily on U. S. financing. These measures would be applied to new situations and not to current disputes. January 25. By amendment to the Rhodesian Sanc- tions Regulations, the Treasury formally revoked the embargo on imports of strategic and critical materials of Rhodesian origin and of ferrochrome produced from Rhodesian chromite. The general license issued also authorized transfers in payment for the commodities concerned. January 27. Licensing requirements were terminated for exports to most destinations of refined and unre- fined copper and copper-base scrap. 507 ©International Monetary Fund. Bilateral negotiations with the EEC on trade issues were concluded. February 15. The Foreign Assets Control Regula- tions were amended to authorize U. The Transaction Control Regulations were amended to authorize shipments of certain stra- tegic goods to mainland China, when shipment is made from and licensed by one of 14 specified foreign coun- tries (members of the Coordinating Committee for East- West Trade Policy). February 15. The IMF announced that it had decided, on the basis of a request from the Govern- ment of the United States, to terminate the Fund's investment in U. S. Government securities and to liqui- date the Fund's general deposit of gold held with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. February 15. The Export Regulations were amended. For export control purposes, mainland China was trans- ferred from Country Group Z to Country Group Y. As a result, the lesser controls applicable to the U. S. S. R. became applicable also to mainland China. March 3. The President issued an Executive Order establishing a Committee for the Implementation of Textile Agreements to oversee and carry out all textile trade agreements. March 9. The VFCRP guidelines were amended with immediate effect to prevent subsidiary banks in a hold- ing company from consolidating a newly acquired lending ceiling with ceilings of other banks in the same holding company. March 9. The Secretary of Agriculture announced an increase of about 7 per cent in meat imports as authorized under P.L. 88-482 and the bilateral agree- ments with supplying countries. March 10. Quotas for 1972 on imports of watches and watch movements from U. S. possessions were announced. March 16. A Presidential Order authorized the Over- seas Private Investment Corporation to extend its loan and guarantee programs to U. S. private investors in Romania and Yugoslavia. 508 March 30. The Treasury issued an explanatory statement concerning the impact of recent international currency realignments on the administration of the Antidumping Act. March 31. The Treasury issued regulations for the implementation of Titles I and II of the Financial Recordkeeping and Currency and Foreign Transactions Reporting Act (P.L. 91-508, also referred to as the Foreign Bank Secrecy Ac t ). With effect from July 1, 1972 all persons maintaining foreign accounts were required to disclose that fact on their Federal income tax returns and to maintain ade- quate records of such accounts. In addition, persons transporting, mailing, or shipping from the United States to a foreign country, or receiving f rom outside the United States, domestic and /or foreign currency or bearer instruments in amounts in excess of US$5,000 had to report such transactions to the customs author- ities. Financial institutions were required to report to the Treasury any unusual currency transactions involv- ing amounts in excess of US$10,000, and to keep records for five years of all transfers into or out of the United States in excess of US$10,000. April 18. The Treasury released proposals to amend the Antidumping Regulations mainly with a view to speed up its investigation of charges. (Stricter anti- dumping regulations came into effect on January 8, 1973. On the same date, the Treasury imposed a countervailing duty on imports from a manufac turer enjoying subsidies in his home country.) May 5. It was announced that communications had been received from the steel producers of the EEC, the United Kingdom, and Japan expressing their intent to renew for three years the 1969 arrangements for voluntary restraint of steelmill products to the United States. The ceiling on the annual growth rate of such exports was reduced from 5 per cent to 2% per cent. (The producers of the United Kingdom had not par- ticipated in the earlier arrangement.) May 8. The par value was changed from 0.888671 gram of fine gold, equivalent to US$35 a fine ounce, to 0.818513 gram of fine gold, equivalent to US$38 a fine ounce. May 11. It was announced that the FDIP would be continued during 1972, with ceilings generally at the 1971 levels. The two-month extension of certain year- end deadlines would be made available again for the 1972 compliance year. The Office of Foreign Direct Investments would give particular attention to the problems of direct investors who shift from exporting to nonaffiliated foreign nationals to exporting to affili- ated foreign nationals, and of direct investors who utilized bank discount facilities for export sales to ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution foreign affiliates in 1970 and 1971. Provision would be made to assure consistent treatment of expropriation losses. May 15. The Ryukyu Islands were reclassified from Schedule A to Schedule B under the FDIP. May 16. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange opened a fu tures market for foreign currencies. May 26. The Department of the Interior issued new regulations allowing imports of crude and unfinished oils for use in petrochemical processes. They came into effect 30 days after publication. June 5. The President modified the controls on imports of cheese. The effect was that quotas were extended to certain types of high-priced specialty cheeses. June 16. The Office of Foreign Direct Investments issued revised instructions concerning applications for specific authorizations or exemptions from the general FDIP regulations. (1) The new guidelines allowed U. S. companies to enjoy better ratios of export credit to exports with their affiliated foreign companies. While the practice had been to grant relief based on the average of this ratio over the preceding four years, companies might now receive relief based on the three years (out of the last seven years) for which credit terms were the longest. Moreover, they were per- mitted to lengthen terms to affiliates whenever these were the customary arm's-length terms of trade. (2) Companies were allowed to float their own equity issues overseas and treat the proceeds as the equivalent of the proceeds of long-term foreign borrowing. The Office of Foreign Direct Investments, however, required evidence that these were stock sales that would not otherwise have occurred as well as assurances that the shares would be retained for investment by foreign nationals. (3) Any direct investor that had had affili- ated foreign national property expropriated by a for- eign government at any time during which the FDIP had been in effect could apply for specific authorization to make positive direct investment. June 26. The President directed the removal of all quantitative restrictions on meat imports for the remain- der of 1972. June 26 and June 30. A number of revisions to the FDIP regulations were announced, effective July 1. ( 1) Direct investors could substitute foreign borrow- ing for borrowing by the direct investor f rom its over- seas finance subsidiary, and treat the new borrowing as a continuance of the borrowing for which it was substituted. (2) Direct investors could assume obliga- tions incurred by their overseas finance subsidiary to repay overseas borrowing (or borrowing that would qua l ify as overseas borrowing) if it were continuously ou ts tand ing for at least 12 months. ( 3) Greater flexibility was provided for the holding and allocation of avail- able proceeds of long-term borrowings. (4) The use of U. S.-source financing to reduce export credit extended UNITED STATES by a direct investor to its affiliated foreign companies would no longer constitute a negative transfer of capi- tal under the regulations, provided the U. S.-source financing was exempt from restraint under the VFCRP. (On January 2, 1973, the following contemplated changes were announced: (a) credits extended by direct investors to their affiliated foreign nationals with respect to the export sale or lease of qualifying U. S. goods and services on normal commercial terms would be exempted under the FDIP regulations; (b) the alternative minimum positive direct investment allowables would be consolidated into a single world- wide minimum allowable of $6 million a year; and (c) as in the 1971 and 1972 program years, direct inves- tors would be allowed to count certain transactions effected in the first two months of 1974 for purposes of computing their 1973 program compliance in respect of the repatriation of foreign claims. (Since in accord- ance with (a) the extension of qualifying export credits would be exempt from charge under the FDIP after December 31, 1972, repayments of such credits to the direct investor after that date would not be counted as negative transfers of capital for 1973 or subsequent compliance years.) The exemption of qualifying export credits would eliminate any substantial distinction between the FDIP and the other U. S. capital controls in the treatment of extension of export financing.) June 30. The reciprocal trade agreement with Vene- zuela was partially terminated. The amended agree- ment continued in effect most-favored-nation treatment for the exports of each country into the other and provided for continuation of U. S. tariff concessions on petroleum imports. July 19. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reactivated the swap network and drew on its swap agreement with the Deutsche Bundesbank. The Federal Reserve System thus resumed intervention in the for- eign exchange markets. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA Exchange System * No par value for the currency of Upper Volta has been established with the Fund. The un it of currency is the CFA Franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French f ranc. Exchange trans- actions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02, free of commission charges. Exchange transactions relating to foreign countries, i. e., countries other than France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area, take place in a dual exchange market at rates based on the fixed rate for the French franc and the Paris exchange rate for the foreign currency concerned in either the official exchange market or the financial f ranc market. Settlements eligible for the official exchange market are payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, and most other current transactions, as well as all current payments by or in favor of domes- tic and foreign public authorities and public bodies. All other settlements with foreign countries, as well as transactions in banknotes of foreign countries and banknotes issued by the BCEAO, take place through the financial f ranc market at freely fluctuating rates. The principal current payments and receipts channeled through the financial franc market are those relating to travel expenses, capital earnings, workers' remit- tances, family remittances, and study abroad. Exchange rates in the official market are based on par values and central rates; the effective parity relationship for the U. S. dollar in this market is CFAF 255.785 = US$1. With the exception of those relating to gold, Upper Volta's exchange control measures do not apply to (1) France and its Overseas Departments and Territories (except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account (Cameroon, the Central Afr ican Republic, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Dahomey, Gabon, Ivory Coast, the Malagasy Republic, Mali, Maur i tan ia, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Upper Volta itself, are considered fore ign countries, and in principle finan- * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, the exchange rate of CFAF 1 — F 0.02 was ma in ta ined, and the effective parity relationship for the U. S. dollar became CFAF 230.207 = US$1. The rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02 was also maintained on March 19, 1973 when new exchange rate arrangements between the French franc and certain other currencies came into effect. 1 The CFA franc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Dahomey, Ivory Coast, Maur i tan ia, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 512 cial relations only with foreign countries are subject to exchange control. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Bureau in the Directorate of the Treasury and of Public Accounts in the Ministry of Finance and Com- merce, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offer ing for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta, inward direct investment and all outward investment, and the soliciting of funds in Upper Volta for placement in foreign countries. The approval authority in respect of exchange control, except for imports and exports of gold and business travel allocations in excess of CFAF 400,000, has been delegated to the BCEAO and, w i th in limits specified in the exchange control regulations, to authorized inter- mediaries. The BCEAO also is authorized to collect, either direct or through the intermediary of the banks and the Postal Administration, any information neces- sary to compile the balance of payments statistics. All exchange transac t ions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks, the Postal Administration, or the BCEAO. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of Commerce at the Ministry of Finance and Commerce. Import attesta- tions for liberalized commodities are made out by the importer himself and are visaed by the customs. Prescription of Currency Upper Volta is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area; settlements with France (including its Overseas Departments and Territories, except the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas), Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area are made in CFA francs or French francs. Certain settlements with Ghana are made through special accounts. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign or Financial Ac- counts in Francs. All settlements with Portugal, Rho- desia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO bank- notes may be credited to Financial Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Ouagadougou by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that ma in ta ins an Operations Account w i th the French Treasury is prohibited. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Imports and Import Payments Imports originating in or shipped from Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports from countries in the French Franc Area may in prin- ciple be made free ly, although exceptionally special regulations may be issued. Imports from EEC coun- tries, with minor exceptions, are liberalized and require only an import attestation. Most imports from other countries are subject to licensing. Imports from non- EEC countries outside the French Franc Area are admitted in accordance with an annual import pro- gram, determined each year by the Directorate of Com- merce. Under this program, global quotas are estab- lished up to which import licenses are issued for speci- fied commodities. Imports f rom Ghana are subject to special regulations. All impo rt t ransac t ions re la t ing to foreign countries must be domiciled w i th an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000. The import licenses or import attestations entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documen ta ry credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodi- ties have a l ready been impor ted. Payments for Invisibles Paymen ts for invisibles to France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are permitted f ree ly; those to other countries are subject to exchange control approval, which for many invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. All paymen ts to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Authorized banks and the Postal Admin- istration have been empowered to make transfers to fore ign countries f ree ly, on behalf of residents, up to CFAF 50,000 a t ran s fe r. Payments for invisibles related to trade are permitted f ree ly when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to non- residents in the fo rm of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted. Residents traveling for tourism to countries other than France, Monaco, and the other Operations Account countries of the French Franc Area may obtain an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a trip (CFAF 87,500 for children under t en) for any number of trips a year; any foreign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 remaining after re turn to Upper Volta must be surrendered. The basic allocation for travel abroad for business purposes is the equivalent of CFAF 20,000 a day, with a max imum of CFAF 400,000 a trip. Resident travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a max imum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by any institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury. Travelers to other countries may take out any amount in BCEAO bank- UPPER VOLTA notes, but if their destination is not to a member country of the West African Monetary Union, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out, in addi- tion to any means of payment established in their name abroad, foreign banknotes up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000 or subject to the submission of appro- priation (if it was either declared upon entry or acquired by draw ing on a Financial Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency or by exchange of foreign travelers checks, e tc . ), any larger amount. They may also take out any fore ign means of payment other than banknotes acquired in Upper Volta by debit to a Financial Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency, again subject to submission of documentation. Finally, they may take out freely up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, and banknotes issued by Operations Account countries. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the French Franc Area may be made free ly but for statistical purposes certain agri- cultural products require a license from the Directorate of Commerce. Exports to Portugal, Rhodesia, and South A f r ica are prohibited. Exports to all other coun- tries are permitted free ly but some also require a license. Certain commodities can be exported in special circumstances only. Exports to Ghana are subject to special regulations. Export proceeds received in cur- rencies other than those of France or another Opera- tions Account coun try must be surrendered. All export transactions relating to fore ign countries must be domi- ciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000, and the exporter must sign a foreign exchange commitment (engagement de change) and submit a customs certification (attestation d'exporta- tion). Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom transactions in invisibles with France, Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area may be retained. All amounts due f rom residents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries f rom foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date. Such proceeds and earnings must not be received in or f rom Portugal, Rhodesia, or South A f r ica. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue ma in ta in ing an Operations Account with the French Treasury, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. Resident travelers must within eight days surrender to an authorized bank any fore ign means of p aym ent in excess of CFAF 5,000 that they br ing in. 513 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA Capital All capital movements between Upper Volta and Portugal, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Capital movements between Upper Volta and France, Monaco, and other Operations Account countries in the French Franc Area are f ree of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts f rom such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requ iremen ts that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inwa rd direct inves tment and all ou tward inves tmen t, and over the issuing, advertising, or o f fe r ing for sale of fore ign securities in Upper Volta; these controls relate to the transactions themselves, not to paymen ts or receipts. With the exception of those over foreign securities in Upper Volta, the control measures do not apply to relations with France and its Overseas Departments and Territo- ries (except the French Territory of the A f a rs and the Issas), Monaco, the other member countries of the West A f r ican Monetary Union, and those other coun- tries whose bank of issue is linked w i th the French Treasury by an Operations Account. Special controls are ma in ta ined also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of f u n ds for deposit with foreign pri- vate persons and fore ign firms and institutions, and over all publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate bu i ld ing operations abroad; these special controls do apply also to France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. Both the mak ing and the l iqu ida t ion of investments, whether these are Upper Volta investments abroad or foreign investments in Upper Volta, must be reported to the Minister of Finance w i th in 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere par- ticipation is not considered as direct investment, pro- vided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. The fo l low ing are, however, exempt f rom th is authoriza- t ion: (1) loans con s t i tu t ing a direct inve s tmen t, which are subject to pr ior dec la ra t ion, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by indu s t r ial firms to finance transac t ions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports in to or exports f rom Upper Volta, or by in te rna t ional t r ad ing houses to f inance i n t e r n a t i o n al m e r ch an t ing transac- tions; (3) loans con trac ted by authorized bank s; (4) loans other than those men t ioned above, when the total amount ou t s tand ing of these loans, in c lud ing the new borrow ing, does not exceed CFAF 100 m i l l ion for any one borrower, and p rov ided that the annual in terest rate does not exceed the no rmal m a rk et ra te. The repayment of loans not cons t i tu t ing a d irect inves tment requires the special au tho r iza t ion of the M in is ter if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special au tho r iza t ion. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control au thor iza t ion by the BCEAO, a c t ing on behalf of the Minister of Finance. The lend ing of CFA f r a n cs to nonresidents for periods of up to two years, howeve r, is freely perm i t ted. Ord inance No. 70-074/PRES/PL-TP of December 31, 1970, the Investment Code, provides p re fe ren t ial treat- ment for fo re ign investment in Upper Volta. Two pref- e ren t ial categories (A and B) are established, in accord- ance w i th which p re fe ren t ial t rea tment w i th respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified enterprises for periods of up to 25 years. The benefits under Category B are far more liberal than those under Category A; they are negoti- ated between the investor and the Gove rnmen t, and the enterprise accorded such benef i ts must be of exceptional impor tance to the development of the coun t ry. Law No. 25761 /AN set up an assistance f u nd for new industries. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any fo rm in Upper Volta. Imports and exports of gold f rom or to any other coun t ry requ ire prior authorization by the External Finance Bureau in the Ministry of Finance and Commerce. Exempt f rom this requirement are ( 1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac tured articles containing a minor quan t i ty of gold (such as gold-filled or gold- plated articles); and ( 3) imports and exports by trav- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution elers of gold objects up to a combined weight of 500 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs dec lara t ion. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY Exchange Rate System On October 7, 1960 a par value for the Uruguayan Peso was established by Uruguay with the Fund; how- ever, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. There is a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market and finan- cial market. Payments and receipts in respect of imports, exports, freight and insurance on imports and exports, and certain public sector exchange operations are settled in the commercial market, where the exchange rates are fixed (although adjusted from time to t ime), while all other permitted exchange transac- tions take place in the financial market, in which the exchange rates fluctuate. On December 29, 1972 the buying and selling rates in the commercial market were Ur$725 and Ur$732 per US$1, respectively, and those in the financial market were Ur$875 and Ur$880 per US$1, respectively. The Central Bank supplies foreign exchange to the commercial banks for imports, and the proceeds from exports (valued at the officially assessed price or aforo where applicable) must be surrendered to the monetary authorities.1 Commercial banks operate on their own account in the financial market, but are not permitted to exceed the ir overbought positions of February 29, 1972 and must surrender any excess exchange holdings to the Central Bank. The application of exchange taxes (detracciones or retenciones) to the proceeds from certain traditional exports and the payment of subsidies through tax credit certificates (reintegros) on proceeds from certain non- traditional exports give rise to various effective buying rates that d iffer from the commercial market buying rate. A tax of %o of 1 per cent is payable on all funds received f rom abroad. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through authorized banks, banking houses, and the monetary authorities. The latter collect import surcharges and export taxes, hold the special deposits required for certain imports, and receive export and import regis- trations. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agree- ments may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system; these coun- tries are Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, and 1 On March 1, 1967, a new Central Bank was established but some operations are still being carr ied out on its behalf by the Bank of the Republic. The te rm "monetary a u t h o r i t i e s" as used here r e f e rs to both b anks taken toge ther. 516 Venezuela. Settlements with other countries are made in U. S. dollars or other convertible currencies. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to registration prior to the placing of orders abroad. The registrations are gener- ally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. Certain imports are effec- tively prohibited. Most imports are subject to an import surcharge (recargo), a special deposit (consignation), and /or prescribed terms of payment. Goods are classi- fied into nine categories; goods in one category bear no surcharge; goods in the other categories are subject to surcharges of 10, 30, 40, 60, 75, 90, 150, or 225 per cent, payable at the time of registration. Imports from LAFTA countries receive a fu ll or partial exemp- tion from the surcharges. Many imports are subject to consignaciones in Uruguayan pesos of a certain per- centage of the c.i.f. va lue; the deposit must be lodged with the mone tary authorities at the time of registra- tion and is refundable upon application after six months. For the period J anu a ry 1-March 31, 1973. imports by each importer in each surcharge category up to 58 per cent of the value of his import declara- tions (denuncias de importation) exempt from con- signaciones dur ing the period July 1 —December 31, 1971 are exempt f rom consignaciones. For imports in excess of the margin exempt from consignaciones, the required deposit rate varies depending on the surcharge category applicable as of July 21, 1971. For imports free of surcharge, or imports w i th surcharges as of that date of up to 50 per cent, the consignation is 450 per cent (315 per cent for imports f rom LAFTA countries; for imports with surcharges of more than 50 per cent and up to 110 per cent, the rate is 900 per cent (630 per cent for imports from LAFTA coun tr ies); and for imports with surcharges above 110 per cent, the rate is 1,200 per cent (840 per cent for imports from LAFTA coun tr ies). The regime of consignaciones applicable to capital goods is suspended, pending the issuance of new regulations govern ing the ir importation. Imports by the public sector that have been approved by the Central Bank and imports financed with external loans at maturities of at least 10 years are among those exempt from consignaciones. Most imports are subject, in addition to any customs duty required, to an additional import duty of 18 per cent of the c.i.f. value, payable upon customs clear- ance. The tax is not applied to imports originating in GATT or LAFTA countries, nor to imports of specified agencies and public institutions; in addition, an exemp- tion of 100 per cent, 85 per cent, or 40 per cent of the applicable tax is provided to specified imports. All impor ts va lued at over US$1.82 are subject to consular charges of Mo of 1 per cent of the peso amount result- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ing from the conversion of the f.o.b. value at a rate of Ur$55 per US$1; the amount of the charges is pay- able in foreign exchange, at a rate of U r$l — US$2.10 (at a rate of Ur$l = US$1 for private imports of petroleum and petroleum products, alcohol, and tetra- ethyl lead, at a rate of Ur$l = US$0.50 for imports by ANCAP (the state oil and alcohol monopoly) of the same commodities, and at1 a rate of U r$l = US$1.05 for certain other imports of ANCAP) .2 Consignaciones and surcharges in most cases are cal- culated either on assumed c.i.f. prices (aforos) estab- lished for many commodities or on the actual c.i.f. value, whichever is higher. In a few cases, the calcula- tion is based on an officially assessed price (also referred to as aforo), which usually is expressed in U. S. dollars per kilogram. Since April 27, 1971 import registrations have been subject to the following system. Sales of foreign exchange for imports are prohibited unless minimum financing requirements are fulfilled. At the end 1972, foreign exchange was made available by the banking system only for imports payable 180 days or more after the date of shipment. For imports for which financing under these conditions could not be obtained, the Cen- tral Bank could authorize the sale of exchange on a case-by-case basis. The sale of exchange was made at the earliest 15 days prior to the maturity date, and provided that the importer had deposited the peso equivalent of the transaction within 30 days after the date of approval of the application for customs clear- ance. In such cases, the sale was made at the rate of exchange in effect on the date of the deposit; for importers not making the deposit within the 30-day period, however, the sale of exchange was made at the rate in effect on the date of payment. In 1971 special arrangements were applied to certain other import payments and an exchange rate guarantee was given subject to the lodging of a peso deposit. Certain arrears have arisen in the implementation of these arrangements. Payments for Invisibles Freight and insurance on imports and exports are settled in the commercial market. All other payments for invisibles are settled at the financial rate. There are basic exchange allowances for certain current invis- ibles. Thus, for tourism and other travel, the alloca- tions (including fares) are: for travel to Argentina, $a 1,750 a person a t r i p ;3 to Brazil, Cr$ 1,200 a person a t r i p ;4 to Chile and Paraguay, either $a 1,750 or Cr$ 1,200 a person a trip; to other South American 2 These charges are equivalent to 11.55 per cent, 5.50 per cent, 2.75 per cent, and 5.775 per cent, respectively. 3 On January 26, 1973 the allowance for travel to Argentina was reduced to $a 1,000. 4 On January 26, 1973 reduced to Cr$600. to Brazil was the allowance for travel URUGUAY countries, US$25 a person a day, subject to a maximum of US$500 a person a trip; and to all other countries, US$30 a day, subject to a maximum of US$900 a person a trip. Exchange for family remittances is restricted to close relatives with permanent residence abroad and is subject to a maximum of US$150 a month for each recipient and remittor, no recipient or remitter being permitted to receive or effect a remit- tance more than once a month. The sale of foreign exchange for students on scholarships abroad is limited to an amount per month no greater than the difference between US$500 and the amount of the monthly schol- arship. For certain other invisibles, exchange is granted for the full amounts due. Payments for other specified types of invisibles may in principle be made freely through the financial market, subject to the regulations issued by the Central Bank. However, at the end of 1972 implementing regulations governing sales of exchange for many of these had not yet been issued. For such transactions (including profit and dividend remittances, royalties, commissions, and amortization and interest on private sector loans), the financial mar- ket remained effectively closed. There are no limitations on the export of foreign or domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of the principal exports are subject to taxes (detracciones or retenciones), which are withheld by the monetary authorities on the basis of the aforo value of the commodity concerned. The tax is stipulated in pesos per un it of export commodity, but it may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso proceeds of the export, except that for exports of meat the stipulated maximum is 25 per cent while for wool the permitted limits are 2 per cent and 35 per cent of the aforo value. The exchange proceeds of traditional exports subject to taxes must be surrendered in full to the monetary authorities not later than 30 days after shipment has been authorized; the proceeds from exports of nontraditional products must be sur- rendered within 60 days if the sale is on a cash basis or within 210 days if the sale is made on credit. For most exports, including wool and meat, minimum f.o.b. values (m in imum surrender prices or aforos) expressed in U. S. dollars per kilogram have been established for various grades and types. Subsidies (reintegros) of up to 40 per cent of the f.o.b. value are granted on certain nontraditional exports. Exports of certain types of beef and dairy cows, wool ewes, specified minerals (including iron, copper, zinc, aluminum, and n icke l), and protein concentrates used for animal feed are prohibited. As at the end of 1972 exports of certain animal fats, animal bristle, greasy wool, and skirted greasy wool, were also tem- porarily prohibited. Exports of wheat, sorghum, corn, and sunflower seeds are from time to time permitted up to certain quantities. 517 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds from invisibles may be held, utilized, or sold to the banking system. There are no limitations on the import of foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital Inward capital transfers by either residents or non- residents may be made freely through the bank ing system, and the exchange may be sold in the financial market anonymously; if the seller of foreign exchange identifies himself, however, he is entitled to repurchase in the financial market on any fu tu re date the same amount of foreign exchange. Outward capital t rans fe rs are subject to prior authorization; those of resident- owned capital are restricted. All obligations in excess of US$1,000 that are contracted abroad by the private sector must be declared within 30 days of the date of the contract. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad, provided that the transactions are registered. Gold may be exported only if accompanied by evidence of prior importation. Any private purchases abroad for nonindustrial use, how- ever, must be financed from the buyer's own exchange holdings. Imports and exports of gold for industrial use are settled through the commercial market. Changes during 1972 January 1. The exchange rate structure was simplified by the introduction of a dual exchange market and the elimination of differential "commissions" on exchange transactions. Transactions relating to imports and exports as well as certain public sector transactions were effected in a commercial market, while all other permitted transactions took place in a financial market. The buying and selling rates in the commercial market were initially set at Ur$495 and Ur$500 per US$1, respectively; these rates would be adjusted from time to time, within the framework of a flexible exchange rate policy. The rate in the financial market would be allowed to fluctuate free ly; the opening rate was about Ur$750 per US$1. March 2. Decree No. 177 amended the surcharges applicable to imports, as follows: (1) the increase in surcharges to 300 per cent on imports previously sub- ject to surcharges of 50 per cent or more (established by Decree 803/971 of December 6, 1971) was rescinded; ( 2) the 5 per cent surcharge on goods not transported in Uruguayan flag vessels was abolished; ( 3) the surcharge rates of 25 per cent, 50 per cent, 80 per cent, 110 per cent, 170 per cent, and 250 per cent were reduced to 10 per cent, 30 per cent, 60 per cent, 90 per cent, 150 per cent, and 225 per cent, respectively; and (4) imports subject to surcharges of 60 per cent or more, (which, by virtue of a Decree of April 14, 1963 were subject to a minimum additional surcharge) became subject to a minimum additional surcharge of 10 per cent ( for imports of motor vehicle kits the minimum additional surcharge remained 15 per cen t). The same Decree extended the ban on imports of capital goods from March 31, 1972 to June 30, 1972, and established that the suspension through March 31, 1972 of imports with surcharges of 50 per cent or more (established by Decree No. 884/971) would now apply to imports with surcharges of 30 per cent or more. Imports for the installation of industrial plants authorized by the Ministry of Finance and con- sidered in the national interest were added to the exemptions from the ban on capital goods imports. March 2. Decree No. 178/972 provided that all exchange proceeds from exports of traditional and nontraditional products must be surrendered to the Central Bank through the banking system. Circular No. 358 regulated transactions in the commercial market. In order to purchase foreign exchange at the rate of exchange prevailing on the day of deposit of the peso equivalent, importers had to deposit the pesos when applying for customs clearance. March 2. Circular No. 359 regu la ted transactions in the financial market. All nontrade transactions were channeled through this market, in which the rate of exchange would be determined by supply and demand. The amount of exchange sales permitted and the con- ditions of sale for specified types of transactions would be announced in due course by the Central Bank. Holders of foreign exchange could sell it freely in the financial market through the banking system without disclosing their identity; however, identified sellers would have the right to repurchase an equivalent amount of fore ign exchange on any f u t u re date.
