Central Bank Circular No. 409 and Communication No. 72 /54 announced a new scheme for the consolidation of commercial arrears on imports governed by Circulars Nos. 252, 254, 260, 295, 332, 265, 289, and 318. Certain import payments due to mature in the period through December 31, 1973 were also covered by the announcement. Upon receipt from the banks and firms involved in the original importa- tion of the goods of a guarantee that the payment was still pending, the Central Bank undertook to issue negotiable bonds in settlement of the outstanding arrears. The bonds would be denominated in the for- eign currency of the original transaction and would be issued in two series. The first would be to cover obliga- tions arising from import operations under Circulars Nos. 252, 254, 260, 265, and 289 and the second to settle other obligations covered by Circular No. 409. The bonds would bear interest at 7.5 per cent a year, payable f rom November 1, 1972 for bonds in the first series and from April 1, 1973 for bonds in the second series. Remittances through the financial market of any interest payments due for periods prior to November 1, 1972 and April 1, 1973, respectively, would be regulated by the Central Bank. The bonds would be issued in accordance with a schedule of amortization payable on a rising scale in 16 quarterly installments f rom December 31, 1973 to September 30, 1977. Circular No. 409 also required importers to deposit w i th in a specified time the local currency equivalent of the obligations concerned, if these deposits had not already been made, and established the rates of exchange at which such deposits would be accepted. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA Exchange Rate System * The par va lue is 0.265275 gram of fine gold per Venezuelan Bolivar. No transac t ions take place at the par va lue. Exchange t ransac t ions take place at the fol- lowing rates.1 The Cen tral Bank of Venezuela purchases proceeds of the pe tro leum and iron ore expor t ing com- panies at the rate of Bs 4.30 per US$1. Any proceeds from exports of cacao and coffee that are offered for sale to the Cen tral Bank must be purchased by it at the rate of Bs 4.385 per US$1. The Central Banks sells exchange to the Gove rnment and its agencies and to the commercial banks (for sales to the public only) at Bs 4.385 per US$1.2 The commercial banks purchase fo re ign exchange f rom the pub l ic at rates close to Bs 4.38 per US$1. Commercial banks must sell exchange to the pub l ic at Bs 4.40 per US$ 1 for all transactions; fore ign banks may only sell fo re ign exchange that has not been obtained from the Central Bank. Some foreign exchange is also negotiated on the two stock exchanges, where buy ing and selling rates usua l ly are slightly below B s4 .40 per US$1. Exchange houses are permitted to deal on ly in bankno tes, coins, and travelers checks. The Central Bank offers swap facilities under which it buys U. S. dollars at Bs 4.37 and resells at Bs 4.40 af ter 90 or 180 days. Administration of Control There is no exchange control mechanism. Import and export licenses, when requ ired, are generally issued by the M in i s t ry of Development or the M in is try of Ag r icu l tu re and Livestock, depend ing on the commod- ity. Under the terms of an agreement between the Gove rnment and the Cen tral Bank, the latter has the respons ib i l i ty of en su r ing that a subsidy is applied to imports of wheat for human consumption and to cer- t a in expor ts of coffee and cacao. Prescription of Currency Payments between Venezuela and Argen t ina, Chile, Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts ma in ta ined w i th each other by the Cen tral Bank of Venezuela and the cen tral banks of the countries concerned. Proceeds f rom exports of pe tro leum and petroleum derivatives must not be received through these accounts. Otherwise, no prescription of currency requ iremen ts are in force. * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, Venezuela with effect f rom February 19 changed the buying rate of Bs 4.30 per U. S. dollar to Bs 4.20 and that of Bs 4.385 to Bs 4.285. The Central Bank's sales of foreign ex- change sales to the commercial banks hencefor th took place at Bs 4.285, and those of the banks to their customers at Bs 4.30 per US$1. 1 The exchange rates given (except those for the Central Bank's swap transactions) are those applicable to sight draf ts on New York. 2 The Central Bank does not sell foreign exchange to the public but does sell minor amounts to its staff and certain government officials, at the Bs 4.40 rate, for travel expenses and personal remit- tances. Imports and Import Payments The import of certain goods is either prohibited or reserved for the Government; these include fu l ly assem- bled automobiles, certain textiles, coffee, c i trus f ru i t, bananas, pineapples, melons, salt, opium, cigarette pape r, na tu ral pearls, and matches. In add i t ion, many other commodities requ ire import licenses; quan t i ta t ive res tr ic t ions applicable irrespective of origin are main- tained on these items for protective purposes. Licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia and South A f r ica. Import licenses for some products are issued on the cond i t ion that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quantity imported (contingentamiento). Imports of wheat for human consumption receive a subsidy of 25.55 per cent of the f .o .b. value, calculated at Bs 4.40 per US$1; they requ ire an import license, and the Central Bank's Import Subsidy Office establishes eligibility for the subsidy. All other commodities are free from import licensing. Imports from Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. Import paymen ts may be made free ly. Payments for Invisibles All paymen ts for invisibles may be made freely; private sector purchases of exchange for this purpose are made f rom commercial banks or exchange houses. Resident and nonresident travelers must on departure pay a travel tax of Bs 80 a person a trip; exemptions exist for children under seven, fore ign tourists, Vene- zuelan and fore ign diplomats, and personnel of inter- na t ional organizations. Travelers may freely export domestic and foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain furs and hides, scrap metals, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the exportation of many other commodi- ties, except petroleum. Most export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Development, but those for coffee and cacao are granted by the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. Exports of products containing subsidized imported wheat are subject to special arrangements to ensure that the sub- sidy received is repaid. The export of gold and precious stones requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. The petroleum and iron ore exporting com- panies must surrender to the Central Bank export pro- ceeds, to the extent of their local currency requirements (including taxes), at a rate of Bs 4.30 per US$1. Otherwise, there are no surrender requirements for export proceeds or other exchange receipts. Exporters of coffee and cacao may (but need not) sell exchange proceeds to the Central Bank at Bs 4.385 per US$1; they may receive an export subsidy calculated to pre- 523 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA vent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Vene- zuelan ports from falling below specified minimum amounts regardless of external prices for these prod- ucts. Eligibility for this subsidy is maintained also if the exchange proceeds are not surrendered. The mini- mum prices guaranteed by the Government range from Bs 175.00 to Bs 185.44 a quintal for coffee, and are Bs 121 or Bs 150 a quintal for cacao. In principle, the benefit of these arrangements may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. All exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited, as are exports of petroleum and military equipment to mainland China and North Korea. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are freely disposa- ble. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, with the exception that the Currency Law prohibits the importation for commercial purposes of foreign coins other than gold coins. The importation of Venezuelan gold coins is reserved for the Central Bank. Capital All capital transfers are permitted freely. Brokerage activity in Venezuela, however, in shares or units of foreign investment trusts or mutual funds is prohibited. There is no registration procedure for incoming capital. The Central Bank regulates bank credit to nonresidents and companies whose capital is more than 50 per cent owned by physical persons or companies that are resi- dent or domiciled abroad. The General Banking Law of December 30, 1970 authorizes the Government to regulate bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 per cent owned by nonresident or foreign physical persons or companies. This law also provides special regulations for foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment pur- poses. The Central Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coins, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated between licensed importers, exchange houses, and the public. Commercial banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents but do not normally deal in gold with the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are reserved for the Central Bank, as is the import of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela. Other imports and exports of gold require licenses. Imports require licenses from the Ministry of Finance and in certain cases also from the Ministry of Development, while exports are licensed by the Ministry of Finance only. The law prescribes a license for all imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the Ministry of Development as an industrial user, but in practice imports and exports by private persons are permitted free of license. Imports of gold coins and of gold bars and ingots weighing more than 12 kilograms are free of customs duty; all other gold imports are subject to duty at varying rates. All imports of nonmonetary gold are subject to consu- lar duties ranging from 2 per cent to 3% per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1972 January 1. Venezuela gave notice of termination of the reciprocal trade agreement with the United States. The agreement partially expired on June 30. January 3. By virtue of Joint Resolution No. 7 of the Ministries of Development and Finance, import licenses became required for imports from all sources of those commodities in List I of the U. S. trade agree- ment that previously were exempt f rom licensing. July 1. The import licensing requirements imposed on January 3 were removed. In addition, certain com- modities subject to import license prior to January 3 were exempted from licensing. 524 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM Exchange Rate System No par value for the Vietnamese Piastre has been established with the Fund. The exchange rate structure is based on an official rate and a special rate, both of which may be adjusted from time to time; on Decem- ber 31, 1972 they stood at VN$465 and VN$320, respectively, per US$1. Different effective exchange rates arise from the application of certain subsidies, equalization taxes (taxes de perequation), and commis- sions. Payments and receipts must be effected through the authorized banks. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in forward buying or selling of foreign exchange in the domestic or foreign exchange markets only in relation to payments for imports and only in certain specified currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the National Bank of Viet-Nam (Directorate-General of Exchange). Most remittances must have the prior approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange; the authority to approve some payments for private invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. Imports financed by U. S. aid require licenses and are subject to special contracts or procurement procedures. Import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Economy (Directorate of Commercial A id) and are countersigned by the National Bank (Directorate of Foreign A id ). Licenses are gen- erally not required for imports financed with Viet- Nam's own exchange. Prescription of Currency With the exception of import payments under the French credit insurance program, all payments must be made in U. S. dollars. Proceeds from exports to France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Japan, and the United Kingdom must be received in the currency of the country concerned. Other receipts may be accepted either in a currency quoted by the National Bank (deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, or pounds sterling) or in any other convertible currency, provided that prior to repatriation such other cur- rencies are converted into a currency quoted by the National Bank. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may maintain accounts with banks, subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Nonresident Accounts in Free Piastres may be freely credited with the proceeds f rom the sale of convertible exchange and may be freely debited for most paymen ts to residents. A category of nonresident accounts, Capital Accounts, covers piastres owned by nonresident foreigners that may not be transferred abroad. Balances in Capital Accounts may be used for investment. Their use is subject to the approval of the Directorate-General of Exchange. Investments financed from Capital Accounts generally are not covered by the Investment Law of 1963 (see section on Capital, be low), and proceeds from the liquidation of such investments are credited to Capital Accounts unless the Ministry of National Economy has declared them eligible for the privileges of the law. Balances in Capital Accounts are negoti- able between nonresident foreigners. Imports and Import Payments The bulk of imports comes under one of three head- ings: ( 1) imports financed with funds from the U .S. Agency for International Development (A ID ); (2) imports financed from Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange resources; and (3) "third-country-financed imports," i.e., imports financed with French, German, and Japanese loans, or French export credit. In principle, products imported under the AID programs are not included among imports that are financed otherwise. However, when AID financing proves insufficient for obtaining imports of essential products, such imports may be financed from Viet-Nam's official exchange reserves. Many imports are prohibited. Except for those commodities also financed by the U. S. AID programs and prohibited commodities, all imports financed with Viet-Nam's own exchange are effected through the "Import Credit" procedure, under which they are exempt from license. All other imports require licenses. Certain imports are subject to advance deposits and/or equalization taxes. All imports of textile piece goods are subject to an equalization tax of VN$200 per US$1. Some imports are permitted without foreign exchange (sans devises); these include imports by end-users with branches abroad, gifts and samples, spare parts for international airlines, and other small imports, when the Directorate-General of Exchange is satisfied that the foreign exchange privately held by the importer has not been obtained illegally. Import licenses generally are valid for all noncom- munist countries; the main exception is that goods financed by U .S. aid must originate in "PD31" coun- tries (the Republic of China, India, the Republic of Korea, Morocco, Pakistan, the Philippines, Singapore, Sri Lanka, and Tunisia) or the United States. All imports financed with Viet-Nam's own foreign exchange and valued at US$500 or over require a let- ter of credit. In addition to the advance deposit require- ments mentioned above, commercial banks may require margin deposits on the opening of import letters of credit according to the standing of the importer and 525 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET-NAM the market situation for the commodity concerned. Importers are required to pay the import value minus VN$100 per US$1 at the time of the allocation of the import credit when importing under the "Import Credit" procedure; the balance must then be paid upon utiliza- tion of the letter of credit. Some essential commodities are exempt from margin deposit requirements; these include flour, milk, sugar, newsprint, petroleum prod- ucts, fertilizers, agricultural implements, and raw materials and industrial equipment imported by end- users. Some imports under suppliers' credits are subject to a different type of deposit (consignation). Payments for Invisibles Most payments for invisibles require approval by the Directorate-General of Exchange. Students approved by a special commission are granted US$80 a month for study in the Republic of China or Hong Kong and US$150 a month for study elsewhere; they are also granted allocations for tuition and medical fees and for extraordinary expenses. Foreign specialists employed in Viet-Nam may transfer up to 50 per cent of their salary every month, but not more than US$600 a month. In principle, foreign firms are generally permitted to transfer up to 70 per cent of their net annual profit after tax, after examination of their accounts and after deduction of any losses in previous years. Profit trans- fers by foreign enterprises established or expanded between February 14, 1963 and June 2, 1972 under the terms of the 1963 Investment Law are governed by the provisions of that law unless they meet the require- ments of the "Foreign Exchange Working Capital System" (see section on Capital, be low). Although dividends declared in Viet-Nam and accruing to non- residents and foreign residents may in principle be transferred abroad, under the terms of the 1963 Invest- ment Law transfers of profits and dividends are limited to 20 per cent annually of the declared capital. Net annual profits after tax from projects covered by the new Investment Law, Law No. 4/72, may be trans- ferred without limit. Each resident authorized to travel abroad is entitled to purchase the following amounts of foreign exchange at the official rate: travelers to the Khmer Republic and Laos US$30 a day, with a maximum of US$300 a person a trip, and travelers to other countries US$40 a day, with a maximum of US$2,400 a person a trip. The allocations mentioned may be supplemented by the equivalent of US$40 in foreign banknotes. Travelers are permitted to take with them up to VN$5,000 in Vietnamese banknotes. Foreign exchange not used by foreign travelers may be re-exported when a declaration is made to the customs and evidence is given that any utilized exchange has been sold to an authorized bank. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports do not require a license; they must 526 be domiciled (registered) with an authorized bank, however, which is responsible for the repatriation of the foreign exchange. All exports to communist coun- tries, exports to any destination of manufactured or semimanufactured products originally imported into Viet-Nam, gold, rice, rice products, and certain other items are prohibited; the prohibition does not apply to imported goods that have been processed in Viet-Nam, provided that the va lue added corresponds to, or exceeds, a specified proportion of the export price. Exporters are allowed to retain in EFAC (Exporta- tions, Frais Accessories) accounts 10 per cent of their total export proceeds for the settlement of incidental expenses related to the export transaction. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom invisibles must be surrendered at the official rate. Foreign military personnel and official U. S. civilian personnel serving in Viet-Nam are paid in scrip ("mili- tary payment certificates" or MPCs) which can be exchanged for piastres at the official rate only through special official channels (military bank ing facilities). They are not permitted to possess foreign banknotes or travelers checks in Viet-Nam, but there are military banking facilities under which eligible foreign persons may open accounts in piastres, MPCs, or U.S. dollars at two U. S. banks in Saigon. Travelers entering Viet-Nam may bring in any amount of foreign exchange, but it must be declared to the customs on entry. A traveler may bring in Viet- namese banknotes up to a total of VN$5,000. Foreign military and civilian personnel (government officials) must surrender on arrival any foreign banknotes they bring into Viet-Nam. Capital Under general regulations, capital may be imported without formalities, but foreign investors must register their capital with the Vietnamese authorities and agree on the terms of the investment in order to be able to repatriate their capital and to t rans fer profits. Under the Investment Law of 1963, special benefits could be accorded to new foreign investments in the sectors of the economy that are given high priority. The mini- mum investment in agriculture was established at VN$0.5 million, and in industry at VN$1 million. Imports of equipment and spare parts needed by foreign undertakings covered by the law were exempt from customs duties. Foreign technicians employed by these enterprises were exempt from income tax for 2 years. Foreign investments were free of taxes on profit, securities, and real estate for specified periods of time. The new investments were not subject to any national- ization measures for the first 15 years from the date of the written authorization granted to the investor; they were accorded the same treatment as that applicable to ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution domesic investments. The law provided for the transfer of profits at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent of the invested capital, and for the repatriation of the original investment after 5 years at an annual rate of up to 20 per cent if the capital was newly imported (a f ter 20 years for investment of foreign-owned capital previously held in V ie t-Nam). A new Investment Law promulgated on June 2, 1972 has superseded the Investment Law of 1963. The pro- visions of the 1963 law, however, are still applicable to the enterprises which were governed by them. Under the new law, which mainly adds new fiscal benefits to the provisions of the 1963 law, fiscal incentives are granted to new investments whether financed in Viet- namese currency or in foreign exchange brought from abroad, provided that (a) the investments are made in a "priority sector" and (b) that the initial capital is over VN$10 million in the primary sector and over VN$20 million in the secondary and tertiary sectors. Besides fiscal exemptions the foreign enterprises enjoy- ing the benefits of the law are authorized (a) to trans- fer abroad total net annual profits and (b) to repatriate after five years of operation the capital invested, in annual installments of 20 per cent. Investments not covered by either Investment Law nor by the regime described in the following paragraph are subject to the regulations and case-to-case decisions of the Directorate-General of Exchange, which nor- Table of Exchange Rates (as at December 31, 1972) VIET-NAM mally authorizes the transfer of up to 70 per cent of net annual profits after taxes but does not permit dis- investment; such investments are not eligible for the above-mentioned tax exemptions. Under a "Foreign Exchange Working Capital Sys- tem," foreign capital imported in the fo rm of direct investment or as medium-term and long-term credit in cash or in kind may be registered with the National Bank and treated as follows. Capital must be brought from abroad and sold through authorized banks, where it is credited to a "Foreign Exchange Working Account." Profits, dividends, and interest on such capital may be transferred annually up to a maximum of 20 per cent of the registered amount and repatriation may be made up to an annual maximum of 25 per cent of the regis- tered capital. Imports and exports of capital normally are made at the official rate. Gold Within Viet-Nam, the holding of gold and all trans- actions in gold are subject to licensing, but the con- trols are not rigidly enforced and unlicensed holdings of gold by individuals are tolerated. Only the National Bank is empowered to import and export gold. All domestic transactions in gold are subject to a luxury tax of 10 per cent on the sale value or the manufacturing cost. Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA Exchange Rate System * No par value for the Western Samoa Tala has been established with the Fund. A fixed relationship is main- tained between the tala and the New Zealand dollar; the middle rate is WS$0.8076 = $NZ1, and the Bank of Western Samoa's buying and selling rates on December 30, 1972 were WS$0.8019 and WS$0.8132 per $NZ1, respectively. The Bank of Western Samoa's buying and selling rates for the U. S. dollar were US$1.4937 and US$1.4662, respectively, per WS$1 on December 30, 1972. Administration of Control Western Samoa is a member of the Sterling Area, although it has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U .K. Exchange Control Act, 1947. Exchange control is administered by the Minister of Finance operating as the exchange control authority; the Minister may delegate his approval authority to the Financial Secretary, who in turn may delegate part of his powers to authorized banks. All payments to non- residents of Western Samoa require the approval of the Ministry of Finance. The Ministry, however, has dele- gated to the Bank of Western Samoa, the only author- ized bank, authority to approve certain payments up to any amount and certain other payments up to specified amounts. Prescription of Currency Most settlements with Sterling Area territories take place in Sterling Area currencies, but there are no prescriptions as to the currencies in which payments to or from nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between the accounts of resi- dents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited from all sources for reasons of security or health. Other commodities may be imported from any source. Each licensed commercial importer receives an annual allo- cation of foreign exchange, to be taken up on a quarterly basis, which may be used freely for the import of any commodity that is not prohibited except automobiles. The allocations are made by the Ministry of Finance and communicated to the Bank of Western Samoa; the latter automatically provides the foreign exchange required for import payments upon submis- sion of documentary evidence. Persons who are not licensed importers may import any commodity freely up to WS$100 a person a year but require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance for imports of higher value. The import of automobiles, whether for business or personal use, is subject to specific approval on a case-by-case basis by the Ministry of Finance. Payments for Invisibles Payments for certain invisibles, such as overseas con- tractual obligations and insurance, are approved auto- matically by the Bank of Western Samoa up to any amount or within limits determined by the Ministry of Finance. Paymen ts in excess of these l im i ts as well as paymen ts for all other invisibles require the prior approval of the M in i s t ry of Finance. Remittances in respect of study abroad are freely authorized. The Ministry of Finance approves up to any amount the transfer of genuine income derived locally from pen- sions, rents, interests, and dividends by persons per- manently resident overseas. Residents traveling to American Samoa, whether for business or private purposes, are entitled to a foreign currency allowance equivalent to US$50 a person a quarter; an additional allowance of US$15 a day is provided to cover hotel expenses. The basic travel allowance for other coun- tries is equivalent to WS$10 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$ 1,000. The Ministry of Finance grants supplementary allocations when evidence of genuine need is provided. Resident travelers may take out foreign banknotes, as part of their foreign currency allowance, up to WS$20 a person a trip. Resident and nonresident travelers may take out any amount in domestic currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Virtually all exports requ ire the prior approval of the M in is try of Finance. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agr icu l ture on grounds of low quality, or by order of the Head of State to alleviate domestic shortages. Copra exports are controlled by the Copra Board and banana exports by the Produce Marketing Division. Export proceeds must be surrendered to the Bank of Western Samoa within a reasonable time after shipment. Where exceptional circumstances exist, the Ministry of Finance may waive this requirement for certain export items. * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U.S. dollar was being devalued, the Western Samoa tala remained pegged to the New Zealand dollar, at the previously existing ratio. The transfer of legacies from estates of deceased local residents due to beneficiaries per- manently residing overseas is approved up to a limit of WS$ 10,000 a year. The Bank of Western Samoa approves transfers of g if ts to relatives and dependents, either for special fam i ly occasions or by way of mainte- nance, up to WS$200 a year for each fam i ly group. Foreign investments in specified activities in Western Samoa are encouraged. The Enterprises Incentive Act No. 27/1965, as amended in 1969, makes provision for the granting of certain relief of customs duties, income tax, and business license fees to persons engaged in approved enterprises. Not for Redistribution YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC Exchange Rate System * The currency of the Yemen A rab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is issued by the Central Bank of Yemen. No par value has been established with the Fund. All transactions take place in a free market at a fluctuating exchange rate. Since May 1972, however, a Central Bank guideline has been in effect advising commercial banks to adhere to a rate of YRls 5.00 = US$1 in their foreign exchange transactions, with a maximum deviation of 1 per cent on either side of this rate. On December 31, 1972 the rate for the U. S. dol- lar was about YRls 5 per US$1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered on behalf of the Minister of Economy by the Central Bank of Yemen, which has the au tho r i ty to grant exchange licenses and licenses for imports and exports. The only commercial banks and authorized dealers are the Yemen Bank for Reconstruction and Development (YBRD) and four branches of fore ign commercial banks. Prescription of Currency Settlements under bilateral payments arrangements 1 are made in the currencies and through the accounts provided for by these arrangements. In addition to a license, the importation of certain com- modities requires the permission of the competent min- istry or, for certain textiles, of the Sanaa Textile Fac- tory. Importers who have obtained an import license may obtain the necessary foreign exchange from the local banks or the free market. Imports that are financed by the importer with his own foreign exchange held abroad do not require an import license. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN Exchange Rate System * The currency of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen is the Yemeni Dinar, which is issued by the Bank of Yemen and is defined as equivalent to 2.13281 grams of fine gold. No par value has been established for the Yemeni dinar. The central rate is YD 1 = US$2.60571, and the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen has availed itself of wider margins. The effective parity relationship for the U. S. dollar on December 31, 1972 was about YD 1 = US$2.60. On December 31, 1972, the National Bank of Yemen's buying and selling rates for the U. S. dollar were YD 0.375 and YD 0.396 and those for sterling were YD 0.895 and YD 0.915. Administration of Control The administration of exchange control is carried out by the General Department for Exchange Control through the Foreign Exchange Committee, which has delegated certain powers to the Director of Exchange Control, who is a member of the Committee. The Ministry of Economy and Industry issues import and export licenses; those for gold and other precious metals require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers (licensed commercial banks approved by the Director of Ex- change Control); at present the only commercial bank and authorized dealer is the National Bank of Yemen. Except for payments for imports against letters of credit or documents, which may be approved by an authorized dealer, and for payments by the oil refinery, all payments for imports (including those of precious metals) require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Two public corporations and a semi- public corporation are engaged in foreign trade (see Imports and Import Payments, be low). The oil refinery is treated as a resident entity but in its operations gen- erally is not affected by the existing exchange and trade controls. Prescription of Currency The People's Democratic Republic of Yemen has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U.K. Exchange Control Act, 1947, but under current U.K. exchange control regulations continues to be regarded as part of the Overseas Sterling Area. Exchange trans- actions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers in accordance with prescription of currency regulations that are in certain respects similar to those applicable in the United Kingdom. S. dollar be- came approximately US$2.89 per YD 1. 534 ments to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds and certain receipts from invisibles must be received in prescribed currencies x and surrendered to authorized dealers. Payments for imports must be made in prescribed currencies. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts may be held by certain persons not resident in the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen. The principal type of nonresident account is the External Account in Yemeni Dinars. External Ac- counts may be credited with proceeds from convertible foreign currency transferred f rom abroad, with bank interest payable on such accounts, and with balances f rom other External Accounts. Transfers from abroad must be in the form of bank d ra f ts; the accounts cannot be credited with payments in the form of foreign bank- notes (unless they have been declared to the customs on en t ry ), or with locally raised or locally earned funds. External Accounts may be debited for any payments to residents, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for payments abroad in any convertible currency. Imports and Import Payments With minor exceptions, all imports other than those of the oil refinery require individual licenses. Most overland merchanting trade with the Yemen Arab Republic is also exempt from the licensing requirements. There are special regulations governing merchanting trade with neighboring countries. Imports from Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. An import program is drawn up annua l ly, but its quotas are operated flexibly. Payments for imports on a c. & f. basis against letters of credit or documentary d ra f ts can be made by authorized dealers without the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control; all other forms of payment for imports require such approval. Insurance on imports must be effected locally. A Board of Trade, which is an integral part of the Economic Organization, is in charge of the trading activities of the nationalized companies. The National Company for Foreign Trade has a monopoly over im- ports of flour, sugar, wheat, rice, ghee, cooking oil, tea, and cigarettes. The National Import Company Ltd. im- ports certain consumer goods not mentioned in Law No. 37 of 1969. The National Company for Home Trade is the sole importer of automobiles and other vehicles, all government requirements, and most re- quirements of the public hospitals, as well as other specified items. Imports into and exports from the free port zones within the port of Aden are free of exchange and trade controls (except in respect of transactions 1 Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U. S. dollars. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution between these zones and the rest of the People's Demo- cratic Republic of Yemen) and are exempt from customs duties. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. The basic exchange allowance for tourism, which residents may take up without applying for exchange control approval, is the equivalent of YD 125 a person a trip in travelers checks, drafts, and foreign notes and coins (50 per cent of this amount for children under t e n ) .2 Allowances for other types of travel are granted on the merits of the application. Foreign employees of approved enterprises and the oil refinery are allowed to remit abroad up to 50 per cent and three eights, respectively, of their total earnings (net of taxes). All insurance is nationalized; existing policies have been transferred to the National Insurance and Reinsurance Company, and payments abroad in respect of premiums are not permitted. Travelers may take out the equivalent of YD 5 in domestic banknotes and up to the equivalent of YD 125 in travelers checks, foreign banknotes, or other foreign means of payment. Furthermore, nonresidents may take out any foreign exchange declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports, including petroleum products, are exempt from licenses. Exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Except for exports to the Yemen Arab Republic and other neighboring countries specified by the Foreign Exchange Committee, export proceeds must be received in prescribed currencies within six months of shipment and must be sold to authorized dealers upon receipt. The proceeds of exports or re-exports to the Yemen Arab Republic and other neighboring coun- tries may be surrendered in the national currency of the importing country. Proceeds from Invisibles All claims of residents for services rendered to non- residents must be collected in foreign currency (or re- ceived from an External Account) when due and sur- rendered to authorized dealers. Travelers may freely bring in foreign banknotes but not more than YD 5 in domestic currency. Capital Virtually all capital payments and transactions require prior approval. Expatriates are normally permitted upon departure to remit their liquid funds to their country of permanent residence. All remittances abroad of interest and profits require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. Profit remittances abroad by foreign firms under Law No. 23 also are subject to the Exchange Control Law (Law No. 16) and in any one year should not normally exceed 50 per cent of the accrued net profit. Beginning five years after production has started, the net value of the enterprise (calculated on the basis of actual or book value or surrender or liquidation value, whichever is less) is transferable at the rate of 25 per cent a year; if an expatriate national or foreign investor encounters difficulties, however, his capital may be retransferred six months after entry. Interest due on any loans obtained abroad af ter the firm concerned has been estab- lished may also be remitted, provided that all duties, taxes, and other government dues have been paid. Gold Only the monetary authorities and authorized dealers may purchase, hold, or sell gold bullion. Licensed gold- smiths may purchase, hold, and sell other unworked gold and gold coins and ornaments. Other residents may hold gold only in the form of ornaments or numismatic coins. Exports and imports of gold by registered gold- smiths require licenses issued by the Ministry of Econ- omy and Industry (General Department for Foreign Trade), af ter the approval of the Director of Exchange Control has been obtained. Travelers may bring in or take out reasonable amounts of gold, in the form of ornaments only (not exceeding YD 250 in value for incoming travelers and not exceeding YD 100 for departing travelers). Imports and exports of gold by travelers are subject only to customs control, but incom- ing travelers must sell to an authorized dealer any gold coins or bullion they carry. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA Exchange Rate System * The par value is 0.0481478 gram of fine gold per Yugoslav Dinar, corresponding to Din 18.4571 = SDR 1 or Din 17.00 = US$1. There is no exchange market.1 The National Bank of Yugoslavia quotes rates for leading convertible currencies on the basis of their rates against the U. S. dollar in international centers. On December 30, 1972 the National Bank's buying and selling rates for the U. S. dollar were Din 16.75 and Din 16.85. Administration of Control On the basis of laws governing these matters, the Federal Executive Council prescribes the general pro- visions in respect of foreign trade and exchange trans- actions. The Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade, by virtue of these general provisions, establishes rules and regulations, makes decisions governing commercial transactions, and issues import and export licenses when required. It is also charged with securing balanced trade with payments agreement countries. The Federal Secre- tariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions gov- erning exchange transactions. This Secretariat and the National Bank of Yugoslavia administer the exchange controls. The National Bank prescribes the methods of payment to and from foreign countries; it also licenses compensation transactions. All foreign exchange transactions must be carried out through the National Bank or an authorized bank. The latter are of three types. Fully authorized banks, which must have a minimum foreign exchange credit fund equivalent to US$2 million and an annual exchange turnover of at least US$80 million, may engage in all foreign exchange transactions in Yugo- slavia and abroad, as well as in foreign credit opera- tions (including the granting of guarantees). Limited authorized banks, which must have a minimum foreign exchange credit fund equivalent to US$400,000, may conduct foreign exchange operations in Yugoslavia only; they may neither keep foreign exchange accounts abroad nor engage in foreign credit operations, except through the intermediary of a fully authorized credit bank. Authorized exchange offices may only deal in foreign banknotes and travelers checks; this status is open to all commercial and savings banks and to cer- tain specifically authorized banks. Commercial exports and imports may be effected by all economic organizations (both producing and trad- ing undertakings) registered for this purpose. Economic organizations that are not registered to conduct foreign trade channel their orders through economic organiza- tions which export and /or import on their own behalf. Prescription of Currency Payments to and from countries with which Yugo- slavia has bilateral payments agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set forth in those agreements. If no agreement exists, set- tlement is usually made in a convertible currency. Yugoslavia has payments agreements requiring settle- ments through bilateral accounts as follows: (1) in U. S. dollars with Afghanistan, Albania, Algeria, Brazil, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Ghana, Greece, Hungary, Mongolia, Poland, Romania, and the U. S. S. R.; and (2) in their respective currencies with India and Iraq.2 Certain settlements with Bangladesh, Colombia, Mexico, and Pakistan take place through special accounts. A degree of multilateralization of pay- ments is provided under the bilateral payments agree- ments with Afghanistan, Iraq, and Ghana. Nonresident Accounts Foreign juridical and physical persons may maintain accounts denominated in foreign exchange and in dinars in Yugoslavia according to the following rules. Foreigners resident outside Yugoslavia may freely open accounts in convertible currencies in Yugoslavia. For- eign missions and foreigners resident in Yugoslavia may freely open with authorized banks accounts expressed in foreign currencies or dinars. Foreign juridical and physical persons may freely open nonresident accounts in convertible d inars with authorized banks. Foreign exchange accounts in convertible currencies of nonresident juridical and physical persons are kept in the currency deposited.3 Balances on these accounts may be used for all payments in Yugoslavia, in dinars or in the currency concerned, and abroad, in any con- vertible currency. Transfers from these accounts are free if made in the currency in which the account is kept; outward transfers in other convertible currencies are subject to the account-holding bank being pre- pared to make the necessary conversion. Nonresident foreign exchange accounts in bilateral 2 With effect f rom Janua ry 1, 1973 settlements with India and Hun- gary took place in convertible currencies, following the termination on December 31, 1972 of the bilateral paymen ts agreements. :! Accounts may be denominated in any of the following currencies: Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian f rancs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, I ta l ian lire, Ne ther lands guilders, Nor- wegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U. S. dollars. Other convertible currencies must be converted into one or more of the forego ing currencies. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution currencies may be opened only for foreign juridical and physical persons resident in Yugoslavia and subject to prior approval by the National Bank. Balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia or for retransfer to the bilateral country to which the account is related. Nonresident accounts in convertible dinars may be credited freely with amounts whose transfer in con- vertible currency has been authorized and they may be debited freely for permitted payments in Yugoslavia and for transfer abroad in the convertible currency of the account holder's country of domicile. Nonresident juridical and physical persons may also open other dinar accounts with authorized banks. These other accounts may be credited with dinars acquired in Yugoslavia in accordance with the existing regulations or subject to the approval of the National Bank of Yugoslavia. Balances are in principle nontransferable and may be spent in Yugoslavia only for noncom- mercial payments by the account holder or by members of his close family, or by the owner and staff of foreign firms if the account holder is a foreign juridical person. If balances on these accounts derive from copyright royalties or from work performed in Yugoslavia by foreigners, from pensions and disability allowances of persons who have emigrated from Yugoslavia, or from alimony payments, transfers may be effected in accord- ance with the existing regulations. Resident nationals may maintain foreign exchange accounts or foreign exchange savings deposits in con- vertible currencies w i th any authorized bank, provided that they originate from receipts specified in the rele- vant regulations. These accounts are kept in the cur- rency deposited, are interest bearing, and interest is paid partly in the foreign currency deposited and partly in dinars. Foreign exchange accounts may be retained for an indefinite period of time and may be drawn upon freely for payments in Yugoslavia and abroad on behalf of the account holder or his immediate family; balances are not transferable to other persons or accounts (see section on Proceeds f rom Invisibles, below). Yugoslav emigrants residing abroad and former emigrants returning to Yugoslavia may also open for- eign exchange accounts in Yugoslavia that may be used freely for payments in Yugoslavia or abroad. Foreign exchange accounts in bilateral currencies may be maintained by resident nationals. In the case of currencies of Eastern European coun tr ies4 and Mongolia the accounts are denominated in account dollars; for other bilateral countries the accounts are kept in the currency deposited. In general, balances may be used only for dinar payments in Yugoslavia or for retransfers to the bilateral country to which the account is related. 4 Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Eastern Germany, Hunga ry, Poland, Romania, and U. S. S. R. YUGOSLAVIA Imports and Import Payments Commercial imports may be effected only by eco- nomic organizations registered as participating in for- eign trade. In addition to economic organizations specializing in foreign trade, most major industrial pro- ducers are registered. The import of certain basic food- stuffs, such as wheat, rice, coffee, lard, edible oil, and sugar, is carried out by economic organizations that have been selected by the Federal Office for Food Reserves, on the basis of public bids. For most commodities, import licenses are not required. All commodities included in the foreign trade nomenclature are classified in four categories 5 accord- ing to the manner in which exchange is made avail- able: LB —liberalized goods; GDK —goods imported under global exchange quotas; RK and DK—goods subject to individual quotas (RK if individual quotas are fixed by quan t i ty and DK if they are fixed in d in a r s ); and D —imports subject to ad hoc licensing. About 1,850 items (out of a total of over 4,500) are classified under LB; protective equipment for work- ers and all other goods not specifically included in the GDK, RK, DK, or D lists are also liberalized and free from any quantitative restriction. LB goods are mainly raw materials, foodstuffs, and spare parts; they also include some consumer goods. In 1971 as well as in 1972 goods currently imported under the LB regime accounted for about 29 per cent of total imports.6 Exchange for payments for LB imports from the con- vertible currency area is made available freely in any convertible currency appropriate to the exporting coun- try. Payments for imports of liberalized goods from payments agreement countries must be made in the manner prescribed in the relevant payments agreement and may be restricted according to the availability of funds in the appropriate clearing account. The GDK list comprises most consumer goods, cer- tain raw materials, and most capital equipment. In 1971 imports of commodities presently on this list amounted to about 46 per cent of total imports; in 1972 they also were about 46 per cent of total imports. Such imports can be made under several d ifferent procedures. Those for nonconsumer goods are as follows: Each importer of raw materials and other reproduction materials receives a global foreign exchange quota and may use the exchange so allocated to purchase any such goods listed as GDK. For certain imports by the metalworking, shipbuilding, electrical, and textile industries the authority to use the allocated foreign exchange quota is dependent on the exports that the 6 With effect f rom Janua ry 1, 1973 a fifth category was add ed: DL—goods liberalized under special license. These goods are certain items, such as tape recorders and watches, that previously were GDK, RK, or DK items. 6 With effect from January 1, 1973, however, goods whose 1971 import value totaled some US$500 million were transferred from the restricted import categories to the LB category. 537 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA importers have made (import-export l ink ing ) .7'8 Major exporters, i.e., exporters whose exports settled in con- vertible currency account for more than 51 per cent of their total sales proceeds, are permitted to pay freely for imports of raw materials and other reproduc- tion materials for their own needs. Payment for imports of capital goods on the GDK list may be f inanced f rom specific exchange allocations; a considerable portion may be freely financed from retention quota funds (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, below), funds originating in depreciation allowances, and credits obtained abroad, including suppliers' credits. The spe- cific exchange allocations are limited mainly to large investment projects, inc lud ing public utilities; the amounts are determined by the Federal Assembly. Eco- nomic organizations may acquire foreign exchange not exceeding 10 per cent of their annual depreciation allowance, although certain services qua l ify for per- centages varying between 30 per cent (ocean and river shipping) and 100 per cent (air transpor ta t ion). One half of the exchange thus allocated is in convertible and one half in bilateral currency. Imports under commodity quotas (list RK or list DK ), mainly selected agricultural and mineral prod- ucts (such as wheat, sugar, rice, coffee, and salt) but also cigars, cigarettes, and machine tools, are subject to maximum quotas established for each commodity and cannot be imported under any other procedure. The quotas are established either in physical quantities (RK) or in dinars (DK ). There are separate quotas in each case for imports from convertible area countries and payments agreement countries; their allocation among importers is decided by negotiations among the economic organizations.9 Imports of present RK and DK items amounted to about 21 per cent of imports both in 1971 and 1972. Goods in list D comprise gunpowder, ammunition, opium, motor vehicles, tractors, certain textile fibers and yarns, television sets, railroad rolling stock, and aircraft. Import licenses are required only for list D commodities.10 Such licenses do not imply the right to purchase foreign exchange; the economic organizations must supply the exchange from their global exchange quotas or retention quotas.11 Imports of D items accounted for 4.3 per cent of total imports in 1971 and about 4.7 per cent in 1972. 7 This system is also applied to certain DK imports. 8 Early in 1973 the existing system for the textile industries was terminated. 9 In principle, any such allocation among importers must be agreed upon among economic organizations within the Federal Economic Chamber. If the importers are unable to agree among themselves, the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade is authorized to decide on the distribution. Imports of coffee, wheat, sugar, rice, and salt for final consumption are administered by the State Food Administration, which is authorized to select the most competitive importer from among registered importers. 10 With effect f rom January 1, 1973 import licenses were also required for goods under the new DL regime. (See footnote 5.) 11 Under a new procedure that came into effect on January 1, 1973, import licenses automatically entitled the holder to purchase the for- eign exchange. 538 For certain goods there is an additional requirement, irrespective of those set out above, for a special import license ("accordance") issued by the Federal Secre- tariat for Foreign Trade. At the end of 1972 these goods were 62 LB items, 41 GDK items, and 4 RK items. For all 107 items, the Secretariat may prescribe direct importation f rom the country of origin; these items include a wide range of tropical foods tuffs and f ru i t s, raw materials, fats, oils, and textiles, as well as tin and raw cotton. Private persons who are Yugoslav nationals and hold foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks may use these funds free ly to import goods intended for their own use or for the use of close relatives, regardless of the impo rt regime for the goods. Also, Yugoslavs re turn ing f rom work abroad may import goods intended for their personal needs or the needs of their own household, provided that such goods were paid for f rom the sav ings from the ir foreign earnings; such savings need not be kept on foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks. As an exception to the foregoing, owners of foreign exchange accounts and Yugoslav nationals working abroad may only import motorcars, trucks, motor- cycles, mopeds, and bicycles, together with mounted motors and essential spare parts for these vehicles, through a registered enterprise and provided that pay- ment is made through a foreign exchange account held at a Yugoslav bank. Yugoslav and foreign nationals are exempt f rom this prescribed manner of payment and method of impor ta t ion, however, under the following circumstances: when they return for permanent resi- dence in Yugoslavia, provided that they have spent at least five years abroad; when a vehicle is inherited; when a motor vehicle is purchased out of an insurance indemnity received for a motor vehicle that has been destroyed and had originally been paid for in foreign currency; and if they have spent at least two years abroad continuously and have owned a vehicle for at least two years. Yugoslav citizens re turn ing from a tourist trip abroad may import any amount of goods intended for the needs of their household. However, if the va lue of the goods exceeds Din 1,000, these goods must be handed over, at the customs office at the point of entry, to a domestic forwarder for delivery to the owner's address; such delivery cannot be made unless the cus- toms duties are paid. Compensation transactions are only authorized in exceptional circumstances, both in 1971 and 1972 they accounted for less than 1 per cent of total imports. At this time 13' 14 they are also required to deposit with an authorized bank an amount in d inars equal in value to the import order. The deposits are not interest bearing and they are used to purchase the foreign exchange for the impo rt paymen t. Deposits are not required for paymen ts made by debiting foreign exchange accounts of importers. Many agricultural commodities and foods tuffs are subject to variable import levies. A 1 per cent special tax for customs evidence and a 3 per cent equalization tax are payable on all commodities not exempt from customs du ty; in addition, an import surcharge of 6 per cent of the c.i.f. value at the border (2 per cent for certain essentials, such as wheat flour and raw cotton) has to be paid for all dutiable commodities. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to merchandise trans- actions, including transportation, are fu l ly liberalized. Exchange to cover export promotion expenses abroad is made freely available to exporters. Pensions, wages, and salaries are transferable under certain conditions. Payments in respect of royalties and alimony granted by court order are freely transferable, but if a payment is to be made to a country with which Yugoslavia main- tains bilateral paymen ts arrangemen ts, then such pay- ments may be made only if the agreement in question provides for this to be done. Authorized banks may sell fore ign currency up to the equivalent of Din 600 for remittances for court and other fees abroad and for specified personal expenses. The National Bank of Yugoslavia may sell any amount of foreign exchange for the foregoing and for unspecified purposes justified in light of the circumstances. There is no basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad. Travel agencies, however, may obtain special exchange allocations to enable them to sell organized tours abroad against payment in dinars. The National Bank may also authorize travel agencies to sell foreign exchange for both group and individual travel abroad. The exchange is provided in the form of travelers checks and cash. Payments for other invisibles may be made from the remitter's own foreign exchange funds (e.g., from retention quotas, or, when made by various social and socio-political organizations, from specific annual allocations). Not more than Din 500, in denominations of Din 50 or less, may be taken out by travelers. Foreign travelers may bring in and take out any amount in foreign exchange without declaring it. Exports and Export Proceeds In principle, exports are free of control, except for certain raw materials (including copper) that are in 13 The deposit requirements were abolished with e f fect f rom Jan- u a ry 1, 1973. 14 The implementing rules are such that deposits for payments in nonconvertible currencies for imports f rom the bilateral area may be made less than one mon th before payments fa ll due. YUGOSLAVIA short supply on the domestic market and certain other materials such as gunpowder, weapons, and narcotic drugs. Exports to countries with which Yugoslavia has a bilateral payments agreement are subject to approval by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. Such approval may be given for a group of commodities or for all commodities to be exported within a certain period (global approva l). Permission to export to bilateral countries may be made conditional on an undertaking to import from such countries. In accord- ance with bilateral arrangements, Yugoslavia restrains exports of certain commodities to France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Sweden, and the United States. Proceeds from exports must be repatriated within 60 days from the date of exportation, unless specific approval is granted to deviate from this rule. The sur- render of these proceeds is not required. The fu ll export proceeds may be credited to foreign exchange sight deposit accounts which the exporter maintains with an authorized bank of his choice; separate accounts must be established for each currency. Exchange on these accounts may either be used, subject to the relevant regulations, for payments for imports and invisibles or be sold to an authorized bank. Retention quotas may be used to pay for imports of certain con- sumer goods if such imports are made by economic organizations that are in the catering and tourist indus- tries or are engaged in setting up trade fairs, and by film enterprises; such imports are also permitted as consignment stocks. The part of the export proceeds that remains at the free disposal of the exporter for payments abroad is referred to as the retention quota; the remainder may be retained indefinitely but can only be used to import liberalized raw materials and cannot earn interest. The retention quotas may also be placed on interest-bearing time deposit accounts with authorized banks. The per- mitted retention rate is 20 per cent for all export earn- ings f rom goods and services (45 per cent for the foreign exchange earnings of hotels and 100 per cent for the exchange receipts of Yugoslav enterprises operating abroad). In some instances (services rendered to for- eign tourists, sales of newly mined gold to the National Bank, e tc .), sales against payment in dinars are regarded as exports for retention quota purposes. Producing enterprises selling consumer goods in Yugoslavia for foreign currency may retain 15 per cent of the foreign exchange thus earned. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be repatriated within 60 days from the date on which the claim is payable (90 days after completion of projects for Yugoslav organizations' exchange earnings from construction activities) but need not be surrendered in full. Receipts from services are eligible for retention quotas. Exchange proceeds may be used for payments abroad connected 539 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA with the activities of the economic organization con- cerned, including payments for purchases of equip- ment and other material for its own needs. The retained exchange is not transferable to economic organizations other than those with which the recipients are coop- erating in technical and business matters, but it can always be sold to authorized banks. If the exchange is used to pay for imports, the usual import procedures apply. Residents who, while employed abroad, depos- ited their savings in foreign savings banks and obtained a "savings book," may withdraw their balances in the form of foreign exchange when in Yugoslavia. Residents may hold interest-bearing foreign cur- rency accounts in Yugoslavia. The accounts may be credited with the fu ll amount of a person's savings from per diem allowances, salaries, and other earnings abroad, from fellowships, from royalties, and from inheritances. They may also be credited with 50 per cent of the amount of foreign exchange accruing from pensions, disabled persons' allowances, alimony, and grants received from abroad, and with 100 per cent of the amount of foreign exchange accruing from indemnities and insurance, up to an amount equivalent to Din 136,000 per transaction; for amounts in excess of this figure, 30 per cent of the excess may be placed to the credit of a foreign exchange account. l f) These accounts may be used freely for the personal needs of the account holder and of close members of his fam- ily; they are not transferable to other persons or accounts and may be retained for an indefinite period of time. Retail sales of manufactured goods by authorized trade organizations to foreign tourists in Yugoslavia paying in foreign exchange are made at a discount of 10 per cent, representing the exemption from turn- over taxes. This discount is granted only on purchases in authorized shops against checks expressed in for- eign currencies or against certain foreign banknotes. Not more than Din 500 in Yugoslav banknotes, in denominations of Din 50 or less, may be brought in by travelers. Capital Foreign loans and credits may be freely contracted by fu l ly authorized banks and economic organizations, with the exception that no consumer goods may be imported on deferred payment terms and that no for- eign financial credits may be taken up with a grace period of less than two years. Foreign loans and credits must be recorded with the National Bank. Loans must ordinarily be repaid with foreign exchange that is either obtained by the economic organization as export retention quotas and foreign exchange amortization (depreciation) allocations or acquired from banks 15 With effect from January 1, 1973 the f u ll amount accruing from indemnities and insurance could be credited to the fore ign exchange account. 540 according to the regulations governing the foreign trade regime. Credits in the former category are subject to prior dinar deposit requirements; the deposits are noninterest bearing and are held with the National Bank until full repayment of the foreign credits. In the case of finan- cial credits and time deposits in foreign exchange received by business banks, the five basic rates of deposit introduced in April 1972 ranged from 1 per cent for maturities over ten years to 40 per cent for maturities of less than two years. However, as a tem- porary measure beginning in mid-December 1972, a dinar deposit requirement of 75 per cent was required for all financial credits regardless of maturity. In the case of credits for importation of capital goods, the deposit rates at the end of 1972 were ( 1) 20 per cent for credits with a maturity up to two years; ( 2) 10 per cent for credits between three and five years; and ( 3) 1 per cent for credits with a maturity over five years. However, if the capital goods were imported for investments in underdeveloped regions of Yugoslavia, the latter deposit rates were 10 per cent for credits with a maturity up to three years and 1 per cent for credits with a maturity in excess of three years. For 'foreign credits of any kind guaranteed by Yugoslav commercial banks, a dinar deposit of 5 per cent was required which yields no interest and is held to maturity. Certain for- eign credits were specifically exempted from the fore- going deposit requirements; these include credits from specified international financial organizations and credits contracted for or on behalf of the Federal Government or the National Bank of Yugoslavia. Foreign credits repayable with foreign exchange acquired according to the regulations governing the foreign trade regime are trade credits for raw materials and intermediate goods, usually up to 360 days matu- rity; counterpart payments in dinars must be made according to Na t ional Bank regulations in force at the time. At the end of 1972, the requirement was a 66 per cent down payment on the date of contract or date when goods clear customs, with the remaining 34 per cent payable 30 days before final maturity of the credit. Exceptions were (a) that in the case of imports of raw materials subject to import quotas (RK) and imports of capital goods and equipment to be incor- porated into projects and ships under export contracts, a deposit of 100 per cent must be made 30 days prior to repayment of the credit; and (b) that certain basic raw materials (such as crude oil, wool, and cotton) were exempt from d inar counterpart requirements. All other t rans fe rs of a capital na ture by residents or nonresidents require ind iv idual licenses. Foreigners may invest in certain Yugoslav economic organizations but only through jo int ventures; such foreign investment is limited to 49 per cent of the organization's capital. Profit transfers abroad may be financed from the retention quota, and in addition profit transfers are perm i t ted up to one third of the joint ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution venture's foreign currency earnings from exports of goods and services. 16 The investment income of Yugoslav economic orga- nizations earned abroad must be repatriated within 90 days; however, when repatriated the profits are gov- erned by the regulations for retention quotas. Resi- dents are obliged to repatriate and, with the exception of inheritances, to surrender all foreign exchange held or accruing abroad on capital account. Under the Law on the Establishment of Enterprises Abroad, Yugoslav economic organizations and the authorized banks may export their capital for investment in foreign enter- prises and may also establish their own enterprises abroad. Other capital transactions abroad by residents are usually not approved. A decision of the Federal Executive Council of October 14, 1955 requires the Yugoslav authorities to continue to permit the remittance of inheritances to citi- zens of the United States, provided that the remittance is requested within three years from the date of distri- bution of the estate. Gold The National Bank has issued certain commemorative gold coins, which are not legal tender. Yugoslav and foreign travelers are freely permitted to import and export these coins, subject to customs declaration and, for exports, subject to proof that they have been pur- chased in Yugoslavia. Residents who are private per- sons may hold gold coins in Yugoslavia, which may be sold to the National Bank of Yugoslavia or to any authorized bank, and they may freely hold, purchase, import, and sell gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Domestic economic organizations that have been reg- istered as trading in gold may import gold jewelry under the GDK import regime; they may freely export gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Authorized banks may freely export gold coins. Sales of newly mined gold to the National Bank against payment in dinars (calculated by applying the Din 17 per U. S. dollar rate to a price of US$38 an ounce) are regarded as exports and entitle the seller to a retention quota of 20 per cent in convertible foreign exchange. Other domestic sales of newly mined gold by the producers may be made at a price which equals the average quotation in free gold markets abroad. Domestic eco- nomic organizations using gold for their normal activities may purchase gold from domestic producers or abroad on the basis of quotas allocated to each individually.
