Not for Redistribution ZAIRE Exchange Rate System * The par value is 1.77734 grams of fine gold per Zaire, corresponding to Z 0.5 = SDR 1. The central rate is Z 1 = US$2 and Zaire avails itself of wider margins. The intervention currency is the U. S. dollar. The Bank of Zai're ( the central bank) quotes an official rate of ex- change for the Belgian f r anc based on the rate for the zaire quoted on the official exchange market in Brussels. The buying and selling rates for other quoted currencies, except the U. S. dollar, the French franc, and the CFA franc, also are based on official market rates in Brussels. For the U. S. dollar, the Bank of Zaire quotes a fixed rate of Z 1 — US$2, buying and selling. Quotations for the French franc and CFA franc are based on daily quotations for the zaire in the official exchange market in Paris. Forward exchange transactions are prohibited. Administration of Control The Bank of Zaire has regulatory authority over all foreign trade and payments. Specifically, the Bank has discretionary power to authorize payments and receipts in foreign exchange by residents of Zaire, and to per- mit the importation, exportation, and transit of goods. Prescription of Currency Payments from nonresidents must be received in listed convertible currencies quoted daily by the Bank of Zaire.1 Special authorization for the acceptance of other currency may only be given in respect of currencies that can be exchanged freely without a discount. Payments to nonresidents must be made in the listed currencies. The Bank of Zaire has concluded special payments arrangements with the central banks of Rwanda and Uganda, but at the end of 1972 these had not yet gone into effect. Nonresident Accounts There are three categories of nonresident accounts: Nonresident Accounts in Zaires, Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts, and Convertible Accounts in Zaires. Nonresident Accounts in Zaires may only be debited with the approval of the Bank of Zaire. Such accounts, when opened by diplomatic missions and international organizations established in Zaire, may be debited freely but may be credited only w i th the proceeds of sales of foreign currency and w i th payments made by the Gov- ernment. Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts may be credited for any permitted payment in foreign currency; * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, the rate for the U. S. dollar was main- tained unchanged at Z 1 = US$2. 1 Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, CFA francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norweg ian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U. S. dollars. 544 they may be debited freely for transfers to accounts abroad or to Resident and Nonresident Foreign Cur- rency Accounts, and for sales of foreign currency against domestic currency. Nonresident nationals require special authorization from the central bank to open these accounts with authorized banks; nonresident foreigners may open them freely. Convertible Accounts in Zaires may be credited in accordance w i th Circular No. 131 2 and debited freely for conversion into foreign currency or for any pay- ments in domestic currency. Such accounts may be held by residents and nonresidents but must not be credited w i th paymen ts for exports of goods or services. Imports and Import Payments The importation of a number of goods is prohibited on grounds of public policy; these are mainly arms, ammun i t ion, narcotics, and juke boxes. Import licenses are only required for a few goods on a list A (jewelry, precious stones, precious metals, gold coins, rubber tires, and sugar). The central bank has issued a general im- port and payments license which for all other goods guarantees the availability of foreign exchange when payments fall due, provided that the importer files an import declaration w i th his bank following the actual placing of the order and provided that the invoice price has been verified and found acceptable by the foreign correspondents of the Societe Generate de Surveillance. Applications for import licenses, whether requiring foreign exchange or not, are made initially to authorized banks in Kinshasa. Applications are forwarded to the central bank after certification. Af ter approval of the application by the central bank, which is given in the form of a visa, the import license application is returned to the authorized bank for validation. Import licenses are validated by the authorized banks w i thout u n d ue delay and remain valid for customs clearance du r ing a period of six months starting from the first day of the mon th following that in which valida- t ion by the commercial bank takes place. Foreign exchange is made available for all licensed imports, the validated license cons t i tu t ing at the same time an exchange license; for paymen ts purposes, the license rema ins valid as long as the relevant payments have not been completed. The counterpart of the value of goods imported under the Belgian food aid program and the U. S. import support program and the ag r icu l tu ral aid program must be deposited w i th in 120 to 180 days after their shipment. All imports are subject to a statistical tax of 3 per cent ad va lorem. In add i t ion, most imports, irrespec- - Conversion of foreign cu r rency at the official rate, transfer from another Convertible Account in Zaires, or au thor ized paymen ts by residents to nonresidents. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution tive of origin, are subject to a temporary import sur- charge of 5 per cent ad valorem on the c.i.f. value. Payments for Invisibles Policy related to payments for invisibles is formulated by the central bank. Certain payments are subject to authorization by the central bank, which is given or refused on a nondiscriminatory basis; the approval authority for other current paymen ts has been delegated to the authorized banks. The Bank will not authorize exchange for the payment of commissions in favor of shippers or purchasing agents or, except for imports payable on arrival, and provided that the supplier has arranged it, for insurance on imports. Futhermore, ex- change for f re ight and insurance on imports and exports between Zaire and Belgium, Germany, the Netherlands, and Scandinavia is not granted unless shipment takes place by vessels participating in the CEWAL confer- ence, or vessels specifically approved. All other pay- ments for services performed by nonresidents are in principle authorized. Transfers abroad of salaries of foreign nations, however, are restricted to 50 per cent of earnings af ter taxes. Transfers in respect of certain administrative expenses abroad by enterprises, interest on private loans, and certain portions of insurance premiums are, as a rule, authorized. Net profits of firms w i th foreign capital participation are transferab le up to an amount propor t iona te to that participation. Fares for travel abroad may be paid in Zaire in local currency. Zairian nationals traveling abroad may buy foreign exchange in amounts depending on the dura- tion of the journey, up to the equivalent of Z 400 a trip; applications exceeding this amount are subject to individual approval by the central bank. The export of domestic banknotes is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign means of payment declared upon entry, minus the equivalent, at the official rate, of Z 20 for each day spent in Zai're. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports not covered by general license require individual declarations. Banks are normally authorized to approve such declarations, in which exporters under- take to collect the exchange proceeds. The declaration must specify the nature of the merchandise to be exported, the price, and the currency in which payment is to be received. Export declarations are normally valid for three months; within this period, the proceeds must be received and surrendered. Most exports of minerals are subject to special regulations to take into account the time required for processing abroad. For mineral products, a provisional payment of about 70 per cent of the shipment's estimated value has to be received and surrendered within 8 days after shipment. For diamond exports, two thirds of the value estab- lished at a preliminary examination in Zaire must be surrendered before the shipment is dispatched. Export ZAIRE proceeds from coffee must be surrendered within 45 days after shipment. Receipts from other agricultural exports must generally be repatriated within three months of validation. The exportation of coffee is a monopoly of the National Coffee Office. Minimum export prices have been established for coffee, tea, ivory, and certain other commodities. All exports are subject to a statistical tax of 3 per cent ad valorem, and all commodities except cement are subject to export duties. Proceeds from Invisibles All exchange receipts from invisibles must be sur- rendered. The import of domestic banknotes and coins is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign means of payment and may take out on departure the amount declared on entry, less the equivalent of Z 20 a calendar day spent in Zaire. Capital The repatriation of new foreign capital brought in under the provisions of the Investment Code (Ordinance- Law No. 69-032 of June 26, 1969) is guaranteed, as is the transfer of prof i ts and dividends on such capital. With minor exceptions, other transfers abroad of capital owned by residents or nonresidents are not permitted. Gratuitous transfers of real estate are subject to approval by executive ordinance. When the local cur- rency part is paid by the debtor, amortization on foreign loans can be transferred in accordance with the terms of contracts that the central bank has endorsed to guaran- tee the availability of exchange for such transfers. The foreign currency assets of the authorized banks are not permitted to exceed their short-term liabilities in foreign currencies. Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities, pro- ducers of gold, and industrial users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewe lry, at home or abroad. The import and export of gold in any fo rm, except jewe l ry cons t i tu t ing the per- sonal effects of a traveler, require the prior approval of the central bank. Producers are required to sell 10 per cent of their production at the official price of US$35 an ounce to the central bank. The UBIZA Company has a monopoly over the refining of domestically pro- duced gold and over the export of the refined product. Changes during 1972 January 13. Subsequently, certain exemptions were announced and certain adjustments were made on the basis of documentation supplied by importers and foreign suppliers. January 13. Authorized banks were prohibited from granting foreign exchange for freight and insur- ance in respect of imports and exports not meeting this requirement. It was specified that diplomatic missions and international organizations would henceforth be regarded as residents for purposes of the opening and utilization of accounts denominated in zaires. A temporary import surcharge (taxe conjoncturelle temporaire) of 5 per cent ad valorem was levied on the c.i.f. value of most other commodities. May. A National Coffee Office (Office National du Cafe) was established and was given a monopoly over all coffee exports. August 8. Circular No. 140 restricted the export and import of Zaire banknotes, both of which had been free, to Z 30 a person; fur thermore, the import of Zaire banknotes was permitted only to travelers who could produce evidence of a previous stay in Zaire. The import by travelers of foreign means of payment remained unrestricted, but amounts imported had to be declared and registered upon entry. Nonresident travelers were required upon en try to show that they had sufficient means to spend Z 20 a day. They could re-export their declared foreign means of payment after deduction of at least Z 20 for each day spent in Zaire, subject to evidence that local currency had been obtained by conversion at the official rate at an authorized bank; such deduction was not required if evidence could be provided that a corresponding m in imum had been taken up locally by debit to a Convertible Account in Zaires (or, with the prior approval of the central bank, to the debit of a Non- resident Account in Zaires). The exchange of foreign means of payment for zaires other than at an authorized bank henceforth was prohibited, as was shipment through the mails of any means of payment expressed in zaires. August 11. It was announced that imports from Belgium or any other country where zaires were traded at a discount would be restricted to 15 per cent of total imports and that the privileges accorded to residents of these countries under the Investment Code would be suspended. Both measures were revoked in September. August 29. A payments agreement was signed by the Bank of Zaire and the Bank of Uganda. October 18. The Bank of Zambia ( the central b ank) maintains fixed buy- ing and selling rates for the U. Administration of Control Exchange control is adm in is tered by the Bank of Zambia under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Finance. Much of the au tho r i ty for approving nor- mal current payments is in tu rn delegated to the com- mercial banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange. The control of trade is the responsibility of the Minister of Trade and Industry, who also issues import and export licenses. Prescription of Currency Zambia has ceased to be a Scheduled Territory in terms of the U. K. Exchange Control Act, 1947 but under current U. K. exchange control regulations con- tinues to be regarded as a country of the Overseas Ster- ling Area. Authorized payments, including payments for imports, by residents of Zambia to residents of coun- tries other than Rhodesia may be made in Zambian currency to the credit of an External Account, or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. Payments from residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be received in sterling or in Zambian currency from an External Account, or in any foreign currency freely exchangeable for U. S. dollars or ster- ling. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. All permitted payments to residents of Rhodesia must be made in Rhodesian currency, in Zambian currency to an External Account-Rhodesia, in sterling to a Rhodesian Account in the United Kingdom, in U. S. dollars, or in Canadian dollars, and proceeds from exports to Rhodesia must be received in U. S. or Canadian dollars. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Zambian currency held with authorized banks by residents of countries other than Rhodesia are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited with authorized payments from residents of Zambia, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any foreign cur- rency except Rhodesian currency by nonresidents to authorized banks. They may be debited for payments * Following the announcement on February 12, 1973 that the U. S. dollar was being devalued, Zambia maintained unchanged the gold parity of its currency. Zambia continued to avail itself of wider margins. for any purpose to residents of Zambia, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for purchases of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency f rom authorized banks. Blocked accounts in Zambian currency held with authorized banks by residents of any country other than Zambia are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Zambian currency and with any unrem i t tab le por- tion of rents and profits which have accrued to non- residents. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Normally, approval is given for the investment of bal- ances on blocked accounts in Zambian securities, pro- vided that these are held in Zambia to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on blocked account bal- ances is freely transferable to the account holder's coun try of residence, except interest due to a resident of Rhodesia, which is also blocked. Imports and Import Payments Most imports f rom Rhodesia are prohibited, as is the import from all countries of certain specified com- modities for health, safety, or moral reasons; the import of certain other commodities is also prohibited unless specific conditions have been complied with or special permission is given by the Ministry of Trade. There is an open general license for imports from any source other than Rhodesia. The open general license covers personal and household effects, samples, and diplomatic shipments. Imports of items listed in the open general license do not require individual import licenses, nor do any other goods, provided that the person import- ing them does not import more than K 25 worth of such goods in any one month. All other imports require individual import licenses. Import licensing aims at containing imports within a specific monthly import target. This limit does not apply to government imports, purchases from main- land China related to the financing of the local expen- ditures for the TanZam Railway, or essential machinery and equipment for the copper industry (when financed by external borrowing). Restricted import items are divided into three categories. The First Group consists of essential items, for which licenses normally are guaranteed. The Second Group also consists of essen- tial commodities, but licensing normally depends on the level of stocks available. The Third Group consists of all other commodities, mainly consumer goods; most items in this group are licensed restrictively.x Many commodities are imported by state enterprises (INDECO, MINDECO, and FINDECO). Import licensing aims in part at containing imports from Rho- desia and lessening reliance on the Rhodesian transport 1 The import licensing system was reorganized with effect February 1, 1973. f rom 547 ©International Monetary Fund. This entails restric- tion of imports of these goods f rom South Africa, as goods of South Afr ican origin cannot be discharged in Dar es Salaam. Foreign exchange or permission to credit a nonresi- dent account in accordance with the prescription of currency regulations normally is authorized automati- cally for all permitted imports, subject to the presenta- tion of the relevant documen ts showing that the goods have either been received in or consigned to Zamb ia; special a r rangemen ts are in force, however, for pay- ments in respect of f re ight charges on goods carried by Rhodesia Railways, and prior exchange control approval is required to open commercial letters of credit for amounts in excess of K 5,000 covering imports that do not require an ind iv idual import license. The existing open general license for imports was revoked and replaced by one with nar- 549 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA rower coverage. Previously, the open general license contained two commodity lists, one with items that could be imported freely without an individual license and one with items that were subject to restrictive individual licensing; all items not included in the first list could be imported freely by anyone up to K 50 a month for each importer. Henceforth, three of the items on the first list required individual licenses (lubri- cating grease, aviation fuels, and certain other oils and fue l s ), while the others remained free of license; the second list was canceled and items previously on this list remained subject to restrictive individual licensing. The amount up to which any item could be imported freely was reduced to K 25 a month and this facility was restricted to immigrants and persons repatriating to Zambia. September 12. The restriction on remittances of profits and dividends whose introduction had been announced on December 4, 1971 was put into effect for one year. Permission to remit profits and dividends by subsidiaries or branches of companies whose head offices were situated outside Zambia was granted only when they did not exceed 30 per cent of the non- resident share of the equity capital and provided the 30 per cent did not exceed one half of the net profits accruing to the nonresident owners of incorporated companies. September 12. Remittances of rents to nonresidents were for one year restricted to a max imum of 50 per cent of the net annual rental income as certified by a professional appraiser. October 13. In view of the recent changes in U. K. exchange control, and pending the issuance of formal amendments to Zambia's Exchange Control Instructions, 1967 and the exchange control circulars issued under it, authorized dealers were informed that henceforth no differentiation would be made between former or pres- ent Scheduled Area countries (Sterling Area countries) and the rest of the world. All transactions which pre- viously could be approved by authorized dealers without reference to the Bank of Zambia by virtue of the coun- try involved being w i th in the Sterling Area now had to be referred to the exchange control authorities. Sched- uled Area Accounts were redesignated as External Accounts. The prescription of currency was amended accordingly. The position of transactions with Rhodesia and the rules governing Rhodesian Accounts were unchanged. 550 ©International Monetary Fund.
